name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday 25 March 2015 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Today, from the Mediterranean, we are once again reaching startling news. More than 400 refugees are still missing after a refugee boat capsized off the Libyan coast on Sunday. Among the missing are a large number of young men and probably a number of minors. It is to be feared that most of them have drowned. It would be one of the worst refugee disasters since October 2013. We are all safe at this difficult moment in our thoughts with the families of the victims. I would like to take this opportunity, above all, to thank the emergency services who work there in extremely difficult circumstances for their tireless efforts. Ladies and gentlemen, this tragedy is a matter of mewilderment and also shows us how unstable the situation is, particularly in Syria, but also in Libya and other countries bordering the Mediterranean from which the refugees come. We urgently need political solutions for these countries. Ladies and gentlemen, in the last week alone, Italian rescue workers have rescued more than 6000 people from distress at sea. Europe's mediterranean border is the deadliest border in the world. More than 3,000 people have died trying to cross the Mediterranean last year. We will certainly observe a minute's silence for the victims. However, ladies and gentlemen, I cannot read these words here without reminding you of the following. I stood here on 7 October 2013 and asked for a minute's silence for the victims of Lampedusa. I asked you on 15 September 2014 to observe a minute's silence for 200 drowned migrants. I asked for a minute's silence on 12 February 2015 for 300 drowned migrants. I'm back here today and I'm doing the same thing. I would like to say to you that I do not consider this worthy. The pity for the victims goes deep. But we cannot go on to observe minute's silence for hundreds of deaths, but the problem itself is not changing. (Applause) That is why I am appealing not only to us and to the other institutions of the European Union. I appeal in particular to the Member States of the European Union. The migration policy that is their responsibility must lead us to have better protection of refugees. However, it must also lead to a more effective approach to the causes of flight. Disintegrated states on Europe's borders are the cause of these flight movements. We must do everything in our power to help people in need. However, it is also our duty, ladies and gentlemen, to do everything we can to tackle the causes of flight intensively. I include in the sad news the terrible attack by the criminal organisation Al-Shabaab on the university in the northern Kenyan town of Garissa, which on 2 April claimed the lives of 148 innocent people, young men and women, students from the university there. This is not the first time this terrorist group has shown its inhumane attitude with a brutal attack on innocent people. What particularly shakes me is that there has been a systematic hunt for people of Christian faith. Our thoughts are also with the people of Garissa, with the friends and relatives of the victims. We wish the injured, some of them severely mutilated, a speedy recovery. Here, too, we should do everything in our power to help. The fight against inhumane terrorism is not just a fight against a criminal organisation. It is a struggle to defend our fundamental values. If we give up this struggle, ladies and gentlemen, we will give up the civilisational basis of our society. I would therefore ask you to stand up for all the victims in this sense. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence) Ladies and gentlemen, following our minute's remembrance, I have been asked to point out that in Syria, in the Yarmouk refugee camp near Damascus, 18 000 civilians, including 3,500 children, have been encircled and besieged for more than two years. The humanitarian situation in the camp is catastrophic. Most of the people are cut off from the outside world, and the people there lack everything, water, food, medical care. Here, too, we are seeing women and children being held hostage by the so-called Islamic State and other militias and not for the first time being abused as human shields. Therefore, although I know that this is not an essential contribution to solving the problem, I still call in the name — as I do. I hope that all of you, all those involved, in particular the military, will spare civilians, especially women and children, give them safe escort, give United Nations agencies access to the camp and ensure basic supplies of missing things. The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Middle East is the organisation that is most intensively involved, and which we, from the European Union, are also providing massive financial support. I believe that you all share my view that UNRWA needs our full support and that we must act. I do not want to have to make a minute of mourning for thousands of dead in the Yarmouk refugee camp here in one of the next sittings. (Applause) I would therefore ask all of you, and in particular those colleagues who have a direct influence on international organisations, to help with this. Thank you for your understanding.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 12 March 2015, in accordance with Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. First of all, I have here a request from Mr Corbett for a point of order. You're welcome!

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, in your announcements you made no mention of any Member leaving a political group. I ask this because, in the UK, the United Kingdom Independence Party has made a big song and dance about Ms Janice Atkinson having been expelled from their party, yet here in the European Parliament they seem to be keeping her as a member of their group, quietly, discreetly, keeping her – presumably in order to take advantage of the facilities and finance that such membership provides to them. Is this not a case of hypocrisy, or is it just an error in transmission to you? (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Corbett, I would like to thank Mr Corbett for his I would have been grateful if you, as a particularly experienced colleague, had mentioned to me the Rule of the Rules of Procedure to which you referred. If you had given me the article, I could have commented on it. However, since you did not mention it to me, I cannot comment on the article, but only in general terms. In general, I take note of two things. Firstly, I insinuate that you know that membership of political groups is not decided by political parties in the Member States, but by the groups here in this House autonomously. In this respect, it is up to the respective group to decide who it accepts as a member or not. Secondly, this is not a matter that is being debated or put to the vote here in plenary, unless fundamental rules are violated. However, I cannot see any such violations of the rules.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, I would just simply say that this is a matter of legal proceedings. There are human rights in this matter of the kind that many Members of this Parliament are very keen on, not least Mr Corbett himself. The lady in question has hired a lawyer and, although she has actually been removed from the UK Independence Party, there is still a process laid down by statute, internally and externally. That process will continue in an appropriate manner. So perhaps Mr Corbett will find that point reassuring.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you for the enlightening comment. But it also had nothing to do with the Rules of Procedure.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as co-chairman of the EFDD Group, I wanted to inform those who do not know that this Member is currently suspended from the group, so she has no right to vote and cannot work within the group at this time until the police inspection is completed. In the end, on the basis of the result, decisions will be taken as per the group's internal statutes.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Borelli, I would like to thank Mr Borelli for his That was a reply to Mr Corbett's question in accordance with the Rules of Procedure. Thank you very much! In agreement with the political groups, I propose an amendment to the final draft of the agenda: the Commission statement on the commemoration of the fires in textile factories in Bangladesh and on progress on the sustainability pact for Bangladesh will be postponed to a later meeting. Are there any objections?

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I consider this matter to be extremely serious.  Indeed, on this occasion, we saw the ravages of globalism, of the most cynical international capitalism possible, one that benefits precisely from low wages, of people who work in conditions of genuine slavery and whose products come afterwards, free of customs duties, ruining our company in whole parts.  I also consider that this policy has been responsible for hundreds of deaths for which we Europeans and Westerners are collectively, albeit indirectly, responsible.  Therefore, I believe that this project should not go off our agenda and be dealt with immediately.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you very much. (Parliament approves the application.) Request from the EPP Group to include, as a second item on the agenda after the votes, a debate on the Commission's declaration - without the presentation of proposals for resolutions - on the EU-Mexico PNR agreement. The plenary session would be extended until 10 p.m.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Our request is particularly topical, because the penalties imposed on airlines if there is no agreement between the EU and Mexico on passenger data would then amount to USD 30 000 for each flight from 1 July. We would like to debate an opinion from the Commission and this here, in order to know what procedure is planned by 1 July.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mrs Hohlmeier.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, as I have requested many times in recent years for this issue to be put on the agenda, my group obviously supports the request. However, I would suggest that we slightly modify the title because there is not as yet an agreement between Mexico and the EU – there is not even a proposal for an agreement. We support the request to include it on the agenda, but I would suggest that we modify the title.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I recommend to Mrs in't Veld and Mrs Hohlmeier that we rename the title 'Commission statement on the planned PNR agreement between Mexico and the European Union'. In this way, we have fulfilled Mrs in't Veld's wish. (Parliament adopted the motion) The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance has requested that a debate be put on the agenda on the council and Commission statements on Greece, entitled 'Eurogroup negotiations on the conclusion of the current revised programme'. There should be no resolution on this.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have scheduled these micro-sessions, these small meetings of Parliament in Brussels, so that we can also react to current developments. You, like me, will have been following the press throughout Europe in recent days and have found that the word 'Grexit' is on everyone's minds and that there are more and more voices anonymously from European governments or from the European institutions to the idea that the best for the European Union and the best for Greece would be such a Grexit. I think that is negligent. I believe that this is primarily negligent towards the citizens of Greece, who would experience an even greater, more difficult humanitarian emergency if such a Grexit were to take place than is the case today after years of austerity. However, I also believe that the European Union as a whole, not only the euro area economically, but the European Union as a whole, is taking a great risk when such a Grexit occurs. And I think, Mr President, that in this debate situation, as it exists in Europe today, this sitting is absolutely the moment when we can get information and constant negotiations from the Commission and the Council.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mrs Harms, you had my attention. But I think you had less of other colleagues. Does anyone wish to speak in favour of Mrs Harms' request? I do not believe that Mr Lucke would like to speak in favour of Mrs Harms' request. Mr Lucke, would you like to speak in favour of Mrs Harms' request? Mr Lucke, I am off the socks! You're welcome!

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am grateful to you for letting me explain to myself what I want to say and what I do not want to say. I think Mrs Harms' request is very correct. The European Parliament urgently needs to deal with this. For the official position of the EU, expressed, for example, by Commissioner Dombrovskis in his hearing, was that there could be no Grexit, that the euro was irrevocable and that it was unthinkable for a country to leave the euro. He had initially expressed himself differently, then, as he said, he revoked it in writing. But that is the official statement. And now that a great many members of governments and scientists are indeed advising, or at least putting into the room, the possibility of a Grexit taking place, we need to know what the Commission's state is on this. Will she assist a Grexit if necessary? Are there any preparations for this? Or does the Commission believe that Grexit is not possible anyway? And then Greece will be left out of the euro completely unchecked if it happens one day by accident.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Lucke, I would like to thank Mr Lucke for his I was surprised by this unusual connection. Nor did I intend to explain what you want to say. Even if I had the intention, I do not think I would be able to explain what you are going to say.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the My group is opposed to the request to put a debate on the situation between Greece and the euro area on the agenda today, because, firstly, we believe that a basis for the negotiations was drawn up together on 20 February. This basis still applies today. All the others we have so far are rumours, they are newspaper reports, they are statements that come from the Commission, from other sources that are supposedly well-informed, but which are constantly being denied. I do not know on what basis we actually want to discuss where the facts are. I believe that we need a good debate on Greece, in my view in the next part-session or later, but one that avoids us ourselves becoming the game of rumours and perhaps exacerbating the situation even further. That is why we are rejecting this discussion at this stage, although I fully agree with Mrs Harms that dealing with the problem is actually a disgrace to the European Union.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation of Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas on behalf of the Committee on Budgets on a draft Council regulation amending the regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 (05479/2015 - C8-0047/2015 - 2015/0010(APP)) (A8-0125/2015).

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are now facing a revision, albeit a technical one, which follows the very significant delay in the implementation of operational programmes. In fact, all funds in shared management from 2014 to 2020 are affected. As of 31 December 2014, more than three hundred operational programmes had not yet been adopted and could not benefit from the credit deferral procedure offered by Article 13 of the Financial Regulation. All Member States are affected. Indeed, more than 21 billion euros would have been lost without this revision. For some states, it is even the bulk of the commitment appropriations for these programs that are affected. Some examples: for the Czech Republic, 99.6% of the funds would be lost, for Romania 80%, for Spain, more than 60%, and for the United Kingdom, more than 50%.  Fortunately, Article 19 of the Multi-Year Financial Framework allows for the introduction of an amendment by May 1 of this year to transfer allocations from 2014 to 2015 in the event of non-adaptation of these programs. For all these reasons, you will understand the opinion in favour of this revision that we are proposing to the vote. However, given the territorial impact on all countries and the equally large amounts at stake, this predictable revision adds to the worrying dysfunctions of our budgets. First, this situation again raises the question of the sincerity of our budgetary decisions, since at the time they were made, we were late and we knew it. Secondly, in the context of a chronic investment deficit in Europe, such a delay in the arrival of the Structural Funds, linked to the validation of operational programmes, is difficult to accept and thus delays investment in the territory. Thirdly, this delay in implementation will also have an impact on payment appropriations, because by shifting commitments by one year, it is the entire payments that could be staggered by the same amount, which would add additional pressure on the Union's payment credits at the end of the period of the multi-year financial framework. We know this snowball effect, this accumulation of unpaid bills which undermine the credibility of the Union by leaving thousands of project holders in front of this budgetary cavalry.  Let me be clear, this revision will not aggravate the payments crisis, as we know it now, but nevertheless it risks amplifying the one that awaits us at the end of the period and I welcome all the more the Commission's statements, by which it pledges to use all the flexibilities offered by the multi-year financial framework to limit the consequences of this revision.  However, Commissioner, I am afraid that this flexibility is not enough. Parliament had already expressed its fears at the time of the MFF agreement in 2013. This financial framework - for the first time in the history of European construction - was and remains inadequate and inadequate.  Thus there are a number of budgetary adjustments which, when combined, constitute what I will call the "must-haves" of a revision this time not technical, as is the case today, but political, of the multi-year financial framework.  Unpaid debt crisis, European fund for strategic investments and reserve of flexibility: this is a first non-exhaustive list on spending. But we are all aware here of the Council's budgetlessness and the dismal negotiations of the annual budget. And all this makes us think about the very structure of the European Union's budget. This revision — not the technical review, but the political review that awaits us — offers us all a historic opportunity.  We owe this opportunity or duty to three elements. Firstly, the elections resonated as a wake-up call from European citizens, some of whom expressed their doubts, and others expressed their rejection of the Union. Secondly, the economic crisis requires us to have a countercyclical intervention in which the European budget must take its place, as can be seen through the EFSI debate.  Finally, of course, there is the democratic question, the question of political responsibility that challenges us as a legislator. Have we ever seen a Parliament vote on budgetary expenditure without questioning revenue? It's a bit of a backwards world: we spend without being in the least responsible for revenue and without raising taxes.  At present, Member States' contributions make up 75% of the EU budget, a situation that feeds into the logic of the so-called, improperly moreover, the just return, which breaks community ambitions. A budgetary structure that fuels the payments crisis by transforming the Union's budget into a variable for adjusting national budgets, but above all destroying solidarity between the citizens and peoples of Europe, the indispensable driving force behind our common project. Commissioner, we must announce the great return of own resources, allowing us to tackle the major issues of the common market and to support the European society project.  Commissioner, my plea for a real post-election review of the multi-year financial framework comes mainly from the fact that I share the Commission's sentiment. We are at a turning point in European integration and in the face of the rise of nationalist populists, we cannot afford the luxury of failure for lack of ambition. This technical revision calls for a political revision of the budget as early as 2016. You can count on the support of the Democrats in this house to that end and we are waiting for your proposals.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: alternate rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, and I would like to greet all my colleagues and all my colleagues. Indeed, we are dealing with an imminently technical proposal. The proof is that it has had unanimity in committees and, in particular, unanimity in the Committee on Budgets, but it is a proposal on which we can also make political considerations and draw lessons for the future.  The delay in the multiannual financial framework has led to the delay of operational programmes and, in particular, of the operational programmes of cohesion policy. No wonder it is the European Fund for Strategic Investments, where cohesion policy is, but where the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development are also the most affected and in this cohesion policy is the one with the greatest expression. It is important, it is urgent that regional operational programmes, in particular the regional operational cohesion policy programmes, where the ERDF, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund are located, all enter at great speed at cruising speed. I would remind you that in the European Union we have 272 regions, but one in four of these regions is below 75% of GDP per capita, with 100 being the Eu average, i.e. one in four regions is designated as a least developed region. And these cohesion policy funds are essential to combat asymmetries but they are also important, and today they have a new way of acting and have a new framework, so that there are synergies with the funds that are in what is called the Common Strategic Framework. They too contribute to employment, they also contribute to growth. In particular, they contribute to the priority of smart growth. Today, cohesion policy is also research. Today, cohesion policy is also innovation in a number of Member States and hence the importance of not being able to lose resources that have added value for the whole European Union. We're talking about a transfer that's not payments at all. We are talking here about a transfer that is an authorisation appropriation: EUR 21.1 billion that has not been used and will be mainly used in 2015, but also in 2016 and 2017.  It is essential that these programmes which we are talking about, but also the programme and the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, and the Internal Security Fund, which are also housed here, are properly set in motion. This transfer, this modification, this revision of the multiannual financial framework will allow 300 programmes not to be affected by the delays I have already mentioned.  It is also important to stress that the multiannual financial framework needs flexibility, needs a review that takes into account the need for growth, the need for employment, and also needs flexibility for new programmes, for programmes, such as the Juncker Plan, which may take a look at the multiannual financial framework in the revision of the multiannual financial framework, in particular for possible lines that will be used to finance this Juncker Plan. What I ask is that this multiannual financial framework, this revision of the multiannual financial framework, should have the same vote as it had in committees, namely that there is unanimity that also existed in these committees.  The European Union needs it, European citizens thank you.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, my most sincere thanks go to the rapporteurs, Ms Thomas and Mr Fernandes. They have presented very clearly the importance of this proposed amendment for the European economy, as well as the urgent need for a decision to be taken. We in the Commission, together with Member States, made every effort possible to adopt as many programmes as possible in 2013 and to do so with a higher standard for quality of spending. We launched informal dialogues with Member States in advance of the formal adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and I can say here that, as a result of concerted efforts, the time that was taken to adopt programmes during this round of the MFF was four months shorter than in the previous MFF. But despite these efforts, because of the late adoption of the Council regulation laying down the MFF for 2014-2020 and also owing to delays involving the legislative acts, we unfortunately had the negative impact of having 300 programmes, or 47% of the programmes, that we could have adopted in 2014. As already mentioned, this is an amount of EUR 21.1 billion. So, with six months lost because of the delay, all we are proposing in this technical adjustment is to use flexibility to extend this period by allowing us, as framed in Article 19 of the MFF Regulation, for a revision of the MFF before 1 May 2015. I would like to share with you three very quick points. First, staff at the Commission are working very hard to accelerate adoption so we can have around EUR 16 billion for 2015 and the remainder, as proposed, adopted in 2016. Second, we have very much appreciated the fact that Parliament’s Committee on Budgets has taken this issue very seriously and has worked on getting a fast proposal here in this Chamber. I certainly join the rapporteurs in hoping for a positive vote. Third, both Ms Thomas and Mr Fernandes talked about the need to use the flexibility that Parliament has been fighting for to adjust the MFF in future years. I just want to recall that we have committed to a mid-term review and revision of the MFF, and we in the Commission will be working on a very serious proposal when the time comes. We are very mindful of the significance of all we do and the speed at which we do it for the health of the European economy, improving our competitiveness, creating more jobs, and improving the lives of the European people. You have our commitment to act on your approval of revision immediately but also to make sure that money flows into programmes that generate opportunities and growth in Europe.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Rap avis REGI. – Mr President, the adoption of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a key condition not to lose the 2014 allowances for the various funds that could not be used due to the late adoption of some of the programmes. I am convinced that the European Parliament today will give a considerable vote in favour of this revision.  Cohesion policy is one of the most affected by these delays and faces some of the largest sums we are considering. That is why, thinking that it is the most successful investment policy of the European Union, we must quickly resolve this problem. There should be no need to waste time after today's adoption of the review, so that implementation goes full speed forward. The 2015 budget must also be amended and I call on the Commission and the Member States to complete the programme for the adoption of outstanding programmes as soon as possible so as to eliminate delays. I also call on the European Commission to ensure and assure us that these delays will not turn into further accumulations in payment delays, which are already affecting cohesion policy programmes.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we are in mid-April, and 47% of the approximately 300 operational programmes are far from being approved. An unprecedented situation, which obliges us to resort to the evaluation of bureaucratic and unnecessary procedures, which cause delays. The Commission and the Member States should take note of these delays and treat them as a priority so as to avoid similar situations in the future. The mid-term evaluation will give the opportunity to review the timing of the adoption of operational programmes. The outstanding payments in Section 1B of the Union budget must be part of the package of revision proposals in the interim evaluation. This year, the Commission foresees the transfer of EUR 21 billion from unused commitments in 2014. I draw attention, however, to the fact that we are thus obliging Member States to absorb a much larger amount of funds by supplementing unused allocations, and there is a risk of disengagement of allocated funds. We must ensure that each Member State's commitment and payment appropriations are complied with. On the other hand, the high level of accumulation of outstanding payments and unpaid invoices by the end of 2014 for programmes financed by the Structural and Investment Funds will increase the volume of payments in 2017. In order to avoid possible agglomerations, the Commission should consider that the remaining allocations will be staggered between 2015 and 2017. We are at an important point in the process of starting the current programming period, so we believe that any delays can have serious consequences for the implementation of investments at the level of the regions and on European citizens. National authorities must show cooperation in order to adopt the remaining operational programmes in a timely manner and to start funding under those programmes.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, as has been said here, we are discussing an amendment to the financial framework, which is essential to be able to take advantage of these EUR 21 billion, which, for different reasons, could not be programmed in 2014 and we moved them to 2015. I don't think anyone opposes this, and we all agree that it needs to be approved quickly and that the important thing is for these programmes to move forward. But I would like to focus a little on my speech on what will happen to payments, not only because of this change in the financial framework but because of what means moving payments towards the end of the framework. Because, in this debate with the Commission on payments and the situation of unpaid invoices, it is true that, with the information we have, it seems that the situation is stabilising in what has to do with the past financial framework. But unfortunately, we are delaying payments from the principle of the financial framework towards the end. Fundamentally, for two reasons: because of this change in the financial framework — and because of the delay in the implementation of the programmes, we will have more payments at the end of the period — but also because we had to use payments in 2014 that were scheduled for the end of the term of office, due to lower payment scheduling in 2014. So, in this review of the financial framework we were talking about before, let us hope that the European Commission will take this into account and can put enough payments into account so as not to have as regrettable a situation as we have had so far.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is almost a year and a half since the Union's financial perspective for 2014-2020 has been implemented and, as it turns out, many operational programmes in the areas of cohesion policy, regional development or agricultural policy prepared by the Member States are only at the stage of approval by the European Commission. The delays caused by this concern more than 300 operational programmes in all Member States and it is therefore necessary to reprogram the current financial perspective for the coming years. Hence the need to revise both the Multiannual Financial Framework and, consequently, the preparation of amending budget No 2 for 2015, which will allow more than €21 billion in commitments from 2014 to be transferred to the 2015 budget. This will allow expenditure to be realised in 2016-2020.  I would also like to express my hope that there will now be a clear acceleration in the implementation of the programmes and that there will be no cuts in the individual national envelopes with the medium-term review of the financial framework in 2016.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, let me congratulate the two rapporteurs, Mrs Thomas and Mr Fernandes. In particular, José Fernandes because it seems that, in recent times, he has been in charge of all the budgetary reports that fall to the EPP Group. Surprising, but true. Once is not customary, I will praise an article of the regulation of the multi-year financial framework. Blessed Article 19! Without this article, 21 billion commitment appropriations, which were available as early as 2014, would have been cancelled and therefore would not have been available for the financing of projects in shared management. Congratulations! And, at the same time, let me reflect. I find it very surprising that we have, at European level, of doing every seven years completely tabula rasa, in terms of not only the financial resources but also the legal basis for funding programmes and the legal basis for possible adjustments to procedures, which implies new apprenticeships by national administrations to launch the programmes. Is this way of working the smartest? Tabula shaved every seven years! This means, in particular, that the current Parliament has nothing to say about the content of the programmes that were decided by the previous Parliament. Colleagues, we must protest against this method. That has to change. We cannot go on like this because it is a bad way of managing and it is a sign of non-respect for democracy that underpins the legitimacy of the European Parliament.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reality of youth unemployment, which affects more than five million young people in Europe, is even harsher and more worrying in Spain, where more than half of them are jobless. And more than 300,000 young people have left our country since 2008, as both the Garnet Tide and Youth Without Future have denounced at parliamentary headquarters. This is the terrible balance of the precarious situation we face because of the policies of austerity and adjustment implemented by both the Socialist Party and the People's Party. The current change in the multiannual financial framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee is good news, but this is an insufficient measure. Ladies and gentlemen, don't kid yourself. And most of all, don't fool us. We're, again, facing a makeup operation. We are, again, facing a political commitment that does not move towards quality youth employment with rights. We will continue, from this group, to advocate a much greater increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and the generation of activities from the social and solidarity economy approach.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, like other speakers, I am very satisfied that this MFF adaptation is happening and that even the darkest corner of our legislative triangle – the Council, I mean – is not causing any problems.  Programmes under shared management present a series of difficulties. They are often highly prone to errors as Member States put more emphasis on spending a maximum amount of EU money than on the quality of the projects supported. These errors have resulted in the non-certification of EU spending for years. The Commission is hesitant to control Member States too much for political reasons and is relying on Member States’ control systems, which are often inadequate. Therefore, it is often Parliament which has to defend the principles of good management and quality spending when it comes to programmes under shared management. In this context, the delays we are witnessing today in the implementation of a new generation of shared management programmes are not necessarily entirely negative if they result in the setting-up of quality control systems which would guarantee that finally most of the funds, if not all the funds, are well spent. From a budgetary point of view, I am just worried that the postponement of a significant sum of commitments – we are talking about EUR 21 billion – will increase even more the pressure on the already very tight level of payments, and that the Council will ignore the increased need for payments in later years once more. But the Green Group, with its powerful 50+ votes, will of course support the adaptation of the MFF and joins the chorus of congratulations to the rapporteurs.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I hear it being said in this Chamber that no one is against this. Well I suppose I was elected to give an alternative view and I can certainly say that we are against this because we believe that Britain can spend its money more efficiently in support of our regions than by sending the money to Brussels to be spent for us. The opinion of the Committee on Regional Development is in full support of a Cohesion Fund that is approximately 33% of the overall budget. This has not achieved its key objectives. It has drained financial resources from Member States and is not helping Member States to recover from the economic crisis. We hear that EUR 20 billion of commitment appropriations could fall by the wayside. Well what does ‘fall by the wayside’ mean? It means money going back to the European people, back to the countries, back to the taxpayers. So not everyone believes that the answer to every single question has to be ‘more Europe’. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to thank mr. for accepting the blue card, and I would also like to ask him, because he is clearly against cohesion policy and funding from these funds and considers it unnecessary, is he aware of the fact that in many countries today it is cohesion policy money that makes up the main part of the investment and practically participates in what it means to solve the financial and economic crisis in these countries? Is he aware of this fact?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – To me it is very simple. If, as a country, we in the UK – or others in whichever Member State – send money across to Brussels and then Brussels sends it back, we could achieve the same result or better by financing those projects directly in the Member States from a national government that actually understands what is going on on the ground in those countries. So to me it is quite simple.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are very often considering this issue of transferring funds from one budget line to another in committee meetings, and we always treat it as if it were just a technical issue. However, it must be pointed out to the High House that this is not the case, that this is a very serious systemic issue. We are wrong to assume that a large Union budget is a big benefit for the countries of the European Union, but this assumption is wrong, because, after all, a large Union budget is a cost imposed on EU countries, and we must not forget that. If the appropriations in a budget line have not been used and nothing bad has happened, it goes without saying that they should go to the budget reserve and in the future should automatically reduce the Union budget, reducing the burden of the Union for all countries. A cheaper Union is a better Union, and we should be aware of that.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this report is not only important as a technical adjustment to the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is necessary, but it is also an important political message. It must be remembered that the citizens of the European Union are watching us and watching how we respond to current threats, for example in the area of internal security. And I am glad, Commissioner, that you have kept your word and that you have come between us with this amendment and that you continue that tendency to communicate with the European Parliament, which I personally very much appreciate.  First of all, I would like to mention two specific funds whose programmes could not be implemented further without this adjustment and which are becoming increasingly important: the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. Every day we deal with the problems of illegal refugees, the large number of asylum seekers, the threat of terrorism and ISIS, and spending on homeland security and other important projects in history. I would therefore like to see this money left over under the Structural Funds transferred to these areas, which I see as very priority. There must be sufficient funding for these actions, as Mr Deprez mentioned, for example. I therefore believe that this proposed amendment will pass smoothly through both the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, this report, even if it is technical, reminds us how we are faced with a recurring situation which points to some dysfunctions of the European Union. But at the same time, as Mrs Thomas said, it allows us to imagine possible improvements in the financing of structural and cohesion policies.  I would like, since the opportunity is given to me, to stress first of all the need to communicate more towards citizens and local authorities, who are rarely properly informed of the benefits of Europe on their territory.  Secondly, I would like to recall the important leverage that these resources allow for states and local authorities, particularly for investment.  Finally, I call for a simplification of the procedures for co-construction and validation of structural policies to allow for greater fluidity and reliability, which will encourage local actors to make greater use of the Structural Funds. I believe that there is an absolute need to make these Structural Funds more accessible, so that we do not end up with unused funds today. They must be an accelerator of project implementation and not an administrative and structuring machine.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, the amendment to the regulation setting out the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020 must, of course, be voted on. But this need highlights the heaviness, complexity and inertia of our procedures. At a time when everyone is sounding the alarm about the chronic investment deficit in Europe, which is stunting growth and activating mass unemployment, we have to postpone EUR 21 billion because we have failed to validate programmes and projects.  This requires us to review our private practices of government and political leadership. The European Union is governed by rules, at the risk of generating a technocratic and bureaucratic monster. I therefore call for the drastic simplification of our rules and procedures. But, Madam Vice-President, since you mentioned the mid-term revision of the multi-year financial framework, I hope that, in your proposals, you will make adjustments to commitment credits and payment credits that prevent us from sacrificing the credits of the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe and Horizon 2020, which are so essential for the future. Because these are investments of the future.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we can certainly remedy a situation that has been managed in a superficial and pressing manner today, and we must, in fact, bring back more than a third of the funds allocated to these programmes, because there have been delays in their adoption in 2014. I have to say, therefore, that Europe too is not immune from phenomena that I thought were exemplary, in a negative sense, with regard to the reality of Italy, where delays and botched adjustments are the order of the day.  Despite this necessary premise, we are, of course, also in favour of flexible use of the Multiannual Financial Framework, and this should apply to many situations. We are approaching a first revision of the Financial Perspective and I believe that the Union's priority should certainly be reviewed in order to concentrate the resources available where they can really create development, growth, employment and equity. In any case, I hope that the funds that we want to bring back today will finally be used constructively and not thrown to the wind, as has happened all too often, even recently in Italy, especially in the regions that would need it most.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: Mr President, the revision of the multi-year financial framework is aimed at transferring EUR 21 billion in commitments that were not used in 2014, the equivalent of 15% of the 2014 budget, over subsequent years. If it is a purely technical revision, it is also indicative of particularly serious, even scandalous, substantive elements. I am talking in particular about the stock of unpaid debts, which grows year after year, thus showing a totally sclerotic and bureaucratic management. Despite the 4.8 billion euros obtained in the trilogue, at the end of 2014, the amount of unpaid bills amounted to more than 24 billion euros compared to 11 billion in 2011. And we are still waiting for a clean-up plan. Meanwhile, it is the local authorities that are paying the price. This absurd system justifies for some a new federal leap, which is nothing more than a leap into the void and would be an intolerable attack on the sovereignty of States. The only answer to this appalling management is to leave the Member States full sovereignty over their budget and the allocation of investments. Finally, all this should not make us forget that France benefits little from this system since in 2013 it was a net contributor to the EU budget to the tune of 9.4 billion euros.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, of course I also welcome the proposed modification of the MFF and the subsequent draft amending budget No 2, in respect of which I am the PPE’s shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Budgets. Although this is not a problematic or disputed issue here in this House, it was essential in order to ensure that Member States do not lose EU funds allocated to them. However, we all know that the late approval of the MFF Regulation and of the European Structural Funds regulations led to the delayed adoption of partnership agreements and subsequently to delays in the adoption of operational programmes. We now need to act to avoid fund losses, and we are rightly doing so, but of course in the future we will need to do more. We will need to prevent the next MFF regulation, ahead of the next EU budget, from also being adopted late and we in Parliament should be ready to do our share. The Council should of course also be ready to do its share and we count on the Commission’s role as an honest broker early in this process so that we avoid the late adoption of the next MFF Regulation. Especially in the context of the economic crisis and the shortage of investments, the timely adoption of programming documents is essential for the implementation of EU policies. EU funds are an essential tool for investments and for job creation and we need them now more than ever, given high levels of unemployment. That being said, we should not blame the EU institutions alone for these delays. Some Member States showed, by having almost all operational programmes adopted, that there is a way, while others, including my own home country Romania, still lag behind. Therefore I call on Member States, and especially on the net beneficiaries, to adopt all operational programmes in a timely manner in order for the EU funds allocated to them to reach the people of Europe. One last issue to which I would like to draw attention is the risk of decommitments in the second half of the MFF. We count on the Commission’s role early in the process to avoid decommitments in the second half of the MFF application.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, along with colleagues, I sincerely hope that this vote will go through later on today. These operational programmes have real people on the end of them, and I know this all too well because in my region I have a county called Cornwall, which is due to receive about GBP 500 million as a result of cohesion funding. But, because of the UK Government’s failure to adequately get operational programmes agreed, there is a real risk of delays in that and we are already seeing redundancy notices and people losing their jobs as a consequence of this failure, so it is not cold statistics, it is real lives that we are talking about here. But there is also a question I would like to ask, because particular programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative have deadlines on them, and the delay in agreeing operational programmes can mean that there is a very short window within which to spend those funds. I hope that it will be possible not just to have flexibility on the commitments but also on the time available to spend the money that should be wisely spent on those programmes.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Dear Mrs Georgieva, dear colleagues, the revision of the multiannual financial framework with a view to delaying the implementation of key projects is an important and necessary step and, as this debate shows, is the subject of consensus in both the European Parliament and the Commission. The transfer of unused commitment appropriations to the next financial period is key to the start of the new programming period and is therefore closely linked to the European Union's efforts to create a more competitive and prosperous economy. As we know, the last agreement on the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 delayed the adoption of the legal acts of the European Structural Investment Funds for this period. These delays negatively affect the economies of the Member States and are associated with significant losses. The Structural Funds are the Union's most important investment policy and therefore their effective preparation and use of European resources will generate growth and jobs. All European countries must have equal access to finance and support from the Union institutions. I therefore welcome the commitment expressed at the beginning of the debate by Commissioner Georgieva that the Commission should cooperate more closely with Member States and regions, the facilitation of not only the speedy launch of the programmes, but also their successful implementation thanks to the full and efficient use of all resources. Regions and Member States can no longer afford to waste time. Economic development requires immediate measures and real support.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we are discussing a delay in public institutions, both Community and national and regional, which will probably mark the future of programming, especially as regards the Structural Funds and cohesion policy. And so we will have an effect on the good quality of expenditure, beyond the classic and ancient problems that overlap in budgetary policies between commitments and payments. That is why it is important that, after this vote, we work together with the Commission to speed up three issues: faster adoption of national and regional programmes, more attention to this activity, and secondly, we avoid concentrating resources in a single year with the risk of increasing disengagement then by the 2018 deadline. Thirdly, we need more commission activities, more capacity for initiative, to feel active partners, especially towards national and regional authorities, also in the light of a possible legislative change in the middle of the mandate to better accompany the programming and use of resources.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are voting on a technical adjustment which, however, stems from some very specific political choices. If the Council had been less stubborn in the negotiations that this Parliament conducted at the end of the last parliamentary term, perhaps we would have been able to adopt the multiannual financial framework in time. Perhaps more programmes would have started and been put in place and today we would not be with EUR 21 billion allocated but not spent. The Commission's proposal to move the sum from 2014 to 2015 is therefore fair and common sense, but unfortunately simple common sense is no longer enough. We cannot continue to put pieces into an instrument that is clearly unsuited to the role it should play: the multiannual financial framework should be the basis on which to build all European policies. You see in Italy, a few days ago, the pylon of a bridge fell and wisely Minister Delrio said that that pylon will not be replaced but the whole bridge will be rebuilt, to make it safer and to make it more suitable. I would like to remind both the Commission, and especially the Council, that at the end of the last parliamentary term a post-election review of the multiannual financial framework was promised and this review should be carried out very quickly and should be a thorough, very thorough review, probably following the example of Minister Delrio italiano.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, we are looking at a vital report for the proper functioning of programmes aimed at the Member States, namely the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. The multiannual framework must provide predictability and consistency to the social actions of the European Union, so it is necessary to re-establish the amounts that could not be used by the end of 2014 – more than EUR 21 billion.  I believe that it is in the interest of all beneficiaries that this report be voted on, in order to ensure adequate funding and full use of funds for all programmes included, but in particular for programmes relating to job multiplication for young people, to ensuring a competitive framework in Europe and, last but not least, those relating to solidarity and social cohesion in the EU-28.  I take this opportunity to draw attention to the need to improve the programmes carried out under the multiannual framework. The effectiveness of a programme does not depend in a singular way on the budgeted amount, but also on the procedures that allow this amount to be fully used and to reach the target, to the beneficiaries in Europe's poorer regions, in order to achieve a very clear objective: a social Europe.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, the revision of the MFF has been made necessary because of three major delays: in adopting respectively the MFF and the regulations concerning the EU funds, and in the approval of operational programmes.  In practice therefore, in the course of 2015, Member States will need to commit the amounts which were previously envisaged for two years – 2014 and 2015. Furthermore, 2015 is the last year for absorption of the funds from the previous programming period. All this means exceptional pressure on the responsible authorities to comply with the relevant requirements for proper commitment of resources. Hence there might be a significant increase in the number of infringements for which Member States could easily be faulted. Really effective protection of the financial interest of the Union begins with the provision of enough time for the proper preparation and implementation of the relevant budgetary rules and regulations.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their report. In the report they highlighted that at the end of last year only a small percentage of operational programmes were adopted. I am pleased to say that in Wales we managed to adopt our operational programmes in November of last year and already we are funding projects. Unfortunately in England that is not the case. Because the UK Government changed the management structures, the operational programmes there have still not been agreed and of course this has consequences – consequences for those who want to apply for new projects, but also for those who have existing projects they want to continue. That is having real consequences for those who work in those projects and for the beneficiaries of those individual projects as well. That is why it is so important that this Parliament, later on this afternoon, accepts these changes to transfer the money in order that we can start to fund the projects right across Europe. I would indeed urge the Commission to put pressure on the Member States and also urge the Member States themselves to take action to make sure the operational programmes are now agreed as quickly as possible.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, we proclaim that more new investment is a paramount requirement if European economic recovery is to be sustained. So it is strange to find that so many billions of investment allocations under the EU’s own budget have again remained unspent from last year to this. We are looking at over EUR 21 billion from the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the agricultural fund and the migration fund. The truth is that if these funds had been managed under provisions that were devolved fully to national governments their absorption rate would have been much higher. The EU is not a federal system, but the procedures it follows in funding projects are more onerous than those followed in the US. Methods defining the management of co-funded projects are too frequently delaying project implementation. Too often they are applied on a one-size-fits-all basis. Of course this problem has been with the European Union since its inception, but one would have hoped that by now – especially following the recent years of economic crisis – efficient solutions to the challenge of spending allocated monies in time would have been discovered. The opposite seems to have happened. For instance, the impression is that state aid rules are being applied too stringently to project proposals. Projects delayed or reformatted mean more costs and less economic impact. Here too, the road to hell is paved with good intentions.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have mixed feelings about this amendment and the recommendation we are going to make. On the one hand, I am pleased that we are not losing money, because we are doing this at the last moment – 1 May is the deadline – but on the other hand, I am concerned that this type of situation is taking place at all. We should try to understand where this came from. On the one hand, the question for Mrs Georgieva: to what extent has the Commission's change contributed to this? What did you have on your desk? Is it the Commission's fault? Because changing the Commission was a fact, it could be a partial excuse, but only a partial one. The second question: to what extent should we blame the Member States for the delays? Are The Member States still burdened with the burden of implementing the 2007-2013 backlog, and are we moving so much towards the implementation of the 2014 commitments? It would be worth some assessment here. Commissioner Georgieva, too: after years of experience, actually decades of experience, perhaps it would be worth thinking about simplifications, especially for those countries where we have good experiences?

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this proposal aims to transfer to 2015 funds which, due to the late adoption of the regulations, could not be used until the end of 2014. This is a positive proposal that must be adopted, all the more so as it is accompanied by a declaration of willingness by the European Commission to actively cooperate with national and regional authorities in the implementation of these funds in areas that are fundamental to sustainable development and the fight against asymmetries. The solution found in this case, however, does not allow us to rest in relation to the "original sin" that seems to have contaminated this multiannual picture. At a time of stagnation, Commissioner, at a time of economic stagnation, when many countries benefiting from cohesion programmes are in great need of investment, it is unacceptable that a bureaucratic regulatory framework without internal flexibility should allevise the positive effects that could be expected of such investments. In Portugal, after 16 months on the entry into force of this framework, the first competitions are only now beginning to be opened and not one euro has yet reached the economy, the scientific and technological system or the training institutions. I hope that today's amendment will be adopted, that this will allow the resources we have to be better spent, not to be wasted on machine inefficiencies.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I welcome the Commission's announcement that it will be an active partner and cooperate with national authorities using all available measures with a view to adopting the programme as soon as possible following the adoption of this amended Council Regulation setting out the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020. The funds to be transferred in 2015 for economic, social and territorial cohesion and sustainable growth and natural resources should certainly be spent for this purpose and I hope that there will be no changes to the multiannual financial framework that would redistribute these funds for other purposes.  I find this proposal to revise the regulation very stimulating for the continuation of rural development work, as some Member States do not yet have an approved rural development programme and therefore could not even use the funds from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. The survival of villages across Europe depends on this money because if we want people to stay living in the countryside we must provide them with adequate social, social and communal infrastructure and self-employment through agriculture, rural tourism and other activities that can take place in the countryside and provide income to the rural population.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the draft Council regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is to be welcomed and approved by this Parliament. We are talking about a fundamental step towards completing the process of launching the new programming period for cohesion policy, which would avoid any negative impact on the regions, cities and therefore on European citizens. The European Structural Investment Funds are the Union's most important investment policy and it is therefore essential that all resources are used quickly and effectively to generate growth and employment, objectives that we have an obligation to keep high on the European Union's agenda. The revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework must therefore be carried out by ensuring the implementation of the programmes that were adopted later than expected. The new programming period has already suffered too many significant delays and further decommitments must be avoided. I would also like to highlight the need for the Commission to cooperate more closely with the Member States and the regions, promoting better quality of projects and simplification of procedures, with the aim of achieving full and effective use of all resources.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I agree with the amendment of the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, because more than 300 operational programmes financed by the Structural Funds and the other Funds of the European Union will thus be able to be implemented by strengthening the regions of the Union. This will support growth and reduce unemployment in the countries of the European South, and in particular in Greece which has been impoverished by the Memorandum. This will enable development projects in the Greek region to be financed by the Cohesion Fund. Through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, flood-suffering farmers in Tenagi, Philippi, Serres and Evros will be able to be supported. From the Asylum and Migration Fund there will be relief in Greece that is in danger of becoming a new Lampedusa due to the thousands of refugees flocking to the Aegean islands. Finally, we denounce from this step the blackmail policy of the Troika, which has frozen the implementation in our country of the programmes financed by the European Union, in order for Greece to succumb to the blackmail policy of the lenders.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, although this is seemingly a simple technical issue, a legal change, there is indeed one key political decision at stake here. What is this key political decision? This is a question of the credibility of the European Union. We can't afford to find ourselves in a situation like this if we had 21 billion pledged funds, allocated funds, and unpaid funds for months and years. It is those who believe most in the European Union, who often run for these funds, that lose faith in what we do.  That is why for all that predecessors have said, and especially, as a man with experience who has done more than 200, 300 European programmes, I am in order to simplify the procedure within the European Union for obtaining funding. It's absolutely necessary.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, we welcome this flexibility mechanism which allows the re-in-use funds to be relocated in 2014 for the coming years. This situation was already foreseeable, given the lengthof application procedures in the new Community framework. At the level of the Common Agricultural Policy, and in particular in terms of single payment applications, there are significant delays which should be appropriate dwellers from the Commission to make time limits more flexible. We cannot fail to take advantage of this debate to stress once again that this multiannual plan is at odds with the propaganda calling for a Europe of social cohesion, but which then does not give it the means to correct the asymmetries, more over and over at a time when the European Union itself constrains national states to use expansionist policies. We also do not understand that, in this context, the extraordinary revenue stemming from the own means of financing is not used to try to reduce this current deficit, as a stain that affects the credibility of the European Union, and which imposes on national states what it is unable to do in their own homes.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – I therefore think that it is clear from today's debate that there will be confirmation of the proposal to amend the Multiannual Financial Framework. And I think that the Commission's proposal to reallocate much of the appropriations directly in 2015 is to be supported, and of course there will be a turn and a risk – for errors – for irregularities. And I must say that, in its multiannual audits, the Court of Auditors points to errors, irregularities in the use of European funds.  However, it is even worse than mistakes if European funds are not used at all, either because of delays or because of the complexity of the regulations. Therefore, of course, it is an important challenge for the Commission to fulfil its promises to act on principle towards the objectives of a targeted budget. This, of course, also requires the simplication of regulations, so that we no longer only deal with bureaucracy, but also on the very content of projects. And, of course, we need to find the reasons for the delays and start dealing with the causes of the delays and correcting them, not just the consequences.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my support for the proposal for a Council regulation amending the regulation on the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020. This proposal will have positive consequences on the new cohesion policy, which is essential for European development and recovery from the economic crisis. The new cohesion policy provides support to new innovative businesses, supports small and medium-size enterprises, creates sustainable jobs, improves skills, combats poverty, promotes social inclusion, gives remote regions broadband, tackles the brain drain, improves the environment, promotes energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy resources, builds vital transport links and strengthens the efficiency of public administrations. It is therefore important that resources are used in a timely manner and as effectively as possible to generate growth and jobs. I hope that the swift adaptation and implementation of remaining programmes will be carried out soon, that the calculations made by the Commission will prove to be realistic and that the increase in the payments will be sufficient.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, first of all, and the work done by the specialised committees in Parliament. There is no doubt that we need a review of the MFF. However, I want to point out that we, Parliament, are doing our job if we vote on this report today. The responsibility, however, lies with the Commission. Madam Vice-President, I think you know very clearly what the problems were in the year 2007-2013. There have been big problems, thanks to complicated procedures, high bureaucracy: many costs to applicants and very large delays in payments. I was part of the government of my country and I know the problems very well. If you do not simplify the procedures, we will wake up next year and in two years with the same problems. The investment fund must have effects, including the elimination of regional gaps. I cannot agree with what you have told us and what Mr Juncker has told us, that regional criteria will not be used. Come from a country where you know what the need for investment means. You must also take into account the geographical criterion, you must also take very clearaccount into account what criteria are taken into account for the selection of experts, so that, in the end, this money from citizens is distributed so that we can achieve the reduction of the gaps. Basically, i tabled an amendment, calling for experts to be under parliamentary control. I hope to have a 2014-2020 exercise with much better effects than last year.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, many thanks to all those who have taken the floor to speak in support of a positive vote later on in this Chamber. Let me just make four points in response to comments and also to the questions addressed directly to the Commission. First, the impact on payments.  Our view is that it will be manageable, based on past payment profiles, but most importantly on the fact that, in dealing with the payment crisis we have had, together with Member States we have done a very good job on obtaining better projections for payment schedules so we can structure payments in a more prudent and predictable manner.  There was a question on whether there is a risk that countries will not be able to use the money. The n+3 rule applies and that means that once commitments are made there is time to execute the programmes that are approved. In fact the time is basically three years more than we have in the MFF, so this should be possible with programmes being approved this year. For some, approval will come early next year. All the funds committed are to be used.  I want to stress again that we have drawn very important lessons from the payment crunch in terms of how we can better manage the relationship between commitments and payments in our budget. Let us remember that we are no longer in the days of plenty. We have to learn to live with tighter budgets; focusing on the quality of spending and not just on the spending itself form part of this learning. My second point is on simplification. I heard loud and clear those of you who said that we need to have simpler rules so that programmes can be implemented and the level of errors can be reduced. I could not agree more with this. In the Commission this is a very high priority for us. We call also on Parliament to work with us, please, and not to add new control rules when they may not be necessary, when they do not add much value. But this applies also to Member States. Member States sometimes gold-plate rules and, even if we come with something that is simpler, bells and whistles are added and it is no longer simpler. So we all have to work systematically on implementation. My third point concerns the value for money. Is this something that should be supported? There were voices saying let us just give the money back to Member States. I want to speak using the language of facts. Cohesion money is there to benefit the countries that are on the receiving end but also the European Union economy as a whole. Analysis of the use of Cohesion Funds from the previous period demonstrates a very tangible impact on growth rates in cohesion countries: for Latvia, 2.1 % higher growth, for Lithuania 1.8 %, and for Poland 1.7 %. These figures represent additional jobs but also purchasing power for goods and services from other countries. One more fact: there is a very interesting report on the European Union, called Golden Growth, which says that we have invented the most powerful convergence machine in the world, one that has allowed European Union countries to accelerate their transition from middle-income to high-income status in the most impressive way that has ever happened. Over recent decades some two dozen countries have made this most difficult jump from middle to high income. Half of them are members of the European Union and the other half countries that have discovered oil or have used very aggressive competitive practices, sometimes without too much democracy attached. So we are the place where we are able to grow without compromising on democracy, human rights or social inclusion, and without discovering oil. That may be something we would have liked but, frankly, in terms of climate change, it is better not. My last point is on the mid-term revision. I have heard the points you made, which are very valid ones. We will certainly analyse very closely whether the MFF still adequately reflects priorities and we will propose adjustments if necessary. If these priorities require revision, we will of course come up with a proposal for revision. I want to stress that we would make full use of the new flexibility instrument for new priorities and the global margin for commitments. We would, of course, work broadly with Parliament – I see Committee Chair Mr Arthuis here with the Committee on Budgets – in order to make best use of our taxpayers’ money for the betterment of our economy and our people.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur - Mr President, very quickly I would like to thank my colleagues for supporting the favourable opinion we have issued with the co-reporter, Mr Olbrycht, who was unable to be present today. This is a favourable opinion which, as you have seen, Commissioner, is supported by a very large majority in this House. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her explanations, although we will have further appointments tomorrow on the payments plan.  I also see the interest of my colleagues in all these budgetary matters, which is very good news, and I would like to give us all an appointment for the revision of the multi-year financial framework that you have mentioned, which this time will no longer be only technical but also political.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today at 6.30 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – The changes to the ceilings in the EU’s Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 are necessary and inevitable. EU funds have a huge impact on the real lives of people as an essential tool for job creation, improvement of our environment and stimulation of infrastructure investments. We must ensure that Member States will not lose EU funds allocated to them and that the EUR 21.1 billion in uncommitted appropriations, representing 15% of the 2014 budget, will reach our citizens. Thus I welcome the proposed amendment and very much hope that my colleagues will vote in favour of it as well.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Mr President, colleagues, I will support the proposed amendment to the regulation, which aims to carry over the EUR 21.1 billion that was not used in 2014. The amount of unused funds was caused by a delay in agreeing a regulation on the multiannual financial perspective. Consequently, various pieces of legislation laying down provisions for the implementation of the Funds have also been adopted late. This concerns the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. Their provisions were only adopted in May 2014. For this reason, as many as 300 programmes (47 %) could not be accepted in 2014 and the appropriations allocated to them were used. It is therefore necessary to adopt the amendments to the Regulation as soon as possible and to transfer unused funds to this year's budget in order to ensure the implementation of all the programmes envisaged.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The European Parliament welcomes the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. It is therefore very important that we in the European Parliament support this recommendation on the transfer of commitment appropriations from 2014 to 2015, as this is necessary in order to complete the process of starting the new programming period for cohesion policy and to avoid any negative consequences for regions and cities, and thus for European citizens. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the Union's most important investment policy, so that all resources are used as efficiently as possible and as efficiently as possible in order to promote growth and create jobs.
