The new programming period is already very much delayed and it must be ensured that there are no further delays or any losses.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. We are discussing a necessary technical review in the face of major delays in the approval of operational programmes for the use of European funds. In 2014, more than three hundred programmes, 47% of the total, were not adopted. This situation affects all Member States and which, without the approval of this revision, would result in the loss of EUR 21 billion. With the investment deficit with which we are familiar, such a delay in the use of the Structural Funds is unacceptable. The rules provide for the possibility of transferring these allocations from 2014 to 2015 and we can only welcome this. What we are practising is positive flexibility, but it does not solve a structural problem. The financing of structural and cohesion policies must be simplified and made more accessible. There is a general need for a revision which is not merely technical but which is political and also concerns the multiannual financial framework. It must change its attitude to the European budget. The economic crisis requires our budget to play an active role in supporting development. This is one of the steps that we must take in this new parliamentary term if we really want the EU to be the architect of a new course based on growth and opportunities for citizens.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the ESI Funds are the Union's most important investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in a timely and efficient manner to lead to growth and job creation. As a representative of the poorest country in the European Union, Bulgaria, it is essential to me that all operational programmes work properly, as I closely monitor how entire regions are depopulated because they have no prospect, no economic growth, no education, no health care. That is why I believe that this proposal to amend the multiannual financial framework is of paramount importance, as the transfer of appropriations by one year will prevent delays in payments under many operational programmes, which would have negative consequences for regions and cities and therefore for European citizens.  I would now like to call on the Commission not to forget Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which obliges the EU to develop and implement its own initiatives which lead to the strengthening of its economic, social and territorial cohesion, and to pay particular attention to rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition and regions affected by severe and permanent natural or demographic handicaps.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 31 December 2014, more than 300 operational programmes in the Member States remained uninded. However, with the new year, these countries could not benefit from the transfer procedure provided for in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation. We are talking about EUR 21 billion that could have been irretrievably lost without this revision. In some countries, this was even the majority of the commitment appropriations under these programmes: in the Czech Republic it was 99.6%, in Romania it was 80%, in Spain it was over 60%, and in the UK it was more than 50%. It is now necessary to make efficient use of the €21 billion that was transferred from the previous year. For this, however, a revision of amending budget No 2 for 2015 is needed, which will ultimately allow expenditure to be realised in the period 2016-2020.  We are at an important moment in the process of starting the current programming period, so we should be particularly careful, as any delay can have serious consequences for the implementation of investments in the regions and for citizens. National authorities must demonstrate cooperation to undertake the remaining operational programmes in good time and to start funding those programmes. The Commission and the Member States should take these delays into account and their priority in order to avoid similar situations in the future. We therefore have the opportunity not only for a technical review, but also for a historic political revision.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – If we do not want to lose EUR 21 billion, a revision of the multiannual financial framework is essential. All EU countries, including Slovakia, would lose this money. At a time of chronic investment shortages, this would seriously damage employment and growth across the EU. This revision is of a technical nature and I do not see a problem with its approval. However, we must already work on a political review of the entire system for financing the European Union's budget. This means, we must ensure new funding for the EU budget, which is independent of the current economic or political situation in the individual Member States and which will no longer allow the European Union to pay for its invoices to municipalities, towns, entrepreneurs, hospitals,... I am pleased that an initiative has been launched in the European Parliament to kick-start this process. I believe that by the end of next year, when the Slovak Presidency in the EU will peak, we will be able to move our efforts to create new own resources to the final stage.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. – Turkey's current refusal to recognise genocide is an integral part of the crime and, at the same time, is the seed for a repeat of such crimes. The Armenian genocide should not be discussed simply as a historical event, but as a political lesson for the present and the future. When the crimes of the Ottoman Empire and later that of Nazi Germany took place, some states and politicians of the time chose the attitude of appeasement and the so-called policy of cooperation, but today everyone condemns those crimes. However, history repeats itself with Erdogan's Turkey bringing that repulsive person back through its neo-Ottoman vision. Cyprus, with one third of its European territory under the continued occupation of Turkish troops, is proof that crimes are still being maintained today because political and individual purposes prevail in favour of Turkey, at the same time as we condemn the crime it committed 100 years ago. We want a Turkey with a European perspective that respects the institutions and legitimacy of the EU and not for self-interest. So the question to consider is whether we should condemn a genocide in retrospect, or whether it would be better, for humanity, to prevent it from being committed.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The amendment of the MDM For 2014-2020 is of the utmost importance in order to ensure that EU funds not used in 2014 can be spent by Member States this year. Cohesion policy and the smooth continuation of rural development programmes in 2015 are particularly important Hungary, where six out of seven regions are considered disadvantaged. It is regrettable that the current Hungarian Government has managed to win EU support for catch-up by two billion euros less than the governments before 2010. Nevertheless, in the framework of cohesion policy, some 95% of public investment in Hungary has been made from EU funds in the last five years. Cohesion policy cannot therefore be the loser of budgetary debates! In order for cohesion policy to fulfil its real objective of catching up with the European average in disadvantaged regions and raising living standards, conditions of use need to be made more flexible in the next budgetary period. In order to reduce regional disparities, It is important that Member States pay particular attention to increasing renewable energies and energy efficiency and to supporting small and medium-sized enterprises providing two thirds of European jobs. It is regrettable that the current Hungarian Government currently has serious backlogs in all three areas.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. – The agreed Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 represents a budgetary statement of the political priorities or commitments made by the European Union for that period. It is therefore right that the budgetary appropriations for commitments planned for 2014, which could not be used, should be moved to the following year. Especially in a situation where the non-use has occurred solely on the basis of legislative delays. More than 300 programmes worth EUR 21 billion have not been adopted due to institutional delays. It is necessary to be active and act as soon as possible. Programming of the new structural policy must be started quickly. We must not afford to lose any funds that could be positively used to stimulate growth and increase employment in much-needed way. Even if a move is needed, we should not see this so-called instant solution as final. The Multiannual Financial Framework should be reviewed and the Council's position changed, in particular in the approach to payments. While commitment appropriations are being shifted, payment appropriations, which are increasingly being neglected, are not being addressed. Ignoring the problem of unpaid invoices, to which the eur 21 billion will later be added, is a journey to hell. Unfortunately, the figures printed on paper do not lead to the inclusion of disadvantaged people or the convergence of regions, it is the actual payments that can support viable projects.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. We voted today on the Council's proposed decision to establish an employment advisory committee. It is now essential to coordinate Member States' employment policies and to put in place a coordinated employment strategy. The task of this committee will be to monitor the changing employment and employment situation in the Member States and the Union, to formulate opinions and also to promote the exchange of information and experiences between Member States and with the Commission. If the missions of this committee are important, I stress the importance for the committee to consult with the social partners who will, I am sure, be very helped in these various missions. Thank you for your attention.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. – The proposed transfer of cohesion policy commitments from 2014 to 2015 aims to remedy the situation where delays in adopting the rules have not led to timely approval of all the operational programmes envisaged under the planned framework. Almost half of the programmes require an overhaul of the Multiannual Financial Framework in order not to lose the appropriations allocated for 2014. The current situation results in a delay in the implementation of cohesion policy funds in the Member States and regions. At the same time, the risk of under-implementation of cohesion policy appropriations in the current budgetary period and the failure to implementation of projects key to the Union's economic growth and development are increasing. The European Structural Funds play an irreplaceable role in union and national investment policy. I therefore consider it extremely important, in accordance with the Council's procedure, to give its consent to the proposal for a regulation so that all resources are used as soon as possible and as effectively as possible. I myself will support it during the vote for the above reasons.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – I welcome and support the European Commission's initiative on the transfer in the coming years of EUR 21.1 billion, planned for 2014 in the hiring of loans, following the delay in the adoption of European regulations. I believe that, given the limitations envisaged in sizing the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, other amounts that could not be committed in 2014 and 2015 need to be transferred in subsequent years.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – The European Structural and Investment Funds are the most important elements of the Union's investment policy. It is in the fundamental interest of the European Community that all resources be used in the best possible time and in the most efficient way to stimulate growth and create jobs. I, too, consider it important that the previous period be closed without member states losing resources due to various administrative delays. At the same time, I must draw the attention of my fellow Members and the Commission to the fact that we do not merely have to pay attention to the utilization of structural and investment funds. As a European Democrat and a representative of the Hungarian people, I depment the fact that there are several EU budgets available that would help, among other things, to end unemployment and retrain those who are temporarily out of work, but the Hungarian Government has so far not called off a single cent of it. It is in the interest of all of us, of the whole of Europe, that the Member States make effective and meaningful use of all means to alleviate unemployment. I therefore propose that, in addition to facilitating the use of the Structural Funds, we should also examine the use and utilization of other funds and, if necessary, make them easier to access.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Structural and Investment Funds are undoubtedly the most important tool of the European Union's investment policy. It is therefore a priority to take appropriate action to ensure that all the resources allocated to projects are used as in a timely manner as possible, and in the most effective way possible, in order to stimulate growth and jobs. The new programming period has already seen significant delays as a result of the late adoption of the Cohesion Policy Regulations 2014-2020, so it is all the more important to ensure that there are no further slowdowns or losses. The application of the amendments is a necessary step towards finalising the process leading to the start of the new programming period for cohesion policy without any negative consequences for regions or cities and, consequently, for European citizens themselves. It is important for the Commission to work with Member States and regions to implement the programmes effectively and diligently in order to achieve full efficient use of all available resources.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide (2015/2590(RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, looking back from 24 April, we will mark the 100th anniversary since the dark period of human history when many Armenians fell victim of atrocities committed under the Ottoman Empire. We mourn for the lives lost and for the suffering endured by those men, women, and children. The Council is well aware of the recent resolution of the European Parliament of 12 March on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in 2013 that, among other issues, called on all the Member States to acknowledge these atrocities as genocide and encouraged them and the EU institutions to contribute further to its recognition. We also take note of the Euronest resolution of 18 March this year, which touched on the same subject and contained the view that ‘preparing the ground for future reconciliation between peoples is of the utmost importance’. Armenia regards these events as genocide. Some EU Member States have also formally recognised this in their national legislation. However, I shall note that there is no common agreement as to the definition of the tragic events that took place 100 years ago. There are different reasons for this. Unfortunately, these tragic events still strongly affect the relations between Armenia and Turkey. Without any doubt, it is important to have a common interpretation of the history. However, I should not be the one telling you that this may be a very difficult goal to achieve. But, looking forward, what is of immediate importance is to do all we can to promote the development of constructive relations between both sides. The Council is committed to continue supporting the normalisation of Armenian-Turkish relations and encourages both sides to remain committed to the process of normalisation without preconditions. I would like to use this opportunity to invite both Armenia and Turkey to use every window of opportunity towards achieving this aim. The ratification by both sides of the Protocol on the establishment of diplomatic relations between the Republic of Armenia and the Republic of Turkey and the Protocol on development of relations between the Republic of Armenia and the Republic of Turkey signed in Zurich in 2009 should contribute to the normalisation of relations between the two countries, including the establishment of diplomatic relations. Normalisation of relations between Armenia and Turkey goes beyond mere bilateral interest. It has significant impact on both countries’ relations with their mutual neighbours, thus positively affecting security, stability and cooperation in the region. I would like to mention that the EU supports concrete activities targeting both countries, aiming at promoting confidence and people-to-people contacts. The Commission may have more details on this, but I wish to recall that the EUR 2 million project financed under the Instrument for Stability was launched in 2014. This project supports civil society efforts towards the normalisation of relations between Armenia and Turkey. The EU is committed to further engage with Armenia and Turkey. It is also high on Latvia’s Presidency agenda. We remain committed to provide necessary assistance to promote constructive relations between states.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission fully acknowledges the significance of the upcoming events commemorating the Armenian centennial, as well as the divergence of views on this particular tragedy. It has had far-reaching consequences for Europe, with many of our current Member States integrating the Armenian diaspora and therefore also keeping the memory of these events alive. What happened a hundred years ago continues to be felt in this century and to negatively affect Armenian-Turkish relations. The upcoming centennial commemorations in April this year will most probably create additional sensitivity but will also be another test case for the future of bilateral relations between Armenia and Turkey and a chance for advancing reconciliation. Reconciliation is a core foundation of the European project and values. The Commission continues to support the normalisation of Armenian-Turkish relations and to encourage both sides to remain committed to the process of normalisation, without preconditions, through the implementation of the protocols they signed in 2009. It is essential that in this period of reconciliation partner countries are able to face their past through open and sincere debate. The Commission is glad to note that a debate has been taking place in Turkey over the past ten years. It is important that such an opening is acknowledged, encouraged and protected, including through well-calibrated messages from the European Union. Last year’s statement by the then Prime Minister, Mr Erdogan, was a welcome step and the Commission encourages further meaningful steps paving the way towards full reconciliation. As mentioned by the Council, the Commission supports concrete activities aiming to promote confidence in people-to-people contacts. We have committed EUR 2 million to a project supporting reconciliation and to greater civil society cross-communication. We also clearly expressed these messages of support during Commissioner Hahn’s recent meetings held in mid-March in Yerevan with the Armenian President, Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs and also with Armenian civil society. The EUʼs support was highly appreciated, and there was a similarity of views on the positive impact that improved Armenian-Turkish relations could have on the whole region and on the multilateral track of the Eastern Partnership.  In April we shall join the Armenians in solemn commemoration and mourning for the lives lost, recalling the horror of what happened in the final days of the Ottoman Empire. Regardless of the words we use to describe those awful events, there can be no denial of their historical reality. They represent a dreadful atrocity afflicting the people of Armenia which must never be forgotten. Parliament can count on the Commission to work together to draw the right lessons from history so that we do not repeat past mistakes and in the future we build a Europe that is a welcoming home for all European people.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The 20th century is marked by mass murders — mass murders on ethnic, ideological, religious grounds, through and on the run and in many other things. In particular, my own country has participated in this with the mass murders of Jews, Sinti and Roma and others, and we rightly call this genocide. We feel a moral responsibility for this, and I am still grateful today that the Israeli Prime Minister, Mr Ben-Gurion, gave us the signal and met with the German Chancellor, Mr Adenauer, in New York 14 years after these millions of murders. But the Bolshevik regimes have also killed many people. This is not to be put into perspective. Every act is cruel and irresponsible in itself. One cannot put into perspective by enumerating deeds. But the Stalinist, Bolshevik dictatorships also committed their crimes. Such genocide was also the act of Armenians, the hundreds of thousands of people who were killed under the Ottoman Empire in connection with the First World War. Nor do I want to forget the Pontos Greeks and the Aramaeans. I believe that, at the centenary of this day' return, we must realise that this must never be accepted again and that it is part of people's identity that the murders of their predecessors can also be called genocide. President Erdogan's statement, among other things, that he has apologised for such acts should be the way for Turkey to commit itself to this genocide in its history, namely under the Ottoman Empire. I believe that, for this reason, the 1948 United Nations Convention is intended to send out a clear signal that we are not only condemning in retrospect, but that we are taking responsibility for the fact that it never happens again. In Rwanda and other countries, the international community has failed in such cases. That is why this is an appropriate moment to ensure that we always take responsibility when genocide threatens. For whatever reason, there is never an alibi or justification for genocide, no matter what the political circumstances.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Brok, thank you very much for these clear words, which we agree with. Today we commemorate the deaths of the Armenian genocide 100 years ago by the Ottoman Empire. Today, however, we also recall the Idea of European Peace, the importance of the protection of minorities, mutual respect and tolerance. I know that there are some colleagues who do not want to hear it, but genocide must also be called genocide. This applies to all of us, including Turkey. It would also be an important step, also in order to put relations between Armenia and Turkey on a new footing, to make this recognition of the realities. This includes opening up the archives. However, it is also due to those who deal with this issue in Turkey. You have mentioned the Turkish President, and the Turkish Government has also taken the first steps in this direction. Turkish non-governmental organisations are working very this issue. We encourage them to continue along these steps in the right direction. Especially as a German and aware that the German Empire was an ally of the Ottoman Empire, I know that it is very difficult to reconstruct one's own history, but also a basis for respectful, trustworthy international access to international cooperation. Without the work of history and the help we have received from others, Mr Brok and I would probably not be able to speak in this Parliament. However, anyone who abuses this request from the European Parliament for political purposes has misunderstood us. The resolution is a step towards Turkey and should not be used as an indictment. We want to make it clear that we want good relations with Armenia and Turkey.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, nine days’ time will mark the official centenary of the beginning of the Armenian genocide by Ottoman Turkey. Today we must commemorate that tragic event and think of the one and a half million innocent murdered victims. But today should also be about looking to the future. Since closing its border with Armenia in 1993, Turkey has pursued a relentlessly hostile policy towards Armenia. This centenary offers an opportunity for Turkey to reach out, to recognise the genocide and to seek dialogue with regard to reopening the international border as a gesture of goodwill. Turkey claims justification for the closure of the border by citing its solidarity with its Turkic brothers in Azerbaijan, but we have seen this for the smokescreen that it really is by witnessing Turkey’s inaction over the persecution of Turkic Tatars in Crimea. Armenia and its diaspora do not seek restitution or compensation, they only seek recognition. Erdogan’s Minister for Europe has claimed that accession to the EU remains Turkey’s number one priority. Let that claim be honoured today by joining the 11 EU Member States and national parliaments that recognise the Armenian genocide and offering closure on this dark episode of Turkish history.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been working for a few months now on the adoption of this European text on the commemorations of the centenary of the Armenian Genocide. This is a question first and foremost European. It concerns the past and its truth, it concerns the future and its promises.  This text has been the subject of fruitful negotiations, and I publicly thank the political groups and all of our colleagues who participated. The centenary of this tragic event imposes a dignified attitude and Parliament has conquered it.  At the buttonhole, Mr President, I wear a myosotis, Vergissmeinnicht, it is said in German. I want to thank Mr. Brok and Mr. Fleckenstein, among others, for their tribute and the words they spoke. Personally, I will, of course, be a little more demanding. I would have liked the spirit of these texts to be more commemorative and more focused on the ever-establishing links between Armenian civil society and Turkish civil society, a victim of repression when it wants this genocide to be recognized. Personally, I must say publicly that we cannot yet be satisfied - even if we are moving in the right direction - with the vague condolences of Prime Minister Erdogan, now President, and Mr Davutoglu, with regard to the victims who have been killed, killed, murdered and families have been thrown on the roads all over Europe. So I will say one simple thing: where is the Turkish Willy Brandt today, the German who, in November 1970, went to Poland to kneel, not speak, in front of the monument of the Jewish victims in Warsaw, thus showing the world that there could be no history and future without the recognition of the truth? One more effort, Mr. Erdogan, and you may be a statesman.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I do not think we will have a complete picture unless I inform you of what Mr Davutoğlu and Mr Erdogan have just said on the subject. Mr. Davutoğlu said that the Pope's statements are in line with the axis of evil. Mr Erdogan said that this debate in the European Parliament would come in one ear and come out of the other. I think it is useful for Parliament to know this during our debate. I was in favour of voting in favour of an amendment that said that we welcome recent statements by Mr Erdogan, who regretted the tragic, as he simply calls them, "events" of 2015. I have to say that I am now troubled by the above-mentioned statement. Nevertheless, I believe that Turkey must be in line with its past and must recognise the facts and call them genocide. I understand that a century of teaching in Turkey's schools about non-genocide is not helping. However, the real political leaders at times like this seem. This leadership must push things forward because it cannot ignore the international community which is calling on it to recognise genocide. Turkey's proposal for a joint study of the archives by Armenians and Turks will not, in my view, lead to any result other than the squandering of another century of debate on this issue, without going anywhere. The image presented by Turkey, namely that the European Parliament is fighting it, is wrong. The European Parliament is dealing with it because Turkey, if it wants to join the European area, must solve its problems, both at home and abroad - problems with the Kurds, with the Armenians, with Greece, with Iraq, with Iran, with Cyprus.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the As a European, but above all as an Austrian, I myself have learned how difficult it is and how long it takes for the atrocities – genocide – to be recognized in their own history by members of their own people and by their own ancestors, and it is clearly stated that genocide, genocide, is a crime that has never happened again, and that naming them as genocide is central to making it possible for the descendants of those who have experienced this suffering and trauma to continue to live. The naming of genocide is what we are doing here with this resolution. I think it is necessary for the Armenians and Armenians to be told again by the European Parliament: it was a genocide, we remember it, and we condemn it. I am glad that many EU Member States, including national parliaments, have now recognised this genocide. The others should do the same. It is also necessary for Turkey to recognise this genocide. Yes, the first steps are being taken, including in Turkey, especially from civil society. But it's not enough. It is necessary that this recognition should also be given by the official Turkish Government. However, I would like to comment on something else. Austria-Hungary, like Germany at the time, was also an ally of the Ottoman Empire. Too little historical research has been carried out to work through this knowledge and also to make it clear that this must never happen again. Never again being complicit in the fact that genocide is taking place and doing nothing about it – that is also the European mandate of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, genocide, a hundred years ago this word did not even exist! It was not published by Raphael Lemkin until 1944. For this reason the Armenian people carved out in the words Metz Yeghern, "Great Evil" the pain of his tragedy. It does not matter if there were eight hundred thousand or more than a million victims; it does not matter whether more people died from cold, hunger and disease than torture, rape and killing; it does not matter the sterile struggle of numbers and justifications. Why can it be more odious and intolerable than the persecution of the other just because it is something else on its own? This colleague is the greatest horror of genocide, of any genocide. But today we are not here to judge, this resolution is not an act of condemnation, it is a fitting tribute to remembrance and a humble invitation to reconciliation with others and with oneself. Accepting the mistakes of the past is a great relief for a people. Our partners are well aware of this and have not been able to prevent either the mistakes of dictatorship or those of colonialism. My son knows that, that he cloaked himself from both of them. It is precisely these wounds that make us true and sincere friends of Armenia and Turkey. That is why we are asking them to ratify the Zurich protocols, the word of hatred and vengeance can no longer be combined, even in the past. The horizon of the future is made up of reconciliation, collaboration and peaceful coexistence. Know to recognize and be conscious.  Primo Levi wrote that the Holocaust is a page in the book of humanity from which we should never remove the bookmark of memory. Well, today we are asking the Armenians, the Turks, all the peoples of the world, to bookmark this page too and never to remove it, ever again.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – The genocide of Roma in the Second World War, the continuing genocide of Christians in the Middle East, they call for reflection. The other genocide, the genocide of Armenians, leaves deep wounds to this day, and a century later the consequences are still visible and palpable. There is in fact no question of an acknowledgement, an excuse or any form of compensation or restitution of goods by the Turkish Government to this day. On the contrary, President Erdogan today declares that any decision by the European Parliament will go one ear in and the other. The EU, which is emerging as a human rights champion, is on the sidelines. I would remind you that on 12 March this Parliament the Panzeri human rights report was voted on, which called for recognition by the EU Member States, as opposed to legal recognition. Fortunately, there was Pope Francis, who dared to call things by their names. My party, along with many supporters, is also calling on the European Parliament to adopt a resolution that obliges the Turkish Government to recognise and reconcile. Only then will Europe as a continent be called a beacon of peace.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I regret that the Commission, present with us today, did not dare to utter the word 'genocide', because, Commissioner, we are now discussing the genocide of the Armenian people and the centenary of this genocide. The title of our resolution, which we will be voting on shortly, is this.  This text calls in a very clear way for Turkey to recognise the genocide, which is particularly important in the perspective of reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. In other words, it is not to criticise Turkey, but not to give it lessons that we adopt this resolution, but to encourage it to take a further step towards the recognition of this genocide. That is why we have taken note of the openness and apologies already made by the current President and the current Prime Minister.  Let me tell you that I understand the difficulty of the Turks in recognizing the genocide. It was equally difficult, for example, for Romanians to recognize their participation in the Holocaust and crimes against Jews and Roma.  However, I believe that we are not fully human if we do not recognize what our predecessors did. Because it is not a question of history or science as Mr Erdogan claims: it is a question of memory and not a question of history. Memory is the responsibility of political leaders, opinion leaders and ordinary people. It is not the preserve of scientific seminars.  That is our perspective.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I will pay tribute today, like everyone else, to the memory of so many innocent Ottoman Armenians who were victims of the atrocities perpetrated in the context of the World War I. I would like to reiterate the call to both sides, Turkey and Armenia, to ratify and implement, with no preconditions, the protocols of 2009 and to take all necessary further steps towards the normalisation and improvement of their bilateral relations. It is of utmost importance to keep the memories of the past in order to prevent new conflicts and not to repeat them in the future. I would also like to emphasise the need to avoid any political instrumentalisation of such events and work together towards reconciliation. As a historian, I would conclude by saying: it is wise of politicians not to use or to misuse history for political purposes.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: We are all aware that the subject of the Armenian genocide is still very sensitive and difficult to discuss, even now, 100 years after the events. But this resolution is not a resolution against anything or anyone and certainly not against the Turkish people or its leaders. This resolution is, however, a first important step in giving the past a place. By recognising and commemorating the Armenian genocide, future generations will no longer be trapped in the past, but will be able to free themselves from it. That is why the Belgian Federal Parliament in 1998 was one of the first national parliaments to recognise the terrible fate of Armenians and other populations as genocide. The most important thing is probably to understand the historical and ideological context in which the genocide may have taken place. In this way, we can learn lessons if there are still ideologies that can result in aggressive regimes, where forced deportation and genocide can no longer be excluded. I therefore regard this resolution primarily as an important lesson and a warning to our and future generations.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, we all have high hopes and expectations for the historic reconciliation of two nations and states; two very important partners of Europe situated in a very vibrant region. I am of the opinion that in a situation like this the one which was bigger and stronger back then, and which is bigger and stronger today – that is Turkey – should be leading the process. In Europe, we have a few more examples of such a struggle and we also have the positive cases that should be followed. I see our role, as the politicians of Europe, to help this happen at every instance. Courageous, sincere, forward-looking and European, I truly expect Turkey to act this way. Decent and respectable recognition of this strategy would signal the ‘Europeanness’ of Turkey, which is more and more needed today. This is so much needed for the entire region and it is needed today, not tomorrow.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. The journey from Nuremberg to The Hague was long and long. But legal judgments on genocide are never the end of the matter, they are always just the beginning of a comprehensive investigation. For me and my group, the centenary commemoration of the Armenian genocide is part of the European understanding of contemporary history. We must jointly explain why multicultural life on the Bosphorus was so bloody suffocated at the beginning of the First World War, including with the participation of German military advisers. I also expect the Turkish Government to take the same view of this process. We need a new political start, as we did five years ago in the days of football diplomacy. I call on the Turkish Government to give back its dignity to the victims and to themselves!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, just a month ago I had a breathtaking view in front of my eyes: I saw the biblical Mount Ararat from the Armenian side of the closed border with Turkey and I realised how deep our common European history is and how rooted it is in this region that we are discussing today. I think we have to do everything to encourage confidence-building at all levels: at the historian’s level, at the grass-roots level and at the level of politicians so that Turkey and Armenia can come to terms with this tragic genocide that we are commemorating now. A large number of Members of the European Parliament were actually able to participate in a commemoration in Yerevan a month ago, and it was a deeply impressive moment for all of us when we were laying flowers on the monument in Yerevan. We must continue to gently push Turkey to come to terms with its own past. We must encourage the Turkish authorities to open all the archives: providing historians, academics and researchers the opportunity to shed light on these tragic events which indeed today we have reason to call genocide. We can also do a lot in the UN framework: we can support the UN Human Rights Council, which has proposed an international day of commemoration and dignity of the victims of genocide, and that would be 9 December.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, says that the first act of genocide is the demonisation of a people, the last act being its denial. Well, then I invite you to divide a million and a half human beings for 365 days. Days during which their massacre took place. 4100 men, women and children massacred every day in a way that is difficult to imagine just because armenians, this is genocide. And no one in this meeting can afford to deny it. History says so, as the Ottoman Court says, condemning the perpetrators of the genocide, turkish historians say, not least Taner Akçam who said that only known archives would be enough to call that crime genocide. So I'll tell you armenia: Turkish politics can also call me a liar! Remember, however, that the story is written by the same people who hanged the heroes.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like first of all to express our compassion and solidarity with our Armenian friends around the world, whose rights and recognition of genocide have been repeated for many years. I would also like to salute all my French compatriots of Armenian origin whose civilization and patriotism are exemplary when they have never ceased to cultivate the memory of their great civilization. As a member of the delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee in the European Parliament, I would like to once again denounce the scandalous attitude of Mr Erdogan, locked in his sickly denialism and inhumanity, which claims that the recognition of the Armenian genocide is not part of the Copenhagen criteria.  At a time when another genocide - that of the Christians of the East - is perpetrated before our eyes, it is also because they were Christians that more than a million and a half Armenians were massacred by the Ottoman regime at that time.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – The history of the world is not only the pages of great growth and enlightenment, but also the bloody crimes committed against peoples or large groups of people. This is a crime committed against the Armenian people in 1915. This year, the world marks the centenary of this crime, and the blood of its innocent victims is still poisoned by relations between Armenia and Turkey. I call on the Turkish leaders, Members, intellectuals and the widest society to seek reconciliation with their past, to accept past events and to lay the foundations for genuine dialogue and reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. The ability to take responsibility for your history is a measure of the nation's size. I believe that the Turkish people will be able to do so because they cannot create a healthy, modern society unless they are based on the truth.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution is not intended to provide a historical reading of the Armenian genocide, but to highlight a political reading of it. european countries. This is the problem today, of a regional power struggling to contain its ambitions in this context. Now the theme is that reconciling with one's past is crucial to close wounds and look to the future, and one must not be afraid of words at all. Turkey is an important and strategic player in the region, but it is above all it that touches it at the moment and that it has the task of opening a new democratic phase in its historical history.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, the very House in which we sit is built upon foundations that were built out of absolute carnage. It would be quite wrong – and our two sister institutions are present here today – for anybody to expect this House to do anything other than to stand by our core principles. If we do not support the resolution that has been put before us in the vote that we take, then I am afraid the world will know that this House does not stand by the principles it preaches to others.  I visited Yerevan very recently. Whilst I was there, taking part in the Euronest discussions and our parliamentary cooperation committee, we finalised texts and I have co-signed the resolution that is going to be put before this House. Whilst President Erdogan may take the view that he is going to ignore what this House has to say, for how long is he going to ignore all of those Turkish people that are saying exactly what we have said in our resolution? I say to the Turks and I say to the Armenians: ‘Our intent is constructive. We want to help you both to move forward towards normalisation of relations.’ But to do that we must first stand by our own core principles. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Sir, does your support for core principles extend to dissociating yourself from the Conservative Party’s enthusiastic sycophantic position as being a cheerleader for Turkey to join the European Union, and if not, why not?

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I think we have just had a very clear demonstration of the type of politics that Mr Erdogan himself is playing. I am afraid that the setting up of national agendas in order to ensure that the greater picture is ignored is not the constructive intent to which I refer. This House and the foundations upon which we are built demand of us that we stand by those core principles to which I referred. Of course our two sister institutions may not be able to come and stand exactly with us but, as long as we know that they support the position we are taking, based upon our individual circumstances, then we know as a Union that we are in a strong position. I stand by every word of what I have said.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I take the floor, not to talk about history, much less to argue about historical topics, because I do not believe that this is expected from the grandstand of the European Parliament. And to be honest, I don't feel competent, not because I haven't read any other book about the events that provoked the draft resolution we're discussing, but because I'm convinced that reading or hearing something about a topic might be enough to form some personal opinion, but it still can't energize you with the self-confidence to turn that opinion into a common one. Dear colleagues, controversial historical events should not be transformed into modern political conflicts. Historical facts, when they are facts, will not cease to be so, whether someone denies them or accepts them. I plead against the self-targeted political use of historical facts, against self-targeted digging in the past, against the choice of confrontational themes by him. Turkey and Armenia are mature enough and far enough ahead in their democracy to resolve this issue with dialogue. I don't think the debates in the European Parliament today will contribute anything to that. Yes, they would make it difficult for him. Graduating, I was born in the Balkans, a region marked by severe conflicts but also with a unique ethnic tolerance. Mr. Chairman, the great Balkan poet and Nobel laureate Ivo Andric, in his work, writes about the bridges on which together we must move towards the future, not go back to the past. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr. Kuçük, as a representative of a party which in its name has the words "rights and freedoms", do not you think that crimes against humanity and genocide should be reprimanded and those who have committed them must bear their political responsibility? The Armenian genocide and the destruction of the Thracian Bulgarians is an indisputable historical fact. You can read this and ask any specialist on the subject. My question is: Should genocide be reprimanded and denied in your opinion, and should those who committed it be held accountable?

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Mr President, the Blue Card procedure implies dialogue. I don't think my colleague Angel Dzhambazki is in dialogue with me. Apparently, he hasn't heard my call for a tolerant and dialogue world. Therefore, Mr. Dzhambazki, I will not give you my rejoinder.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: In this case, Mr Kyuchyuk, in the light of the content of the statement under the 'blue card', I can only agree with you.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the Turkish genocide against one and a half million Armenians in 1915 is one of the darkest pages in the history of the 20th century. What is worse is that this crime against humanity continues to this day, with the Refusal of the Turkish State to acknowledge the genocide and apologize. The final stage of a genocide is its refusal because it leaves open the way for similar crimes to be committed in the future.  Turkey must stop the violations of international law, lift the threats of war against Greece and end the military occupation of part of Cyprus, recognise the genocide against the Armenians and the Pontians it committed a century ago and declare its practical remorse, opening its borders with Armenia and accepting the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. In any other case, Turkey cannot be considered part of modern Europe.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, in The Armenian language there was talk of the Mec Yełeṙn, the great catastrophe. I don't want to discuss the adequacy of the concept of genocide to what really happened. It's probably the most appropriate. And we can't forget or minimize. We must continue to work in all areas to face the truth, however raw and painful. And we must expect from the current Turkish authorities to assume, without subterfuge of any kind, the horror of what happened a hundred years ago, in the context of World War I. But, for the same reason, we must know how to distinguish between the serious responsibility of the Ottoman Empire at the last stage of its existence and the demand that we must make to the present Turkish state today. Let us therefore work to make compatible the knowledge of the truth, the recognition of the responsibilities that correspond to that empire and the concrete progress towards understanding between the respective peoples and institutions. Let us not make this anniversary an un defenceless trial of the Turkish society and city that today welcomes millions of refugees, who want to look to the future in peaceful coexistence with their neighbours and who see in Europe the common framework of freedom, justice and prosperity to which it legitimately aspires. That's European responsibility. Our slogan today must be 'reconciliation'. That is the key word that should guide our reflection and our decision.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: "The stories of all our countries are different. Unlike tragic and painful.  But despite the painful stories of ours, the suffering of nations and the tragedies of torn families, it is very important to remember the past as it really was.  Only by telling ourselves the truth and recognizing our past will we be able to look firmly to the future and seek reconciliation. This is the only way to ensure that cruel and inhuman events never happen again.  Therefore, as we approach the centenary of the Armenian genocide, I would like to remind you that as early as 2005, the Seimas of the Republic of Lithuania adopted a resolution, and a few days ago Pope Francis, and today, the European Parliament, mentions the victims of these terrible massacres by calling the massacre in the real name genocide. And this is very important. Dear colleagues, the foundation of the future is the past, let us not be afraid to turn back sometimes.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdogan's discomposed and violent reaction to the words of Pope Francis is a handheld demonstration of how much more this Turkey is from us, other than our values, other than the principles of the peoples on which the peoples of Europe are recognised. We must have the courage to call things by their name: Erdogan is a negationist, he speaks as a mafia against the Pope, he makes threats, which those who represent a country like Turkey – let us remember the precedent of the attack on the Pope – have a particularly serious meaning that Europe, through its amendments to the resolution, should find the courage to respond and to say that that Pope who addressed himself with the words of mercy and love among the peoples you can't answer with language from Toto Riina, as a mobster. The head of state of a country that would like to enter Europe, and God be watching us from this mistake, should not allow himself to speak as a mafia towards Pope Francis.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Mr. President. I believe that this is a very important day for the European Parliament, very important for Armenia, which is very important for all those who denounce and fight criminal practices against peoples, against ethnic groups, ethnic minorities or national minorities around the world. The genocide that was committed 100 years ago, in 16/17 1915 against the Armenian people, is a great stain on the history of the European peoples, in the history of the Asian peoples and should be remembered here.  That in no case means a condemnation from Turkey, and that is what Turkey itself has to understand. To criticize a practice of a government, which was the government of the Ottoman Empire at that time, does not mean condemning the Turkish Republic or the Turkish people, it means just saying that these practices cannot be repeated and Turkey should first make this distinction, recognising what happened 100 years ago and, of course, deploring, showing that it is totally outside of this set of practices. For a Portuguese which is closely linked to Armenia, Portugal, mainly by the action of Calouste Gulbenkian, we could not fail to have a word here today for Parliament.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, our commemoration this year of 100 years since the First World War brings us to remember the tragic events involving Turkey and Armenia. It is quite right that we honour all who died and seek to learn the lessons of history in order to help us all live a better future. But there are Turkish friends who believe the motivation behind these and similar expressions of sentiment are about using history in order to prevent a better future. To these Turkish friends I say as follows. In the past my country, Great Britain, has been responsible for events which caused suffering and which cause us pain. The British set up concentration camps in the Boer War which were used to kill one in 10 of the Boer population. In Malaysia, the British deported half a million ethnic Chinese. Irish colleagues in this Chamber know how British rulers refused to feed the starving during that country’s famine. In an attempt to resist calls for independence in Kenya, Britain interned up to a million innocent civilians and forced them to work as slave labour. I am a proud Briton, but I do not seek to deny these events from my country’s past. I do not feel the need to equate these events with past sufferings of my fellow countrymen and women. Indeed, I am proud that leading figures of my own party took part in movements for liberation, towards reconciliation, to establish modern and equal relationships within our Commonwealth. So British Labour MEPs will support this resolution. We will welcome the recognition and condolences which have indeed been offered by Turkey itself. We will encourage reconciliation. We will reject any attempt to link this issue to Turkey’s EU accession but, whether the word used is ‘massacre’ or ‘atrocity’, ‘tragedy’ or indeed ‘genocide’, people died. And – whether it was more than or fewer than one million people who died, irrespective of the number of Turks who died in the subsequent war, whatever the academic argument about whether a genocide was committed before the genocide convention was itself passed, and despite the rulings of the Armenian Constitutional Court and of the Turkish Parliament which have blocked attempts at mutual understanding – sensitive to the emotions which are still felt today by relatives and descendants, we support today’s debate and resolution to honour the memory of all who died. (Applause)

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When I say the Holocaust, everyone knows what's going on. Nazi Germany murdered hundreds of thousands of its own Jewish fellow citizens, millions of citizens of other countries, almost 3 million citizens of Polish, my country. Until 75 years ago, quite recently – there are older Members in this Parliament – it was inconceivaable for someone to walk the streets of Frankfurt dressed in skull poke. Yesterday at Frankfurt airport I saw Jews not only in skullcaps, but also in huts, and in hats, with pejsami. They weren't afraid. The German service referred to them in the same way as to everyone else.  When we talk about Armenians, it's different. One hundred years ago, the now de-existent Turkish state launched a pogrom of Armenians. More than one and a half million Armenians were killed. There is no doubt about that, there are only differences of interpretation. Armenian people talk about genocide, our Turkish friends talk about events. The result is that the border between Armenia , the country of our Eastern Partnership, and Turkey, the newly formed Republic of Turkey, which is almost a hundred years old today and a candidate country for the European Union, is closed. Is the Republic of Turkey cutting itself off from the Ottoman Empire to such an extent that even the alphabet has changed, in this case it felt like an Ottoman heritage? I wish the Turks and Armenians the opening of the border and mutual cooperation and membership of the European Union. May armenians in Ankara be greeted like this.... (The President has taken the vote of the Member)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Colleagues, if you have one minute it is simply not acceptable and not respectful to other colleagues to speak for one minutes and 45 seconds or so. Please stick to your allotted speaking time or else ask your political groups to give you more time.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: President. Ladies and gentlemen. This year and this month, the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, also known as the Armenian holocaust, is celebrated. It decimated and led to the forced deportation of more than one million Armenians between 1915 and 1917 during the final phase of the Ottoman Empire.  This holocaust, carried out by the government of young Turks, was the first attempt that existed in the 20th century to exterminate an entire people. It followed, as we all know, other holocausts with very clear, identical purposes. The Nazi and stalinist and today, unfortunately, we continue to witness passive persecution of a political, religious and ethnic nature. 100 years after this tragedy of humanity, it is important today not to forget or silence the brutality of the massacres and forced deportations committed in the name of policies of ?? whose sole purpose has always been the extermination of the Armenian people. History haunts us and if we do not have the courage to face and admit the mistakes of our ancestors, we will never be able to close a blackboard, chapter of our common history and promote much-needed reconciliation. As someone has said recently, we cannot silence what we have seen and heard, and so what is now requested here is not condemnation for what has happened but rather the pure recognition of the facts. Thank you.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: – From the town where I live comes a book that is one of the most impressive about the Armenian tragedy, "Forty Days" by Franz Werfel. It turned out in this tragedy that the Ottoman Empire was the dungeon of nations, as it was said, and in the end there are people in our parliament, even from countries that suffered under the Ottoman yoke. People from Bulgaria, Greece, Cyprus and also Romania.  And I must say that all of this is the hope for me that the European Union will ultimately be the place of reconciliation and redress of wrongs. And I wish that the two nations, armenians and Turks, would meet in the European Union. And there is some hope for that, too, is the current statement by Turkish president Erdogan, who has actually expressed regret, regret and apology for what happened in 1915, a century ago.  I believe it is also a challenge, this reminder of this tragedy that The Christians of the Middle East need our help, solidarity and protection.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our institution already recognised the Armenian genocide in 1987 in 1915. And today, with this new resolution, we commemorate this undeniable historic event: it is its 100th anniversary. I would like to say, Commissioner, that the word 'genocide' should be used and not 'massacre'. Genocide is genocide! We have all fought in our Member States for the recognition of this genocide, so this word has historical significance.  I would also like to pay tribute to the victims of the Armenian genocide, which is far from being a detail of the history of the Ottoman Empire and which Turkey should stop denying. If Turkey recognizes itself as heir to the Ottoman Empire, it must also consider itself as heir to its history and therefore to the Armenian genocide. That is why I would also like to pay tribute to those in Turkey who have helped to lift the taboo of genocide and who will commemorate this Armenian genocide in Istanbul next week.  Let me remind my colleagues that the Turkish Green Party recognises the Armenian genocide and that it is the responsibility of other European political groups to act so that other Turkish political partners do the same. Finally, and I would like to end with this sentence, as the pope recalled this week, "to conceal or deny evil is to let an open wound bleed without dressing it".

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, colleagues have eloquently stated that, 100 years ago, Ottoman Turkey carried out what has been described as a systematic genocide. That was a century ago, but in today’s Turkey the government still refuses to apologise adequately and properly to the Armenian people. In today’s Turkey there are 21 journalists in jail and up to 150 awaiting trial. In today’s Turkey the opposition is liable to arrest. In today’s Turkey the government is attempting to control access to the Internet. Despite this blatant rejection of democratic values, Turkey is nevertheless an EU candidate country that has even been allocated more than EUR 4 billion in EU Pre-Accession Assistance. The Commission should think again. Moreover those parties, especially the British Labour Party and the British Conservatives, who are cheerleaders for Turkey’s candidacy, should start to be honest instead of blathering the platitudes that we heard from two of their representatives earlier.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, Turkey, a descendant of the bloodthirsty Ottoman Empire, has committed systematically exterminating Christian peoples in the last century. Ancient Christian populations of the Near East, Greeks, Pontians, Armenians, Chaldes and Assyrians, were slaughtered, uprooted and displaced, both in the context of the ex-Turkishization of Anatolia and for the sake of the strategic needs of Turkey and its German allies, in the context of the Great War. The numbers of victims refer to a holocaust of genocide: 1,500,000 Armenians, 353,000 Greeks of pontus, 800,000 Greeks and about 750,000 Assyrians, Chaldes and Syrians. One hundred years later, Turkey, in deliberately deaf cooperation with the West, continues to commit genocides, this time at the level of memory. While refusing to acknowledge the crimes she has committed, which go unpunished, she has the audacity to call for her to join the European family. Ladies and gentlemen: the recognition of genocides and days of remembrance are not a field of political debate. They exist to remind us where human atrocities, especially Turkish, can reach.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Commissioner Kristalina Georgieva said, the historical truth of genocide cannot be denied. Moreover, according to the International Association of Genocide Scholars, denialism is precisely the last act of genocide. So we simply cannot deny this historical truth of what happened 100 years ago. In addition, we must bear in place that it is precisely on the basis of the armenian genocide that the term has been given to describe the crime of genocide on which the 1948 United Nations Convention is based. But I say one thing, ladies and gentlemen, if we have really learned our lesson from history, we too must not repeat the mistakes we have too often made during the history we have made. In the face of atrocities, we turned our heads. Today there are atrocities that call our responsibility and we are still tempted sometimes to turn our heads the other way. They had been taken to Syria, those same sands that collected their blood today collect the blood of other martyrs: we do not turn our heads even today!

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Mr President, the twentieth century brought about the collapse of the Ottoman Empire and the birth of modern Turkey. Among the blackest moments of this era is the loss of one and a half million Armenians, which is 100 years old this year. They were not soldiers, like those who by the millions were lost at the same time in the fields of the great war, but hundreds of thousands of family members who were uprooted by deportations and death marches through mountains and deserts. The 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide may open the debate to continue President Erdogan's unfinished step last year in recognising Turkey's responsibilities for crimes against Armenians, to go even further with the help of Turkish civil society. This will enable the 2009 agreement to be revived, with a significant contribution to the security, cooperation and stability of the South Caucasus. We in the European Parliament do not adopt resolutions on punishment, but we contribute in our own way to overcoming contradictions, but overcoming the bravery of political leaders.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – In September 2014, 100 Turkish intellectuals made two demands to their government: the replacement of the textbooks for history and then an official apology to the Armenians for the genocide of a century ago. These requirements are inseparable, they are inseparable. This brings us to the heart of the controversy over today's Armenian genocide, a political controversy. After all, no official Turkish repentance can follow on from an officially concealed Turkish past. Let's be honest. You are from Germany, Mr President. Read the German press for the past few weeks. However, the description of the Armenian genocide in Turkish history books has made things worse. Victims become perpetrators and vice versa! Commissioner, how much do you weigh on this so offensive systematic Turkish history in the ongoing negotiations with Ankara? Or do you disregard the self-image and worldview of future Turkish generations? That would be a denial of our European principles!

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, at the dawn of 24 April 1915, in Constantinople, six hundred Armenian notables were murdered on the orders of the Ottoman regime. This is the beginning of the first genocide of modern times and I am summoning Albert Camus here to kindly remind the Commissioner of the importance of using the exact words. Our Parliament was, as early as 1987, as it said, the first international organization to recognize this genocide. Almost thirty years later today, and although the position of the Turkish government has changed - I do not downplay this - it is still the recognition of this genocide that crystallizes relations between Turks and Armenians. This is further evidenced by the recent statements by President Erdogan on the words of Pope Francis.  Was it therefore essential, in our resolution, for the rest quite balanced, to welcome the condolences of a President who, on the other hand, is camped on de facto denier positions? Like my colleague and friend, Jean-Marie Cavada, I don't think so. Winston Churchill and others, like Elie Wiesel, said: "A people who forget their past condemns themselves to relive it."  Our House Europe has a role to play in building a common future between Turks and Armenians. That is what we want to do today.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the armenian genocide is a crime against humanity that Ankara continues to deny, to erase from its political consciences. Unfortunately, it is also censured in the European negotiations with Ankara, even though some States and this Parliament in 1987 gave the massacres the name of murder of a people as such. It is as if Europe had united it without German recognition of the Nazi genocides. The Union would not have been born without such recognition, which is full of the legacy of the past. In the case of Ankara, full responsibility for what the young Turks and the Ottoman Empire have done. This negationist policy prevents Turkish governments from not only appeasement with Armenia, but also self-criticism of the invasion and violence in Cyprus in 1974. I will conclude by saying that I am sorry about what was said after the Pope's denunciation by an Italian minister that there is not a single historical truth about the Armenian genocide.

name: Hans JANSEN
text: – At the beginning of the last century, the then Turkish rulers took measures that their nationals considered to be anti-Islamic. You know: the caliphate was abolished, the Arabic alphabet was replaced by the Latin, Islamic law was replaced by European law. But in one respect, Islamic law has been applied: the Christian Armenians have been bitterly persecuted. Any application of Islamic law to Christians will result in events that we call genocide, because under Islamic Sharia law, non-Muslim people have no rights! It is our task today to commemorate the Armenian genocide, but we still have one task: to ensure that the same thing does not happen to Europe. That is why I ask the Commission: do not give space in Europe to Sharia law to commemorate the plight of armenians.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, I pay tribute to the victims of the genocide in Turkey 100 years ago with brotherly solidarity with the communities of Armenians expelled from their homelands in Hungary and Romania. Holocaust denial is punishable by law in many countries. On the other hand, the atrocities of the Communist dictatorship are often denied, minimized or relativised, and the historical fact of the Armenian genocide is not acknowledged by the perpetrators themselves. In the case of these crimes against humanity, it is impermissible to apply double standards. In a spirit of justice and legitimy, and in the interests of historical reconciliation between Turks and Armenians, we must name and strongly condemn the horror of the 'Endlösung' aimed at the total anniversion of Armenians in Turkey. Let this be a memento for us of the Islamic State's mass killings of Christians.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we commemorate the first systematic genocide of the 20th century. In the middle of the First World War, this was later repeated during the Second World War in the extermination of Jews, Sinti and Roma. Franz Werfel's books were banned by the Nazis because he foresaw this. Millions of people have been systematically humiliated, martyred and killed, and destroyed. Most have looked away, didn't want to see it and played down the crimes in the hope that grass will grow over it. That was a false hope. That is why it is good that today the Parliament of the peoples of Europe remembers these crimes and honours the victims. Only remembering and admitting guilt help us not to repeat the mistakes of the past, and they are a sign of strength, not weakness.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – What I hold in my hands is oblivion - a symbol of reverence, adoration and respect for the memory of a million and a half Armenians and hundreds of thousands of victims of other nationalities of the genocide committed by the young Turkish government.  This monstrous crime against humanity began in 1913, when a regular Turkish army and a bashibozuk tored hundreds of Bulgarian villages in Thrace, killing and driving hundreds of thousands of Bulgarians from their homelands. The genocide continued in 1915 and 1916, when the young Turkish government ordered, organized and carried out the physical destruction of more than a million and a half Armenians within the borders of the Ottoman Empire. The purpose of the Turkish authorities is the massacre and expulsion of all nationalities other than Turkish.  This monstrous genocide must be harshly condemned. The Turkish government, a successor to the Ottoman Empire, must be compelled to admit its guilt, take political responsibility and compensate the heirs of the victims. I strongly condemn the Turkish genocide over the Armenian, Bulgarian and other peoples of the Empire. I have therefore proposed, signed and supported the EP resolution condemning Turkish atrocities and the Armenian genocide. I conclude with the motto of the Armenian community dedicated to the centenary of the genocide: "I remember and condemn, remember and demand, live and remember, live and demand."

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, here in the European Parliament today we mark a sorrowful anniversary – one year of the Armenian genocide, which took over a million and a half human sacrifices and caused immeasurable anguish and suffering to the ancient Armenian people.  The different reading of the historical past continues to create contradictions and divide states and peoples. Overcoming these divisions can only be done in the way of historical reconciliation and on the basis of the recognition of objective truth and the facts of history.  Today we pay tribute to those who died during the Armenian genocide. But let us also remember the other ethnic groups within the Ottoman Empire, subjected to centuries of persecution, among which was the Bulgarian population, which, especially in the second half of the 19th century, fell victim to the Bataclan massacre, the bloody pogrom against the April Uprising and many other such events that startled and terrified the then European public. History must be a source of wisdom and unification, and I hope that the Republic of Turkey will find the moral strength and courage, together with Armenia, to go down the path of cooperation in the interests of the citizens of both countries and the prospect of European integration. We must not allow the dark shadows of the past to extend to our present and future. Bow to the memory of the victims of the Armenian genocide and all victims of crimes against humanity!

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, Mrs Georgieva, colleagues, with today's resolution, the European Parliament sends to modern Turkey three messages of exceptional interest to Turkey itself.  First, the unconditional recognition of responsibility for the Armenian genocide will be strong evidence that today's Turkey unequivocally breaks with the tragic legacy of the Ottoman Empire and does not share any neo-Ottomanist views today.  Secondly, it will also be such a clear sign that the Turkish leadership is capable of modern European consciousness and an unambiguous ability to take responsibility for the darkest pages of his country's history not as self-humiliation, but on the contrary - as a testament to the maturity and wisdom of modern Turkey. And thirdly, it is such recognition that the right path to historical reconciliation, oriented towards the future between Turkey and Armenia, is a truly necessary development as an extremely important positive contribution to the current extremely exacerbated geopolitical reality.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Yes, the Armenian massacre was the first genocide of the 20th century. For us gathered in this Chamber, for most of us, this is obvious in the light of sources, in the light of the research of historians. But it is not obvious, it is not easy to admit great crimes and Turkey is by no means an exception. Russia – I recall – still has trouble with the proper relationship to the massacre of defenceless prisoners – 21 000 Polish officers and other people shot m.in. in Katyn. The truth about this genocide crime was also hidden for political reasons by Polish allies of World War II, Britain and the United States. Even The Germans, who are often regarded as a model for settling with the past, still have a lot of work to do in this regard. An example would be the greatest crime committed against civilians during World War II and the massacre of tens of thousands of residents of the Wola district of Warsaw in the first days of the Warsaw Uprising in August 1944. To this day, this massacre is completely unknown to Germans and Europeans, and certainly colleagues have not heard of it.  Therefore, turkey's resistance must not come as a surprise. We should work all the more to break this resistance, because Turkey's lasting friendly relations with Armenia will only be possible on the basis of historical truth.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, there are a number of countries in Europe that have not adopted either a law or a resolution calling the violence against Armenians between 1915 and 1917 genocide. Unfortunately, my country, the Czech Republic, is one of them.  I am glad that today we are adopting a resolution that calls things by their real names. He says that the Armenian genocide committed by the Ottoman Empire is genocide. It is a resolution whose spirit is in trying to bring the positions of today's Turkey and today's Armenia closer together. Members of national parliaments will be able to rely on the authority of the European Parliament. This resolution opens up the possibility for Turkey to deal with a 100-year-old tragedy with honour. It opens up the possibility that it is the Turks themselves who look openly and courageously at their past. Just as Germany did when it accepted repentance for the Holocaust instead of defiance.
