Turkey is, ladies and gentlemen, our ally, and we are obliged, even in this resolution, to treat it as an ally. That is to tell him the truth, just as Holy Father Francis did a few days ago.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is good and important that the European Parliament commemorates the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. But it is not only about the history of the Ottoman Empire and today's Turkey. As a German Member of Parliament, I would like to remind you that the German Empire was aware of these crimes from the very beginning. At the time, Germany, as an important ally, accepted the genocide because it did not want to jeopardize relations with the Ottoman Empire. Europe presents itself as a patchwork of memory politics on this issue. While in some countries the denial of genocide is even punishable, many Member States, including Germany, have not yet explicitly recognised the genocide. I hope that our resolution will help to find a common European culture of remembrance of the Armenian genocide. I therefore hope that in future all European parliaments will follow our example.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, sir, also for running the time. That is exemplary!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, 100 years have been completed this year by the Genocide of the Armenians by the Turks. The orders for the mass purge of Armenians were given by Sultan Abdul Hamid, but the main responsibility for the widespread massacres and genocide of the Armenians lies with the Neo-Turkish movement, which also committed the Pontian genocide and the mass massacres of thousands of Greeks in Istanbul, Izmir and other parts of Turkey. The massacre of more than one and a half million Armenians is one of the first modern genocides. Today, when the jihadists slaughter thousands of Christians, we must send a firm message that we will not tolerate any more massacres, and this can also be done by acknowledging the Armenian genocide and condemning their mass slaughter by the Turks for being Armenians, because they were Christians. It was a genocide committed for reasons of ethnic cleansing.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – (microphone off) ... victims of the Armenian genocide and violence against other nations at the end of the Ottoman Empire. With this resolution, we do not change history, but we are committed to it in accordance with our values, principles and positive European experiences of reconciliation. The consequences of genocidal acts, which find it difficult to affect the dignity of individuals and entire nations, can be successfully tackled only through truthfulness, pieteta, justice and work for reconciliation. I support the resolution as a contribution to strengthening the conciliation process between Armenia and Turkey, which, in the interests of peace and a good neighbourhood, is essential to overcome an era of pain and strained relations.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: PPE). Mr President, Commissioner, the events to which you referred were genocide; Turkey has proven to be burdened in the twentieth century with the genocide of Armenians, Greeks, Assyrians, Chaldians of Asia Minor and has never apologized for this crime. On the contrary, it distorts history: the other day in Ankara, we were told with terrifying audacity that it was the Armenians who carried out the massacres. Peace and reconciliation can only happen when Turkey becomes a democratic state and apologizes for this crime. Until then, in the collective memory of nations, Turkey will bear the burden of these crimes.  We can't erase history. No one asked jews to erase the holocaust so that Jewish children wouldn't hate the Nazis. On the contrary, it was only when Willy Brandt, in his brave act, apologized, that true reconciliation came and the two peoples were loved and stood by each other. Therefore, do not ask the Armenians to give in again and consent to this fascist regime that exists in Turkey.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by These events have been followed for years by a thud of silence, and until now the authorities in Turkey have not pleaded guilty to the crimes committed. To make matters worse, so far not all countries have officially recognised the Armenian genocide, and in Turkey itself, those who fight to deny this carnage must face penalties under the Penal Code for insulting the Turkish people. We must not allow such tragedies to ever happen. Let us learn from our common history and learn to solve the problems of today's world diplomatically. This is particularly important in this day and age, when we have to face rising xenophobia, hatred and terrorism, or religious fanaticism. Therefore, we must pay all the more attention to these events, which are a reminder that the history of the world is full of these inglorious events. And today, especially here in this place, we have to remember that.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Millions of Armenians around the world are not commemorating — and we with them — a regrettable war incident that would have occurred in the turmoil of the First World War. No, they commemorate the fact that 100 years ago the authorities of the Ottoman Empire went to put into practice their insane plan, which was to exterminate the Armenian people. Fortunately, they did not succeed. But the intention was there. The Armenian people should be levelled, eradicated. All Armenians should be killed. This is called genocide. Turkey will not become a better state and will not be able to be confirmed on its way to the European Union because it opposes this realization, this historical truth, for the time being. Turkey must also recognise that this is part of its history in a different state at a different time. Only then can europeans take it seriously as a candidate country.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, we commemorate today the tragic death of 1.5 million Armenians, but the estimated numbers do not tell the whole story which is about the unique tragedy of each human being who lost his or her life as a result of these brutal murders. I think it was Stalin who cynically concluded that the death of one person is a tragedy but the death of millions is just statistics. That is why we have to clearly recognise today, without diplomatic subtlety and on behalf of the Commission and the Council, that murder is murder and that genocide is genocide. The only means to prevent such tragedies from happening is to integrate them as our common historic heritage. All of us need to face squarely these horrible truths. Facing the full truth and agreeing a moral and political verdict is the only way to reach a genuine reconciliation. Today is a moment to face the full truth of the Armenian tragedy, but let us not forget that at the same time about 300 000 Assyrians and half a million Greeks were murdered during the final convulsions of the Ottoman Empire.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: "Mr. President, as we have heard before, this resolution is not a condemnation. This resolution is not against anyone. This resolution is a call for trust. A call for Turkey to recognise the serious genocide that took place in 1915. This resolution is a tribute and therefore these two countries, especially Turkey, must not remain trapped in the past.  We ask that the Zurich protocol be ratified. Likewise, the name is clear, genocide is defined by the 1948 convention and there is no doubt about the name. Today we want to encourage Turkey towards the recognition of genocide. It's not about interpreting the past, it's about commemorating the victims.  In the resolution we also call for them to look to a successful example of the trust of European peoples, and that is why I think this is one good point of resolution. I appreciate what the EPP representative Mr Brock and the Socialist representative, both Germans, have said, because great nations have always had and have the strength to face the past and confess their sins and that is why Turkey needs to open a new page of its future today.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, the genocide of armenians by the Turks remains an undeniable and undeniable historical reality. In this genocide, one and a half million Armenians were slaughtered in the most horrible way. The fact that Turkey has stubbornly refused to recognise the Armenian genocide for a hundred years has so far been a challenge to civilised humanity and a challenge to Europe itself. Turkey is not only responsible for the Armenian genocide, Turkey is also responsible for other genocides. From 1914 to 1923, thousands of Greeks were wiped out in Pontos, Asia Minor and Thrace. It proceeded, in 1955, with the disappearance of the Greeks from Istanbul and continues to this day the national clearing, by modern means and modern methods, in Cyprus. Those who have experienced Turkish barbarism have no doubt that the Turks will not recognise the Armenian genocide and will not recognise it because reality clearly shows that Turkey has a policy of annihilating all its neighbours. Turkey has a policy of barbarism both at home and abroad.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, consider what today's humanity would be like if Germany did not recognise the Holocaust and the Nazi atrocities, think of what today's societies would be like. All civilised states must recognise the Armenian genocide. Turkey must recognise the genocide, not only as a historical fact, but as a guarantee that it will not carry out new genocides. Turkey does not recognise the Armenian genocide, it does not recognise the Pontian genocide, it does not recognise ethnic cleansing in Cyprus.  Europe must have a leading role in the real healing of wounds, but it must not close its eyes.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is the elementary duty of civilised people to call genocide genocide. In the event of the Armenian genocide, we honor the victims and make a warning for the future. I want to say very clearly: the truth cannot be censored, the international community should remember all acts of genocide: the Armenian genocide, the genocide perpetuated by the Germans at Auschwitz, the Soviet genocide in Katyn and in the large-scale genocide, and finally the acts of genocide of our time that bear a terrible witness to modern civilization: genocide in the Balkans and Africa. Poland has a special title to demand the truth in this regard. Our lawyer, a Pole of Jewish origin, Mr. Lemkin, defined the legal category of genocide. The truth cannot be censored.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to encourage Turkey to assume that the extermination, between 1915 and 1919, of more than one and a half million Armenians, was genocide. Taking responsibility and disqualifying these behaviors produces truth, justice, and reparation. And it encourages non-repetition and facilitates reconciliation. Our annual control over the health of Turkish democracy is leading to this change. In April last year, president Erdogan first acknowledged Armenian pain, called those deportations and mass crimes inhumane, and conveyed his condolences to the families of the victims. This development must be encouraged, which will accelerate if there is unanimous international recognition of this genocide, which has been indisputable in the light of the definition in force since 1948. It was an honour for me to chair the Basque Parliament when, in 2007, it took that step.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, I am a citizen of the Spanish State, one of those States which do not want to acknowledge the existence of the Armenian genocide. And there are many within the European Union, which I think should embarrass us. I don't think hiding or concealing what genocide entails will serve to improve political relations. The European Union must be courageous and make it clear that the same cannot be demanded, in a process of reconciliation, on executioners as on victims, on Turkey as on the Armenian people. He must be courageous and acknowledge that many European powers knew and did nothing to prevent this genocide. Commissioner, calling terror by name — Armenian genocide — and demanding its recognition and condemnation is a conditio sine qua non to face a future of peace. And perhaps, from this, we will react and support as we should the desire for freedom of the people of Nagorno-Karabakh, another fringe of the Armenian problem in which Europe can still avoid tragedy.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, it still causes diplomatic differences if the actors in international politics recognise the crimes committed against the Armenian people 100 years ago as genocide. I am convinced that we do not want to offend the Turkish people by acknowledging genocide, the importance of creating a modern Turkish state is enormous, but we cannot pretend that certain things have not happened. We can see the impact of the dark events of history today, even after a hundred years. Let's learn to say things, to call the events of the past by name, because it always involves the possibility of a fresh start. Let us remember the Armenian genocide because respect for the Armenian people, and for human life in general, demands it. Let us remember to strengthen ourselves in overcoming the horrors that still occur in the world today. So that what happened to the Armenian people in the years after 1915 does not happen even to other communities in 2015. By the way, there are still EU countries where mass murderers in the 18th and 19th centuries are celebrated as national heroes.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this resolution, the European Parliament wants to recognise the Armenian genocide and pay tribute to the memory of one and a half million victims, including thousands of intellectuals, artists and parliamentarians. If Turkey wants to join the Union, it must recognise the historical truth of the Armenian genocide by the Ottoman Empire and start an effective peace process on this basis. Only 22 countries have officially recognised the Armenian genocide, including Italy, and so I find Erdogan's harsh words against Pope Francis, guilty of talking about genocide, truly unacceptable. With this resolution we are proposing the establishment of the European Day dedicated, but we also call on Turkey to draw inspiration from examples of reconciliation between the peoples of Europe, as happened after the Second World War.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no point in repeating what is a fact that has already been listed by most of my fellow Members: the armenian genocide has taken place, as we all know, someone persists in not acknowledging it because it has some interest. We know that what happens in Turkey is that if someone says that there has been genocide by the Armenians, they risk arrest and three years in prison for an anti-patriotist law, and that is a truly absurd situation. I do not know whether it is more absurd or paradoxical that it should be a Pope who has to tell a Turkish Government that he is behaving in a fascist way, because Erdogan's attitude is a fascist attitude, and for us he should be the first on the list to go and educate. Because there is no point in us talking to Turkey and we are making a lot of pre-accession agreements, we are giving them money, when we are talking to someone who persists in not even acknowledging that one and a half million people have been killed, so we have to state this very strongly.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, Pope Francis this Sunday called the massacre of some 1.5 million Armenians the first genocide of the 20th century. That's my position, too, because the Armenian genocide is a systematic extermination that took place during World War I and began 100 years ago with the murder of 50 Armenian intellectuals and their committee members.  Armenians were disarmed and killed in the Ottoman army, and Armenian property was confiscated. The Turks deported the women, children, the elderly and the infirm and sent them on death marches to the Syrian desert. Turkish soldiers raped, tortured and eventually crucified several thousand Armenian women. An estimated 2 million Armenians were exiled and about 1.5 million Armenians were deliberately and systematically killed in the first genocide of the modern world. Turks also killed many Syrian Christians, Greeks and other national minorities.  I believe turkey must recognise armenian genocide and show openness to debate in a spirit of reconciliation. No one can do it for them. This is the only way to deal with the past and develop partnership relations between the two countries.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Forgetting the Armenian and Black Sea Greek genocide is a way of keeping alive the wounds of these tragic episodes and, worse than that, it is a way of prolonging the consequences of these heinous crimes. Today is not at stake the trial of its perpetrators, let alone any accusations against turkey and its leaders, nor even the country's claim to join the European Union. What is at stake is simply an elementary gesture of justice towards the memory of a million and a half beings who were deliberately exterminated at the beginning of the 20th century.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the Refusal of the Turkish Government to recognise the crime of genocide creates new problems, new crimes against humanity. The Turkish Government wants in this way to complicit the Turkish people who have absolutely no responsibility for what their ancestors did and it is doing this also because it wants to continue ethnic cleansing in Cyprus. While there are decisions to condemn the invasion and occupation of Cyprus, Turkey insists on ethnic cleansing. That is why our position is that this is a very serious problem, above all other problems.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very sober and dignified debate and it has demonstrated how strong the sense of sorrow is in this House for the Armenians who tragically died or were pushed out of their homeland. As a Bulgarian, I would like to recall one of our most prominent poets, Peyo Yavorov, who wrote one of the best known poems under the title Armenians. Let me quote from it in Bulgarian. "Изгнаници клети, отломка нищожна от винаги храбър народ мъченик, дечица на майка робиня тревожна, и жертви на подвиг чутовно велик" I do not know anybody in the Balkans who is not deeply touched by the fate of the Armenian people. Let me turn to the questions you put. First, the Commission acknowledges and respects the majority view in this House. This view has already been spelt out in Parliament’s resolution on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World in 2013 where you stated that you called, ahead of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, on all the Member States legally to acknowledge it and encouraged the Member States and the European institutions to contribute further to its recognition. We also recognise, as has been stated by the Council and acknowledged by many of you, that there are still differences in views among our Member States on this issue. We focus on ways in which we can support and advance reconciliation, and support and advance unity among our Member States. As an institution we have an obligation to bring views into unity. This is our obligation. Engaging with the Turkish authorities on issues that are so critical to Turkeyʼs ability to advance towards European Union membership is, of course, a matter of very significant concern for the Commission. I can tell you that this is a very serious topic for the Commission, for Commissioner Hahn and for all of us. What we would like to see, ultimately, is peace and harmony in Europe and also for Europe to export peace and harmony in the world. Unfortunately thousands, and hundreds of thousands, and millions of children, women and men die because they are different: in religion, in ethnicity or in the way they consider their social life and their freedoms. We are determined that, for the European Union to be successful, we have to be trusted to be able to carry forward these messages of democracy, freedom, respect for human dignity, and respect for human rights. I can assure you that I will convey back to the Commission the intensity and the spirit of this debate and, obviously, the call that you have already made on us.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I thank you sincerely for the discussion on this very important and sensitive matter. We will take your positions and suggestions with us for further reflection and sharing with relevant services. This debate today has clearly demonstrated that we are all united in acknowledging the suffering endured by Armenians a hundred years ago. States have diverging views as to whether these events can be formally qualified as genocide. The EU’s efforts, however, are forward-looking, having the aim of developing a prosperous and peaceful neighbourhood where partners cooperate regionally. The EU’s ultimate aim is to develop the Union’s bilateral relations with its partners to their fullest potential. Therefore it is important that the EU, including its institutions and Member States, remains committed to facilitating positive and constructive relations between Armenia and Turkey.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: At the end of the debate, seven motions for resolutions were tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will now take place immediately afterwards. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. As Pope Francis rightly pointed out, the massacre that struck the Armenian people together with Catholic and Orthodox Syrians, Assyrians, Chaldeans and Greeks and which affected as many as one and a half million people between 1915 and 1917 can be defined as the first genocide of the twentieth century. Remembering these innocent victims is necessary, indeed necessary, because hiding or denying these kinds of events is tantamount to perpetuating them. I therefore welcome the European Parliament resolution, which commemorates the victims in a spirit of solidarity and justice, firmly condemning genocide as well as all crimes against humanity and prejudice against minorities. At the same time, I believe that this moment of reflection should also be an important opportunity to achieve a normalisation of diplomatic relations between Turkey and Armenia, which could bring human, cultural and economic benefits to both peoples. I therefore hope that, although President Erdogan has said that he is indifferent to the European Parliament's resolution, he will make a real commitment to promoting dialogue and reconciliation between turks and Armenians.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. One hundred years ago, Pope Francis, in his homily of April 12, 2015, called it the first of the "three mass tragedies" that struck humanity during the 20th century, the dark century. I would like to pay tribute here to the Armenian people, whose massacre was planned by an Ottoman Empire in agony: one million Armenians, including women and children, murdered between 1915 and 1916. Following His Holiness Pope Francis, we must tell the Armenian people that we remember; we remember, not to make us the judges of history, but because to keep the memory of the past, of what we have been and of what we are is necessary to build the future; let us remember, as Bernard de Chartres advocated in the 12th century, that "we are like dwarves sitting on the shoulders of giants. If we see more things and more distant than them, it is because we are raised by them." We are no better than our ancestors, but we must make their history our own to raise us.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The silence in Europe over the Armenian genocide is beginning to be broken. Occulted or downplayed, the massacre of more than a million Armenians by the Ottomans is nevertheless one of the pieces of the opening of a bloodthirsty twentieth century. This timidity is all the more surprising given that the Union often claims the right to discern the prices of political morality and claims to build its action on peace, respect for peoples and fundamental rights. However, the Turkish authorities persist in recognising this extermination at a time when the European Union wishes to integrate this country into the community of our States. The recognition of the Armenian genocide is a strong act and must restore intellectual balance in the treatment of the wounds of Europe and its neighbours, wounds that are often still vivid but which we must close by assuming our commitment against what has opened them. Utopian political ideology, the brutality of power and confrontations between religions and cultures can be avoided if we accept respect for freedoms, territories and identities. We cannot share a political space with another civilization, another continent, because our relations in the city will always be different from those forged between Europeans.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – I find it very unfortunate and sad that, even 100 years after the tragic events in the Ottoman Empire, the relevant states cannot agree on whether or not this was genocide. This genocide has caused the extermination of the Armenian community, which lived in the southeastern part of the Ottoman Empire, that is, today's Turkey. After the defeat of the Ottoman Empire in World War I, the new Republican Turkey denied this historical fact. The actions of the current Turkish Government, which is seeking to improve relations with the existing Armenian community, should therefore be applauded. The two countries must continue to normalise their relations and promote cultural and educational exchanges in order to improve mutual understanding and improved relations, which are disrupted by historical events. I believe that it is very important that we commemorate the acts of violence of the past, because now again in Europe there is a radicalisation of circumstances and acts of violence, which must not grow into monstrous proportions from the past.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. The recognition by this Chamber of the Armenian genocide is certainly an important fact. We have been supporting this initiative for years and we are finally seeing an EU position. However, that is not enough, and that is why we would like, given Turkey's continued refusal to recognise the perpetuated genocide, for the EU to take a clear position on Turkey's accession to Europe.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – On 24 April, we are celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. The massacre, which killed many hundreds of thousands of members of the Armenian minority in the Ottoman Empire, continues to strain Armenian-Turkish relations. A look into the past is essential: only when facts are revealed, if correct historiography is carried out, can we prevent a repetition of such acts. The genocides of the 20th century in Bosnia, Rwanda and Cambodia show that genocide has remained an incomprehensible reality in our world since 1915 and that preventing such atrocities remains our top priority. To this end, we must also look to the future: Turkey and Armenia must normalise their relations without preconditions and build a healthy basis for dialogue, mutual understanding and tolerance. Only in this way can the two nations lay a foundation for a stable, peaceful future. In recent days, the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, have made it clear that Turkey in particular must take the necessary steps and mention the crimes of that time by its name. However, the resolution that is being voted on today in plenary is intended to call on both countries to finally take a cooperative path and enable lasting peace.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. –  With this resolution, Europe’s elected representatives have joined the worldwide commemorations that will culminate on 24 April. I believe that, on the commemoration of the centenary of the  genocide against the Armenians, we must make more efforts in order to move beyond and to build a common future, by pushing for a deep process of normalisation and reconciliation between the Armenians and the Turks. Turks and Armenians should support smaller, symbolic efforts that allow for dialogue and understanding, like last year’s statements by Erdoğan, or the return of the Armenian properties that were confiscated by the Turkish state.  This process must occur at the individual, societal, and state levels. This is a process that requires time and reconsideration of identity, as well as of history, but which is essential for both countries’ mutual trust and future cooperation. I believe that it is fundamental that we all recognise, remember and condemn these kind of tragedies, if we want to avoid them in the future. Only through awareness of universal human rights, through passing on a collective memory, and through the consistent application of legal norms and international law, can these kind of crimes be prevented or stopped in their evolution.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On the occasion of the coming 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, I pay tribute to all the victims and their families. This year also marks the 75th anniversary of the nkvd genocide committed by the NKVD on Polish officers, about which the truth has been similarly hidden and denied for many years. More and more national parliaments are adopting resolutions declaring the crime committed in armenians by the Ottoman Empire to be genocide, but there is still no full agreement on what happened in Armenia a century ago. This is demonstrated by the reaction of the Turkish authorities to Pope Francis' speech, in which the Holy Father unequivocally called this murder a genocide.  Reconciliation and the building of the future together must be based on truth and dialogue. The statement by Turkish President Erdogan and Prime Minister Davutoglu expressing their condolences for the atrocities committed in the Armenians is undoubtedly a step in the right direction. The 100th anniversary of this horrific murder is a good opportunity for the Turkish authorities to continue their efforts at reconciliation by opening their archives and recognising the crimes in armenians as genocide. Turkey aspires to be a member of the European Union, which means a commitment to European standards. Without acknowledging the crimes in armenians, the declarations of the Turkish authorities remain only empty words. The European Parliament has consistently reminded the Turkish authorities of this in any resolution on EU-Turkey relations.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The proposal for Resolution 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide contains several powerful messages that I want to emphasize in particular: First, we want to make it clear that the great tragedies of European peoples in our tragic and bloody history cannot be forgotten;  Secondly, the call for the establishment of the International Genocide Remembrance Day is necessary to achieve and commemorate it, which will give permanent warnings of major accidents experienced;  Third, I hold it extremely important that both the President and the Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey have expressed pity for the events of 100 years ago;  Fourth, the announcement that all perpetrators will be punished and the impossibility of statute of limitations on crimes against humanity is extremely important;  Fifth, the call for Turkey and Armenia to launch a comprehensive dialogue in the spirit of European good-heartedness and friendship along the lines of many European countries is the main message for the future of relations in this part of Europe.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – In commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, the issue of the treatment of minorities arises, which is a cause for debate not only in the past but also in the present. In 1914-15, the goal of peacefully solving the problems of the Turkish majority and the Armenian minority and living side by side was not achieved. Just as in the past there was no solution to hostility, either through genocide or other violent means, it is not today. Not only is the application of deterrent sanctions against the minors not the solution, but it also deepens conflicts and strife. Turkey and Armenia are still suffering from the exclamation crimes committed. Confronting the past is extremely important for dispute resolution and reconciliation. This is the only way forward, it is in the long-term interest of both sides, which can kick-start cooperation and progress in both political and economic areas. In addition to the leaders of individual countries, in this case Turkey and Armenia, the European Union can play an important mediating role in reconding the Armenian conflict, since the Union must also stand up for the protection of democratic rights alongside economic interests. Finding the right solutions would have a major impact not only on the country's domestic political situation, but also on its foreign policy and on the development of the Union.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. –  All crimes against humanity need to be condemned. But Armenia and Turkey must get back on track with the normalisation of their relations, which would contribute to the overall security and stability of the South Caucasus. For this to happen, societies of both countries must be encouraged to engage in talking to each other once again. We must address the civil societies, encourage cooperation between youth, businesses, media, people in all spheres of culture and others in both countries to engage in dialogue and cooperation. The Armenia-Turkey Normalisation Process initiative has been a good example for that. It must continue and the EU can contribute to this process.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The commemoration, today, in the European Parliament, of the 100 years that have elapsed since the Armenian genocide reminds us of the most important motivation behind the European unification movement, namely the desire to make impossible war and crimes against humanity on the land of Europe. This sad reminder reminds us that we are in a period, which began last year and will last, in which we mark the centenary of events full of multiple meanings for European nations, whether we are thinking about the Sarajevo moment, the end of the first world conflagration or the tragedies that occurred during the great war.  If we let nationalists, xenophobes, demagogues and populists use the series of these commemorations to promote their own agenda, then we will only contribute to the deepening of the crisis of trust that Europe is in today. We have a duty to look for those meanings that bring peoples closer together, that highlight the common values that we all share. We will thus succeed in helping to overcome the deep moral and trustcrisis that plagues our societies, finding the energy needed to build the European common house.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. – The genocide of armenians by the Turks remains an undeniable historical reality. The fact that Turkey, for a century, has stubbornly refused to recognise the crime of the Armenian genocide demonstrates how far it is from Europe and from the other democratic states of the world. It should be pointed out that Turkey is not only responsible for the Armenian genocide, it is also responsible for other genocides, which it has proven to have committed in the last century, through the systematic extermination of the Christian peoples of the region, such as the Greeks of Pontus, the Assyrians and the Chaldians of Asia Minor. Mr Erdogan's reaction to the EP resolution, which he has directly said he will ignore, is a challenge to civilised humanity and a challenge to the EU itself. Turkey must first find them with itself in order to bring about reconciliation in the region. Unfortunately, this seems to be going to take a while.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. – Commemorating historical events is important for us to learn from them for the future. That is why this resolution, which honors one and a half million innocent Armenian victims during two years of usmanic history, is very important. We hereby point to the atrocities that have been condemned in the last century and condemn any threat to human rights, especially to this extent. All victims of all genocides, which are undoubtedly crimes against humanity, must be recognised internationally. I therefore strongly support the proposal for this resolution to declare a European Day of Remembrance for the Victims of Genocides.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on employment rates for people with disabilities in the EU institutions (2015/2619(RSP)).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for bringing this topic for discussion here in this Chamber.  For the Commission, the whole question of having a diverse staff, of being inclusive, has a very high priority, and I can confirm that in my first meetings with Mr Juncker that was a topic he brought up, specifically in regard to people with disabilities. We are very keen to address this at three levels: at the level of recruitment, at the level of inclusion in the staff of the institutions, and also in terms of the support that is being provided, as needs might change.  We have a general principle of non-discrimination on various grounds in our Staff Regulations, amongst them disabilities, and our commitment to everybody, to each and every one of our staff, is that of fair treatment and equal opportunities. So let me stress, as we are having this discussion, that it comes at a very opportune moment for us because we are working on a new diversity strategy for the period 2015-2019, and in this sense input from the Members of this Parliament would be very useful.  Let me first start with the recruitment phase. We take very seriously our ability to provide conditions for each and every person in Europe who wants to apply for a job in the European Union institutions to be able to do so. We have in our team dealing with recruitment, in EPSO, two experts specifically for the issue of disabilities. In their work they are able to inform candidates and then respond to requests for special accommodation for testing; for example, tests in braille, on paper, with extra time. To be assessed in special facilities we have three rooms that are specifically for people with physical disabilities and, where this is appropriate, an individual person would be assigned to assist the candidate in the application.  Each file is then processed individually to ensure the best possible match between the needs of the candidate and the principles of both proportionality and equal treatment.  Secondly, in terms of being able to accommodate people with disabilities in Commission buildings, we have accessibility in all our buildings and they comply with the recommendations on accessibility by people with physical disabilities that are applicable in the region of Brussels. I would also say that we are looking at whether we can strive towards adopting best practices from elsewhere, at what is being done in other places.  Thirdly, in human resources there is a platform to provide advice and support – for example, for the need to have ergonomically better conditions for work.  We are not able to provide a full file on people with disabilities because of respect for confidentiality in medical records, but that does not mean that we are not making every effort possible to be aware of whom they are and where they are. I can tell you that we use the staff survey. We used it this year and last year to give people a chance to identify themselves through the staff survey, and on that basis we know that 5.7 % this year, 2014, have identified themselves as people with disabilities. This is one percentage more than in last year’s survey. This does not mean a one-to-one match, but it gives us an indication that our efforts to recruit more people with disabilities seem to be bearing fruit.  Parliament asks whether it would not be more appropriate to apply quotas. Our current Staff Regulations do not allow for quotas, but they do encourage us to use other ways to enhance diversity and I can say on my own behalf, and on behalf of my team, that we are looking for ways in which we can do more so that those of us in the Commission, in Parliament, in the Council, those who work in the institutions can be a mirror image of what Europe is, who we Europeans are. We are not there yet, so we have work to do, and I look forward to the debate this evening to give us input in that direction.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: (PPE). – Madam President, back in December last year, I asked the Commission in writing how many persons with disabilities are employed by the institutions of the European Union. However, the Commission was not able to provide any precise data on the number of staff with disabilities or the type of disability they have. The number we just heard was based on voluntary disclosure, so it cannot be taken as official data. I welcome the Commission's statement and I am pleased to hear that you want to address this issue. However, I believe that there is a need for quotas and standards for the employment of people with disabilities both in the Member States and in the institutions of the European Union, as long as the employment of these people is not natural within society. That's not the case today. I therefore call on the Commission to examine good practices in the Member States as soon as possible and to have this transferred as soon as possible to the eu institutions' own standards and, of course, to show these patterns to the other Member States.  In conclusion, I would like to note that the European Union has also signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which has clear rules on how we can help and, more precisely, facilitate the employment of persons with disabilities. This is also an obligation for the institutions of the Union. In conclusion, I would like to say that there are many good examples in the Member States of the Union, such as Hungary. The number of employees with disabilities has doubled thanks to quota requirements in recent years and other financial support and tax incentives. On this basis, I say that there is a need to create a new strategy in this direction.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. People with special needs – we are all aware – are one of the most vulnerable groups of individuals, especially when it comes to their integration into the labour market and into society at all.  Their, often particularly difficult situation, is often forgotten and not aware of it. Their daily rules are often accompanied by prejudice and stereotypes, often faced with discrimination or found themselves in an unequal situation, which you yourself have pointed out.  Unfortunately, employees of our institutions – the institutions of the European Union – also find themselves in this situation from time to time. And this initiative in this debate today has, in fact, emerged from a concrete case. I am very pleased that we have this opportunity today to share our facts with you. You have already mentioned the employment quotas yourself, Honourable Commissioner. These are one of the most effective ways of integrating people with special needs into the labour market. Such arrangements are already known in most Member States of the European Union.  Indeed, the data show that unemployment among people with special needs is indeed a very serious problem in some places in Europe. At this place, I welcome your statement and awareness that we need to do more for people with disabilities.  You have also partially answered what the European Commission is doing. But I, too, would like to call on you at this place to consider concrete legislative solutions, including towards the implementation of employment quotas, both throughout the territory of the European Union and in the Institutions of the European Union.  And to conclude this way, if we are to really achieve change, we must first start with ourselves.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group – Breaking down barriers is extremely important, so I always welcome the fact that the topic of employing people with disabilities is not only being discussed, but also taking place specifically. As a signatory to the Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities and its institutions, the European Union should clearly set an example to the Member States, and making order, so to speak, on its own doorstep is an excellent idea. I understand that quotas can be an attractive solution, but I think it is much more important to create conditions that meet the needs of people with disabilities. We should strive for accessibility to be natural and automatic, so that the European institutions do not forget about it when building buildings, marking rooms, providing interpreters, creating their materials and websites, or providing other support services. These are all things in which, unfortunately, the European Parliament itself still has too many loopholes. Each of us can become disabled overnight. It loses sight, loses hearing, stays in a wheelchair or remains with a chronic disease, and therefore reasoning in the spirit of universal design and barrier-freeness should be a matter of course even without quotas.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I support the start of a new stage in the European institutions in the recruitment of persons with disabilities. This group needs positive discrimination in the european public employment offer. It is an appropriate way to set an example, to apply here, in an extensive manner, the forecasts of the new Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement. The European institutions thus add to the practice of some State and regional institutions that apply this criterion. In the Basque Country, this reserve in some government bodies reaches up to 5%, and 93% of its colleagues believe that their performance is equal to that of the rest and their degree of acceptance in the working environment is 4.6 out of 5. And this measure will also help to raise awareness among society about the needs of these groups and to promote other attitudes in line with the 2020 Strategy. A renewed commitment to a barrier-free Europe. And so we add to the prominence that the whole Union has in companies in the third sector; the social economy and the associationism of people with disabilities in job creation for people who have a lot to contribute. Because many of these limitations force those who suffer from them to develop skills and skills that are true sources of added value in the jobs they perform. Something I learned when a blind person explained to me the usefulness of a keychain that served him to know if there was lighting where he was. And he said, "There are people who need light." Let us think of the extraordinary message conveyed by these words.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, one of Europe's objectives in meeting the 2020 Strategy is that persons with disabilities must participate in the economic and social life of the European Union. But full participation is not possible if they do not have the central element, which is employment. And unfortunately, people with disabilities—and especially women with disabilities—have tremendously high unemployment rates. Promoting employment through reserve fees can be a good measure, provided it is met. And unfortunately, what happens in Spain does not happen, where these reserve fees are replaced by other measures of economic benefits to companies. And so, in the end, unemployment for people with disabilities does not fall. Quotas should also be accompanied by positive measures and good practices, such as adapting jobs and possible access to selection tests. And with this, the European institutions would set a good example and companies would also be encouraged to hire these people.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice-President of the Commission for his determined and active attitude to the diversity of the Commission and the other institutions in personnel policy. It is worth remembering that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was the first human rights convention ratified by the European Union after having the right to ratify international agreements, and this also has a very large example effect. It is important that the European institutions really set an example and take the front line. Of course, it is also certainly the case that the Commission and the Vice-President can also learn good practice from the Member States. It is therefore very important that the Member States also steps are being taken to promote concrete ratification of this agreement. Mrs Georgieva, you mentioned that, at the moment, the Staff Regulations do not allow quotas. This is an interesting question, because we have discussed together that perhaps one day there will be such a uniform administrative law in the Union, and it may be worthwhile for us to return to this issue in this context, because it might be the case that all the European institutions could have such a temporary obligation to introduce quotas for people with disabilities, for example. They are, as many colleagues have said, often the fastest way to make people with disabilities visible. As has also been said here, each of us can become disabled and that is why this is important for everyone.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as is often the case, the European Union is always prepared to criticise the shortcomings of the Member States, but it is not so diligent with its own. Unlike most EU states, we do not adopt any disability quota system for Eurobureaucrats. The Eu ropean Union recruitment agency, EPSO, is organising very tough competitions to recruit new European officials, so if we do not want to apply a quota system, it would be interesting to know what kind of assistance is given to competitors with disabilities, as well as the obvious provision of materials, which can be used, for example, for the blind, as has been said, and above all that real personalised assistance can be given and not limited to simple access to the examination site. This should apply to all professional profiles, including temporary staff and seconded national experts. The same question should then be put to the dozens of European agencies, which not only employ officials, but also other fixed-term staff. I truly believe that the institutions should be more sensitive to the disabled population, especially as regards the usability of information, for example the adoption of sign language or real-time subtitles so that everyone can follow the most important debates in plenary.  In this regard, we in the Five Star Movement have proposed with a written question the use of a special typeface with high legibility designed to make it easy for the dyslexic population to consult written documents. Such a character could be adopted on the website of the European Parliament and the Commission, and I would also like to have your opinion on the feasibility of this proposal, Mr President, and also on you, Madam Commissioner. Our mission here is to break down all the barriers that prevent citizens from participating in the political life of the Community institutions, and these barriers are a little higher for citizens with disabilities, but they are by no means insurmountable.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, this is a very important issue and we support the Commission's intention to deal very hard with the issue of the recruitment of disabled people to staff positions in the institutions. It is well known and proven that in this period of economic crisis, people with disabilities are among the biggest victims of this crisis. It is therefore good that these people can be treated equally with other candidates for certain jobs. However, if a quota is raised, it will be binding and may work the other way around without having the desired effect. More practical would be to provide people with disabilities for jobs in which their disability will not be an obstacle and will not be a reason to be treated differently from other workers. It is very important in their workplace that they feel equal partners and not that they simply exist there because of our pity that gave them a job. People with disabilities have proven that they have skills and that they can offer much more than those of us who are considered healthy. We should not forget the economic benefit to society. Since they themselves have an income to be able to live decently, they will not have to wait for welfare benefits as a handout.  We are in favour of the legislative framework but believe that the question of quota should be reconsidered. Equal opportunities for all.

name: David CASA
text: – L-integrazzjoni ta persuni bi bżonnijiet speżjali fid-dinja tax-xogťol tirrappreżenta waťda mill-ikbar defidi fl-isfera politika, sożjali u tax-xogťol. F'dan l-ambitu, filwaqt li wieťed japprezza l-isforzi li qed jagťmlu l-Istati Membri f'dan il-qasam, huwa importanti li jsir sforz addizzjonali sabiex persuni bi bżonnijiet speèjali jkollhom aèèess sťiť gťal post tax-xogťol. Important huwa, gťalhekk, illi l-acquis in kwistjoni bťal 2000/78 li jistabbilixxi qafas gťat-trattament ugwali fl-impjieg ikun segwit b'mod rett. Il-persuni bi bżonnijiet speżjali gťandhom urżentament bżonn miżuri effettivi li jagťtuhom opportunità u dritt li jintegraw rwieťhom fis-suq tax-xogťol skont il-kapaʻitajiet u l-potenzjal tagťhom. Gťalhekk, il-Kummissjoni Ewropea gťandha tiggarantixxi t-trattament ugwali fl-impjiegi u l-aèèess gťall-persuni b'diżability fi żdan il-Kummissjoni Ewropea u l-istituzzjonijiet tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Il-gvernijiet gťandhom mhux biss jassikuraw li jneťťu kull xkiel u jinkorażżixxu miżuri non diskriminatorji fid-dinja tax-xogťol iżda gťandhom ukoll joffru inżentivi lil min iťaddem li jkun ta' vantażż żaladarba jimpjegaw persuni bi bżonnijiet speżjali. Idealment il-gvernijiet gťandhom jipprovdu qafas ta' sanzjonijiet koordinati, inżentivi u sapport li jkunu jikkumplimentaw lil xulxin, u barra minn hekk, gťandu jiżi żgurat li l-leżiżlazzjoni tal-UE dwar il-persuni b'diżabilità hija implimented u kkontrollata fl-Istati Members.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Remember? 2003 was the European Year of People with Disabilities. It is precisely here that European institutions should continue to set an example when we declare such a year. What is frightening, however, is that our Member States are already much further than the EU institutions. 21 out of 28 European Member States already have a quota system for people with disabilities. It is a very effective means of guaranteeing these people fundamental rights of equality, social participation and a self-determined life. People with disabilities — many agree that they have experience — are an asset to the labour market. In Germany, a statutory minimum quota of 5% applies to private companies, but also to the public sector. That's not much, it could be more. However, it helps so much that we have an employment rate of 6.6% in public administration, through all levels of hierarchy, not just in low-skilled jobs. It is therefore time for the European institutions to set an example. Otherwise, we always want to tell others how to do better.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – Of course, a quota does not really solve the problem. We need to focus more on the competencies, not just on limiting the person in question. That is why I would like to stress the importance of a good inclusive education and vocational training in order to create equal opportunities for people with disabilities. Since the EU has ratified the UN Convention, it must set a good example. You have just spoken about the recruitment phase, which is going very well. But what happens after recruitment? Do people have a chance to get promoted, do they have opportunities to follow courses? Do they have a chance at high-level jobs? Is there a strategy for that? We must encourage people with disabilities to apply for a job within the EU, but the EU is not or is not sufficiently known as a possible employer. What strategy will you apply to resolve this? [The speaker responds to a blue card question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I would actually like to ask the Member whether we understood exactly: do you want the other measures that you have taken beyond the quota, or do you want them instead of quotas?

name: Helga STEVENS
text: "blue card" answer. I have said that a quota does not really solve the problem. You can see in many countries that there is a quota system, but people with disabilities still do not find work. On paper, that's nice, but it doesn't always work in practice. The accompanying measures are lacking, and we actually need more than a quota alone. So the government has to provide support. For deaf people, for example, interpreters must be provided, wheelchair users require workplace adjustments. The employer is not always willing to pay those costs. If the government provides an intervention, it can be better than a quota alone.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – (6) In fact, the most difficult thing, in preparing this debate, was to find even accessible and available information on the policy of recruitment of people with disabilities in the Institutions of the European Union and so we think that we should have the data accessible on the number of candidates, how many workers with disabilities have been recruited and why applications for people with disabilities have been rejected. As you know, the unemployment rate of people with disabilities in the European Union is two or three times higher than that of other citizens and therefore the creation of a quota system would be, in our view, a positive step, although we agree that it is not enough.  It is also necessary and perhaps more important beyond it, to apply personal assistance mechanisms to third parties, to acquire accessible software, to create technical aid of a technological nature, to ensure communication and physical accessibility and also, in addition, to monitor whether these conditions are being successful and such monitoring should be public and regular. Thanks.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – It is clear that the issue of employment quotas for persons with disabilities is linked to positive discrimination, which also shows the maturity of our society and the willingness to address the problems of specific groups. However, whether quotas are the solution. In my opinion, perhaps the evaluation system should be changed at the time of the selection of candidates. If higher scores were awarded to people with disabilities who want to work in an institution in the European Union, we would create an opportunity for them to actually get here. In such ways, people with disabilities would not feel excluded from others, and their exclusion, different treatment is a huge problem.  Another important aspect is the readiness of the Institutions of the European Union to receive persons with disabilities. I think if parliamentarians were to tie their eyes and take the blind wand to try to get into their offices, it would probably be a surprise how difficult it is to do, because in practice there is little infrastructure. I am talking about the need for non-special people to accompany the blind to his place of work, because this will again be perceived as isolation, often referred to by people with disabilities as an annoying exclusion. Let us adapt buildings, create suitable jobs, inform disability organisations in all Member States about the work we have done, let people with disabilities come and make sure of change, create positively discriminatory job vacancies assessment systems and bring about change. That is what I invite you to do.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, the problem facing our institution today is that of virtually all Member States. Everyone has difficulties in solving it and we have found nothing better than the quotas - also known as positive discrimination - to solve it, whether or not they are subject to sanctions in case these quotas, which seem, year after year, to be in the range of 5 to 6%, are not respected. However, I think it is probably another look that should be had, both on disability, which is a problem, and on the disabled person himself. This permanent notion of profitability and profit means that people with disabilities or functional difficulties may not have the same "return" as their non-deficit colleagues.  I think there would be a very good solution: to set the budget available for disability compensation from the outset. From there, whether at the time of recruitment for reserved or unre booked positions or for public servants who would be suffering from functional difficulties and would therefore be in a state of disability, as long as we had the financial leeway to accompany them, they would be, with equal competence and, above all, higher skills. , of course privileged. Positive discrimination would then focus on the abilities of these people, who are often much more developed than others.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, we are addressing a subject that really concerns all of us, because disability is something that may as well concern us or one of our loved ones tomorrow. We are not talking about a population outside ourselves, we are talking about ourselves and our view of others. The first thing I would like to say to you, Commissioner, is that the only thing that makes me confident is your determination. But until we establish numerical scoreboards on the integration of the disabled and the promotion of the disabled, we will not be able to make progress towards the integration of the disabled.  I am not a woman defending quotas, but at least they have a purpose, which is to look at what we are actually doing. I am a member of the College of Quaestors, so I can see the diversity of requests from our colleagues who are with disabilities and the improvements in the workstations that we need to make. And if I have confidence in one point, it is in your determination and our will to all in the European institutions, within the framework of our new working environment, to fully integrate this dimension of the integration of disability and disabled people into our management.  What we ask of the Member States, we must apply to ourselves. That is our view, this is a founding value of Europe, so stay determined as you are today to succeed.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Commissioner, in this European Parliament, we have repeatedly debated the need to recruit as many people with disabilities as possible.  However, despite the numerous conventions, directives, strategies that prohibit any discrimination against persons with disabilities, in the area of employment, people with disabilities still do not have sufficient opportunities to work. For example, in the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020, we call on the Member States to take the necessary steps to create the conditions for the employment of disabled people, but in this strategy we have completely forgotten about access to employment for people with disabilities in the Institutions of the European Union. Why? This needs to be corrected immediately. Commissioner, from your speech, I have realised that we do not have specific precise statistics on how many people with disabilities are employed in the Institutions of the European Union. We probably do not know whether those people who are already working have sufficient opportunities to work in a truly high quality way. In other words, whether they are equipped with a working environment.  I therefore very much ask that the Commission, which started work only recently, could already present a strategy here in the European Parliament here in the autumn with concrete measures to be done to make the Institutions of the European Union a role model for all Member States when recruiting people with disabilities.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union is a party to the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, but it is equally important that all Member States and the Union are parties to the Optional Protocol establishing a mandatory complaint mechanism for individual complaints. The Administration of the European Parliament stresses that it ensures a level playing field for people with disabilities, but is that really the case? Parliament offers the possibility to employ disabled persons without a university degree for only five months. This is far too short. In 2014, the European Parliament recruited only 13 trainees with disabilities and 7 contract staff with disabilities. And how does this go to the overall proportion to the number of people with disabilities in the Union? One-third of the citizens of the European Union are disabled, 80 million people, and here we are dealing with such small amounts. These amounts are abnormally low and this needs to be changed. It should also be possible for these persons to have access to buildings, to enable persons with disabilities to function normally here in the European Parliament, both for workers and potential workers, for citizens of the European Union and for Members of the European Parliament.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, Dear Madam Commissioner of the European Commission, I think what you have put forward is a good step forward. However, what I want to note, there are very different practices in Europe and formally, legislatively very different practices when we talk about the employment of people with disabilities.  What is, however, is in some ways small and astonishing, the European institutions are not leaders in this. And that is what I think we need to talk about today because it is the European institutions that should, in my deep belief, be leaders in this sense on how to set up formal legal employment of people with disabilities in the European institutions. There are very good examples, just mentioned examples from Germany. We can also boast in Croatia that we have good examples, good laws and even in some parts good practice. Regardless of the fact that we have a lot of problems in our country, but the way it was approached formally, the legal employment of people with disabilities is a good way. Of course, there is also talk about the need and punishment, but also about rewarding private entrepreneurs in this sense.  So, what I would like to emphasize, quotas are for me personally one transitional solution. It is better that we have quotas than not have them, but what would be most logical is that we have fair tenders and therefore I think we should fair tenders without prejudice and without thinking about whether a person has a disability or not, than whether they have knowledge or not knowledge.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the United Nations Convention ratified by the European Union guarantees the rights of persons with disabilities both at work, dignity, equality and basic freedoms. It is therefore very important that the European Union takes positive action in this direction. Unfortunately, however, this is not enough as it is merely a piecemeal step in the right direction. The neoliberal policies of harsh austerity promoted by the Union and implemented by several Member States, first and foremost affect vulnerable groups, such as that of people with disabilities, and throw them into poverty and poverty, leading them to marginalisation. It is not only the employment quota for people with disabilities in the Union institutions that is needed, because a change of course is needed towards policies that deepen the social state, that integrate vulnerable groups of the population into society and that also put the private sector before its responsibilities. As a united left we are ready to support positive actions, but we do not forget the main cause of poverty and social exclusion, which is the dissolution of the social state and the austerity policies pursued by the Union and the Member States.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, quotas can sometimes create an impression or assumption that disabled people are unable to compete for jobs; but that is not the whole story. People with a mobility impairment suffer from lower employment rates than others, even including other people with disabilities, due to the lack of infrastructure and accessibility. That, at least, is the case in Estonia, the country I happen to know the best. I would like to inform the Commission of a problem that we have. The Estonian Government is planning to apply the same kind of labour market reform that has given rise to backlashes in Hungary and in Great Britain. Intending to spend EUR 300 million of European cohesion money, they plan to create 500 assessors jobs in the Department of Employment. I would like to ask the Commission, and Ms Georgieva personally, to keep a close eye on the activities of the Estonian Government and on that reform. I would even go so far as to suggest that those 500 European jobs should go exclusively to people with disabilities.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, I have been working with the disability sector for many years and with the European Fund and Spanish organisations. There is no doubt, if we go to the sector, that quotas are necessary. I have heard many interventions here, perhaps because there is no link with the disability sectors. Quotas are not the solution, but they are one more thing. Positive action measures need to be developed, especially to support groups with disabilities with greater difficulties, such as those with intellectual or psychosocial disabilities. That can't be isolated. It has to be done in an environment where there are procurement processes, where there are, as the United Nations Convention says, reasonable adjustments. Today the Commission is not a model. Today we don't know how many are approved of the disabled and how many are not. We don't have any information. What reasonable adjustments have been made to jobs, as the Commission says? What budget is there for this topic? We don't know all that. And, therefore, I believe that the European Union, which works precisely on these issues, has to be a model. And therefore, what I propose to the Union .... There have been many complaints about accessibility. For example, in the Union there is a part of disability practices, but in format that is not accessible. What do I propose to the Commission? Positive measures. I propose a budget, propose reasonable adjustments, propose follow-up, propose an accessible communication and propose a plan. Because in the end, if we want to meet the goals of equality and non-discrimination, it has to start with us.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, the Commissioner spoke with obvious personal sincerity, but I have to say that her institution is simply not serious and not credible about discrimination. She tells us that the Staff Regulations do not permit action to make sure that disabled people have access to these very well paid jobs. So you change the Staff Regulations if you are serious about it. I have tabled parliamentary questions about this – nobody answers, in the same way that I have tabled dozens of parliamentary questions about how many people from ethnic minorities work in the EU institutions. No answers, nobody counts, nobody cares. It is not good enough to be personally sincere. Disabled people have a right to the well-paid jobs in your institutions and you are not giving them those jobs. It does not matter why. You are not. You could, but you are not.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab If, of course, it were a theory, if all the people with disabilities in the European Union had formed one separate nation, it would be the largest nation in our Union. Of course, I am talking about showing the scale of the phenomenon. We are not talking about an outsider, we are also talking about ourselves, we are also talking about our families. This is not some outside problem, but a problem that also exists within this Parliament and our societies. I have the impression that "the couple is going to the whistle", that it is a certain amount of action, and there is not some systematic activity aimed at increasing the participation of people with disabilities at work, but also, for example, when it comes to young people with disabilities in universities. And this is a key issue for us, I believe. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask you, because I agree with your position, how you comment on the fact that in Greece, possibly in other countries of the European Union, because of the crisis that exists, the government does not approve the grant of medicines that are expensive, but necessary for the survival of patients, people who need them. So there is a humanitarian issue. How do you comment on that?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you for your question, Mr President. I dare not judge the governments of other countries, because perhaps also the government of my country has some sins of omission, speaking theological language. On the other hand, I think that the civilisational level of a society, of a nation and of power is determined by its attitude towards, firstly, the elderly, the insemine and, secondly, the disabled or otherwise able to do so. And I think you can't save here because, in truth, it's downright inhumane.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Madam President, and I'm sorry for the delay and a good-there. Commissioner. The current situation of economic stagnation in Europe has worsened labour market conditions in general and made even more difficult the prospects of employability and equal opportunity for people with disabilities. We are now faced with increased difficulty in achieving the previously established employment objectives for individuals with disabilities. Within the European institutions there must therefore be a proactive and positive policy for people with disabilities, ensuring a level playing field in access to employment. We must advocate greater awareness and education of both people and the administration in order to promote fair and equal treatment that compensates people for their merits and allows them to integrate into the fullness of their social rights. Particular attention should be paid to the way in which the European administration implements its equality standards, on access to employment for people with disabilities.   Ladies and gentlemen. I believe that the quota system should not be regarded as a panacea to counter act against the prevailing negative discrimination and may even create exclusion mechanisms. After all, ladies and gentlemen, people with disabilities are no less people than others, and we must do so, ladies and gentlemen and Commissioner, is to recognise and reward their merit and create working conditions that do not constitute obstacles to their employability. Thank you.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am very pleased that we are debating the amounts for the disabled today and that we started this topic by analysing and assessing the situation within the European Commission itself, because the self-assessment of the office, which is a right, is sometimes and almost always very informative and opens our eyes to certain aspects of the matter that may have been previously invisible.  Polish example, this confirms this. In Poland a few years ago we have already introduced quotas with severe sanctions. Any company with at least 25 employees must employ at least 6% of people with disabilities and financial sanctions are very high. We have checked all central offices, as well as local authorities in this regard, how they cope with the implementation of this amount, and it turns out that almost no public or non-public institution is able to achieve this amount – despite sincere desires. As far as central offices are concerned, it is extremely rare for persons with disabilities to apply for competitions. So it is clear that quotas – which are a much-needed tool for the impact of this equality policy – are insufficient in this area and we need a comprehensive policy, a good diagnosis of the causes, barriers that are emerging on the market, in order to cover these amounts with the right policies so that we are effective in integrating people with disabilities into the labour market.  I hope that the European Commission will monitor both itself and the other institutions in this regard, because we need such pressures and motivations in order to implement policy effectively in this area. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Karol KARSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – She has presented here very interesting solutions in our country, while pointing out that disabled people also do not come to work as often as we would like. So I would ask you to indicate how you think positive action could be taken to encourage people with disabilities, to tell them that there are jobs, that we are waiting for them?

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "As far as Poland is concerned, it is clear that the reasons lie in the educational system. We need more accessible education at all levels for people with disabilities. First of all, we need people who are individual assistants and help to achieve certain educational objectives, but above all we need institutions, offices and companies to work with NGOs that specialise in bringing people with disabilities into the labour market. Such examples are, also in Poland, they are very effective, but there are simply not enough of them and we have too rare a network of such cooperation, and it would be very necessary.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, people with disabilities are among the most vulnerable people in our society.
