When integrating into the labour market, they face a number of obstacles, but they are not insurmountable. It is the institutions and agencies of the European Union that should show that the employment of people with disabilities is not only possible, but also beneficial.  In most Member States, there is a system of different measures and quotas for the employment of people with disabilities in both the private and public sectors. What is striking is that such an inclusive policy is lacking in the institutions of the European Union. The policy of the European institutions therefore needs to be revised, and I am glad that you mentioned some of the options in your speech, Commissioner. This year, the UN Commission will assess the progress made by the European Union since the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. A comprehensive strategy by the European institutions to improve access to employment for people with disabilities in these institutions would undoubtedly be a positive and important step.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, unlike members of various minorities that some politicians try to put into the category of vulnerable groups and provide them with better status in exchange for votes in elections, I really consider people with disabilities to be the most vulnerable group and I believe that as responsible societies we must pay attention to them.  Nevertheless, I view the employment of these persons through quotas as a blow to their dignity, especially when it comes to jobs in the Institutions of the European Union. Will the European Institutions have to provide people with disabilities with a job by force of law? Shouldn't it be from here that the awareness that people with disabilities are equal members of society to be judged by their competences rather than physical impairments should begin? I believe that they themselves would much prefer to get a job in the competition of all other applicants because they would prove that they are not special because of physical damage, but because of their exceptional knowledge and ability.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Employment in the European Union is a challenge for all categories of people: for young people, for the elderly and, of course, for people with disabilities. And as a special group and as a vulnerable group, of course we must pay particular attention to this group. There are, as we all see, different ways to do this, and one way is the quota system. However, there are other, equally important, such as the adaptation of jobs, such as education and training. However, most countries in the European Union use the quota system as a way of tackling this problem or increasing the employment of people with disabilities, and therefore it is entirely in place and the logical question is why this is not the case in the European institutions.  Even in our country, in my country, Slovenia, we have had a quota system introduced for many years, and yet it did not give the expected results. We have to improve it.  And, of course, I would not want employers to understand the quota system as a burden, or worse, not as a burden, but as a way of obtaining certain funds and subsidies. We will achieve our objective – and also of the European institutions – only when the employment of people with disabilities is taken for granted, not the result of some binding regulations. And of course it is important that there are as many people with disabilities as possible, not just employees, but in quality jobs, and that they will feel effective in this society.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened to the Commission's statement and, of course, I fully agree with its objectives. Supporting an idea of development and growth also from a social point of view means building a Europe of citizens, and this is therefore a battle of civilisation: combating all forms of discrimination, especially in the workplace, through the development of welfare models, means promoting people, workers and workers, giving priority to knowledge and skills.  We are ting the crisis not only by promoting new paths of industrialisation and the development of the business system, but by investing in the human capital of the most disadvantaged, to whom equal accessibility to work and its places must be guaranteed, starting with the European institutions. With particular regard to the European Parliament, the 2009-2013 action plan adopted by the EP Bureau includes a number of excellent actions, including quota forecasting. It is therefore essential that we continue along this path by providing for appropriate financial resources and with a specific budget line in mind.

name: Marek PLURA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is clear from the information provided by the Commissioner that we certainly cannot talk about discrimination against persons with disabilities in the area of employment in the EU institutions. But at the same time, the same data shows that we should and must talk about a large disparity, too few people with disabilities working in these institutions. I am very pleased with the Commissioner's determination to change this state, and I am convinced, like many of my previous ones, that the parity mechanism would very much consolidate this determination and be one of the tools that can be used to improve the current situation. But also aside from these regular changes, I would like to ask what challenges does the Commissioner herself face? What parity or rather the objective of measures to increase the participation of disabled workers in the EU institutions do you envisage for, say, four years, after carrying out studies similar to those on which you have presented this data to us?

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, Mrs Georgieva, it is imperative that the European Commission set a convincing example of non-discrimination and equal treatment in employment and exercise of the right to work by introducing clear and mandatory rules for the employment of people with permanent disabilities on a quota basis in the European institutions.  The 2000 Directive introduced a common framework for non-discrimination in the field of employment. It is imperative that this measure, together with the other founding documents of the European Union treating equal rights of persons with disabilities, be put into practice.  In this context, it is also worth considering the issue of barriers to the State aid regime, which limit the possibilities of protecting persons with disabilities against discrimination and unequal treatment in employment and the exercise of the right to work.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you have said that the quota system is not allowed by the current regulations and I see that you do not intend to amend them, which I do not understand, because you will understand that both your work and ours are precisely to analyse what is wrong with proposing changes to the rule. Justifying a political position simply on the grounds that the rule does not allow it seems to me to be a rather poor argument. I think quotas are necessary. I think it's also a demand from the sector. I believe that since we signed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, we have committed ourselves to enhancing those rights to equal opportunities, and that more needs to be done. We have to be a model, we have to set an example for other institutions. And so, I think we should incorporate it. We cannot ask the private sector to incorporate, to encourage, which, in addition to public support, creates tax benefits or all kinds of incentives to promote people with disabilities in employment if we do not set an example. I think it is necessary to expand to at least 5%. Introduce at least 5% quotas in European institutions reserved for persons with disabilities. And I think all other measures are not incompatible. I believe that people who are now trying to say that necessary measures, such as increasing technical service or improving accessibility are incompatible with quotas, are misrepresenting the debate, which does not deserve the rights of these people, who have to be able to exercise equal opportunities.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, it can be argued that quota systems and anti-discrimination legislation are contrary approaches to achieving the same goal. While the quota approach is based on the assumption that disabled persons cannot compete on the labour market with the same opportunities as the rest of society, and therefore working places must be reserved for them, the non-discrimination approach assumes that the issue can already be solved through the guarantee of individual rights to equal treatment and through workplace adaptations. However, the two approaches can coexist and can complement each other. In the EU the Employment Equality Directive is a great achievement in the field of anti-discrimination. It led to the elaboration of new legislation in many states that did not have any previous provisions in this field. Establishing a quota system in the EU institutions could serve as an example and could help pave the way towards a more inclusive employment system. This is one of the areas in which it can most affect the life of its citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must work to create a barrier-free Europe for people with disabilities. This was stated by the Commissioner for Employment and Social Affairs, Marianne Thyssen, during the hearing in the European Parliament. Unfortunately, there are still major shortcomings in disability legislation: Directive 2000 of 1978 establishes a legal framework for combating discrimination based on religion, belief and disability in the field of employment.  The point, however, is to move from a general obligation to hire to a more articulated process to properly assess people with disabilities in their working skills and to put them in the right place. A kind of targeted placement, the goal must not simply be to find a job for the person with disabilities, but rather to trigger a virtuous circle that manages to fully exploit the potential of the person, making it a positive and productive element within the working context. Although the Union has responded to this challenge by taking a number of initiatives, there is still a long way to go. It is time for the Eu ropean Union to lay down strict rules, so that even in the institutions of the European Union, more quotas are guaranteed for the recruitment of people with disabilities.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, people with disabilities, in different Member States, face modern social racism. But the worst discrimination against them is not so much due to the stereotypes and social origins of their fellow human beings as to the powers themselves. It is a power of European elites that impose austerity policies and violent fiscal adjustments, which restrict social benefits even to people with disabilities. In Greece, the Troika even reduced disability pensions, which now range between 250 and 525 euros per month.  It is therefore important to reverse social pressure and discrimination against people with disabilities by formulating a disability policy within the framework of the European Union's future 2020 strategy. I hope that this will also be done within the institutions of the European Union and that it will trigger a humane treatment of people with disabilities throughout the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the integration of disabled people in the labour market represents one of the biggest challenges for social and labour market policies in modern societies. The recent economic crisis hit disadvantaged people hard and increased their inactivity and unemployment rates. I therefore strongly support quotas for the employment of people with disabilities. Quotas are a concrete way of demonstrating a country’s willingness to integrate and provide equal opportunities for people with disabilities. Since the guarantee of equal treatment for people with disabilities can lead to the establishment of foundational standards, with which the Member States are expected to comply, I believe the European Union institutions must be in the forefront in the adoption of quotas through the introduction of the obligation to have a certain proportion of persons with disabilities among the staff of the European Union institutions. The employment quotas for people with disabilities are a means to ensure human dignity, fight inequality and reduce social disadvantages – three issues that are at the core of our political will and activity.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – I, colleagues, have a completely different view: not quotas. How do you want to select them, that is, the disabled people? For specific work, different sufferers have different requirements for aids. For example, blind, deaf, mute, people with damaged body ores will need increased costs for specific work to adjust conditions. I'd suggest something else. Rather, to create a programme to support sheltered workshops, production cooperatives, rather to support and facilitate employers for such projects and to control more the functioning of those projects so that the money is not misused. I know from Slovakia that they were abused like this. Plus, let's create public awareness and learning support to integrate them and facilitate the use of their employment, talents and abilities. You know, I had a disabled son, and he had a good preparation in the so-called family school, so I say that it is necessary to encourage the European institutions to create quality, special fields of study for their personal growth, to find a good job, to start youth, to raise them, and in a few years they will be well employed. Those who can handle it well will also be professionally proficient. So, Mrs Kozłowska said that we need quota pressure to set an example of what we are doing. Is that serious? Pushing employers to make them more difficult? And if there are no sufferers, then how do we look for them in our committees and how do we employ them? I think we need to change the approach.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like most sincerely to thank everybody who has taken the floor this evening.  This is certainly an issue that is not just about people with disabilities but about the Europe we want to live in. I want to start with something that flashed through my mind while thinking back to when my own country became a member of the European Union in 2007. For me one of the joys of this membership was that my niece, who was born with dwarfism, would live in a Union where people with disabilities enjoy equal opportunities. I want to believe that this is exactly the Europe we want, a Europe where that happens for her and for everybody else. But we cannot possibly dream of a good life for our children if we do not integrate everybody. We are an ageing region. We need everybody to contribute to our economy and to the well-being of the European people. So for me this is not just a matter of looking at one topic, rather it is the coherence of the values we live by. That takes me on to how we intend to approach the integration of people with disabilities. Firstly, I strongly believe that we have to make recruitment a door through which everybody who wants to enter the institutions can enter. As I mentioned at the beginning, we have done a lot in this area. If you go to the ‘Guide to Open Competitions’ you will find specific information for candidates with disabilities. In every application form there is an access requirements form that can be filled in so if you have disabilities and you need any type of assistance you can get it. Dyslexia is also taken into account in EPSO competitions. As I mentioned, there exists all the elements to make sure that people can compete. What we have to do more of – and I recognise this – is to reach out to people with disabilities and encourage more of them to apply. On the topic of how many apply and what percentage are successful, we have quite accurate data. Out of about 30 000 applicants in the last competition, around 300 made it. Among them were seven people with disabilities. Obviously, if we want more to apply we have to be more open in terms of how we reach out to people with disabilities to make sure they understand that a career in the European institutions is a good career for them.  What worried me a lot in the staff survey when we got the results was that the staff engagement index for people who defined themselves as staff with disabilities was lower than the overall average for staff. In other words, people with disabilities do not feel that they are equally encouraged to engage in the institutions. That tells me that the institutions have to do more to engage with them.  I very much agree with all those who spoke about making sure that we remove barriers for people with disabilities when making an application, but also then to ensure that they can get promoted and to encourage them to progress in terms of applying their skills. That will be an area that we will look into very carefully in the new strategy.  I mentioned in the beginning that we do not have accurate data because of restrictions arising from the confidentiality of medical records. I am determined that we have to find a way to remove this restriction because we cannot rely only on self—identification if we want to be proactive and create conditions that allow people to work to their fullest ability and to grow within the Commission. But this is a question for which I do not have an answer today; a question that we intend to answer as we put forward the new strategy.  As regards the issue of the Staff Regulations, I heard loud and clear those who said that it is a very lousy excuse to state that the Staff Regulations do not allow you to have quotas. So I want to elaborate. I think there is a reason why the Staff Regulations do not allow us to have quotas; it can become a slippery slope. If we get quotas for people with disabilities, then there is pressure to have quotas on nationality and quotas on this and that. While each of these issues on their own may be very legitimate, once we go in the direction of creating a quota system on one criterion in an organisation where there is a very strong tendency to think of national quotas, I think we would see the merits, which has been a very strong factor in our decision-making, being undermined. Now I am not saying that we should not think of maybe applying quotas to only one segment, but I do not want to go into that before I am convinced that we are not going to resolve one problem and create another. But what should our level of ambition be? Well, many of you said what I believe should be our level of ambition. We have to be an example for the European Union. The European institutions have a responsibility to lead by example. In some of our Member States the quota system aims at between five and ten percent; I think the highest is in Germany. So we need to look at what would be the appropriate level of ambition to target as regards people with disabilities.  On self-identification, we are not in a very bad place because in the survey 5.7 % tell us that they have disabilities. Therefore, we have reached a certain order of magnitude. But is this real? We count on people telling us that they have disabilities; but we do not know. So we have to improve the data collection and we have to be able to say where we are and where we are headed. Where we are headed clearly has to be a good message to Europe. It is not just about people with disabilities. If you walk around the institutions, we have a way to go in terms of the presence of minorities and in terms of women in management positions. There is scope for us to make ourselves more diverse than we currently are. How far are we going to go? Obviously I do not want to promise a very rapid change with immediate effect, because a big organisation is a bit like the Queen Mary; you make a policy change and it takes time for this change to be reflected in the composition of our staff.  We are determined and I would obviously support you. You will see me coming here again on this topic. I am sure you will bring me here again. It is an area where I very much value your encouragement for us to do something. We owe it not just to disabled people, but we owe it to Europe to be the place of values that we have been embracing over the decades.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much Commissioner. Thank you not only for what you have said, but also for taking the European Parliament seriously. This is another speech not two minutes, like the other Commissioners, but a longer, serious, substantive speech. Thank you for that.  I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – I do not believe in quotas, for one simple reason: ‘positive discrimination’ is still discrimination, and I object to discrimination in all its forms. We should have working conditions which provide every opportunity for people with disabilities, but the allocation of jobs must be based upon merit not upon gender, ethnicity, disabilities, or any other form of discrimination. Quotas are the antithesis of meritocracy.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. We are talking here about quotas for the hiring of disabled people in the institutions of the European Union. I would remind you that such measures are already being applied in France in the private sector and in the public sector. It should be noted that the unemployment rate for persons with disabilities exceeded 21% in 2012, despite the legislation and numerous awareness campaigns on this subject (for example: week for the employment of people with disabilities...). The subject is therefore of importance and topicality. If I reject any notion of affirmative action, I find it necessary to help people with disabilities find jobs like everyone else.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. – Access by disabled people to information concerning the Union, including information relating to competitions and, again, the effective use of competitions themselves should be ensured. It is a priority that all citizens should be guaranteed the right to participate in the political life of the Union's institutions, and not just in principle. To this end, we have tabled a written question proposing the use of a special high-readable typeface designed to make it easier for the dyslexic population to consult written documents, and we will continue to work in every way we can.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Generally, I am not in favour of quotas. I believe we should instead focus on removing discriminatory barriers and then let people work their own way in the world. That said, I think this might be one of the examples where quotas could be useful. Those accepted to enter the service of the EU institutions are on average less than 1% of those who apply for employment, and for those with a disability the odds are even worse.  If we want our laws and institutions to serve all EU citizens, public administrations should reflect all our citizens. They must have an understanding for issues related to persons with disabilities, and if we have persons with disabilities as part of our administration we will be more effective at achieving this policy.  The EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2011 and consequently the CRPD is now binding on the EU institutions and all Member States. I hope that both national and EU administrations will continue their efforts to fully implement it in their work. We must reach a day where the principles of equal access and equal opportunities truly apply to all.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – In most Member States, people with disabilities continue to face great difficulties in finding work or when they have to keep their jobs, as the unemployment rate remains high - twice that of the general population. Member States and the Commission must strengthen their cooperation, because persons with disabilities have the right to work in a normal environment, without discrimination of any kind against them, including at the level of the European institutions, which must set an example when applying the existing provisions in this field. I believe that priority should be given to preventing these people from being excluded from the labour market and to keep their jobs. On the other hand, young people in such situations who find themselves at the beginning of the road should be supported by including in different traineeship programmes adapted to identify the skills they can develop in order to place them in the labour market.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Back in December last year, my delegation addressed the European Commission the question of how many persons with disabilities are employed in the EU institutions. It is clear from the fact that the European Commission is ready to take action to achieve social inclusion in a tangible way. I believe that it is very important that the Commission examines the good practices of the Member States as soon as possible in the areas of positive discrimination, job accessibility and the application of different subsidies or benefits, and also applies the best ones on a mandatory basis within the institutions of the European Union. Hungary a great example of how a combination of quotas, targeted subsidies and tax incentives can help more and more people with disabilities to work. Although there is still much to be done in our country, I believe that Hungary and several other Member States where the quota system has already been introduced can already show the WAY for the EU.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament with the aim of promoting and ensuring that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – The EU is a major provider of employment in Europe and a dark shadow would be cast over its accomplishments on upholding high social and labour standards if it would fail to apply these to its own employment policies. However, the EU’s work on ensuring equal employment for disabled people and their families shouldn’t stop at its own institutions. Today, fifteen million children in the EU, 700 000 of whom are living in the UK, have special educational needs. While these children risk being denied equal access to after-school care because the majority of existing facilities are unable to accommodate their requirements, their parents incur higher than average childcare costs and risk being denied equal access to employment opportunities, as they are required to take more time off work to care for their child. The fundamental issue is simple – should the EU provide a level playing field for all in the employment market? The answer is a firm ‘yes’, and the EU needs to step up its game to make sure this is adequately reflected in its policies.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. I am surprised that it is precisely the EU institutions, which should be a source of good practice and guarantee rights and equal opportunities for all citizens, that do not provide for recruitment quotas for people with disabilities. For once, it's the states that are going to school. Of course, there is still a great deal to be done at national level too, because only a small percentage of disabled people are employed. What is certain is that the EU cannot show backwardness or worse still unprepared. The European Union has an obligation to include, and above all, people with disabilities working in the great European machine.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Activating and employing persons with disabilities remains a huge challenge for Member States' social policies. In addition, an ageing population is causing more and more people, including workers struggling with health problems. People with disabilities face many barriers to their integration into the labour market. These are not only physical, legal, but also mental barriers. However, condemning people who are able to work to often long-term unemployment is an adverse effect not only on them, but also on public finances due to the long-term burden on social security systems. Employment-based schemes for persons with disabilities present in many Member States do not seem to pass the test. Incentives for employers, information campaigns, as well as well-prepared jobs and flexible and innovative forms of employment provide much better results.  The European Commission, but also other European institutions, should set an example and be a source of good practice showing how to employ persons with disabilities for the benefit of the employer and the worker. To this end, basic statistics are also needed to assess the effectiveness of the measures taken. I hope that the Commission will make efforts to collect such data, of course in compliance with the rules on the protection of personal data.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – Although many people with disabilities are employed, disability still remains a significant risk factor for participation in the labour market. However, major differences still exist between disabled people and non-disabled people and barriers to the labour market are not easily removed. There is a very significant association between educational achievement and success in employment. Therefore, it is extremely important to focus on how to bridge the gap between school age and the labour market for people with disabilities, including attention to education, the employment needs of young people with disabilities and the essential role of lifelong learning. People with disabilities are employed within a broad range and types of jobs but with a large proportion employed in low-skilled jobs. Therefore, it is important to support and encourage people with disabilities to apply for jobs in the European institutions and make sure that they understand that a career in the European Institutions is a good career for them. Disabled people should enjoy the same rights and opportunities as non-disabled people.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – (2000) I consider that there are recruitment quotas to give people with disabilities the possibility of being able to join the European institutions. The existence of these has given thousands of people the possibility to intern and/or work in the various institutions, promoting the much desired and proclaimed social inclusion. I would also like to point out that these same policies should be shaped in the various Member States because we must all harmonise inclusion policies like this. These are positive discrimination policies that must be implemented in the various Member States. We need to act more and more quickly because only by looking at this problem with transversality is it possible to do more and better.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text looks back at quotas for the hiring of disabled people in EU institutions. Such measures already exist in France. It should be remembered that the unemployment rate for people with disabilities in France exceeded 21% in 2012 and that despite the law, numerous communications and awareness campaigns on this subject (week for the employment of disabled people...), the problem remains important. If I do not accept the concept of affirmative action, I find it perfectly normal to help people with disabilities find a job like everyone else.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. – More than 50 million Europeans – over 10% of the population – have a disability that, even today, creates obstacles in many aspects of their lives, including professional life. With the adoption of Council Decision 2010/48/EC of 26 November 2009, the EU acceded to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which is aimed at ensuring that persons with disabilities enjoy all human rights and fundamental freedoms. The institutions must set a good example here, and one possible way would be to introduce quotas for people with disabilities in their calls for tenders. This is an instrument already present in 21 of the 28 Member States, which would help to ensure effective equal access in the Community institutions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The right to work of persons with disabilities must be respected and supported by the European Union. Such an affirmative measure is a positive element. In the European Union, there are more than 80 million people with disabilities, according to the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, while in my country, Romania, there are more than 700 000 people with disabilities. Their presence in the European administrative system strengthens the European institutions. In this way, the EU reiterates its human and social values related to tolerance and the fight against discrimination.  In addition to the elements mentioned in the debate, I also consider it appropriate to represent these special places throughout the EU. We know that in some states there is not good information about these opportunities and enough affirmative measures to stimulate employment, and I believe that citizens with disabilities in those states need to be further supported. For example, Romania already occupies fewer places in the European institutions than the share represented at European level, and this under-representation is even more visible when we talk about places allocated to people with disabilities in Romania. I believe that we must also combat territorial discrimination against people with disabilities. One reason for the limited number is given by the fact that the competition spaces in Romania are not adapted for access to persons with disabilities.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – Article 27 The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which is a signatory to the EU, states of the Party recognise the right to work for people with disabilities, including the right to be able to earn a living from work, and highlights, among other objectives, the employment of persons with disabilities in the public sector. I would like to know if the European Commission plans to encourage the employment of people with disabilities in the Institutions of the European Union in order to show by example its firm commitment to remove barriers to greater employment of people with disabilities, also called for by the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020?  As the Strategy points out, the full participation of people with disabilities in economic and social life is also important for the success of the Europe 2020 Strategy. One of the objectives of this Strategy is poverty reduction, and it is for people with disabilities that the poverty rate is 70% higher than the average, partly due to limited access to employment. As the employment rate for people with disabilities ranges around 50% and higher employment for people with disabilities is needed in the EU, the European Commission should establish a legislative framework that would encourage a positive change to a greater extent.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The integration of persons with disabilities is one of the biggest challenges of social and labour policy and should be one of the priorities in European labour legislation in order to reinforce the generally accepted principles of respecting diversity, providing equal opportunities and fostering the personal development of each individual.  In my view, by setting these quotas for the EU institutions, we will show by our own example how the appreciation of disability when recruiting is a practice aimed at determining an individual's social status and identity at a time when he or she belongs to the working contingent. While such quotas may seem to conflict with the principle of equal treatment on the labour market and to encourage positive discrimination against people with disabilities, they should be a guarantee of equal opportunities and full participation in economic, cultural and social life and as such the level of derogation in anti-discrimination law should be allowed.  Recently in Croatia, the circle of persons with disabilities was expanded from the public sector and to the private sector, which was met with great approval by the public, and I am convinced that this step of the Commission will have the same effect towards a more significant appreciation of people with disabilities. The Commission has clearly demonstrated its will and determination to promote important international instruments for the protection and promotion of the rights of persons with disabilities and therefore deserves our support.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – People with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable social groups, and their integration into the labour market is a major challenge in the field of social and employment. As many as 21 of the 28 Member States have already introduced and implemented mandatory quotas for the employment of people with disabilities in the public sector. The European institutions have not yet introduced these quotas, but they take into account the non-discrimination provisions. The UN Convention on Persons with Disabilities, which has also been in force for the EU institutions since 2011, prohibits, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of disability on all matters relating to any form of employment, including conditions of search, hiring and employment, maintenance of employment, promotion and safe and healthy working conditions. The OECD survey showed that in countries with quotas for the employment of persons with disabilities, the unemployment rate among persons with disabilities is lower than in countries that have not introduced these quotas. Moreover, in practice, it should be easier to implement employment quotas than to strictly follow the principle of non-discrimination. The question arises whether the EU institutions, without mandatory quotas for the employment of persons with disabilities, can effectively ensure equal treatment of persons with disabilities, particularly in recruitment procedures. Some MEPs are already expected to receive complaints from citizens that, particularly in selection procedures, people with disabilities are not allowed to receive equal treatment.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – It is a devastating fact that in the 21st century the poverty rate of people with disabilities is 70 percent higher than the average, the biggest cause of which is limited access to employment. The situation was bad before, but it also deteriorated significantly during the economic crisis. Today, there are more than 80 million people with disabilities living in the European Union who are at risk of becoming a socially marginalised group, i.e. being socially excluded and discriminated against despite numerous worldwide efforts to avoid this. There are over 520,000 living in Croatia, and a group of women with disabilities are particularly at risk.  For all this, it is important that the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 is fully implemented and that in all EU Member States a legally regulated quota that obliges the social inclusion and employment of disabled people, both in public and private sectors, is respected.  I welcome the Commission's proposal calling on the Member States of the Union to make further efforts to fully implement the Disability Strategy 2010-2020 so that people with disabilities can fully exercise their human rights in the finality. The European Union is a leader in many areas and I see no justifiable reason not to protect the rights of people with disabilities.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The legal framework for disabled workers for companies with at least 20 employees, the principle of non-discrimination, the obligation to negotiate measures relating to vocational integration, and widespread accessibility are the legislative framework for disabled workers. However, people with disabilities continue to face great difficulties in finding or retaining employment and their unemployment rate remains twice that of the general population. As early as 2009, the Busnel report entitled "Employment, a right to live for all" stressed the priority to be given to the prevention of professional exclusion and retention in employment. In 2014, the right to regular employment for people with disabilities is still far from effective. The European Parliament has a role to play in order not to leave some of the citizens on the sidelines and to help europe be that of all citizens.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the role of fair competition of knowledge and capabilities is essential when recruiting staff for new job placements. But people with specific needs in most of the cases of such selection are disadvantaged, even if they have prominent abilities for the particular work. These people overcome all kinds of difficulties every day, encounter and fight all kinds of discrimination. Their integration into the social and working environment remains one of the biggest challenges across the Union, although the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was one of the first conventions ratified by the EU. Progress is too slow and barely noticeable.  I therefore believe that the time has come for more radical measures, for adopting the approach of positive discrimination in the treatment of people with specific needs. The introduction of mandatory quotas for the employment of persons with disabilities in the European institutions is precisely such a measure. Moreover, in 21 of the 28 Member States, such quotas have been introduced. The European institutions are lagging behind EU countries rather than setting an example. Quotas do not solve everything, but good practices for positive discrimination based on skills and abilities will be created gradually, which can also be followed by Member States.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. – The Socialists bring this debate to the plenary of the European Parliament in an effort to promote and ensure that the European institutions fulfil their commitment to equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. In addition to a question of justice, it is a duty we contracted when we signed the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. There are currently quota systems for persons with disabilities in the supply of employment in enterprises, public and private, and institutions in 21 of the 28 Member States. However, it is ironic that, while from Europe we call for these rights to be guaranteed, the institutions themselves place barriers to access to employment and professional development for the most vulnerable. We defend that our social model is precisely the differential fact of Europe: a model of fair, inclusive and guaranteeing well-being of equal opportunities for all. These employment quotas are further a guarantee to allow the real independence of these people, and we believe that from here we must be an example for society and other institutions. We cannot ask the private sector to do the same if we do not comply first from the public sphere.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – There are few and poor quality accessible databases on the number of applicants, how many workers with disabilities have been recruited, and why to reject applications. The unemployment rate of people with disabilities in the EU is two or three times higher than that of other citizens. And therefore, the creation of a quota system would be a positive but insufficient step. It is also necessary to apply personal assistance mechanisms to third parties, to acquire accessible software, to create technical aids of a technological nature, to ensure communication and physical accessibility. It is also necessary to monitor and monitor these conditions through public and regular mechanisms.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing – A society that respects the dignity of every person as absolute value should not be satisfied with the abbreviated solution posed by quotas when promoting the inclusion of people with disabilities. Their effect is only short-term, while at the same time questioning the fundamental principle of social inclusion, since they divide society. Let us therefore stop talking about quotas and focus on measures that will have a long-term effect. Inclusion must start already on the school benches, so that all children are given the same opportunity to start developing their talents and abilities, which they will be able to exercise later in the search for a job. And when selecting employees, it is necessary to introduce a transparent methodology and decision-making instead of quotas, complemented by a binding non-discriminatory definition of a job. People with disabilities do not need a crutch in the form of quotas, but a long-term solution that will not call into question their competence, hard work and determination.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – People with disabilities account for 16% of the European population. The participation and inclusion of persons with disabilities is a general principle of the United Nations Convention and a fundamental obligation of those who have signed it, including the European Union. People with disabilities are entitled to work. To ensure equality of persons with disabilities, it is essential to promote non-discrimination, accessibility and positive measures that make it easier for them to access work. The European institutions have a good system of guaranteeing access to positions within the organization chart for persons with disabilities. However, there is currently no quota system as there is no definition of 'person with a disability' in staff bylaws. Quota systems have been shown to be effective as an integrative instrument. Through quotas, we would make it easier for people with disabilities to access work. This is a positive measure that will save existing inequalities. The aim of quotas is to make them obsolete, but in the meantime it is necessary to ensure access.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the envisaged EU-Mexico PNR Agreement (2015/2653(RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all allow me to express my thanks for having given me the opportunity to make a statement on the issue of Mexico and passenger name record (PNR) data. I wish firstly to state that the Commission has always been committed to finding a legally sound European solution to the issue of transmitting PNR data for flights between the European Union and Mexico. Mexico has had legislation in force since November 2012 requiring all air carriers operating flights to and from Mexico to transmit PNR data. The competent authority in Mexico was therefore under the obligation from that date onwards to impose fines on those air carriers that do not transmit PNR data. Mexico tells us that EU carriers are the only ones not providing PNR data to the Mexican authorities. However, the Mexican legislation has not yet been enforced with regard to EU traffic, because the Commission has asked the competent authority in Mexico to postpone the imposition of fines on several occasions. But the competent authority in Mexico made it clear earlier this year that the final deadline for transferring PNR data was 1 April 2015. At this point it is important to mention Parliament’s decision in November last year to seek the opinion of the Court of Justice on whether the draft PNR agreement with Canada is compatible with the EU treaties. This opinion is not expected before the end of the year. The Commission therefore sought a further postponement of the 1 April 2015 deadline until such time as the Court of Justice issues its opinion. The competent authority in Mexico finally agreed to postpone the deadline until July 2015, provided that the European Union commits to start formal negotiations with a view to an agreement. I therefore, as soon as possible, intend to suggest to the College of Commissioners that the Commission request a mandate from the Council to formally open negotiations for a PNR agreement between the European Union and Mexico. It is clear that we will need to take into account the criteria and standards set out in the Court of Justice ruling on data retention of April 2014. This approach has been welcomed by Mexico and has enabled the Commission to secure the postponement of the sanctions from 1 April to 1 July of this year. The Commission should have a Council mandate to start negotiating before 1 July 2015. I have made it clear that negotiations on a PNR agreement with Mexico cannot be finalised before the Court of Justice has issued its opinion on the draft PNR agreement with Canada. The Mexican authorities are aware that this is the case. I have kept – and will continue to keep – Parliament informed. I wrote to the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), Mr Moraes, before 1 April, to inform him of the steps I intended to take to resolve the situation of conflict between the laws of Mexico and the European Union. I am thankful that today you have given the Commission the chance to update you on that matter, and I will inform you once the college has taken the decision to recommend adoption of the mandate.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, thank you very much, Commissioner, for the opinion, which makes it clear that the Commission will urgently ask the Council to release the negotiating mandate for the negotiations for an EU-Mexico PNR agreement. I would ask the Commissioner whether there is any reaction from the Council. It would be interesting to know that, because it is not a proposal that has only been in place since yesterday, but one that we have known a little longer. So the Council should now also come to a decision to give the Commission a negotiating mandate, so that we can then come to an end as soon as possible in the area of a PNR agreement with Mexico, in line with the opinion that the ECJ will give. Personally, I regret for the PPE-DE that we have some delay, because we ultimately have this problem. I thought we could decide for ourselves politically. However, it is essential for me that, on 1 July, we do not see our airlines in a situation where they have to pay USD 30,000 per flight, because this makes the de facto competitiveness of European airlines flying towards Mexico completely impossible. I therefore urge the Commission once again to call on the Council to give the negotiating mandate in concrete terms as soon as possible.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We have just heard that the legislation in Mexico on the receipt of PNR data is not new. However, I do not remember that, since 2002, we have been pushing for an agreement to be reached, and I would say for good reasons. European data protection law is clear: without a legal basis, the transfer of European data to third countries is illegal. On the one hand, I welcome the fact that Mexico is not currently demanding fines from European airlines that comply with this right. On the other hand, in the face of such demands, the question arises as to what is really at stake: better prosecution or simply economic interests? However, when the Commission is given a mandate by the Council to negotiate with Mexico, it must of course be borne in mind – as has been mentioned – that the European Court of Justice is currently subjecting the draft PNR agreement between the EU and Canada to a review of fundamental rights. This was necessary because, in its judgment on data retention, the European Court of Justice established a new and particularly rigorous fundamental rights check for bulk data storage. This House has doubts as to whether the agreement can meet these new requirements and has therefore referred the draft text to Luxembourg. Thus, no PNR agreement may be negotiated before the ECJ has delivered its opinion on the EU-Canada agreement. By the way, the negotiations with Canada have dragged on for more than five years. And – as Mr Avramopoulos has already mentioned – I too am sure that the ECJ will finish its opinion much more quickly. We also need clear principles for PNR agreements with third countries. After the negotiations on an agreement with Australia, some had believed that this could serve as a model for others. However, even the agreement with the United States contained less good conditions and received less support here in the European Parliament. A number of other countries, such as Russia, the United Arab Emirates and South Korea, are already knocking on the door, and it is precisely when third countries with weak data protection regimes want data that uniform and high minimum standards are indispensable. Finally, the Treaty of Lisbon gives the European Parliament the final say on international agreements. We, as MEPs, therefore have a responsibility to approve future PNR agreements only if they are in line with European fundamental rights and do not undermine them through the back door.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The US and Canada want our passenger data. In addition to personal data, these are also telephone numbers, credit card numbers, IP addresses — a great deal of very personal data. But if one puts his hands in the biscuit tin, the other wants it too. So now Mexico wants our data. If Lufthansa lands in Mexico City and does not reveal my data there because it is not allowed to do so, then Lufthansa now faces large fines. European airlines are therefore being held hostage so that the EU allows passenger data to be transferred. I am opposed to this transfer of data. We should protect citizens' data and make data protection a major. Customer data does not have to be addressed by either the EU or the Member States, especially other governments. Let us stop collecting passenger data at all: then we cannot pass it on, even to the United States and Canada.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his presence here and the fact that he has taken action. I also welcome the massive presence of the Council, who are clearly very interested in the matter. I have a lot of questions, Commissioner, and I have a lot of confidence in your contacts with the Mexicans. However, you know that legislation has been in place in Mexico since November 2012. Some of the colleagues here said that we have failed to raise the issue. Well, I would like to give you a little selection here of the actions that I have taken. On 31 May 2013, I tabled written questions to the Commission on Russia’s demand for Passenger Name Record (PNR) data, asking the Commission also which other third countries intended to collect PNR data. We got a reply that by then Qatar, Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Japan and South Korea also showed an interest in PNR systems. Somewhat later we learned of the deadline set by Mexico, which was for 1 January 2014. So, on 5 December 2013 – a month before the deadline – I put parliamentary questions to the Commission regarding the deadline and did not get any satisfactory reply. However, the deadline was postponed until 30 September 2014. On 9 April 2014, I wrote a letter both to the Commission and the Council on the urgency of third countries asking for PNR, including Mexico and the other countries. On 18 September 2014, I wrote a letter to the Commission specifically on Mexico PNR because confusion had arisen concerning the date of the Mexico PNR deadline. I got a reply from the Commission in mid-October stating that the new deadline was set for 1 January 2015, etc., etc. The rest is history. On 9 March 2015, I raised it in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. So yes, colleagues, we have raised the matter and I completely fail to understand why the Commission and the current Commissioner’s predecessors have been sitting on their hands ever since. Two further questions: it is clear that even if the postponement of the deadline to 1 July 2015 is very welcome, we are not going to have an agreement by then. What will the Commission do in order to ensure the legal protection of citizens on the one hand and avoiding heavy fines for carriers on the other? Incidentally, I know that not only have I been asking questions but the countries concerned and the carriers have almost been imploring the European Commission to act, and the Commission has not. We have also asked questions about Mexico passing on PNR data to the United States. We have not got an answer to that. Finally, I would like to know from the Commission: how are you going to fill the gap? How are you going to ensure protection for citizens and carriers? What action is the Commission going to take regarding the other countries that I mentioned, such as Russia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and other friendly nations? Then I would like to get a full report on the situation regarding those other countries.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the To date, there is no COMPLIANCE with EU law, no evaluation of the extent to which PNR can be classified. To date, we have nothing at all to prove that this is a necessary instrument. Fundamental rights – I thought we agreed on this – cannot be negotiated and we cannot be used to avoid fines. Mexico, if I may say so, is one of the most dangerous states in the world, with one of the highest rates of political murders, kidnappings and almost open cooperation between state authorities and the mafia. What Mexico really needs is consistent prosecution and punishment for these crimes, but not the PNR data of Lieschen Müller from Berlin. The threat of fines is extortion. To give in to this is to hand over the fundamental rights of European citizens to the mafia. Why do we not also supply the PNR data to South Sudan, to the Congo? Apart from that, it is not possible to prosecute the airlines at the moment, purely legally, because there is no law for them. No-fly bans, as announced, would be more of a shot in the country's knee. I think that what we are doing here is a scandal, and I think that there must finally be an evaluation of the purpose of this instrument.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Thank you very much, Commissioner, for the outline. Mr President, I think it is very clear, and the Commissioner underlined this, that there is no way that in this Parliament we will get an agreement before we have the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the Canada agreement, because this is a matter of principle that we have to discuss not only in the context of this agreement, but also of several other agreements which are in place or remain to be negotiated, and with regard to our own laws on the retention and analysis of Passenger Name Records (PNR). Here we come to the principle: in our constitutional framework, in our Treaty and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights it is written that there is a fundamental right to data protection and a constitutional principle which states that every intrusion into this fundamental right needs to be justified. In a democratic society, it has to be necessary. That means that we have to discuss how far the collection and analysis of Passenger Name Records, like any other personal data, is justified. We need to discuss whether it is really justified to collect and analyse automatically all data for all passengers, or if instead we should focus on threat, risk and suspicion and demand that those principles be respected by our partners who demand from us that our citizens send data. This is because everything we agree on, and every agreement with third countries, always needs to be based on our Treaty, on our Charter of Fundamental Rights and our constitutional principles. We cannot negotiate them as if they were just something to balance things out. They are there, we have to respect them and we also have to demand that our partners respect them.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current absence of a bilateral agreement between the European Union and Mexico on the transfer of PNR data currently determines the situation that European airlines cannot transfer PNR data to the Mexican authorities without committing any violation of European data protection legislation. At the same time, however, in view of this refusal, we have seen that they risk exposing themselves to heavy financial penalties which the Mexican authorities are threatening to impose. We believe that the use of the threat of onerous fines is not only to be strongly condemned, because it actually forces the decision-making and negotiating power of the European institutions, but that it may also set a dangerous precedent, given that already many other third countries, such as South Korea and the United Arab Emirates, Russia are praying for the conclusion of PNR agreements with the European Union. The European Union has now concluded pnr data transfer agreements with the United States, Canada and Australia. We know that before giving its assent to the ratification of the agreement, the European Parliament recently referred the agreement itself to the Court of Justice for an opinion on its compatibility with European data protection legislation. Of course, this issue is extremely sensitive: even in recent days, with regard to the debate on the European PNR, a number of critical issues and concerns have emerged in relation to the protection of fundamental rights, in particular the protection of personal data and freedom of movement. There are many points which deserve further study and which have led to the Commission's request for a ruling on the substance of the matter on compatibility with the judgment of the European Court of Justice, which declared the directive on retention of data to be unlawful for breach of the principle of proportionality in the balance between the right to data protection and public security requirements. It is first necessary to identify what is meant by PNR data, that is, what kind of data are intended to be included and therefore transferred; that there are criteria for differentiating the duration of data retention; that there are substantial and procedural preconditions for access to data; and finally, which authorities are responsible for accessing and processing the data. It is therefore clear that the examination of these criteria requires time and caution. The caution of public security, in the name of which the transfer of PNR data is strongly requested, cannot put the protection of fundamental rights in the alternative. We therefore ask the Commission what measures it intends to take to ensure that the transfer of PNR data to Mexico is in line with European data protection rules; whether it intends to take steps to ensure that air carriers do not risk high fines or the withdrawal of landing rights when Mexican legislation comes into force. And finally, if you are aware of a sharing agreement between Mexico, the United States and Canada and, if so, what consequences this agreement will have with regard to the personal data transferred by air carriers to the Mexican authorities, and above all what possible legal remedies European citizens will have in the event of a violation of their rights relating to the processing of personal data. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Karol KARSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I agree with the speaker that threatening to impose penalties on European carriers is simply a denial of the principle of negotiations. I therefore also have a question for the speaker: do you not think that, if such penalties were actually imposed, the European Union should impose economic and political sanctions on Mexico?

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Answer to a blue card question. Thank you for your speech, which allows me to reiterate how regrettable it is and to condemn absolutely the use of a threat which, as Cornelia Ernst also said, is in fact blackmail that the Mexican authorities impose on the European institutions. It is not the correct modus operandi, it is not the way to act that must be undertaken in bilateral agreements between the European Union, so there is a firm and decisive condemnation on our part.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, I am opposed on the form and substance of the draft PNR agreement with Mexico. On form, I denounce the weakness with which the European Union is about to give in to the diktat of Mexico. Mexico had ordered him to sign the agreement by April 1. On 27 March, the Commissioner for Migration, Mr Avramopoulos, shamefully gave in and obtained a postponement of the Mexican ultimatum to 1 July. After that date, airlines will be fined $30,000 per flight to Mexico by Mexico.  On the merits, I condemn this PNR agreement, which will seriously invade the privacy of passengers, in violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the judgment of the Court of Justice of 8 April 2014. The PNR agreement with Canada, which is also a problem, has just been referred to the Court of Justice by Parliament.  It is not by globalizing millions of honest people who fly that terrorism will be effectively combated.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, this is a sovereign decision by the Government of the United Mexican States. With extension. What's the way forward? The Commissioner has already said so. The way forward is to ask for the negotiating mandate— Article 218—to start the negotiation and conclude the negotiation. It's that easy. And that's complicated, considering the sentence. But, Mr President, we have not even asked for the negotiating mandate. And the negotiating mandate must be requested at the JHA Council in June. Only this immediate possibility we have to fulfil our obligations to start negotiations by 1 July. An informational fact. Do you know what iberia company in my country does? Fly twice a day to Mexico. Fly seven days a week to Mexico. It flies every day of the month. If the sanctions are applied, every week it will cost Iberia 230 000 euros. Do you realize what this means in the field of trade relations? Something truly inesumable. Do you realize that if there is no Community response each Member State will be able to use its sovereign power to transmit PNR data to another sovereign State requesting it in the field of security and taking into account the preservation of privacy? In any case, Mr President, what I am asking Mr Avramopoulos now - and I have here the press release of the Mexican authorities of the last days of March - what I am asking is that, since you have trusted him, to initiate the request for the opening of negotiations as soon as possible, that is, at the JHA Council in June.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Mr President, you all know that, after Paris, European governments throughout Europe increasingly feel the need to protect their citizens. The threat of terrorism, say governments, threatens us all and therefore different measures are needed. One of the most important of these measures is that governments, or at least many governments, are able to exchange data and registration data on passengers involved in air traffic. I think that this is an important initiative, but at the same time I also think that this important initiative must not lead to the surrender of the fundamental rights on which the European Union, the European Community, is built. We must respect privacy, the protection of personal data and ensure effective remedies. And at least since I saw on television John Oliver's "Last Week Tonight" show interviewing Edward Snowden, who talked about how this data is being moved between Ireland and the United States, I have been at least skeptical about whether these results, these passenger name records, actually respect fundamental human rights.  Nevertheless, I think it is very important that Mexico wants to join this agreement, I think it is important that we take this seriously, that we start negotiations as soon as possible, that we achieve results as soon as possible. At the same time, we must not conclude or sign conventions that do not comply with European law, European law and European standards. I therefore think that it is very important to wait for the legal procedure for the Agreement between the European Union and Canada to be completed, so that there is a reliable result, a legally clear, clear, unambiguous resolution, and then we will be able to conclude the agreement with other countries outside Europe. We must not forget that we cannot afford, politically or morally, to use people's fears to deprive them of their fundamental human rights by elysing people's fears.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, the EU authorities should not hand over passenger name records to Mexico. Last November, the EU referred the proposed EU—Canada PNR agreement to the Court of Justice for a preliminary ruling on its compliance with EU charters, agreements and treaties and we are still awaiting that ruling. It makes no sense to adopt similar data retention measures while a real possibility remains that the Court of Justice may rule against the EU-Canada PNR agreement.  Furthermore, an invasive blanket retention measure such as an EU-Mexico PNR would collect all data from travellers flying between the EU and Mexico, the vast majority of whom have no links whatsoever to any formal criminal suspicion. Targeted law enforcement focusing on suspects already known to the relevant authorities respects the rule of law and is, after all, more effective.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, Mexico is only one example of countries that are introducing legislation regulating PNR collection.
