Like other Members of this Parliament, I also asked the Commission what the plans to deal with each situation are, so I know that Mexico, Russia, South Korea, Japan, Brazil, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Israel, Indonesia and Argentina at least have asked, or intend to ask, for PNR data. The Commission answered that while waiting for the Court of Justice decision on the agreement with Canada, it is up to Member States and national data protection authorities to assess the conditions and decide on what passenger data their air carriers can lawfully transfer to a third country.  I understand that you are waiting, and I believe that the EU solution is very necessary. Without the EU solution we risk that EU citizens will either have no appropriate guarantees for their personal data, or we risk that fines will negatively influence ticket prices and airlines. We need this solution first of all because of security reasons, so we need the agreement with Mexico, but not only with Mexico – it is important to have a much broader solution due to law, due to decisions of the court, oriented on security goals and the rules for data protection. That is why I believe that the EU solution is needed and I wanted to ask the Commission what, apart from the solution with Mexico, are the different possibilities for such an EU solution?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very glad that the Commissioner is in this House so often, because it also shows that there is an appreciation of our work. In all these discussions, the term PNR keeps popping up in a variety of contexts. We have dealt with this intensively in the resolution on the fight against terrorism. Of course, PNR is an interference with fundamental rights. Violations of fundamental rights must be accepted under certain conditions in the fight against terrorism, but they must be in line with the case law, they must be case-by-case and proportionate. I have the impression that sometimes, even under a certain amount of pressure, agreements are concluded very lightly and quickly and that they do not focus so much on the quality of these agreements. As a result, these various pieces of legislation will then be viewed critically and repealed, as we have seen with data retention. That is why, in November 2014, we decided in this House that we wanted to submit the passenger data agreement with Canada to the ECJ, because we had serious concerns, particularly in the area of data protection. I agree with my colleague, Mrs Sippel, that it actually makes sense to wait and not to take another quick shot straight away. If we consider that this discussion is now also taking place from the point of view that we are actually being pressured from outside, then we have a kind of foreign-determinedness in our own discussions on issues that we have to decide ourselves. I am bothered by the time pressure. What is the difference between July and December? I am bothered by the nature of this blackmail. Not even the United States has threatened us. This is the first time that anyone has threatened us. I am also disturbed by the fact – and I am also responsible for the urgent questions on human rights violations on my group – that in this catalogue, this pipeline of the countries that are now coming to us, we have all the countries that we have already dealt with in this House with human rights violations. I do not know whether this is a very good premise. That is why I believe that it would be useful to allow this short period of time and to adopt a sensible measure.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, I think we have to be clear and here, in the end, what we are talking about is giving in, of lowering our data protection standards because airlines are asking for it, because these big companies are asking for it. I think it is important to recall that, in 2013, the Committee on Freedoms of this European Parliament has already rejected the proposal for a Directive on the use of traveller data. And I understand that this is, or should be, above the wishes and demands of airlines. Neither airlines should flag us our data protection policy, nor is the blackmail of the Government of Mexico acceptable. We are obviously concerned that our data may be in the hands of a state with institutions penetrated by drug trafficking, a state where human rights are violated and with high rates of impunity. And, by the way, a question: what will happen to our personal data if, finally, this agreement is signed? Will it be traded with our data? Because, without a doubt, data is now a big deal. Will our data also end up in the hands of multinationals in the United States and Canada for use?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, Mexico, a priority partner of the European Union, has a very advanced PNR system and has been asking PNR data for PNR data for European citizens for more than reasonable time. In the absence of agreement, a moratorium was established. Later, another one. And another, which expired on April 1, at which point Mexico decided to sanction airlines for not providing this data. Thanks to the constructive attitude of the Mexican authorities in the negotiations with the Commission, an agreement has been reached to delay this mandatory data delivery obligation to 1 July. Those are the facts. What we have been given is a respite, but the problem has not been solved, and everyone in this House knows what it is. We urgently need a European PNR, because this is a necessary instrument for protecting our citizens from terrorist attacks. Proof of this is that many other countries have it. As Chair of the Delegation to the EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, I am particularly concerned about this issue. And I address those who opposed and oppose the PNR, who must know that acts have consequences. And when, a year ago, they applauded that this valid instrument was not approved, they did not think that today we would be putting at risk not only the protection of our citizens, but also the normal functioning of our airlines. Ladies and gentlemen, irresponsibility is paid for. And I think we've had time in Europe. What not everyone has is a willingness to have a European PNR. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask you this question as head of Parliament's delegation to the EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee. I understand that everyone who leads similar delegations is committed to the issues of that relation, but am I sure, Congresswoman, that at the moment this convention is sufficiently circumstants?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: "blue card" response. "Yes, I agree that this agreement, as you say, poses problems. And, in fact, the Mexican authorities have been warning for a long time and making moratoriums, and precisely for the sake of that goodwill is when they have said that we will have another moratorium again. But why? Because it has been said that it will be negotiated, that it will be done. If you don't even see anything on our part... Because if you don't want to do this PNR, what we should be telling you we're not going to do. But there are a lot of people in this House and a lot of citizens who vote for us who do. So I don't agree so much that we have to tell them that. We'll have to tell them we're going to do it, but we're not getting it yet. And that's why they've given us another moratorium. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – Ms Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, I was a bit surprised to hear your warm endorsement of transferring data to the Mexican authorities because, quite frankly – I only read the newspapers about Mexico, I have not been there – but the Mexican police do not give me a lot of reasons to have trust in their ability to protect our fundamental rights. I would really like to know whether you feel that the Mexican authorities are able to uphold our standards, whether you have that level of trust in the Mexican authorities, and in the Mexican police in particular.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, I have to say yes, I deposit it. That I place so much confidence because I know Mexico, as you said. I know how they look and how they deal with all the relationships they have with the police and I agree that they have a great point of impunity, as has also been mentioned, and are on track to resolve it. Many other countries would like to have the openness that the authorities have when we go there and when we ask them for any information or something else. Something that other countries, also in those regions, do not have, and that is never reported here.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Colleagues Hohlmeier and in't Veld have already asked the relevant questions on this whole topic. I very much welcome the postponement of the deadline by Mexico to 1 July, but I would also like to encourage the Commission and you in particular to continue to talk to the Mexican authorities here. In two and a half months, this time is already over. This does not seem to me to be sufficient. Over the years, we have gained all these experiences on how to deal with PNR and these contracts. I believe that the political will should also be there here. The relevant question, in my view, is: how can we prevent our European airlines from being ultimately burdened with additional penalties because we have so far failed to respond to requests from Mexico? This has competition and economic consequences. Mexico is a sovereign state and simply wants to know who is coming to its country – a desire that I think is legitimate. It is also an attempt to filter out criminals. Of course, we need to balance the data protection issues. But we have gained experience.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, first of all, let me thank the Presidency for watching our debate with such great interest. If we are talking about PNR data, we are talking about very sensitive data of our citizens, which is why I am very glad that they are so interested in it.  In the current EU PNR negotiations, we place great emphasis on this. Not only can mexico's decision threaten the fundamental rights of our citizens, but its impact on European airlines can be disastrous.  That is why, here, I am trying to urge the European Commission and, above all, you, Commissioner, to do everything in your power to establish a dialogue with Mexico. In order for the current dialogue to be about cooperation and Mexico to consider the introduction of eu PNR in relation to European countries. Because I think it is important that European PNR and Mexican PNR are essentially followed up and that these systems work together.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I believe that a partnership with Mexico and other countries on the matter of PNR is compatible with European Union data protection rules and, with guarantees from both parties, is essential in order to address today’s global security challenges. The collection of personal data with detailed safeguards is a measure that we need to adopt in order to counter the threat of terrorism and to ensure the effective implementation of the European Security Strategy. This is why I believe that we need to move towards a European passenger name record system as well. Therefore, I strongly support the Commission’s agreement with Mexico on the transfer of PNR data, and with other countries as well. We have to take any measure in order to assure the security and the protection of our citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Commissioner, as you pointed out, the European Union-Mexico PNR agreement, according to which personal data will be exchanged between airline passengers travelling from the European Union to Mexico and vice versa, must be based on the standards of European Union law. In other words, firstly, the rights of citizens of the European Union protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights must be respected, the principle of proportionality must be respected and the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union in relation to the retention of personal data must also be respected. Finally, we must wait for the opinion of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the European Union-Canada PNR Agreement. Therefore, before this opinion is adopted, there cannot be a sufficient legal basis to start negotiations with Mexico. Finally, I wonder whether Mexico is a safe country that can guarantee the protection of personal data that will fall into the hands of the Mexican authorities. This is a country dominated by corruption, organised crime, extortion and kidnapping. I wonder where the personal data of airline passengers will ultimately end up if they fall into the hands of the authorities and the police in Mexico.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, we ask for the protection of the privacy of citizens of the European Union. No one else can decide that but in this case the court will decide. We are also looking for the protection of our economy.  I wonder, Mr. Commissioner, does Europe really have any levers and some opportunities to respond to such blackmails? Maybe there's something else to be said. Maybe the world is changing, thou. Perhaps it is the European Union, which brought the 28 countries together, to be the ones to initiate new processes when it comes to these issues and these values. I think that your role and the role of the Commission and the role of the European Union in this context is extremely large in this world that is clearly changing on a daily basis.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, I would like to draw attention to one circumstance. Of course, we will wait for the ruling of the European Court of Justice, but the question of respect for our standards is not only a question of what kind of data can be transferred externally, but also to whom can it be transferred? After all, there is no doubt that, since we have 200 countries in the world, not everyone is able to meet the standards that we want to maintain here. The transfer of the same type of data to different countries may therefore be justified in one case, in another unjustified. In this case, we are dealing with Mexico, which we may have serious doubts about how this data will be used. Therefore, if the European Court of Justice finds, for example, that certain types of data may be transferred to Canada, it does not mean that the same type of data should be transferred to Mexico or similar countries.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: Μέλος της Επιτροπής. – Κύριε Πρόεδρε, θα ήθελα να ξεκινήσω λέγοντας ότι η Επιτροπή είναι θεματοφύλακας των Συνθηκών, των θεμελιωδών αρχών και των θεμελιωδών δικαιωμάτων και ότι όλη της η προσπάθεια εδράζεται σε αυτά που πριν από λίγο επισήμανα και στον σεβασμό της νομολογίας, εν αναμονή βεβαίως της γνωμοδότησης του Ευρωπαϊκού Δικαστηρίου για να προχωρήσει πιο πέρα. Speaking in English again, I would first of all once again like to express my thanks for this exchange of views. For me it was very useful and I am grateful to all those who took the floor. Given the remarks you made and the questions you asked, I would like once again to make it clear that the concerns and the role of Parliament are respected. The negotiations on a PNR agreement with Mexico cannot be finalised before the Court of Justice has issued its opinion on the draft PNR agreement with Canada.  I would like also to comment on what Ms in tʼVeld said. As I explained, provided that we formally start negotiations with Mexico, they will suspend the fines. It was very clear on their side. My intention is to launch them myself at the end of June. There is goodwill from the Mexican authorities and mutual commitment to reach a legally sound agreement. Since I was the one who negotiated with the Mexican authorities, I can tell you – and I can assure you – that I did not feel that I was being blackmailed. On the contrary, I found interlocutors of good faith. Ms Hohlmeier also made a point which I would like to make reference to. As you know, I discussed my strategy with the Ministers of the Interior in the Justice and Home Affairs Council and the Ministers who spoke welcomed this approach. I am receiving positive signals from Member States in all my contacts.  As I said at the beginning, this is a firm choice to work towards a European solution, a European approach which guarantees more efficiently both the security and the protection of the fundamental rights of citizens. We are already working towards a consistent approach, Ms in tʼ Veld, for all future PNR requests. We will discuss this in the framework of the EU agenda on security.  Finally, it is important to engage with our partners on security issues, and Mexico is one of them. I listened to your comments about Mexico. Let me tell you that, as I said at the beginning, the Mexican authorities are determined to work very closely with us and they have given the necessary assurances on the protection of all this data. Anyway, we shall come back very soon and I look forward to an official discussion on the matter. Mr Weidenholzer also made a remark which I would like to comment on. It is true that I come to the European Parliament very often – not just because of the nature of my dossier, and the fact that I really need to discuss matters with you, but also because deep down inside me I have never stopped feeling a parliamentarian myself.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner, for this important statement on an extremely important issue that appalls many of us, and we are pleased that the Lord has come to us again. I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – Several countries in the world have, or are developing, PNR. Unfortunately, the Union and its Member States have allowed such a process to reach a limit. But let it be clear: not because of this Parliament. It is up to us to ensure the rights of European citizens, be it security or privacy.  I therefore welcome the compromise reached by Commissioner Avramopoulos with the Mexican authorities, but now it is time to act. The Commission should rapidly obtain a mandate to negotiate the Agreement. There is an urgent need to prevent European airlines from being sanctioned, but it is no less urgent to avoid bilateral agreements between Member States and Mexico. It would be a dangerous precedent for future agreements.  A horizontal approach to PNR agreements, as the Commission has already advocated, is also imperative. The personal data of our citizens must benefit from a high level of protection anywhere in the world and we must avoid situations of uncertainty and legal vacuum that challenge the economy and thousands of workers. I reiterate my scepticism towards the PNR systems, but if there are countries that want to impose them, it is the Union's obligation to ensure that the levels of protection enjoyed by its citizens are the universal reference.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – The meaning of our common European market lies in the free movement of people and goods across the Member States of the European Union. Not all countries have been fortunate enough in the past to make economic progress that allows them to pay wages at the same level as in Germany, for example. Small carriers from Slovakia as well as other neighbouring countries have successfully established themselves on European markets in the last ten years. As a result, they are increasing employment in their countries and contributing their own part to the growth of the entire European Union. So let us not take away their earnings, let us not increase costs and let us not create unnecessary barriers. Let us not re-build the Iron Curtain between east and west, this time commercial. German legislation sets a precedent because it imposes wages on employees of other countries. I am upholding the principles of free movement in our common European market, which is why, even today, from this position, I call on the European Commission to act in this case and to suspend German restrictions that are detrimental to citizens.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, state aid procedures employed by the Commission to vet commercial and economic decisions need to be reappraised drastically. It is increasingly failing to recognise that the single market is a fractured one. Peripheral regions with limited endowments have been subjected to competition from areas where vastly superior resources prevail. Traditional small-scale occupations run by micro-enterprises are not allowed protective breathing space. There is a refusal to recognise that state entrepreneurship can be a valid tool in peripheral regions by which to promote new economic activity or to sustain old and dying activities. All this is unfair and is mistaken.  Some economic activities of peripheral regions – islands, coastal and mountain areas – need state subsidies if we want them to survive. Relatively marginal activities in peripheral economies, which account for a minimum percentage of overall turnover in the European single market, should be exempted from state aid criteria when investment and commercial measures are being taken in their favour. But decisions are increasingly relying on one-size-fits-all methods. In a Europe which should stand for the welfare of all citizens there should be no place for state aid rules that seek fairness for big enterprises and deny support to small and traditional concerns.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, asbestos was banned in Europe in 1999, but cases of asbestos-related diseases remain high. The World Health Organisation estimates that it is between twenty and thirty thousand a year, a very large number which shows that asbestos unfortunately continues to produce dramatic effects and is still present at several sites. Some two years after the adoption of Parliament's resolution on the threat to health linked to asbestos, no progress has yet been made by the Commission, from which we are still awaiting the development of a model for the systematic collection of data on diseases, professional and non-occupational, linked to asbestos. It is regrettable that there is still a Europe-wide lack of registers or inventories of asbestos-containing sites and their removal plans, as requested and called for by the European Parliament in its 2013 resolution. The time has come for the Commission to act more effectively by complying with the demands made in the last parliamentary term for a revision of European legislation in this regard, not least in order to make clean-up plans compulsory for states.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On Friday, April 10th – let the President know – Poles celebrated the 5th anniversary of one of the most tragic events in their history, the anniversary of the Smolensk tragedy, in which Polish President Lech Kaczyński and many memorable people died. Although it has been five years, the wreckage of the plane, black boxes, numerous other evidence are still in Russian hands. A growing number of independent experts and renowned scientists are expressing far-reaching doubts about the official findings of the causes of this disaster. Recently, a book on the subject of the well-known investigative journalist Jürgen Rott was published in Germany.  We have talked a lot in this House about the need for solidarity with Ukraine in the face of Russian aggression, and today members of this Parliament have also spoken about this, who in 2010 had many illusions about Vladimir Vladimir Putin and Russia, knowing what he is capable of and what Putin's propaganda is. There is therefore no longer any reason to trust Putin and the Russian justice system in this single case, the case of the disaster in which Democratic President Polish, a member of the European Union, was killed. Poland also needs European solidarity, the help of international experts and an international investigation. That is what I would like to call on you to do: solidarity and help.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - European tourism accounts for 10% of the GDP of Europe's economy. 1.8 million companies today in Europe employ a huge number of our fellow citizens living off tourism.  However, tourism is not present enough in this house, it is not sufficiently present in the documents we receive from the European Commission. There are a number of examples for this, one of those examples being the latest discussions over the so-called juncker fund and the financing of tourism from it. Europe today is 52% part of world tourism. Destination where 52% of tourists come, and in 2030 it is expected to be only 41%. That is why we must institutionalise tourism as an economic branch that will also have its proper bodies at European Union level.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – On 31 March, the milk quotas were out. Despite all the protests, a regime ended that, despite its shortcomings, allowed a minimally fair distribution of the right of each state and each region to be able to produce and guarantee minimum levels of self-supply. The soft landing mechanism of the last ten years points us to what's going to happen. The liberalised market will create enormous difficulties for countries where context costs are higher, further concentrating production in northern and central Europe. I was this week in the Azores, one of the outermost territories, where the dairy sector accounts for about half of the regional GDP. It is therefore an entire economy that is at risk. I call on the European Commission for the need to set up extraordinary support mechanisms to deal with a social emergency currently underway, with prices paid below production costs. I call for the need to create an alternative mechanism that can regulate supply and give safety and decent living conditions to our producers.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – The Committee on Rural Affairs, which is responsible for genetically modified organisms, adopted a historic decision in the Lithuanian Parliament today, which has been decided that Lithuania will fully seek to become a state prohibiting the cultivation of GMOs by means of Directive 412 of the European Union. The Seimas of Lithuania also undertakes to look for measures to restrict the placing of GMO feed on the Lithuanian market. I welcome this rational solution, which should serve as an example for the other Member States. For my part, I call on all the institutions of the European Union to accept this will expressed by the citizens' consumers in an honour and to ensure that each Member State can distance itself from the cultivation of GMOs in its territories. I would like to appeal to both the European Parliament and the Commission so that the procedures governing the will of The Member States to choose the status of a free-range country from GMOs are not subject to exaggerated bureaucratic requirements, and states have a real, not only theoretical, theoretical opportunity to really distance themselves from GMOs.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 14 years later, the European Court of Human Rights has condemned Italy for a crime of torture in connection with what happened at the Diaz school during the G8 in Genoa. The sentence imposed on Italy is a double sentence: both torture of demonstrators and the lack of adequate legislation to sanction this inhuman offence and prevent others are recognised. A legislative vote that allows those who commit this crime to go unpunished. In Italy, the recognition and introduction of the crime of torture has been dragging on for over two years. Two further appeals are brought before the Strasbourg courts for the beatings and humiliations inflicted during the events in Genoa. In those days, something reprehensible happened for a Western democracy: the most basic human rights were trampled underfoot, particularly those enshrined in Article 3 of the European Union Convention on Human Rights, which prohibit torture, punishment, inhuman or degrading treatment. Judgments such as these show that respect for human rights is not taken for granted in civilised Europe, the European institutions have a duty to strengthen and make more effective the mechanisms for monitoring, preventing and suppressing violations of fundamental rights in the Member States.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the European Union expects a large-scale recovery of its economy from the Fund for Strategic Investments. Economic growth alone is not a value, which is why it is important that job creation is one of the primary considerations. Small and medium-sized enterprises account for 67% of jobs in the EU. They should therefore be given priority support. We were pleased to read that the draft legislation submitted by the Commission aims to make better access to finance best for small and medium-sized enterprises. However, the following sentence states that it is appropriate to extend this to companies with a maximum of 3 000 employees. In other words, with this sentence, it effectively defines the medium-sized enterprise category as 3,000 instead of 250, and thus it turns out that the real support for real small and medium-sized enterprises remains a slogan, but a phrase.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, on 2 April 149 people were murdered at Garissa University in Kenya. Most were students, and survivors say they were attacked and shot by Al-Shabab terrorists, who attacked and shot the victims, became engañated with Christian students. The accounts of this massacre are terrible and should make us all, governments and international organizations, but also society as a whole, reflect on whether we are doing enough to contain the religious persecution that Christians in many parts of the world suffer. A few months ago, we received Pope Francis in this Chamber. He himself alerted to this situation and asked the international community not to remain silent, not to look the other way at these murders. I ask you not to remain indifferent to this injustice. Let us all call for decisive Action by the European Union, greater involvement and leadership, at the international level, to show that from Europe we are determined to fight relentlessly for human rights.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – We need the certainty that the Juncker Plan will help to balance European development. The principles of its application must be solidarity, fairness, transparency and, above all, the fight against inequalities. It is clear that we need fair control of the funding initiated by the Juncker Investment Plan and I am calling, in this direction, for a rethinking of the system for approving projects submitted for funding. Large infrastructure must remain a priority and, in this respect, the strategy must look at the overall need to connect the European Union's border areas with the centre. Discussions on the multiplier of European public investment covered by the Juncker Plan, the possibility of reducing European funding for research, the potential unequal distribution of funds and how they can contribute to increasing disparities between European regions are all factors that make it necessary to closely consider the Juncker Plan. Investment and action are needed at European level. However, we must ensure that these guarantees and actions taken to that end will work and will not be an unnecessary tax burden.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I have a simple question for the Commission concerning an application for registration as a protective designation of origin concerning an agricultural product, a traditional cheese called halloumi, or hallim. The application was made by the Republic of Cyprus. It was made for the entire island, but we all know that there is a part of the island which is beyond the control of the authorities of the Republic of Cyprus. Therefore, it is necessary to introduce a compliance mechanism as otherwise those who live in the part which is beyond the control of the Cypriot authorities will not benefit from it and a very substantial number of people are dependent on that particular production. So my question is whether, and how, the Commission plans to introduce the compliance mechanism into that application?

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – Citizens' social rights to work with fair pay, health, social security, etc. are currently in the crosshairs of austerity policies and risk being sacrificed on the altar of fiscal - supposedly - consolidation. Twenty-two MEPs from three different political groups, we highlighted the fact in our question and called on the European Commission to treat the Union's accession to the European Social Charter as a means of upgrading the protection of social rights. Today, four months late, Commissioner Thyssen replied that the Treaty on European Union refers to the European Social Charter. I inform the Commissioner that, in October last year, the European Council, in response to my own question on the violations of the European Social Charter by the Troika in Greece, found by the Charter Committee, declared itself incompetent and therefore, in essence, indifferent to those violations. The bilingualism of the Commission and the Council threatens the foundations of the Union.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, on 15 June 2011 there was a major demonstration in Barcelona, which surrounded the building of the Parliament of Catalonia, and there were insults, threats and some aggression on Members. The police didn't stop anyone. Subsequently, eight young people were indicted, who were not accused of any violent or aggressive acts, because the culprits could not really be found. After three years, the National Hearing acquitted the defendants. But recently, Spain's Supreme Court has reviewed the ruling, and despite accepting nonviolent, non-aggressive events, has sentenced them all to three years in prison. This sentence is literally outrageous, because it criminalizes freedom of expression, demonstration and social protest, even if it is energetic. I would like to record here the shame that the Democrats are faced with the increasing and continued degradation of Spanish justice in favour of certain political and ideological positions.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, you have decided to support the Council's decision to set up an Employment Committee to monitor the achievement of the high employment rate target, to prepare reports and make recommendations on social policy.  Don't you feel at all disconnected from reality? Let me share with you the old Indian proverb of the Dakota Tribe: "If you find out you're riding a dead horse, sit down." Yes, let's set up a horse analysis committee. Let's explore how to ride dead horses elsewhere in the world. Let's adjust the standards for a dead horse. Let's create a fund to encourage dead horses. Let's do an information campaign about proper riding on dead horses. Let's make a strategy and action plan to revive the horse.  Folks, the European Union is the dead horse. If we want to go in front, we have to admit the problem and disemerst.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the explosive dimensions of the problem of welcoming and supporting refugees and migrants fleeing to Greece, Italy and other countries, pushed by the imperialist interventions of the European Union, the USA, NATO and poverty, are documented in the most tragic way by the 400 dead off the coast of Libya.  The European Union and the capitalist system that it serves, create and recycle the problem with tools the regulations that must, here and now, be abolished. Dublin II and III, Schengen, FRONTEX, Eurodac, Directive No 136/66/EEC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 2002 on the protection of the 115, 2008, which provides for up to 18 months in prison, this is the anti-immigrant policy also implemented by the Greek government, keeping thousands of refugees and migrants bound for other countries trapped in inhumane conditions. We demand the creation of open reception and temporary accommodation centres, the abolition of concentration camps, travel documents for those bound for other Member States of the European Union, asylum for all refugees and the legalisation of migrants, especially those who have lived in the country for many years and have strong links to it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr Vice-President, I would like to draw attention to the tragedy that took place in Uherské Brod and its European dimension.  At the end of February this year, a tragedy occurred in a restaurant in Uherský Brod near the Czech-Slovak border. Eight people were left dead after the shooting of the insane gunman, who eventually turned the gun on himself and shot himself. I do not want to address national issues here, which are raised, for example, by the intervention of intervening police officers, but I would like to highlight a problem that has a European dimension.  The shooter was legally holding a firearm under Czech legislation. Let's imagine if he drove a few kilometers across the border and shot a restaurant in Slovakia like this. The possibility of bringing a weapon into the territory of a foreign EU Member State is a reality. At the same time, the conditions for obtaining a firearms licence vary widely across the EU. I think that, in the light of the tragedy in Uherský Brod, it is time for the Commission to start preparing EU legislation that will unite the Member States at least to minimum standards, for example in the parameters of medical examination for the possession of firearms. At the end of my speech, I would also like to express my personal participation to all the survivors.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, yesterday the European Commission approved, for the first time, a geographical indication for a Croatian product – Krk prosciutto – which made it on the list of 629 products protected by this label. This is a road map for small producers in Croatia who, without adequate protection of their products, cannot participate equally in the common European market with their products of unquestionable quality and geographical origin. Unfortunately, the current protection system omitted European producers of non-agricultural products. They are protected only at national level through legal frameworks not in line with Member States. Pag lace or Brač stone and stonemasonry, for example, are just some of the products that deserve better protection. Extending the geographical indication to non-agricultural products would increase their recognition, sales and protect consumers by more transparently informing them about the products they buy. I hope the Commission will take these arguments intole.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I allow myself to raise a topic before you – namely the protection of nature and, in particular, forests, as part of the environment, pointing to a specific example for you. I have shocking video footage that shows naked logging on a sixty-year-old pine forest above a Bulgarian village of Banya, Razlog municipality, Blagoevgrad region. Even more shocking is that this forest is destroyed in order to build a landfill in its place, and by European means. I wonder what the European Commission and the European taxpayer think of European money from its taxes being used to destroy a six-year-old pine forest and build a landfill. I think this is unacceptable, and I think spending European money on the destruction of nature and forest is, to put it mildly, unreasonable.  I believe that the European Commission should carefully investigate the facts, circumstances and documents surrounding the spending of European funds, in particular for the construction of this landfill in banya village, Razlog municipality, Blagoevgrad region.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, last autumn, at this forum, I drew attention to how the Romanian intelligence service had declared war on the autonomy of hungarians in Transylvania and the Hungarian region of Szeklerland in a completely unauthorised manner, with the intention of intimidation. This spring, the draft public security strategy of the Romanian Ministry of the Interior criminalised Hungarian minority autonomy by designating racism, xenophobia, extremism and all forms of intolerance aimed at achieving ethnic autonomy as the number one threat to citizens' security. I hereby reiterate my call for the moral and political protection of the European Parliament against the Romanian secret service, which has the tradition of Ceaușescu's infamous Securitate, in our legitimate and peaceful struggle for democratic minority self-determination.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we all know how Russia seized Crimea from Ukraine. We all know how the war started in eastern Ukraine, supported by Russia. Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians took refuge in the neighbouring countries. Hundreds of thousands of them are internally displaced. Millions of people in Ukraine are in need of humanitarian aid due to the combined impact of conflict displacement and extreme poverty. Returnees, refugees and internally displaced persons face shortages in food, health services, basic household items, clean water and shelter. Medicines are in alarmingly low supply.  As we know, the EU and its Member States have jointly contributed aid, directly or through different organisations and bodies. I would like to take advantage of the presence of the Commissioner to make an appeal to the Commission and Council to take additional measures and provide support, especially by increasing humanitarian aid for Ukrainian citizens.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Thank you, Mr President. Five years ago, President Polish Lech Kaczynski was bending. he understood the principle of European solidarity well, and affirmed it, considering it necessary to extend it further and further, through peaceful cooperation between states. However, it was extremely important in his opinion to maintain the pace of integration adapted to the level of development of societies, as well as the key preservation of the principle of democratic legitimacy of power. He opposed Russian neo-imperialism and warned against radical Islamism. His penetrating far-sighted views have resulted in extraordinary attacks by the media and political opponents. It is time to restore his thought to the international community in an uneasy form, because this community has served. Hi his memory!

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, the protracted economic crisis has clearly demonstrated how vulnerable the European financial system is in certain situations. That is why the European Union has introduced a number of measures that can guarantee the safety of citizens. One of the most important steps was to strengthen and unify financial supervisory systems in the euro area. However, the inadequate functioning of supervisory systems is a particular problem in many non-euro area Member States, such as Hungary and, more specifically, In Orbania. In recent weeks, two major companies in my country have had to be suspended: buda cash, which is suspected of falsified its reports for years, and Questor, which is suspected of issuing bonds worth up to HUF 150 billion, or almost half a billion euros, without authorisation or collateral. The Hungarian National Bank, which has not long been responsible for the state supervision of financial institutions in Orbania, has clearly failed in the exercise of this activity. In my view, the fact that the European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, has not been sufficiently attentive to this situation contributes greatly to this situation.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – "Summer totels and quail are the big losers in Malta." I fully endorse this quote from Bird Protection Flanders. Malta missed the historic opportunity in a referendum last Saturday to put an end to spring hunting for migratory birds. Malta's poor reputation in the implementation and enforcement of the Birds Directive is well known. While this island should be a haven for migratory birds due to its geographical location, in practice it is one of the main bottlenecks between Africa and Europe, and hunters kill large numbers of birds in both spring and autumn. This is manifestly contrary to European regulations. Malta was convicted by the European Court of Justice in 2009. I am now asking for a clear signal from the European Commission to stop this hunt in the short term. I also expect the Commission to make this irresponsible practice structurally impossible when the Birds Directive is revised, not only in Malta, but also in the rest of the European Union.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the explanations of vote.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 following the dismissal of 2 804 workers in France following the bankruptcy and closure of the Road Transport company Mory-Ducros. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation. It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and training to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving the application EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory-Ducros from France for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Following the legal liquidation of the French company Mory Global, announced on 31 March 2015, the French authorities requested assistance from the globalisation adjustment fund of 6,050,000 euros for the 2,513 workers dismissed. The economic and financial crisis is mentioned as the main cause of the company's bankruptcy. However, there is no word on the issue of intra-European competition and the deregulation of road freight transport, which promotes flexibility for industry players and puts High-burden French companies in competition with low-cost companies. In addition, this proposal envisages subjecting the sector to the seconded workers scheme. This will not solve the problem of the cost differential, since social security contributions will be paid in the country of the establishment of the company. This aid mechanism could therefore, in its logic, encourage redundancies. Despite this, as other solutions have not been considered, employees need this help for their retraining. So I voted in favour of the application.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for French use. The application concerns the allocation of EUR 6 052 200 from the EGF for French purposes. It will target 2513 workers made redundant from Mory-Ducros. According to the Bank of France, the annual number of bankruptcies in the road haulage sector increased by 35 % between 2007 and 2013. The global financial and economic crisis is estimated to have resulted in a 13.7% reduction in road freight transport by vehicles more than 3.5 t in the EU between 2007 and 2012 and 21% in France. The package of services for redundant workers will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training, and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In recent years, due in part to the financial crisis in the United States, volumes to be transported have declined, while gasoline prices have increased and a price war has broken out in the sector. In November 2013, Mory-Ducros, the former French number two in road transport, was declared insolvent before closing permanently in May 2014. While nearly half of its employees were rehired in a new company, more than 2,500 others remained on the job. I therefore supported France's request for aid of EUR 6,052,200 to these 2,513 ex-employees of Mory-Ducros. Between 2014 and 2020, the annual ceiling of the "globalization adjustment fund" was set at 150 million euros.  I remain convinced, however, that this money could be better used and that the European Union should first seek to address the causes rather than the consequences of the difficulties facing our companies, from unfair competition from non-COMMUNITY - and sometimes intra-community - enterprises to relocations that result from the stubborn refusal to take the necessary protectionist measures.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Many carriers have struggled to withstand declining volumes and falling freight rates following the 2008 economic and industrial crisis. This is particularly the case for the transport company Mory-Ducros, which has seen its turnover plummet in recent years. In bankruptcy, the company was taken over by a new entity - Mory Global - but 2,804 people will remain on the tile. The EGF's support, amounting to EUR 6,052,200, will enable the implementation of a major action plan and services to promote the reintegration of laid-off workers into the labour market.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of France's request to access the Globalisation Funds as a result of 2 513 redundancies made in Mory-Ducros SAS in 84 areas other than France belonging to the Land Transport and Pipeline sector because it meets the criteria required by the EAGF Regulation. These layoffs have been the result of the global economic and financial crisis and 17% of the dismissed are people between the age of 55 and 64 who have to be trained in order to join new jobs and prevent them from continuing into unemployment with a clear risk of exclusion.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The legal liquidation of Mory-Ducros is emblematic of the serious threats to jobs and the economy in France. While the main cause mentioned is the financial crisis, which caused a 21% drop in road freight transport between 2007 and 2009, our leaders pretend not to see that the problem is much greater. They knowingly obscure the real reasons for this bankruptcy: the tax bludgeoning of our companies, red tape, a single currency that is far too expensive and above all unfair competition in this sector established within the Union itself because of the so-called 'detached workers' directive. The liquidation of Mory-Ducros, which had left more than 2,800 employees behind, is now added to the MoryGlobal liquidation, which results in the elimination of an additional 2,150 positions. France has therefore requested a mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support 2,513 dismissed workers of Mory Ducros for a sum of 6.052 million euros. I voted for that help.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to support 2 513 workers out of work in France following the crisis in the heavy goods transport sector. The EGF is a key tool for supporting the internal market, but this Europe should combat the malfunctions underlying it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 2513 workers who have lost their jobs in Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in the land transport sector; redundancies spread across 84 locations throughout the mainland of France. Bankruptcy in the road transport sector increased by 35% per year between 2013 and 2007 mainly as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, which between 2007 and 2012 led to a reduction in road freight transport in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes, by 13.7% in the EU and by 21% in France. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include a single action: advice and guidance to laid-off workers by a team of expert advisors (reclassification cell). These aids, managed through three contractors, ensure the reintegration of as many workers as possible, while covering as much of the french mainland as possible.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of financial support from the European Globalisation Fund to employees of the French company Mory-Ducros SAS, 2804 of whom were made redundant as a result of the financial crisis. Parliament's report notes that 17% of the planned beneficiaries belong to the 55-64 age group and their participation in the proposed support measures would help them avoid long-term unemployment and social exclusion. The redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS are linked to a decline in overall physical output rates in Europe, leading to a decrease in the volume of goods transported and triggering a price war in the road haulage sector, which has led to a decline in the total number of physical outputs in Europe, which has led to a reduction in the volume of goods transported and has led to a price war in the road haulage sector, which has led to a decline in the number of goods carried out in the road haulage sector since 2007. In France, the operating margins of this sector have been increasing and losses have increased, which has led to a wave of bankruptcies in the land freight transport sector.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The establishment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has so far proved to be a very important tool for workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. In my experience, the grants awarded so far have helped the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour market. The French Government's request complies with the requirements set out in the establishment of the Fund, so I supported its adoption in line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed decision to allocate funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) of more than EUR 6 million to the French company Mory-Ducros SAS, which was forced to lay off due to the deterioration of the economic situation in the field of road haulage. As many as 2804 of the 4911 workers employed by the company lost their jobs. This was just one of a number of French companies bankrupted by the reduction in margins for road hauliers since 2007. The EGF will thus provide assistance to workers made redundant, especially to more difficult-to-employ older workers, over whom the threat of prolonged unemployment and social exclusion hangs. The EGF will thus be largely used to train workers for new jobs, and it is welcome that France has started to implement measures to help workers made redundant before applying for EGF funding. In doing so, they helped the workers shortly after they had ended their employment, thus relieving them of the hardship they found themselves in. Of course, measures of a social nature will not be enough. The key, above all, is the creation of new jobs in higher value-added industries, which will kick-start the french economy. There is no doubt that the Juncker Investment Plan, which is on the verge of adoption, can make a big contribution to this.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ France applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of 2,513 Mory-Ducros SAS workers. The layoffs affected workers at 84 plants across France. Since the request fits the criteria, I support this decision.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I deeply regret that this vote does not take place until after the recent liquidation of "MoryGlobal". The workers of this group, the direct victims of a globalization that must be combated, will appreciate... I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will enable the 2,513 laid-off workers in Mory-Ducros, victims of a competitive Europe whose damage is only to be seen, to receive aid of EUR 6,052,200.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since I consider it very important to deploy the resources of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to help the French workers who have lost their jobs and are therefore faced with such a terrible situation.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The crisis facing road freight companies is unprecedented. According to the Bank of France, bankruptcies in the sector increased by 35% per year between 2007 and 2013. This decline initially follows the slowdown in physical production in Europe, as a result of deindustrialization, which has provoked a price war in a market that has become increasingly competitive. In addition, higher oil and certain materials prices have led to a significant deterioration in operating margins. Finally, competition from eastern companies, benefiting in particular from total freedom of movement, has given the Mory-Ducros SAS company the coup de grace. As a result, nearly 2,804 workers have been sacrificed on the altar of the European single market and the total opening of borders. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) only supports job retraining, but does not create jobs. This is why only an ambitious policy of re-industrialization will prevent social tragedies such as that of Mory-Ducros. In support of the employees, I obviously voted for the mobilization of the WEF.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help France following redundancies in 84 units of transport services.  According to Eurostat, redundancies in the transport sector are a consequence of the global financial and economic crisis, which led to a decrease in road transport of goods by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes by 13.4% in the EU and by 21% in France between 2007 and 2012.  The bankruptcy and eventual closure of Mory Ducros led to the lay-off of more than 2,800 employees, who now urgently need professional advice and guidance provided by teams of specialists. That is why the financial support provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund facilitates the conversion of redundant persons to other necessary jobs in the labour market.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of the French company Mory-Ducros. The amount of aid amounts to 6,052,200 euros. Some 2,513 laid-off workers will be able to benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and looking for work. This request, coming from France, is justified given the price war in the road transport sector following the reduction in volumes to be transported and the general decrease in physical production in Europe. These are direct consequences of the economic and financial crisis. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 2 513 workers made redundant as a result of the global economic and financial crisis by Mory-Ducros SAS, a transport company. The general decline in production in Europe has led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported and has triggered a price war within the road freight sector, which has led to a continuous deterioration in operating margins, a series of losses for the sector, particularly in France, and a wave of bankruptcies, including that of Mory-Ducros.  The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying actions, such as assistance in finding employment, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promoting self-employment and entrepreneurship. I regret that Italian companies do not benefit adequately from this fund because of the lack of support from local institutions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of workers who have been made redundant.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no Government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Mory-Ducros, which operates in the road haulage sector. The redundancies concern 84 sites in mainland France.   The bankruptcy and closure of this company is seen as being the result of the global financial and economic crisis, causing road haulage in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes to decline in the EU and in France between 2007 and 2012. This decline follows the general decline of physical output in Europe.   I am happy to note that a personalised service consisting of advice and guidance provided by a team of expert consultants will be provided to the redundant workers. This will constitute active labour market measures within the eligible actions set out in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current mobilisation of the EGF was carried out in the bankruptcy of Mory-Ducros SAS. This company was operating in the transport sector and the redundancies affected 84 locations throughout mainland France. The crisis in the sector is linked to the general decline in physical production in Europe, which has led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported and has triggered a price war within the road freight sector. This was followed by a wave of failures, including that of Mory-Ducros SAS. Following the creation of a new company, more than 50 agencies out of a total of 84 were resumed and 2 107 workers out of a total of 4 911 were rehired; Therefore, 2 804 workers have actually been made redundant, and the proposed support measures are intended to try to prevent them from unemployment at length.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in support of the 2513 employees of Mory-Ducros. I feel all the more concerned that most of the redundancies have affected the Ile-de-France, my constituency of election, in which I have frequently seen the economic and social devastation caused by the deindustrialization of our country. The Mory-Ducros company has been hit hard by the economic and financial crisis. According to Eurostat, between 2007 and 2012, road transport of goods in road vehicles of more than 3.5 tonnes decreased by 13.7% in the European Union as a whole and by 21% in France. The price war as a result of this decrease, as well as the evolution of various costs on the rise (materials, petrol, wages) caused an increase in the bankruptcies of companies linked to this sector by 35% per year between 2007 and 2013 according to the estimates of the Bank of France. As a patriotic Member of Parliament committed to the future of our companies, but also and above all to the precarious situation that many of our compatriots face, I could only support the Denanot report, which will give them financial compensation and thus provide some relief.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Eurostat calculated that within the European Union the transport of goods by road with vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the period 2007-2012 and in France by 21%.  The use of the Intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund by the transport company French Mory-Ducros is due, as to the many other demands made by the European Parliament, to the continuation of the global economic and financial crisis which has had the effect of drastically reducing consumption. I voted in favour of France's request to the European Commission, which was also welcomed by the Council's Budget Committee, to mobilise EUR 6 052 200 to support the 2 513 workers, many of whom have unfortunately already seen the termination of their employment contract.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure examined refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France for a total amount of EUR 6 052 200. It concerns the redundancy of 2 513 workers. The request is based on the relocation of redundant workers from Mory-Ducros, an economic company classified in DIVISION 49 of NACE Rev. 2.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  According to reports by the French authorities, the two events that caused the redundancies are the bankruptcy and closure of the company. The Bank of France also noted that, due to the global financial and economic crisis, failures in the road freight sector increased by 35% in the period 2007-2013 while road freight transport by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes in France decreased by 21% in the period 2007-2012 compared to a decrease of 13.7% in the EU. The French authorities have given all the guarantees. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of France because I believe that this appropriation can represent at least partial compensation between the costs and benefits that can result from structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. I considered that the 2 513 redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS, a company operating in the land transport sector, are an indirect consequence of these changes due to globalisation, since the general decline in physical production in Europe has led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported and has triggered a price war within the road freight sector. All this has led to a wave of failures, including that of Mory-Ducros.  I therefore felt that the intervention of the European institutions was appropriate for the protection of European workers affected by structural changes due to world trade.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 in favour of France with the aim of supporting the 2513 workers made redundant in Mory-Ducros SAS.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF following France's request for financial assistance for the occupational reintegration of workers made redundant by Mory-Ducros SAS, a transport company. Following the economic and financial crisis, road transport for vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in Europe and by 21% in France between 2007 and 2012. The quantitative reduction in circulating products, together with the increase in transport costs, has led to a significant reduction in profit margins for companies in the sector. The situation created forced Mory-Ducros to go bankrupt and the consequent closure of the company, which had 4 911 employees. While State French is already actively promoting measures to fully redeploy those made redundant by Mory-Ducros, the EGF allocation will make it possible to finance a group of experts who will provide personalised assistance to the 2 513 workers still unemployed, increasing the likelihood of rapid reintegration into working life.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Here 2 804 personnel working in the ʽLand transport and transport via pipelinesʼ sector have been made redundant. Such redundancies are linked to events directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis. Now 2 513 redundant workers will receive advice and guidance from a team of expert consultants. I have thus voted in favour of this report to support workersʼ integration back into the labour market.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 following the dismissal of 2 804 workers in France following the bankruptcy and closure of the Road Transport company Mory-Ducros. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The redundancies in Mory-Ducros were the result of the bankruptcy and closure of the company. According to the Bank of France, bankruptcies in the road haulage sector, have increased by 35 % annually when comparing 2013 to 2007. The Commission has concluded that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF. Through this action workers made redundant will receive advice and guidance from a team of experts. I believe in the value of solidarity and giving workers a chance to start over again and hence I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Mory-Ducros SAS, within the framework of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015. The company French operates in the field of land transport and pipelines, which is fundamental to the completion of the internal market and often affected by the effects of the global economic and financial crisis, demonstrated by the reduction in physical production in Europe.  The Union's action in the social field will, on this occasion, assist 2 513 redundancies for reintegration into the labour market. It is important that the French Government, in submitting its application for financial assistance from the EGF, for EUR 6 052 200 or 60% of the total costs, has clearly interpreted the additional nature of the support requested. In fact, actions are planned to benefit from the other complementary EU legislative and budgetary instruments, inserted in order to ensure an efficient and integrated use of resources. In the coordinated package of personalised services presented, it is also stated that other initiatives have been taken by the national authority to address the continental dimension of the case in question, even if recourse to the EGF, tailored to the specific needs of workers.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The global economic and financial crisis has had a negative impact on physical production in Europe, and thus on the volumes to be transported. According to the Bank of France, bankruptcies in the road freight sector grew by 35% per year between 2007 and 2013, and the case of Mory-Ducros is a notable example of this. That is why I supported the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the 2,513 former employees of this company, so that they could benefit from personalised services to reintegrate into the labour market. I was also sensitive to the situation of 17% of laid-off employees in the 55-64 age group. These people are more at risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion, and they need targeted assistance.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF for France in order to support the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant at Mory-Ducros, a company hard hit by the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 23 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Mory-Ducros as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. The redundancies took place at 84 plants in France. According to the French authorities, the redundancies at Mory-Ducros led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the company. According to the Banque de France, between 2007 and 2013 the number of bankruptcies reported in the transport sector increased by 35% per year. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, between 2007 and 2012, road haulage by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France. Personalised services for redundant workers include the following— one measure: advice and guidance for redundant workers. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request for a financial contribution of EUR 6,052,200 for 2,513 laid-off workers of Mory-Ducros SAS, which was France's second largest freight operator.  As a result of the financial and economic crisis, the sector has been hit hard. A price war has broken out due to the decline in physical production in Europe. An increase in costs (petrol, wages, materials) was added, resulting in a deterioration in operating margins, large losses and numerous bankruptcies in the road freight sector.  Mory-Ducros accumulated significant losses in 2012 and 2013. In November 2013, the company declared its insolvency and was placed under judicial administration. In February 2014, a liquidator was appointed. As part of the liquidation, the newly created company, MORY Global, took over 50 branches (out of 84) and rehired 2,107 workers (out of 4,911).  Of the remaining 2,804 workers, 2,513 will be able to receive expert advice on individual career paths and training to develop their job search skills, with the help of the EGF. The EGF's contribution is 60% of the cost of these personalized services.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – On 23 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Mory-Ducros as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. The redundancies took place at 84 plants in France. According to the French authorities, the redundancies at Mory-Ducros led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the company. According to the Banque de France, between 2007 and 2013 the number of bankruptcies reported in the transport sector increased by 35% per year. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, between 2007 and 2012, road haulage by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France. Personalised services for redundant workers include the following— one measure: advice and guidance for redundant workers. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The latter, following the liquidation of Mory-Global, is common sense. The European Union cannot afford to avoid a situation it has itself provoked. The 2,315 workers concerned are subject to the globalist and free-trade policies promoted by the European Commission. We will not be able to secure the employment of the French until we put an end to the unfair competition that is causing lower wages and deteriorating working conditions. The mobilization of this Fund therefore appears to be compensation for the damage suffered by employees. However, we must ensure that this remedy does not become an automatism. Indeed, the aid allocated allows the problem to be dealt with exclusively, without considering its substance, leading the situation to repeat itself. I would remind you that the fairest measure, long before that of compensation, is that of the preservation of French jobs by a national, independent and realistic economic policy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because I believe that this mechanism is misconstructed and its importance is to drain millions of euros without an effective result.
