In the case of Mory-Ducros SAS, a French company active in land transport and pipeline transport, I believe that there is no reason to retrain workers, as these modes of transport are about to expand their influence within the European Union. EUR 6 052 200 will be allocated to 2 804 redundant workers. This financial resource is huge and I think the effect will be minimal.  By allocating this money, we will not open new jobs, instead we will try to get the job done by the social services in the country where these workers paid their social security and taxes. On top of that, this money will be paid out years after the application has been submitted, and I don't think the redundant workers will wait 3, 4 or 5 years to start looking for a new job. The longer a person is unemployed, the harder it will be for them to get a job. That is why I believe that before we continue to mobilise funds, we need to completely review and reconstruct this mechanism.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I believe that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. In the case of France's Mory Ducros, which operates in the land transport sector, redundancies totaled 2,513 out of 2,804 workers. In France, bankruptcies in the road haulage sector increased by 35 % annually between 2007 and 2013 as a result of the economic crisis that has led to a decline in goods production in Europe, a price war in the sector and the resulting bankruptcies of companies.  Whereas the application meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, the aid package which I voted in favour of consists of vocational guidance and planning measures, EGF training grants, training and second-cycle education programmes, higher education programmes, business and self-employment support, as well as income support, including the EGF scheme for contributions to training expenditure.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The French authorities submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 2513 redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines, with redundancies being spread across 84 locations across metropolitan France. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This report refers to France's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support 2513 workers from a land transport company, transport by pipelines or pipelines and storage and rental of related materials, Mory—Ducros. The redundancies made by the company are located in the whole of metropolitan France. The largest number of redundant workers (257) is concentrated in the Île de France region. At the time of the redundancies, the company was the second largest operator of these services in France, mobilising around 4 500 vehicles per day. With the crisis, road freight transport in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes contracted by 13.7 % in the EU and 21% in France between 2007 and 2012. We agree with the mobilisation of this (known insufficient) aid, quickly, although this fund only represents limited support for those who are the main victims of the capitalist crisis. We reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to help European workers cope better with the consequences of the economic and economic crisis on world trade. In February 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of France, namely for the benefit of 2 513 Mory-Ducros workers for a total amount of EUR 6 052 200. These employees were made redundant as a result of the bankruptcy and subsequent closure of the company, as the volume of road freight traffic in the European Union decreased by 35 % between 2007 and 2013 and by 21 % in France.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting € 6,052,000 for the 2,513 redundancies out of 2,804 due to the bankruptcy of Mory-Ducros in France.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. – The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people. For the above reasons my vote is against the application EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory-Ducros.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The redundancies in Mory-Ducros SAS are linked to the general decline in physical output in Europe, which leads to a reduction in volumes that, as described in the report, is directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis.  The Union has set up the European Global Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to workers who sustain the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market.   I support financial assistance to Mory-Ducros SAS workers who have become redundant and hope that deployment of assistance will be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. As far as the procedure is concerned, under point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, the Commission shall submit to the budgetary authority, if the application is positively considered, a proposal for the use of the Fund and at the same time submit a request for appropriate transfer. I voted in favour of this decision because I believe that, in the absence of agreement, tripartit procedure should be initiated immediately. I welcome the fact that, according to an internal agreement, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs should be involved in the process in order to provide constructive support and contribute to the evaluation of applications submitted to the Fund.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. For this reason, I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory-Ducros).

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of France in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of 2 513 laid-off workers in Mory-Ducros, a company operating in the land transport sector.  This is the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 052 200. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation or the financial crisis and to help them find new jobs.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise funds because the application complies with the requirements and above all because it allows help and new hope to be offered to thousands of citizens and families affected by the crisis.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for an EP and Council decision mobilising a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contribution of EUR 6,052,200 in relation to the redundancies of Mory-Ducros SAS because its bankruptcy resulted in the redundancy of 2,513 workers distributed in 84 locations in mainland France. Of these, 17% are over 55 years of age and face a higher risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion. Mory-Ducros, like the entire road transport sector, has paid for the effects of the economic and financial crisis, the decrease in physical production in Europe and the consequent compression of the volumes to be transported and the operating margins of companies, forced into a price war in order to safeguard their turnover. Once again, it is up to the workers to pay the price of the crisis. The EGF's funding of tailor-made job search and retraining services, carried out through a one-stop shop, is important and necessary, but it is not enough. The EU needs to go further and address the crisis in the freight sector (-13.7% in the period 2007/2013), equipping itself with even more effective tools for the protection and protection of workers.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Mory-Ducros report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I welcome that the EGAF funding  is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 2513 redundant workers into employment. The application relates to redundancies in Mory-Ducros Sas, which are spread over 84 sites in the whole mainland of France, and are linked to a decline in physical output in Europe.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. France has requested assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the dismissals at the end of 2013 of 2,513 employees at 84 sites in France at Mory-Ducros SAS.  This group was once the number two French trucking of parcels. According to industry professionals, the courier market has been affected for several years due to soaring diesel prices, fierce competition, but also the economic crisis, which has reduced the production of material goods in Europe.  The Bank of France reports a 21% drop in volumes transported in France between 2007 and 2012, following the economic crisis. Until recently, the company, taken over as MoryGlobal by its main shareholder, Arcoles Industries, has experienced insurmountable difficulties that have led to its legal liquidation. In total, nearly 5,000 employees will have been laid off in the space of three years, leading to a major social disaster in France.  I therefore voted in favour of this aid of 6,052,000 euros, in order to support the retraining of sacked employees in the best possible conditions.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As usual with the mobilisation of this fund, we do not oppose it since it consists in the provision of direct (subsidy) and indirect (training) aid to workers dismissed by companies that fail because of industrial conversion adjustments and the fickleness of certain markets, both factors characteristic of globalization. However, in the justification we specify that we see these aids as simply palliative or corrective applied to structurally favour the current unfair and unsustainable economic model, to the point that they justify the continuity of the spiral of deind industrialisation that has been undermining the economies of the Member States.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides one-off support, under specific conditions, to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. As a trade unionist and a member of the Trade Union Intergroup, I therefore voted in favour of this report which was an application to provide approximately EUR 6 million of EU aid to help around 2 500 workers who lost their jobs from France’s former road haulage company Mory-Ducros in 2014. This fund will support those workers made redundant in finding new jobs. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In this case in the road haulage sector  several thousands of people have lost their jobs. Bankruptcies in France in this sector have increased by 35% annually. This is seen as being the result of the global financial and economic crisis. This request fulfils the criteria for funding.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. My vote in favour of this mobilisation in France of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is part of the general framework of the Socialists' commitment to the principle of European solidarity, a true foundation constituting the EU and the reason for our work here.  This mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 will support the reintegration into the labour market of 2,513 workers laid off in 84 locations in mainland France by Mory-Ducros. Socialists across Europe work for a true society united in adversity and a model of social justice, and the French people and their workers must know that they have our efforts and support in the search for decent living conditions and quality employment for all citizens.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EGF application to support 2 513 workers made redundant from the road haulage industry in France.  The overall fund is just over EUR 10 million with a EUR 6 million contribution from the EGF which represents 60% of the total costs. I am particularly pleased to see that over 17% of the beneficiaries which French authorities expect to target are aged 55-64, as this is a group particularly vulnerable to long-term unemployment and social exclusion.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 23 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Mory-Ducros as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. The redundancies took place at 84 plants in France. According to the French authorities, the redundancies at Mory-Ducros led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the company. According to the Banque de France, between 2007 and 2013 the number of bankruptcies reported in the transport sector increased by 35% per year. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, between 2007 and 2012, road haulage by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France. Personalised services for redundant workers include the following— one measure: advice and guidance for redundant workers. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As usual with the mobilisation of this fund, we do not oppose it since it consists in the provision of direct (subsidy) and indirect (training) aid to workers dismissed by companies that fail because of industrial conversion adjustments and the fickleness of certain markets, both factors characteristic of globalization. However, in the justification we specify that we see these aids as simply palliative or corrective applied to structurally favour the current unfair and unsustainable economic model, to the point that they justify the continuity of the spiral of deind industrialisation that has been undermining the economies of the Member States.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour. Given that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns, I consider it appropriate for the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be used to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off in Mory-Ducros in France

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of 2,513 redundancy workers of the French company Mory-Ducros SAS, as the financial contribution in question seeks to prevent long-term unemployment and social exclusion.  It is important to ensure that support for workers, in these cases, is as quickly available and dynamic as possible to help them reintegrate into the labour market as soon as possible. In addition, it is important to take into account older age workers at higher risk of unemployment and to support services tailored to the needs of workers that further mitigate the negative consequences of major structural changes.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This request relates to the granting of 6.05 million euros in aid to former employees of the Mory-Ducros company. Such assistance will facilitate the retraining of laid-off workers - victims of the economic crisis and austerity policies - after a reduction in domestic demand by the various Member States between 2007 and 2012 which saw a 21% drop in road freight transport. The link between redundancies and the economic and financial crisis is, in this case, established and authorizes the granting of monetary aid. Therefore, I have decided to vote for this proposal.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jean-Paul Denanot's report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Mory-Ducros. The Fund will provide EUR 6.52 million for 2,513 laid-off employees of the Mory-Ducros carrier, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries re-enter the labour market. This Fund shows Europe's concrete action with citizens. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by France following the redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. It also aims to promote the reintegration of sacked employees into the labour market. I am the the fore, the case for the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 6,052,200.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that additional support should be provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. France had applied for assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 2,513 employees of Mory-Ducros SAS. The redundancies affect a total of 84 sites in France. The job losses are to be seen as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, which has also severely affected the road haulage sector and led to a general decline in production in Europe. The total estimated cost of this package is EUR 10 million, of which the EGF would provide EUR 6 million. The redundant staff should receive vocational guidance and guidance in order to better find new jobs. For reasons of employment and social policy, I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 On 23 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Mory-Ducros as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. The redundancies took place at 84 plants in France. According to the French authorities, the redundancies at Mory-Ducros led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the company. According to the Banque de France, between 2007 and 2013 the number of bankruptcies reported in the transport sector increased by 35% per year. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, between 2007 and 2012, road haulage by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France. Personalised services for redundant workers include the following— one measure: advice and guidance for redundant workers. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. After having already made this known in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the Denanot report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for former employees of the French company MORY DUCROS S.A.S. 2,513 sacked employees operating at 84 sites in France will benefit from an EGF budget of EUR 6,052,200 for a eur 10,087,000 project. This plan will enable the creation of a reclassification unit to provide advice and redirect sacked employees to best adapt their skills to the demands of the labour market. I encourage the French authorities to make a new request for the mobilization of the EGF following the legal liquidation of the company MORY GLOBAL a few weeks ago. Like their former colleagues, recently dismissed employees are perfectly entitled to receive financial and logistical assistance from the EU as part of their future reclassification. I will not fail to fight in favour of this request for European aid.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Denanot report to mobilise, within the framework of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), more than 6 million euros for the sacked employees of the former French freight transport company Mory-Ducros. This support of 6,052,200 euros will enable 2,513 employees of the company, who operated until May 2014 at 84 sites across France, to receive expert advice on individual career paths and training to develop their job search skills. By supporting this new aid, the European Parliament once again demonstrates the European Union's ability to respond in a concrete way to the economic and social upheaval caused by the financial crisis.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted to grant 6.05 million euros in aid to the 2,513 workers laid off by the road transport company Mory-Ducros, because it is important to show solidarity with them. But I would like to stress that the European Union is largely responsible for what happened to them. It has imposed on France a policy of austerity that has compressed domestic demand for road transport. On the other hand, and above all, it has organised unfair competition by allowing European road transport companies, particularly from Eastern Europe, to practice "cabotage" in France. Cabotage is authorised by the European Regulation of 21 October 2009. This regulation allows the trucks of these foreign companies to take advantage of an international transport in France to carry out in addition three operations of loading and unloading goods, before returning to their country. However, Companies in Eastern Europe give their drivers much lower wages than French drivers, not to mention payroll taxes. This is why more and more customers prefer to use their services. And in the end, that's one of the reasons Mory-Ducros collapsed.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Positive vote. The mobilization of the European Adjustment Fund aims to help employees whose sector of activity is affected by a crisis, or who must undergo structural changes. This is due to the consequences of free trade and globalization. This is the case for sacked employees of road freight transport. The financial crisis is not the only one responsible for the delicate situation of this sector, austerity policies have their share of responsibility with a negative action on domestic demand. It is regrettable that this report does not focus more on the unfair intra-European competition that French freight companies are experiencing, particularly with cabotage. Differences in remuneration, sometimes with the absence of a minimum wage in some European countries and the various legislation, particularly in the context of social security contributions, put French companies in difficulty.  However, as the proposal in this report supports employees in difficulty, it seems necessary to support it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 following the dismissal of 2804 workers in France following the bankruptcy and closure of road transport company Mory-Ducros. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition in the market, which causes smaller profits for one company, means lower prices for customers. It is impossible to force more successful firms that employ people to pay through taxes on less successful firms that have to lay them off. In an environment that is not cursive of subsidies and similar contributions, it is much easier to create new firms that employ these people.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ The global economic and financial crisis has also had a profound impact on the French company Mory-Ducros, which was active in the field of land transport. The reduction in transport volumes is closely linked to the reduction in material production and to the price war between carriers, which has also led to an increase in the bankruptcy of transport companies. The redundancies of the company's 2 804 employees have a major impact on employment in this sector. The submitted application meets the requirements for a contribution from the EFG. It aims to take swift action to enable redundant workers to engage in employment and thus prevent their long-term unemployment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, as more than 2,500 redundant French workers in the field of land transport are supported in this regard. Also, in order to provide workers with assistance immediately, the French authorities decided to start implementing the personalised services to the affected workers on 24 February 2014, well before the decision and even before the request for EGF support for the proposed coordinated package. Furthermore, it should be noted that France, like Greece, is affected by unemployment. Thus austerity in France increased the number of unemployed from 4,960,000 in May 2012 to 5,918,000 in February 2015. Indeed, on 15/4/2015, French Finance Minister Michel Sapin presented detailed and new fiscal adjustment measures worth 4 billion euros that will increase poverty and unemployment.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which allocates 6,052,200 euros to 2,513 graduates of Mory-Ducros in France.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ By way of an explanation for my vote, I considered this to be an appropriate cause for mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to the application submitted by France, for a financial contribution of EUR 6 052 200, following 2,513 redundancies, which affected 84 locations throughout mainland France, at Mory-Ducros SAS, a company operating in the classified economic sector ("Land transport and pipeline transport").  The European Union must intervene in support of the countries and its inhabitants so that the consequences attributable to changes in trade can finally be reduced.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the report for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in Mory-Ducros. We are facing the failure of a transport company, like many others that have had to close as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and from the European Union we must support the workers concerned, so that they can return soon to the labour market.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers and the self-employed who have been made redundant or have had to cease operations as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation and a global financial and economic crisis. These crises also led to insolvency and closure at Mory-Ducros. As all the criteria for mobilising this fund have been met, this request should only be supported.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important fund which provides additional support for workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis. This fund retrains and reskills redundant workers helping them find new jobs.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Mory, which specializes in logistics and transport of road and sea goods, has experienced three bankruptcies in four years: Mory Team in 2011, Mory Ducros in 2013 (the focus of the application) and Mory Global in 2015. Indeed, there was a decrease in road freight transport of 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France between 2007 and 2012. This decline follows the general trend of decreased physical production in Europe. The French state could have taken the measure of this phenomenon in order to respond to it in an ecological planning objective by promoting the conversion in rail freight, for example. But it prefers to blame the rise in "costs" in the sector without distinction between wages and basic materials (petrol). The requested funds (6 million euros) will be used to feed the 2014 Employment Protection Plan before a new request is made to enable the implementation of the next plan for Mory-Global. Thus, this globalization aid fund plays its destructive role: it actually encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Aware that this system of aid and redistribution will not solve the problem in the long term and that the European Union is partly responsible for the economic and social devastation, considering that European funds come from the Member States and that in this case it is a French company, given the difficulty in which the dismissed persons find themselves and the state of emergency of the situation , I voted FOR.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment.  The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to France to give this aid, who submitted the Application EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory—Ducros for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 2513 redundancies in Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in the economic activity sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 division 49 (Land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines), with redundancies being spread across 84 locations across metropolitan France.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 2 513 workers in the road-haulage sector in France due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in France. The EGAF funding of EUR 6 052 200 is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 2 513 of redundant workers into employment. The redundancies are linked to the decline in physical output in Europe, which leads to a reduction in volumes to be transported and triggered a price war in the road haulage sector, resulting in a steady deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France since 2007

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Eurostat data, the road freight sector has suffered a significant decline due to the reduction in volumes to be transported and in France the crisis in the sector has led to a 21% decrease. There are just over 2,500 beneficiaries of the financial disbursement that is the subject of the vote, with a forecast cost of EUR 10 million. I voted in favour.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important institution of solidarity within the Union; an active employment policy instrument that shares the burden of returning to the labour market between the worker, the Member State concerned and the Union, and its results help both the worker who is able to re-enter the labour market, the Member State that is forced to deal with unemployment and the Union which is aiming to increase employment. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, between 2007 and 2012, road haulage by vehicles over 3.5 tonnes fell by 13.7% in the EU and 21% in France. As the volumes to be transported declined, a price war broke out in the sector, with various costs rising, resulting in a continuous narrowing of operating margins. As a result, mory-ducros in France, which is part of the transport sector, went bankrupt and was re-counted. 2 804 workers have been laid off and the amount requested from the Fund will help to provide 2 513 active labour market benefits. On the basis of all this, I found the application worthy of support.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Mory Global, formerly Mory Ducros, has been the subject of intense competition from Eastern European carriers. After first going bankrupt, it was placed in liquidation again at the end of March. More than 2,000 layoffs, or nearly 5,000 jobs, have been cut in three years. In particular, the company pays the price of opening markets to competitors from less socially so-called countries, with whom the cost war is lost in advance. In order to finance the reclassification of employees, it is clear that we must support the release of European funds for adjustment to globalisation, even if this means having the Union's taxpayers finance the price of its ultra-liberal policies.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  France's application to the EGF refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 052 200, corresponding to 2513 employees, of which 2804 were made redundant by Mory-Ducros.  I support the mobilisation of this financial budget in order to cover the bankruptcies in the road haulage sector. Among other cases, this is also the result of the global economic and financial crisis which caused the road transport of goods to decrease European economic activity by 13.7 % and, in the particular case of France, by 21% between 2007 and 2012 (Eurostat).

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 2,513 Mory-Global workers, the French authorities requested 6.05 million euros in aid to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  The only reason given is that of the financial crisis. Any criticism of intra-European competition, including cabotage, which leads to unfair competition to the detriment of road freight companies located in France, is knowingly omitted.  Furthermore, the proposal envisaged by some Member States to subject the sector to the detached workers scheme will not solve the problem of the cost differential, since social contributions will be paid in the company's country of establishment and the average salary of French road hauliers is higher than the current SMIC. Therefore, the application of the detached work regime and the minimum wage to foreign road hauliers is only a partial and insufficient solution in view of the distortion of competition generated.  If this post-use aid mechanism is reprehensible in its logic since it cushions or even encourages redundancies, the aid in this case seems indispensable for the retraining of the dismissed workers of Mory-Global. So I voted for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 6 million euros to support the reclassification of 2,513 employees made redundant in the event of the bankruptcy and closure of the French road haulier Mory-Ducros. Road freight transport has been hit hard by the economic crisis. Activity fell by 13.7% in Europe and by 21% in France. At the same time, costs have increased (petrol, labour, materials). Mory-Ducros, once France's second-largest road haulier, was unable to cope with the shock. The European Union therefore provides protection and assistance to the most vulnerable sacked employees. Almost 1 in 5 beneficiaries of this intervention is over the age of 50.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of mory ducros sas workers, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade and the global economic and financial crisis. According to the data cited by the French authorities, the redundancies were caused by the general decline in physical production in Europe, which led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported and triggered a price war within the road freight sector. Since 2007, therefore, there has been a continuous deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France, which has led to a wave of bankruptcies, including that of Mory-Ducros. The coordinated package of personalised services to be cofinanced will be directed mainly towards counselling and vocational guidance actions, training and retraining, and allowances for job search and mobility will be provided. We are therefore sure that these European incentives will be a valuable aid for the reintegration of these workers.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. This application, the eleventh in the framework of the 2015 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 6 052 200 in favour of France. It concerns 2 513 of the 2 804 workers made redundant by Mory-Ducros, a company operating in the field of land transport and pipeline transport. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of Mr Denanot's report because I believe that workers, victims of the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the advancement of globalisation, must have full support from the European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with paragraph 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management - the request of EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory-Ducros, submitted by France. As special rapporteur of the S&D Group for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I support the implementation of the project, which complies with the relevant European procedure and rules.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is helping workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns, such as the closure of a large company. Our European companies, which respect social rights for workers that have been created and acquired over decades, are lagging behind because of the higher costs that this entails. Imports into the EU of products that have not been produced under certain minimum social standards must be banned as soon as possible. Until that happens, we can only mitigate the damage caused by globalisation in the countries concerned. I therefore voted in favour of releasing the funds from the Fund.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of more than 2,500 employees of the Mory-Ducros company at various industrial sites, this report proposes the mobilization of an envelope of more than 6 million euros to cover part of the measures that have been taken to accompany the laid-off workers. The scheme in question aims to identify, validate and shape the professional project of each employee, identify the training or adaptation needs necessary for the implementation of this project and accompany the employee until the effective return to employment, without limit of duration, the support ending only when the national monitoring commission has validated the return to employment. I have, of course, voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to provide financial support to a French company.    In view of the potential negative impact, financial assistance to redundant workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and effectively as possible. Support measures would help to avoid long-term unemployment and social exclusion. In addition, the package of measures would contribute to the transition to a resource-efficient and sustainable economy. In this context, it is essential that workers made redundant are given assistance to reintegrate into the labour market as soon as possible. It is to be welcomed that the French authorities provided emergency support to redundant workers well before the decision was taken and even before the egf application was submitted and introduced measures tailored to individual needs. It should be noted that the application submitted complies with the requirements for determining the amount of the financial contribution from the EGF. There is therefore no impediment to the decision on granting aid.  Timely and effective measures will help to return as many eligible workers as possible to the labour market and prevent the spread of negative consequences throughout the region.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The so-called Globalisation Fund is increasingly being used by the EU institutions and is being used by the EU and the governments of its Member States for the purposes of manipulating labour consciences and concealing the real cause of redundancies and soaring unemployment. By presenting the capitalist crisis as so-called "financial", it attempts to exonerate the capitalist system which, either in crisis or development, gives birth to, reproduces and recycles crises and unemployment inherent in the exploitative system. The crumbs of the Fund, inadequate even as a temporary breath for the dismissed, are attempted to be used to contain indignation, cover up and embellish capitalist barbarism, the unpopular policy of the EU and the urban governments that serve monopolies, while most of them reinforce various mechanisms – false training enterprises. Unemployment is not dealt with either by EU funds or by the crumbs of extreme poverty. In order for unemployment to become a definitive past, for stable work with rights for all, the working class needs to strengthen its fight to overthrow the unpopular policy, the exploitative system itself, in order to take into its own hands the power and wealth it produces.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Union has drawn up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market; whereas Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible; Whereas the adoption of the EGF Regulation reflects the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of the crisis mobilisation criterion, the increase in the Union's financial contribution to 60% of the estimated total costs of the proposed measures, the increase in the efficiency of the processing of EGF applications within the Commission and by Parliament and the Council obtained by reducing the time taken for evaluation and approval of the , the extension of the actions and beneficiaries eligible for the self-employed and young people, as well as the financing of incentives for the creation of their own businesses, for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the French authorities' request to the EGF for a financial contribution following the redundancies from mory-ducros SAS relating to 2 513 workers and the amount of EUR 6 052 200, representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures in order to ensure a financial contribution for their application. Redundancies in the company will have an extremely negative impact on mainland France, especially the Île-de-France region, which is an area of great importance to the French economy. I point out that workers from this sector have very specific skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult for these workers to search for new employment, and in particular this applies to older-age workers who lack little until retirement. I welcome the fact that, in agreement with the targeted beneficiaries, their representatives and trade unions, a harmonised package of services tailored to their needs has been developed.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Again, the dogma of free competition has created unbearable pressure for a French company. Again, instead of addressing the roots of evil, we are simply mobilizing funds to help employees by offering training with hypothetical benefits. It is obvious that I cannot refuse aid to these workers who are victims of absurd political choices, but it is without illusions that I am in favour of this report, the umpteenth cautery on a wooden leg.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the approval of EUR 6 052 200 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations in order to partially finance redundancy losses at Mory-Ducros SAS.  Member States need to show solidarity towards each other when needed and I am glad that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. At the same time, Union financial assistance to redundanst workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible. France applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of 2,513 workers at Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in the land transport and pipeline transport sectors, with redundancies affecting workers at 84 installations across France. The report found that the redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS were linked to a general decline in material goods production in Europe due to a decrease in the volume of goods for transport and started bidding on prices in the road transport sector, which led to a steady decline in operating margins and a series of losses in the sector in France since 2007. With a view to assisting redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs, I support rapporteur Jean-Paul Denanot's report on the mobilisation of €6,052,200, representing 60% of the total cost.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The mobilisation of the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) is this time in france's favour for the occupational reintegration of redundant workers from Mory-Ducros (a company operating in the road freight sector), according to, as per procedure, a proposal for a decision adopted by the Commission. The French authorities have stated that the global economic crisis has led to a 35% failure of companies in this sector with a fall in freight transport with vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes in both France and Europe (also due to the fall in production and sales).  I hope that the tailored services for workers funded by the Fund will help them retrain. Among the services provided, there is also a counselling and guidance service that a group of experts will give to workers.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 Even today, I have to add my already slightly traditional remark that I supported the report, although I am following with some concern the almost exclusive use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for businesses from the so-called old Member States. I still believe that this trend will ease in the near future.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. This fund was requested in 2015, amounting to more than 6 million euros, to support the reintegration of sacked employees of the Mory-Ducros group. I strongly support this request and I would like to stress the importance of such a European instrument to help and accompany European citizens directly affected by globalisation. This assistance will help finance the reorientation of these workers and their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 France submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF following 2513 redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in division 49 of NACE Rev. 2 (Land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines) during the period from 13 March to 13 July 2014. According to the Commission, that application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is found, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to the global economic and financial crisis, since the general decline in physical production in Europe, which caused a reduction in volumes to be transported and triggered a price war in the road freight sector , has led to a steady deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France since 2007, and that, on the other hand, such redundancies will further aggravate the unemployment situation in France, with a high risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion, given the advanced age of the workers affected. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of France.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In approving European job-seeking aid for the 2,500 laid-off workers of the French road freight transport company Mory-Ducros on Wednesday afternoon, MEPs showed that European social policy was not a empty word. Financial support via the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which follows that received in March by 2,498 laid-off workers in Belgium: Duferco, Saint-Gobain Sekurit, Caterpillar and Arcelor Mittal Liège to the tune of 5.2 million euros; Europe does not skimp on acting in the interests of its citizens when they are directly affected by economic redundancy. Citizens obviously expect something else from the European project than a passive social policy, based solely on the 'safety net'. For this reason, it is essential to facilitate financing for SMEs and innovation on the one hand, and on the other hand to boost investment in major infrastructure projects, which create wealth, jobs and social cohesion. A policy, which is shuddering, but which must be implemented more quickly, including in sectors, such as road freight transport, which are under full force from global and intra-European competition.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report, which concerns the granting of 6 million euros in aid to former employees of the French carrier Mory-Ducros. After several years of severe economic difficulties, the French company unfortunately had to close in May 2014. While nearly half of its employees have been rehired in another company, 2,513 workers are now unemployed.  The French authorities have applied to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). The Fund allows, under certain conditions, to allocate financial assistance to employees who have been made redundant due to major changes in international trade, such as globalization or the global economic crisis. This support from the Union is essential and is in addition to the measures already taken by the French State in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of those made redundant.  With these funds, they will be able to benefit from personalized and regular support for the construction of their new career path, advice or various types of training in order to maximize their chances of returning to sustainable employment.  It is now up to the Council to validate the request of the French authorities so that the aid of 6 million euros becomes effective and benefits French workers.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created precisely to support the reintegration into the market of workers whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, continuing the global financial and economic crisis. This was the case with Mory-Ducros and the French authorities provided all the necessary guarantees.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 2513 workers who have lost their jobs in Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in the land transport sector; redundancies spread across 84 locations throughout the mainland of France. Bankruptcy in the road transport sector increased by 35% per year between 2013 and 2007 mainly as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, which between 2007 and 2012 led to a reduction in road freight transport in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes, by 13.7% in the EU and by 21% in France. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include a single action: advice and guidance to laid-off workers by a team of expert advisors (reclassification cell). These aids, managed through three contractors, ensure the reintegration of as many workers as possible, while covering as much of the french mainland as possible.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The global financial and economic crisis has not spared the road freight transport sector of more than 3.5 tonnes, whose activity fell by 13.7% in the European Union and by 21% in France between 2007 and 2012. This contraction in activity led to a price war between the various companies in the sector, leading to numerous restructurings over the same period. This is particularly the case in the Mory-Ducros company, where 2,513 workers were laid off as a result of this sluggish economic environment. Therefore, in order to provide assistance to these many workers, I naturally voted in favour of the request made by the French authorities for a financial contribution from the EGF to the tune of EUR 6,052,200. May this contribution enable them to regain job stability quickly.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Mory-Ducros SAS, which operates in the land transport and transport sector by oil or gas pipelines, has been faced with a drastic reduction in its turnover in Europe due to a generalised drop in the volume of raw materials or goods transported on the European market. This has led to a price dispute in the road haulage sector, reducing operating margins and leading to consecutive losses since 2007. Subsequently, the company went bankrupt and sent to unemployment 2513 workers. Given that the EGF was created with the aim of providing support to workers made redundant from companies that have suffered from structural changes in world trade standards due to globalisation and it is certain that the application submitted by Mory-Ducros SAS meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I agree with its mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200. I would also like to leave a word of hope to note that in this case a new company was set up, Mory Global, which has taken over more than 50 branches out of a total of 84 and reemployed 2107 workers out of a total of 4911.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of 2,513 workers made redundant by a company operating in the economic sector, because I am convinced that Europe must help its citizens and the approval of this request is one of the means by which we can be closer to those in need.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the sum of around six million euros, compared with 2 513 redundancies due to the bankruptcy of Mory-Ducros, a company operating in the heavy goods transport sector.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As usual with the mobilisation of this fund, we do not oppose it since it consists in the provision of direct (subsidy) and indirect (training) aid to workers dismissed by companies that fail because of industrial conversion adjustments and the fickleness of certain markets, both factors characteristic of globalization. However, in the justification we specify that we see these aids as simply palliative or corrective applied to structurally favour the current unfair and unsustainable economic model, to the point that they justify the continuity of the spiral of deind industrialisation that has been undermining the economies of the Member States.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 following the dismissal of 2804 workers in France following the bankruptcy and closure of road transport company Mory-Ducros. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund EFG/2014/017FR/Mory-Ducros to the amount of EUR 6 052 200. I believe that this instrument can give tangible help to the 2 513 workers made redundant by Mory-Ducros, a company operating in land transport and pipeline transport. This case is yet another example of the effects of the global financial and economic crisis, which led to a 21% decrease in heavy goods transport by road in France between 2007 and 2012. I therefore hope that this economic contribution will enable these workers to re-enter the labour market as soon as possible.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France. A total amount of EUR 6 052 200 from the EGF will be used to support the reintegration in the labour market of 2 513 workers made redundant in Mory-Ducros. The redundancies concern 84 sites in mainland France. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – the EGF is an instrument by which the Union provides support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The application for a financial contribution from the EGF submitted by France for aid to Mory-Ducros SAS, in which 2513 redundancies were made redundant, fulfils the eligibility criteria for this aid. The redundancies at this company are linked to the overall decline in physical production in Europe, which has led to a reduction in the quantity of goods to be transported. This has sparked a price war in the road haulage sector, which has led to falling margins and an increase in losses. The EGF will finance only one measure from the package of personalised services, namely advice and guidance for laid-off workers, in order to ensure that the labour market is reintegrated as soon as possible. It is important that the implementation of the measure takes into account the expected future developments in the labour market and the current focus on a sustainable resource-efficient economy. France started implementing the adjusted measures as early as the day following a positive assessment of the application for a financial contribution by the Commission, well before the final decision to grant support from the EPG in order to provide quick assistance to the workers made redundant, so it is important that the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF be supported immediately.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support 2,513 employees of Mory-Ducros SAS, a company operating in the land transport sector, whose redundancies affected 84 locations across France. The redundancies are due to the global financial and economic crisis, which, due to the decline in general physical production in Europe, has led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported. A price war has broken out within the sector, which, compounded by the upward trend in various costs (petrol, wages, materials), has led since 2007 to a continuous deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France, including the bankruptcy of several companies including Mory-Ducros SAS. The total aid of EUR 6 052 200 provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund consists of a single action, to be implemented through a one-stop shop (retraining cells) managed by three contracting agencies, which aim to cover as much area as possible in mainland France and to ensure the reintegration of as many workers as possible.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Fund in this case as well. It is time for the EGF to be activated also for cases of collective redundancies in Slovak companies and for the Slovak Government to respond to my repeated calls.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The French authorities applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies at Mory-DUCROS SAS in France. Mory-DUCROS is active in the field of delivery services, transport and delivery and storage and rental of materials. These services are available in France and abroad. As a result of the global financial crisis, war and road freight bankruptcy, the Commission is proposing to mobilise an EGF of €6 052 200 to help workers who have become redundant and whose need to do their jobs has ceased. I therefore support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ I did not support the proposal. First of all, it is interesting that the 'victim of globalisation' in this case is to be a road transport company. In search of all the damage that globalisation has done, the applicants for money are clearly quite creative. But regardless, this post, as well as other similar posts, is harmful. As it is paid from taxes on employees and companies, fewer real jobs are created and competitiveness is reduced. This further increases the problem that this money was supposed to solve.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the use of ervop funds to adapt to globalisation to help made-up redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS. As a result of globalisation, physical production in Europe is declining, reducing demand for road transport, leading to price wars in the road haulage sector, and the result of this war is a wave of bankruptcies, including the bankruptcy of Mory-Ducros. I supported the report in particular because almost one fifth of the recipients of aid will be from the 55-64 age group. The unemployed in this age group often have considerable difficulty finding new work, so they need help to prevent their long-term unemployment and social exclusion.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. On 15 April, MEPs, meeting in a plenary session in Brussels, voted to provide 6 million euros in aid for sacked employees of Mory-Ducros under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF). The request for assistance concerns 2,513 workers at more than 80 sites in metropolitan France. Prior to its liquidation in February 2014, the Mory-Ducros Group was the second largest operator in the courier and charter sector. The group has been hit hard by the decline in road freight transport in vehicles over 3.5 tonnes. Due to the crisis and less activity, this decreased by 13.7% in the European Union between 2007 and 2012. This decline led to price wars and increased competition among carriers, while their operating margins declined in the face of the concomitant rise in the cost of gasoline, wages and materials. The Fund was created to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers who have been victims of globalization.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As usual with the mobilisation of this fund, we do not oppose it since it consists in the provision of direct (subsidy) and indirect (training) aid to workers dismissed by companies that fail because of industrial conversion adjustments and the fickleness of certain markets, both factors characteristic of globalization. However, in the justification we specify that we see these aids as simply palliative or corrective applied to structurally favour the current unfair and unsustainable economic model, to the point that they justify the continuity of the spiral of deind industrialisation that has been undermining the economies of the Member States.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Our delegation almost systematically votes on the demands for the mobilization of the 'European Globalisation Adjustment Fund', as it is a programme of support for employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultra-liberal policies applied in this European Union unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that make it live.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As usual with the mobilisation of this fund, we do not oppose it since it consists in the provision of direct (subsidy) and indirect (training) aid to workers dismissed by companies that fail because of industrial conversion adjustments and the fickleness of certain markets, both factors characteristic of globalization. However, in the justification we specify that we see these aids as simply palliative or corrective applied to structurally favour the current unfair and unsustainable economic model, to the point that they justify the continuity of the spiral of deind industrialisation that has been undermining the economies of the Member States.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns and are affected by relocations. This case concerns Mory-Ducros, a company operating in the 'Land Transport and Pipeline Transport' sector in France. The amount to be allocated to EGF is 6 million euros. As is usual, I voted in favour of mobilizing the EGF in this case.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The economic crisis that the European Union has suffered in recent years has had a hard impact on the economic and social fabric of the continent. Additional support measures for workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in trade models, especially when they avoid long-term unemployment and social exclusion in age groups such as 55-64 years (more than 17% of beneficiaries subject to these measures) are welcome.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 052 200 following the dismissal of 2 804 workers in France following the bankruptcy and closure of the Road Transport company Mory-Ducros. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in France, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, there is a need for structural reforms to re-establish economic growth. The MEPs of the N-VA have therefore abstained on this dossier.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The dismissal of 2513 workers by Mory-Ducros is located in the whole of metropolitan France.  The largest number of redundant workers (257) is concentrated in the Ile de France region. At the time of the redundancies, the company was the second largest operator of these services in France, mobilising around 4 500 vehicles per day. This episode is another reflection of the overall decline in production in Europe, resulting in the reduction in volumes to be transported, aggravated by an increase in the various costs, namely petrol, led to a steady deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France since 2007. We agree that this aid is mobilised swiftly, although this fund only represents limited support for those targeted by the consequences of the liberalisation of world trade, and further reaffirms our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of the neoliberal policies that have once again led to this outcome.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers and the self-employed who have been made redundant or have had to cease operations as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation and a global financial and economic crisis. These crises also led to insolvency and closure at Mory-Ducros. As all the criteria for mobilising this fund have been met, this request should only be supported.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (proposal EGF/2014/017 FR/Mory-Ducros by France). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade or the aftermath of the global financial and economic crisis, with a view to facilitating their return to the labour market. There is no doubt that the redundancies at Mory-Ducros SAS are linked to a wave of bankruptcies linked to the global financial and economic crisis. Workers aged between 55 and 64 are a group that is particularly at risk of being excluded from the labour market as a result of long-term unemployment. The purpose of the funds is to help redundant workers find new jobs through active instruments, including training. The European Union's financial assistance to redundated workers should be dynamic, provided as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The so-called Globalisation Fund is increasingly being used by the EU institutions and is being used by the EU and governments in its Member States for the purposes of manipulating labour consciences and concealing the real cause of redundancies and soaring unemployment. By presenting the capitalist crisis as so-called "financial", it attempts to exonerate the capitalist system which, either in crisis or development, gives birth to, reproduces and recycles crises and unemployment inherent in the exploitative system. The crumbs of the Fund, inadequate even as a temporary breath for the dismissed, are attempted to be used to contain indignation, cover up and embellish capitalist barbarism, the unpopular policy of the EU and the urban governments that serve monopolies, while most of them reinforce various mechanisms – false training enterprises. Unemployment is not dealt with either by EU funds or by the crumbs of extreme poverty. In order for unemployment to become a definitive past, for stable work with rights for all, the working class needs to strengthen its fight to overthrow the unpopular policy, the exploitative system itself, in order to take into its own hands the power and wealth it produces.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. This report refers to France's application to the European Globalisation Fund to support 2 513 workers from a land transport and transport company by pipelines or pipelines, storage and rental of related materials, Mory-Ducros. The redundancies made by the company are located in the whole of metropolitan France. The largest number of redundant workers (257) is concentrated in the Ile de France region. At the time of the redundancies, the company was the second largest operator of these services in France, mobilising around 4 500 vehicles per day. Following the so-called global economic and financial crisis, road freight transport in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes contracted by 13.7 % in the EU and 21 % in France between 2007 and 2012 (Eurostat).
