The draft also addressed the need for a more effective monitoring system that takes into account the social and labour market situation within EMU, using appropriate social and employment indicators within the framework of the European Semester.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text presenting the Council's decision establishing the Social Protection Committee and repealing Decision 2000/436/EC. This is therefore a green light for the Commission's proposal to set up a strengthened cooperation mechanism, defined by the group of high-level officials, for the implementation of this action. This type of cooperation should cover all forms of social protection and, if necessary, help Member States improve and strengthen their social protection systems, in line with their national priorities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported the Decision establishing the Social Security and Repeal Committee decision 2004/689/EC, as I consider this necessary for that Committee to fulfil its purpose as an advisory body promoting cooperation between Member States and the Commission in the field of social protection policies.  The quality functioning of this Committee requires it to keep pace with the annual growth survey and I believe that the Council has revised the provisions relating to the functioning of the Social Security Committee in a quality way to ensure its effectiveness and continuity with the Cycle of the European Semester. The amendments proposed by the Council should ensure that those objectives are achieved in order to improve and strengthen the social protection system in line with member states' national priorities.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the chairmanship of the Social Protection Committee from two to four years. One of the functions of this Committee is to adapt the proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages according to productivity.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This social protection committee, made up of a group of high-level civil servants, has an advisory role with the EPSCO Council of All Ministers of Employment and Social Protection. The repeal of the previous decision aims to strengthen the objectives of cooperation between Member States by ensuring a binding monitoring of the social situation and the reforms undertaken, and meets the UNION's objective of modernising social protection systems. The role of the committee is above all to weigh in the procedure of the European semester through more significant social indicators and to intervene in the evaluation mechanisms by preparing reports and opinions.  This decision, regardless of the outcome of the European Parliament's vote, will be adopted by the Council independently of the opinion of the European Parliament. In short, this is yet another committee of experts who will interfere a little more in the affairs of the Member States in order to control and manage their social protection policies. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the chairmanship of the Social Protection Committee from two to four years. One of the functions of this Committee is to adapt the proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages according to productivity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mainly technical report on the Council Decision updating the mandate and function of the Social Protection Committee and repealing an earlier decision.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. In view of the Council's draft and the report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, it is considered appropriate to adopt the draft Council Decision laying down the Social Protection Committee and repealing Decision 2004/689/EC.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The figure of the Social Protection Committee follows the mandate of Article 160 TFEU. On an advisory basis, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the social protection policies of the Union and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Social Protection Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough reforms of social protection systems on the Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Social Protection Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, the loss of social rights and the dismantling of social services for the benefit of private capital. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The cuts in expenditure, in the social functions of the State, privatising public resources, promoting redundancies and making labour costs cheaper are totally contradictory to meet social objectives advocated by the Social Protection Committee.  In essence, this Committee, set up to strengthen the social dimension of EMU, serves only to legitimise all aspects of the European Semester. That is to legitimise all the economic policies that the Commission has imposed on countries. We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted negatively on the decision to set up a social protection committee, as I believe that the EU's extension of competences in the areas of employment, social affairs and socio-economics must be strongly rejected.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the new regulations establishing and operating an 'Employment Committee' and a 'Social Protection Committee' within the Council of the EU, committees composed of 'Member States' experts, because we believe that their sole purpose is to bring existing committees into line with the mechanisms of the European Semester and enhanced EU economic governance, i.e. the supervision and enforcement of those unpopular reforms and measures co-decided by the EU and civil governments in all Member States of the EU. The role reserved for old and new, in any case disreputable to workers, committees, is an additional attempt to manipulate the labour and popular masses by promoting the 'dialogue of the social partners', i.e. class cooperation and the subjugation of the working people to the aspirations of business groups, the 'sprinkling' of the anti-labour attack with propaganda smears of so-called 'social sensitivity', such as those to which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government in our country is particularly zealous. The unpopular policy agreed jointly by the EU institutions and the governments of urban management in all its Member States is not 'made up', no matter how many committees and propaganda mechanisms they set up. A strong popular alliance is needed for radical changes in power and the economy for the benefit of the people.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The Social Protection Committee is established with an advisory basis with the formally expressed objective of "promoting cooperation between Member States and with the Commission in matters of social protection policies, with full respect for the Treaty and taking due account of the competence of the Institutions and Bodies of the Union". It's kind of innocuous! In fact, this Committee is set up to strengthen the social dimension of EMU in order to contribute to all aspects of the European Semester. That is, to legitimise all the economic policies that the European Commission has imposed on countries with more spending cuts, in the social functions of the state, privatising public resources, promoting redundancies and making labour costs cheaper. These measures are totally contradictory to the social objectives expressed.  We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted for the report on the draft Council decision establishing the Social Protection Committee and repealing Decision 2004/689/EC, as the relevant parliamentary committee recommended the approval of the Council decision to set up a Social Protection Committee. This committee will have advisory status and will ensure better cooperation in the field of social protection policies between the Member States and the Commission. The Parliamentary Committee recommended that it be ensured that high-quality and sustainable healthcare be provided for all of the four main objectives set by the Commission in the context of the integrated modernisation of social protection systems. While these objectives also relate to a sustainable pension system, fair pay for work and the promotion of social inclusion, their achievement requires ensuring better coordination of employment, social and socio-economic policies of the Member States.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The figure of the Employment Committee follows the mandate of Article 150 TFEU. On an advisory basis, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the social protection policies of the Union and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Employment Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough reforms of social protection systems on the Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Employment Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, the loss of social rights and the dismantling of social services for the benefit of private capital. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report approves the replacement of Council Decision 2000/98 in order to enable the Chairman of the Employment Committee to be elected for a second term.  This is a technical report and that is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This draft Council decision aims to establish the Employment Committee. This committee has an advisory role and aims to advise the Ministers of Employment and Social Protection on the objectives of the European semester on employment. It is carrying out work on multilateral surveillance to monitor the progress made by Member States in implementing the reforms recommended in the country-by-country recommendations. It is therefore yet another committee that interferes in the affairs of Member States by monitoring their ways of managing their social protection policies and reporting them to the Commission. Moreover, the Council's decision does not require the opinion of the European Parliament to adopt this draft. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that Member States should have to coordinate their employment and labour market policies, nor that taxpayersʼ money should be spent on this.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the establishment of an Employment Committee. This committee will be an advisory body of the Council and the Commission to improve cooperation between the two institutions in the field of employment and labour market policy. Its tasks are to promote reflection on a high level of employment in Union policies, macroeconomic policy coordination and economic reform, to actively participate in macroeconomic dialogue at EU level, to contribute to all aspects of the European Semester and to inform the Council and to promote the exchange of information and experience between Member States and the Commission.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This committee is a meeting of "senior officials" whose role is advisory to the EPSCO Council (bringing together all the Ministers of Employment and Social Welfare). This committee contributes mainly to the development of RPP (country recommendations), as well as to the drawing of the European semester's employment objectives. As a coordinating tool, it is supposed to monitor the evolution of employment policies in the Member States by publishing reports and opinions. In my view, this is above all yet another committee that interferes in the affairs of Member States by monitoring their ways of managing their employment policies. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. At each beginning of the legislature, as it is not instituted by the treaties, it is necessary to re-create the advisory committee on employment, which brings together experts and national officials to assist the Council. The Committee's mission is to monitor the employment situation in the Member States and to produce reports or opinions on the issue, initiative or at the request of the Council or the Commission.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this time of economic crisis and with more than 25 million standing in the European Union at this time of economic crisis in the European Union to state whether it will respect the position and text adopted by Parliament. And if, on the other hand, it intends to propose a new text amending that adopted by this House, which will re-consult the relevant ones. Institutional respect, transparency and the need to strengthen credibility and trust in the European institutions obliges them to do so.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This is the establishment of the Employment Committee (which will be consultative) in order to fulfil the objective set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, namely, to promote the coordination of employment policies "in order to promote a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce, as well as labour markets capable of reacting quickly to the changing economy".  Its mission will be to monitor employment trends in the Member States and the Eu, etc. This is particularly funny when we know the level of unemployment in the countries of the Union... Instead of creating inconsistent committees, real empty shells, the Union would do better to stop the deadly austerity policies, even though the research services of the major international institutions now admit their inefficiency.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it important to set up an Advisory Committee whose aim is to promote cooperation in the field of employment and labour market policies between the Member States, a new instrument for coordination between the European institutions and territories that is most necessary at this time of deep and protracted economic and social crisis.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposed technical amendment to allow the chairman or chairperson of the Employment Committee to be eligible for a final second term. This gives greater stability to the work of this body set up to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies and to contribute to the adoption of the EU's broad economic policy guidelines.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the Council Decision establishing the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC. In order to promote coordination of the employment and labour market policies of the Member States, the Council establishes an Advisory Committee on Employment in full compliance with the Treaty and with due regard to the powers of the Community institutions and bodies.  In carrying out its tasks, which include advising and participating in the work of the Council and the Commission, the Committee should contribute to ensuring that the European Employment Strategy, macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process are developed and implemented in a coherent and mutually supported manner. The Committee should work closely with the social partners, in particular those who represent the Standing Committee on Employment.  June 2013 In its conclusions, the European Council expressed the importance of better coordination of employment, social and economic policies, while fully respecting national competences.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against this committee to monitor Member States in the conduct of their employment policies, which is unacceptable.  In addition, I renew my reservations about the European semester on employment, which this committee is responsible for drawing up the objectives.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. With its ultra-austerity policy, the European Union is the biggest provider of unemployment. Yet it finds no problem spending public money when it comes to creating an employment advisory committee. This creation follows the long list including the Social Protection Committee, the Economic and Financial Committee, the Economic Policy Committee, the Education Committee and the Board of Directors of the European Public Services Network. These committees are all public money wasted on technocrats who are completely disconnected from reality, especially employment. That is why I voted against the creation of this new institution and will ask, for the sake of transparency for citizens, to communicate the operating costs of these institutions.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 5 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) provides that the Union must take measures to ensure the coordination of Member States' employment policies, with a view to increasing their efficiency by developing a coordinated employment strategy. Taking into account the growing proportion of citizens made redundant and the large number of companies that have reached the brink of bankruptcy, it is extremely important that, across all EU countries, there is a coherent employment policy.  That is why I voted in favour of this resolution establishing the Employment Committee, a body which will certainly contribute successfully to the guarantee, coordination and implementation of employment policies at European Union level.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament was consulted on the establishment of new prerogatives for the employment committee. In this context of economic and financial crisis, we are facing sluggish growth and a very high unemployment rate throughout Europe. We must do everything in our power to create jobs. This, of course, requires enhanced social coordination. That is why I welcome the role of the Employment Committee, which is tasked with monitoring the evolution of employment policies in the Member States. So I voted in favour of that decision.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today to support the role of the Employment Committee, which must coordinate Member States' employment and labour market policies. In order to respond to the high levels of unemployment in Europe, the Employment Committee must launch a series of measures to promote job creation by evaluating the individual national reform programmes.  The Employment Committee, which brings together representatives of the Member States and the European Commission, can foster cooperation between Member States and the European Commission to meet the employment challenge by proposing strategies to invest in human capital through improved education and training. In addition, the Employment Committee must suggest new initiatives to make the EU more attractive to investors and workers by developing the internal market, improving national regulations, removing obstacles to the creation of new SMEs, stimulating entrepreneurship, ensuring open and competitive markets, improving European infrastructure and increasing flexibility to better adapt to restructuring and market developments.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒  I voted against this Report as the specific vote concerned the extension of the mandate of the chair of the committee from 2 to 4 years.  In the proposal for the change of the mandate, the extension is linked to the cycle of the European Semester, including also country-specific recommendations. The European Semester is a fundamentally undemocratic pact. Its focus is supposedly to avoid economic boom and bust cycles, and is aimed at restoring economic growth to the EU. However, there is no mention of equitable growth and poverty reduction. It shows a clear disconnect between European bureaucrats and the reality that is facing millions of struggling working families in Ireland and right across the EU. The European Semester reform’s primary aim seems to be just to ensure that Member States do not deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is pushing. It does not leave Member States with flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs. In effect it is working to deny both Irish and other EU citizens real political choices when electing their governments and is further eroding sovereignty and reducing economic independence.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I have followed and participated actively throughout the debate on this matter. I believe that this committee has been very effective and served its advisory role very well.  I have voted in favour of this Report particularly as I agree that in the case of the Employment committee, the European Semester is now being given priority and the committee will ensure efficiency and continuity in between each of the European Semester cycles.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of setting up the Employment Committee as presented by the Council decision. This Committee on Employment brings together representatives of the Member States and the European Commission and should promote cooperation between the Member States and the European Commission in order to meet the employment challenge. That is why, here too, we believe that the fight against unemployment must be a priority for the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of setting up such a committee.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which, once again, validates the Council's decision to create another costly and unused institution. Indeed, the Council wants to create an employment committee whose main role will be the drafting by senior officials of non-binding reports and opinions on the employment policies of the Member States. Apart from the fact that France already has various institutions that audit its various public policies (such as the Court of Auditors), the European Union does not have to create an empty shell, financed by the taxes of our citizens, to judge areas of public action that remain the competence of the Member States.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved the Council's draft setting up the Employment Committee as provided for in the text of Article 150 TFEI. This committee is advisory in nature and aims to promote coordination between Member States with regard to employment and labour market policies. The main functions are: (1) to monitor the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the Union and (2) to deliver opinions at the request of the Council or the Commission or on its own initiative, and to contribute to the preparation of the Council's work. In the performance of its duties, the Committee shall consult the social partners. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision establishing the Employment Committee, because it aims to promote the coordination of employment and labour market policies in the countries of the European Union, and thus to combat the unemployment rate in the EU, which according to data for December 2014 is 9.9%. In Italy, in particular, we need additional efforts which this government does not seem to want to make, over and above the façade changes. Indeed, I am convinced that a European Union can act by facilitating the coordination of member states' employment policies, in order to increase their effectiveness and develop a coordinated employment strategy. Furthermore, I welcome the way in which the committee's members are selected, who are chosen from senior officials or experts with proven experience in the field of employment and the labour market, because I believe that such an important and complex issue must rightly be assigned to officials with specific skills.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision establishing the Employment Committee because of the need for a common strategy to find a solution to the problem of unemployment that has been affecting the whole continent for some years. Given the recognized freedom of movement of workers, it is considered, in fact, that the time is more than ripe to implement employment policies at European Union level. From this point of view, the creation of a Committee to monitor internal problems in the Member States and developments in national labour market legislation is essential.  The new entity, which will be composed of experts in the field, will be able to formulate opinions and opinions, either at the request of the Council or the Commission or on its own initiative, and will thus contribute to European programming in the fields of employment and the labour market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report approving the draft Council decision establishing the Employment Committee which monitors the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the European Union as well as formulating opinions at the request of either the Council or the Commission or on its own initiative.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The figure of the Employment Committee follows the mandate of Article 150 TFEU. On an advisory basis, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the social protection policies of the Union and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Employment Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough reforms of social protection systems on the Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Employment Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, the loss of social rights and the dismantling of social services for the benefit of private capital. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I agree with the Council decision to establish the Employment Committee. I believe this will help Member States and the European Union to develop a coordinated strategy for employment and particularly for promoting a skilled and trained workforce and a labour market which is responsive to economic change.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the face of the challenges of globalisation, Member States need more than ever a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce, as well as flexible labour markets. However, to be effective in the face of the global economic and financial crisis, the coordinated employment strategy must be consistent with macroeconomic policies and the economic reform process at European level. This is why the coordination of employment and labour market policies must be supported through the Employment Advisory Committee.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the Council's decision to establish the Employment Committee. The multitude of committees, whose usefulness and legitimacy can be questioned, only strengthens supranational institutions, while adding illegibility. Once again, the European Union is seeking to transfer decision-making centres and solidify structures that are widely contested by citizens of all Member States.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Ulvaskog's report on a Council decision establishing an Employment Committee. This Committee will help coordinate the employment policies of the Member States. The problem of employment, especially among young people, is one of the main challenges faced by not only individual Member States, but also the Union as a whole. I believe that measures need to be taken at European level to tackle it, as because of its scale, it is impossible for countries to cope on their own. In many areas of Eastern Europe there is depopulation of entire regions and leakage due to labour migration. This process must be stopped because it poses a serious threat to the existence of the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report and support the recommendation of the Employment Committee because it targets high levels of employment and underlines the importance of proper management of the guidelines and cooperation of the Member States.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a special legislative procedure for consultation, in which Parliament endorses the wording drawn up by the Council concerning the establishment of the Employment Committee, and the Council should inform Parliament if it depart from the wording it has previously drawn up and approved by Parliament.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Employment Committee is provided for in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. This advisory Committee is formally set up to 'reflect the development of the European Semester'. That is, this Employment Committee should contribute to 'the adoption of the broad economic policy guidelines in order to ensure coherence between the employment guidelines and the general guidelines, and contribute to the synergy between the European employment strategy, macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process in a mutually advantageous manner'. We ask ourselves: advantageous to whom? Certainly, following the logic of the European Semester, it will not be for workers. This is about legitimising instruments at the service of social retrogression, as is proven in the case of the European Semester, under the cover of an apparent social concern. We don't get in the decoy. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Articles 150 and 160 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provide that the European Parliament must be involved in any changes to the Employment Committee in question. Rather, this is a technical consultation, which relates in particular to the possible extension of the term of office of the Chairman of the Committee, since the term of office of the Chairperson can currently be extended once for a period of two years. Since this step, stakeholders have promised greater continuity in the work of the Employment Committee.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the decision establishing the Committee to promote coordination on employment and labour market policies between the Member States and the Commission. The Committee shall consist of two representatives appointed by each Member State and two representatives of the Commission.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the establishment of the Employment Committee because it targets high levels of employment and underlines the importance of proper management of the guidelines and cooperation of the Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Article 5 of the Treaty on Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) states that the Union shall take measures to ensure coordination of the employment policies of the Member States to enhance their effectiveness by developing a coordinated strategy for employment and for promoting a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce and labour markets that are responsive to economic change.  The proposed Council Decision aims at establishing an advisory Employment Committee to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies.  I supported this proposal in the plenary session considering the positive outcomes this initiative will have on EU citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In its conclusions on strengthening cooperation in order to modernise and develop social protection, the Council supported the Commission's proposal to establish a mechanism for the implementation of this measure with regard to enhanced cooperation based on the work of the High Level Group of Officials. The Council underlined that this cooperation should cover all forms of social protection and, if necessary, help Member States to further develop and strengthen their social protection systems in line with their national priorities. Of course, it remains the responsibility of the Member States to organise and finance social protection, and there is no change in that. I voted in favour of this decision because it is very important that all objectives are subject to uniform funding criteria.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution on the draft Council Decision laying down the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC as it is a step forward in the aspect of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union which provides that the Union must take the necessary measures to ensure the coordination of Member States' employment policies, to strengthen its effectiveness by developing a coordinated strategy for employment, and in particular to promote trained, trained and adaptable citizenship to changing productive needs, as well as to ensure the adaptability of labour markets to economic changes.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Unemployment figures in Europe are unfortunately still discouraging. Faced with this situation, the EU has an urgent obligation to take all necessary measures to boost employment and give a future to millions of European families.  I have today voted in favour of the draft resolution establishing the Employment Committee in order to ensure better coordination between EU labour market policies and to provide, through it, an instrument that will ensure greater preparation by the Council in the preparation and implementation of the European Employment Strategy.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision establishing the Employment Committee and repealing the previous Decision 2000/98/EC, because the Committee in question is called upon to play an important role in coordinating member states' employment policies with a view to strengthening their effectiveness, so that the development and subsequent implementation of a European employment strategy and the coordination of macroeconomic policies are formulated in a coherent manner. The committee's tasks are very important because it is called upon to participate in the procedure for adopting the broad economic policy guidelines, to promote coordination between the Member States in the field of employment policies and labour markets, within the framework of the European Semester. By promoting the exchange of information and good practice between the Member States and the Commission, and by participating in macroeconomic dialogue at European level. The Decision provides for the Committee to be composed of two representatives from each Member State and two from the European Commission, taking gender equality into account in their respective appointments.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I welcome the outcome of the vote on the report on the Council decision establishing the Employment Committee. Member States and the Union should work to develop a coordinated employment strategy, and in particular to support skilled and trained workers responding to economic changes in labour markets.  The decision establishing the Committee reflects the development of the European Semester and the committee's role in this process. The weighting of the Employment Committee shall be equal to that of the Economic and Financial Committee, the Economic Policy Committee and the Social Protection Committee. All together, if necessary, will be consulted as part of the European Semester, which is undoubtedly important in the light of the continuing economic inequality in Europe. We look hope for a fair fulfilment of the mandate by the committee, which will be open to consultation with the social partners.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Council decision to establish the Employment Committee given that there is an imperative need for the EU to develop a coordinated strategy for employment, particularly for promoting a skilled and trained workforce and making sure our labour market can adapt swiftly to economic change.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to set up an employment committee. First of all, because of its nature: the consultative nature, in fact, highlighted the need for coordination between the Member States in the field of employment and the labour market. But, certainly more important and urgent, is the objective that this committee has set itself. Monitoring labour policies in the Member States and achieving high employment standards will help to improve the social conditions of many workers who, especially in recent years, have suffered from the weakening of many of their rights as a result of the crisis.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. – We voted against this Council proposal to extend the Presidency of the Employment Committee from two to four years. The fundamental function of this Committee is to adapt the Proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages to productivity.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision to establish the Employment Committee. I believe this is necessary to ensure Europe has a labour market which is responsive to economic change. This will help Member States to develop a coordinated strategy for employment right across the EU and will be particularly useful in developing a skilled and trained workforce.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to set up the Employment Committee as an advisory body of the Council and the Commission. In today's situation, where employment is one of the most serious factors in the EU's economic recovery, we need to use the administrative levers in our hands, to mobilise the expertise of professionals and the ability of the institutions to deal with this problem. I hope that the establishment of an advisory Committee on Employment will ensure the consistent implementation of the European Employment Strategy. It will also contribute to more effective macroeconomic policy coordination and economic reform.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this report to establish the Employment Committee. The Committee, by advising both the Council and Commission, aims to ensure coordination of the employment situation and policies of Member States by enhancing the consistency and effectiveness of such policies with a coordinated strategy with a particular focus on the promotion of a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce. It is also important to note the Committee’s role in the framework of the European Semester.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report.  The Employment Committee plays a key role in advising Employment and Social Affairs Ministers in the Employment and Social Affairs Council, by monitoring progressive aims such as the Youth Guarantee.  The Scottish Government is supportive of the Youth Guarantee and it has proven to be effective in producing a decline in the rate of young people not in education, employment or training in Scotland.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, honourable members, against the background of the economic crisis, high unemployment rates and especially youth unemployment, voting in favour of the decision to set up an Employment Committee is extremely important.  The Committee will monitor the overall development of employment and policy issues in this area, work to develop cooperation, the exchange of good practices and macroeconomic dialogue between Member States. I believe that the establishment of an Employment Committee will stimulate the improvement of european labour market conditions and economic growth in general.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the Presidency of the Employment Committee from two to four years. The fundamental function of this Committee is to adapt the Proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages to productivity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Council's draft decision to establish a Committee on Employment and Repeal decision 2000/98/EC, as I support the creation of a coordinated employment strategy that should raise the employment rate within the European Union to stimulate comprehensive growth.  Most European countries have significantly felt the effects of high unemployment rates that have hit the labour market greatly. It is important to ensure that the current synergies between Member States in market and employment policies are improved. In this context, the Committee's cooperation with other committees and relevant bodies is essential. Although advisory, the role of the Committee concerned can certainly be one of the factors that will contribute to delivering positive results in employment policies.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This committee will bring together senior officials who will have an advisory focus on the EPSCO (Employment, Policy, Social, Health and Consumers) Council. In particular, it will monitor the evolution of employment policies in the Member States through its reports and opinions. In addition, it will be used to establish a social component in macroeconomic negotiations between EU members, particularly when setting the objectives of the European semester. Nevertheless, this vote is biased to say the least, since, whatever the opinion of the European Parliament, this Council decision will be implemented and implemented. We are therefore witnessing a real denial of democracy, giving power to unelected technocrats and not to the representatives of the peoples. That is why I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. The European Parliament was consulted on the decision to establish the Employment Committee, which gave rise to this report. I welcome Parliament's approval of the Council's decision, which is in line with the objective of a high level of employment in all EU policies. The tasks entrusted to this committee seem relevant to me, in particular with regard to the exchange of information and experiences between Member States to improve the employment situation.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to create an employment advisory committee to promote better coordination of national employment and labour market policies. The main function of this committee will be to monitor the evolution of employment policies in the Member States, to participate in the European macroeconomic dialogue and to promote the exchange of information and experiences.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the decision to establish an advisory Employment Committee to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against it because this advisory committee is responsible for monitoring the evolution of employment policies in the Member States. It is not very dangerous at first sight, but the aim seems to be to give social support to the ultra-liberal policy of the Union, which I do not want to do.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The figure of the Employment Committee follows the mandate of Article 150 TFEU. On an advisory basis, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the social protection policies of the Union and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Employment Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough reforms of social protection systems on the Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Employment Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, the loss of social rights and the dismantling of social services for the benefit of private capital. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The TFEU provides for the establishment of an Advisory Employment Committee which should help ensure that the European strategy for employment, macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process are formulated and implemented in a coherent and mutually supportive manner. The proposal for a Council Decision aims to establish an Advisory Employment Committee to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies.  The task of the Committee will be to verify the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the Union.  In fulfilling its mandate, the Committee will consult the social partners and work in cooperation with other relevant bodies and committees dealing with social and economic policy issues. For its composition each Member State and the Commission shall designate two members of the Committee. The Committee shall elect its Chairman from among the members appointed by the Member States for a period of two years, renewable once. The president will be assisted by four vice presidents. I believe that this measure can bring benefits for the realization of the European employment strategy; that's why I voted favorably.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the establishment of any commissions to monitor the employment situation in individual states. The labour market is a matter for each individual state and its constituents. Not to mention that no commission can increase employment in any way.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 At a time when the European Union is filled with armies of unemployed people due to mercelian austerity, the establishment of the Employment Committee to be voted on, which will deal with the development of employment policies in the Member States and in the Union, is a positive first step. This is because this Commission must, inter alia, promote the achievement of high-level employment in the formulation and implementation of Union policies and help to ensure the compatibility of the EU's general economic policies with the employment guidelines.  It should be noted that the creation of this committee will ensure better coordination of employment policy, with full respect for national competences.  The Employment Committee will also consult with the social partners and cooperate with other relevant bodies such as the Social Protection Committee and promote the exchange of information and experience between the Member States and the European Commission. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision setting up the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I also voted against this decision. Again, the aim of this committee is to interfere in the affairs of the Member States by monitoring how they manage their employment policies and reporting them to the European Commission. It is an infringement of the right of Member States to legislate and act.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ By way of an explanation of my vote, I felt that this was a well-balanced report on this issue.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision establishing the Employment Committee, I believe that strengthening and improving social protection through the establishment of a committee is a necessary means of improving the situation of workers. Social advancement makes work profitable by offering safe income through sustainable pension schemes and through health care for all.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the European Parliament's report on the establishment of the Employment Committee. It is important that we put in place all mechanisms to ensure full effectiveness and maximum coordination in the development of Community employment policies, in order to assist in the fight against unemployment affecting so many citizens of the European Union.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I also refused to give my assent to this decision to set up an Employment Committee. I am opposed to the EU's extension of competences in the areas of employment, social affairs and socio-economics.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Council's proposed decision aims to establish an employment advisory committee, in accordance with Article 5 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (FUE Treaty). These provisions are therefore the result of the Lisbon Treaty which I had opposed. They provide for the establishment of an advisory employment committee whose role would be to contribute to the coherent and complementary implementation of European employment strategies, macroeconomic policies and the economic reform process. In concrete terms, it will be a matter of contributing to the procedure for adopting the broad economic policy guidelines and participating in the macro-economic dialogue at EU level, of course within the framework of the European Semester. So widespread austerity. Parliament's report validates the Council's proposal. I vote AGAINST

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Considering that this is a committee: - additional advisory, - composed of members chosen by co-optation, - with uncertain efficiency but costly functioning, - whose objective seems to be to interfere in the prerogatives of the States, I voted AGAINST.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Employment Committee is very relevant to strengthening the social dimension of EMU. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The newly established Employment Committee will serve as a tool to monitor the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the European Union as a whole. It will be comprised of highly qualified senior officials or experts in the field of employment and the labour market. I voted in favour of this proposal as it is crucial that the European Union maintains its path to economic recovery and higher levels of employment, especially amongst young people.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for support regarding changes of Council Decision 2000/98/EC of 24 January 2000 establishing the Employment Committee. Articles 150 and 160 TFEU provide that the Parliament shall be consulted when establishing this Committee. The consultation is of a technical nature and concerns in particular the possible extension of the Chair’s term of office. The draft Council decision provides that the Chairperson shall be elected for a term of two years, which shall be renewable once.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Setting up an Employment Advisory Committee and increasing attention to maintaining a level of employment could be good news

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Article 5 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, the Union is taking steps to develop an employment strategy coordinated to coordinate member states' employment policies, in particular by developing a skilled, skilled and well-suited workforce and a labour market adapted to economic change. The Council's draft decision foresees the setting up of an Advisory Employment Committee to help coordinate member states' employment and labour market policies. I consider the Council's initiative justified in the light of the current employment situation and the Union's employment objectives.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of this High Level Committee on Employment comes at a time when the Union and the Member States are agreeing solutions for the coordination of employment and labour market policies in the different Member States.  I am voting in favour of this proposal, as I consider it essential that the Union's Macroeconomic Policy and its Pillar of Economic Governance be linked to employment policies. Still within its functions is the consultation with the Social Partners.  The composition of the Committee is defined by the appointment by each State of a Member, alongside the European Commission.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This is the establishment of the Employment Committee (which will be consultative) in order to fulfil the objective set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, namely, to promote the coordination of employment policies 'in order to promote a skilled, trained and adaptable workforce, as well as labour markets capable of reacting quickly to the changing economy'.  Its mission will be to monitor employment trends in the Member States and the Eu, etc. This is particularly funny when you consider the level of unemployment that prevails in the countries of the European Union ... Instead of creating inconsistent committees, the EU would do better to stop deadly austerity policies, even though the research services of major international institutions now admit to their inefficiency.  For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which assigns new tasks to the employment committee. Created in 2010, the committee monitors the evolution of the employment situation throughout the Union. It promotes the coordination of employment and labour market policies, while respecting the competences of Member States. It works closely with social partners.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the draft Council decision on the establishment of the Employment Committee, as we consider it essential that the European Union, in accordance with Article 5 TFEI, takes measures to ensure coordination of labour policies in all Member States. The ultimate aim must undoubtedly be to develop a coordinated strategy favouring a skilled, trained and able to adapt both to changes in the labour market and to react to changes in the economy in general. We consider the role that this Advisory Committee can play in the process of economic reform in the Member States to make them as coherent and complementary as possible. One of its tasks will also be to contribute to the coordination of economic policies within the Framework of the European Semester and to facilitate the exchange of information and good practice between the Member States and the European Commission. The Committee will also have to ensure proper consultation of all the social partners and the other competent bodies and committees dealing with social and economic policy issues.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision establishing the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC. This advisory committee will have to monitor the employment policies of the Member States and the Union in order to develop a coordinated strategy for employment, and in particular for the promotion of a competent and qualified workforce capable of responding to economic change.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the draft council decision setting up the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC. Analysing the employment situation at European level, the solutions developed by the Member States and identifying effective and common measures must become a priority for the European Union. Such a special committee can ensure better cooperation at European level on jobs.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the establishment of the Employment Committee, although I believe that such an organisation should have been set up earlier, at the very first symptoms and effects of the already several-year economic crisis, which has also brought very severe social consequences throughout the European Union. I am of the opinion that this Committee must take ambitious measures in the social sphere, especially in the policies affecting European youth. Being one of the biggest victims of this economic and financial crisis, many young people, especially in Europe's smaller economies, have lost hope of realising and supporting the Union.  I also believe that the Employment Committee should pay particular attention to a as if still undervalued social initiative – volunteering. I believe that by recognising it for work experience and enhancing legal status across the European Union, we will enable civil society and entrepreneurship to help tackle unemployment. The severe floods last year in my country – Bulgaria, have shown that volunteering is a social investment, so I call on the newly established Committee to treat this issue with priority.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The European Union wants to expand its competences in the fields of employment, social affairs and social economy. For me, this permanent proliferation of competences is indefensible; that is why I voted against this decision.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision. whereas the committee has a key role to play in the development of the European Semester and in ensuring the implementation of the European Employment Strategy.  In particular, it will contribute to the effective implementation of the coordinated employment strategy and to ensuring that macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process are developed and implemented in a coherent and complementary manner. It should be noted that the role of the Employment Committee is crucial in developing a skilled, professionally prepared and adaptable workforce and promoting labour markets that adapt to economic change.  In this context, it is essential that the role of the Committee is properly reflected in the European Semester and given sufficient leeway and flexibility to adapt to the European Semester cycle, thereby ensuring its effectiveness and continuity.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the new regulations establishing and operating an 'Employment Committee' and a 'Social Protection Committee' within the Council of the EU, committees composed of 'Member States' experts, because we believe that their sole purpose is to bring existing committees into line with the mechanisms of the European Semester and enhanced EU economic governance, i.e. the supervision and enforcement of those unpopular reforms and measures co-decided by the EU and civil governments in all Member States of the EU. The role reserved for old and new, in any case disreputable to workers, committees, is an additional attempt to manipulate the labour and popular masses by promoting the 'dialogue of the social partners', i.e. class cooperation and the subjugation of the working people to the aspirations of business groups, the 'sprinkling' of the anti-labour attack with propaganda smears of so-called 'social sensitivity', such as those to which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government in our country is particularly zealous. The unpopular policy agreed jointly by the EU institutions and the governments of urban management in all its Member States is not 'made up', no matter how many committees and propaganda mechanisms they set up. A strong popular alliance is needed for radical changes in power and the economy for the benefit of the people.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. In view of the fact that the European Parliament approves the Council's draft, invites the Council to inform it if it intends to depart from the text approved by Parliament, asks the Council to consult it again if it intends to amend substantially the text approved by Parliament and instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission and to the national parliaments, for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the Draft Council Decision establishing the Employment Advisory Committee, which will contribute to the formulation and implementation of the European employment strategy, macroeconomic policy and economic reform process. The Employment Committee will actively attend macroeconomic dialogue at Union level, contribute to all aspects of the European Semester, promote the adoption of broad economic guidelines and exchange of experience between Member States in promoting the high employment target using Union activities and policies. Member equality has been achieved through the very establishment of the Committee, as each Member State and the Commission will appoint two members of the Committee. Cooperation with social partners and other committees dealing with social and economic policy issues will lead to better cooperation and coordination in employment across the Union.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The European Union decides to extend its grip on Member States' employment policies. This interference and this new attack on the sovereignty of nations is obviously unacceptable. Each people must be able to democratically decide for itself what it considers most relevant as an employment policy. I must vote against it without hesitation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Ulski's report on the acceptance of the Draft Council Decision establishing the Employment and Repeal Committee decision 2000/98/EC. As this is a specific legislative consultation process, I consider it important to stress that the Council should consult Parliament again if it intends to substantially amend the text accepted by Parliament.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported MEP Maria Ulvski's report on the Draft Council Decision establishing the Employment and Repeal Committee decision 2000/98/EC, as I think it is necessary to strengthen the coordination of employment and labour market policies between Member States. Member States play a primary role in implementing employment policy, including youth employment policy, but the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU for a reason provides for the establishment of an Employment Committee that will have an advisory status and a role to promote coordination between Member States. While employment policies are the responsibility of Member States, it is important to have an EU-wide body to monitor employment indicators and monitor the situation and employment policies in the EU. I believe that the Committee's action will certainly improve the exchange of member states' experience and make a major contribution in defining common objectives. For the collective success of the European Union, Member States, citizens, companies and social partners in the fight against unemployment and poverty, it is important to establish synergies with the new Social Security Committee precisely because of the close link between employment and social protection topics. Strengthening the social dimension of the Economic and Monetary Union is possible mainly through better coordination and monitoring of employment and social dialogue policies, which is the fundamental task of this Committee.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 At the same time, the Employment Committee has proved useful as an advisory body of the Council and the Commission on the issues assigned to it. Also following the report by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the vote in favour of all Members, I support its establishment and, consequently, the repeal of Decision 2000/98/EC

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 As with the previous standard, I supported the proposal on the establishment of the Employment Committee. Employment must be one of the priorities of any policy, and for this reason I am positive about the establishment of this committee and I supported that rule change. On the previous point, I have already highlighted coordination between Member States as an appropriate method of working in this field.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Today, the new Juncker Commission has made employment one of its priorities and is trying to promote employment policy through other European policies. In this context, I supported the amendments repealing the decision establishing the Employment Committee.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Under Article 5 TFEU, the EU takes measures to ensure the coordination of Member States' employment policies with a view to enhancing their effectiveness and developing a coordinated employment strategy.  This resolution adopts the decision to set up an advisory committee, the Employment Committee, which will have as its task the monitoring of developments in the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the Union, the formulation of opinions, whether at the request of the Council or the Commission, or on its own initiative, and support in the preparation of council deliberations referred to in Article 148 TFEU. The members of the Committee and alternates shall be chosen from among high-level officials or experts who have a primary competence in the field of employment policy and the labour market in the Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Any measure aimed at reducing unemployment in the countries of the European Union will always be positive. We hope that the decisions of the Employment Committee will have an effective impact on improving the quality of life of European citizens.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposed technical amendment to allow the chairman or chairperson of the Employment Committee to be eligible for a final second term. This gives greater stability to the work of this body set up to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies and to contribute to the adoption of the EU's broad economic policy guidelines.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today, I voted in favour of the Council's proposed decision to establish an employment advisory committee. I think it is important to coordinate Member States' employment policies and to put in place a coordinated employment strategy. The task of this committee will be to monitor the changing employment and employment situation in the Member States and the Union, to formulate opinions and also to promote the exchange of information and experiences between Member States and with the Commission. If the missions of this committee are important, I stress the importance for the committee to consult with the social partners who will, I am sure, be very helped in these various missions.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council's decision to renew and supplement the mandate of the Employment Committee with new functions. This committee works in a particularly important area - making recommendations on employment issues - in areas not fundamentally regulated by EU law. In the case of the non-binding decision-making process binding on the Member States, it is of particular importance to find compromises, exchanges of good practices and the identification of elements of good European practice through compromise , areas where this committee, together with the Social Protection Committee, is particularly well-engaged. I therefore believe that the updated and revised mandate of the Committee will contribute both to more effective coordination of member states' employment policies and to the further development and development of the informal European governance instrument - the open model of coordination.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Assuming the principle set out in Article 5 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), the Union takes measures to ensure the coordination of Member States' employment policies with a view to enhancing their effectiveness by developing a coordinated employment strategy. In developing this strategy, I consider it a good thing to set up the Employment Committee and the partnership work with the social partners, as well as with other bodies and committees in the field of social and economic policy. Despite being consultative, this Committee should be able to ensure the implementation of the European Employment Strategy and promote greater coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of setting up an advisory committee to promote coordination in the field of employment and labour market policies between the Member States. Each Member State and the Commission shall appoint two full members of the Committee. Its main functions are: to monitor the employment situation and policies in the Member States and in the Union; deliver opinions at the request of the Council or the Commission or on its own initiative; to contribute to the preparation of the Council's work under Article 148 of the Treaty.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the Presidency of the Employment Committee from two to four years. The fundamental function of this Committee is to adapt the Proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages to productivity.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The figure of the Employment Committee follows the mandate of Article 150 TFEU. Consultative in nature, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the employment policies of the Council and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Employment Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough labour reforms on the Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Employment Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, wage reductions or the elimination of labour rights such as collective bargaining for the benefit of private capital.  For all this, I voted against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision on the establishment of an Employment Committee of an advisory nature. I believe that this committee can promote and ensure better coordination both between the Member States and with the institutions of the European Union with regard to the definition of coherent strategies in the field of employment policies and the labour market. I am therefore sure that the committee will help to ensure that the European employment strategy, the coordination of macroeconomic policies and the process of economic reforms are formulated and implemented in a mutually beneficial manner.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ S&D Members of the European Parliament voted in support of the Council Decision aiming to establish an advisory Employment Committee to promote coordination between Member States on employment and labour  market policies. The tasks of the Committee shall be to monitor the employment situation and employment policies in the Member States and the Union. The Committee shall consult the social partners and work, as appropriate, in cooperation with other relevant bodies and committees dealing with social and economic policy matters.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of approving the Council proposal establishing an Employment Committee. This committee will monitor the employment situation in the Member States and the EU. It will support the objective of a high level of employment in formulating and implementing EU policies and action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – Report on the draft Council Decision establishing the Employment Committee and repealing Council Decision 2000/98/EC. I welcome the draft Council decision prolonging and clarifying the mandate of the EMCO Employment Committee, which operates within the EPSCO Council. As the draft Council decision reflects well the role of the Employment Committee in the context of the European Semester, I voted in favour of the report on the draft decision in the vote. The EMCO Employment Committee was established in 2000 by Council Decision 2000/98/EC, which defined the institutions, the main tasks and the functioning of the Committee. Over the past 14 years, the Committee's tasks have adapted to current developments in the Union and today focus mainly on advising ministers on employment outcomes in the context of the European Semester (evaluation of the European Employment Guidelines, joint employment report, EPSCO conclusions on the Annual Growth Survey...), making recommendations to individual Member States in the field of employment and assessing member states' progress in implementing these recommendations, preparing a horizontal opinion on national reform programmes and similar tasks.  In order to monitor effectively the employment situation in the Member States and the Union, the Committee should, in particular, promote the objective of high employment in policy-making and implementation and contribute to the procedure for adopting broad economic guidelines in order to ensure their consistency with the Employment Guidelines.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of this report, the aim of which is to set up an employment committee. To date, the number of unemployed within the European Union is 9.9%, and although there has been a decrease compared to previous years, we are not yet close enough to leaving the crisis tunnel. That is why I believe that the creation of such a committee can make a major contribution to the fight against unemployment. The aim of the Committee, to supervise the labour market and the policies applied by governments in the field of employment, I believe can allow the development of common European policies and strategies, which are fundamental for a further relaunch of the European labour market. In addition, such a committee will be able to allow for greater exchanges of information and macroeconomic dialogue at Union level, which will certainly make an important contribution and greater opportunities in the development of employment plans, not only national but above all European.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ I support the establishment of this committee and believe that we will pragmatically discuss the impact of the legislative acts adopted on employment. In particular, we must always bear in mind the impact on job creation and therefore reduce administrative complexity and simplify the overall environment.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Article 5 (TFEU) of the European Union should harmonise the employment strategy and adopt the same employment procedures in all Member States. The Committee would seek to promote a trained and trained workforce that would be competitive and representative of the market and easily adaptable to global economic change.  TFEU is committed to establishing an Employment Committee that will seek to establish a sustainable European employment strategy. The main objective is to establish macroeconomic policies that will implement economic reforms and implement them in a sustainable manner later. The main role of the Committee would be to oversee the recruitment process as well as the implementation of the employment policy within EU countries. The ultimate goal is to achieve a high employment rate within the European Union and thus strengthen the economic and economic situation within all Member States so that Europe is ultimately economically competitive on the global market.  Macroeconomic dialogue and cooperation at European level as well as information sharing should also be established.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree with the establishment of this committee, just as I do not agree with the establishment of the Social Protection Committee. The best policy for employment is to interfere as little as possible in the employment relationship between the employee and the employer. This includes all kinds of interventions, from excessive bureaucracy to excessive tax burdens. The creation of new bodies, even for the purpose of increasing employment, is therefore directly contrary to these objectives.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We cannot legitimise the insistence on neoliberal policies to support large capital, nor efforts to strengthen the full liberalisation of the market. What the economy needs is a shift towards public spending, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, respect for the special conditions of each country, ensuring decent living for all citizens and creating permanent jobs with guaranteed labour rights.  We have therefore decided to vote against the report because we do not believe that the Commission should define the employment policies of the Member States on the basis of the guidelines for the European Semester.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Employment Committee must aim at high levels of employment and highlight the importance of proper management of the guidelines and cooperation of the Member States.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft creation of the Employment Committee, as I believe that the amendments will make it more effective to coordinate employment strategies at EU level. The draft adopted will enable the institutions of the European Union to work on the basis of these harmonised principles and to draw up proposals on this basis, in particular with a particular concern for skilled and skilled workers.
