Furthermore, in the future, the Commission should consult more intensively with the social partners, which will certainly help to establish stronger control in the field of employment policy. Finally, I think it is important to highlight the European Parliament's work in the consultation process, which, in my opinion, also makes a tangible contribution to making legislation more effective.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text on the draft decision of the Council establishing the Employment Committee and repealing the 2000/98/EC decision. It should be remembered that in carrying out its mission, which includes providing advice and contributing to the preparation of the work of the Council and the Commission, the Committee should help to ensure that the European Employment Strategy, macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process are formulated and implemented in a coherent and complementary manner.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Decision establishing the Employment and Repeal Committee of Decision 2000/98/EC in order for the work of this Committee to fulfil its purpose, namely to promote cooperation between Member States in employment policy and the labour market. The Council requested the abolition of the original decision establishing this Committee, explaining that changes are needed to reflect the role held by the Employment Committee in the European Semester process.  I believe that the Employment Committee will, precisely through the changes proposed by the Council, contribute to the process leading to the adoption of broader economic guidelines and the Process of the European Semester and report back to the Council.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the Presidency of the Employment Committee from two to four years. The fundamental function of this Committee is to adapt the Proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages to productivity.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This committee is an assembly of senior officials whose role is advisory to the EPSCO Council (bringing together all the Ministers of Employment and Social Welfare). Adopting a new decision is supposed to meet the objectives of the European Union and make the social dimension more effective in macroeconomic dialogue. This committee contributes mainly to the development of RPP (country recommendations) and to the development of the European semester's employment objectives. As a coordinating tool, it will continue to monitor and monitor the evolution of employment policies in the Member States by publishing reports and opinions to the Commission. Whatever the opinion of the European Parliament, this Council decision will be adopted. This is another attempt to interfere a little more in the affairs of the Member States. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this Proposal by the Council to extend the Presidency of the Employment Committee from two to four years. The fundamental function of this Committee is to adapt the Proposals of the European Semester to employment policies in the Member States. We are already against the European Semester for proposing measures such as promoting worker mobility as a way to combat unemployment, raising the retirement age, continuing to delve into structural reforms or adapting wages to productivity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I also voted in favour of this report relating to the previous one, and also of a technical nature, on the Council Decision updating the mandate and function of the Employment Committee.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 Having regard to the Draft Council and the report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, it is considered appropriate to adopt the draft Council Decision laying down the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The figure of the Employment Committee follows the mandate of Article 150 TFEU. Consultative in nature, it contributes to the evaluation and supervision of the employment policies of the Council and the Member States. In practice, the figure of the Employment Committee is strongly related to the functions of the European Semester, with which the European institutions coordinate and impose tough labour reforms on Member States, with the complicity of a majority of neoliberal governments. I cannot accept that the Employment Committee serves to legitimize the erosion of democratic sovereignty, wage reductions or the elimination of labour rights such as collective bargaining for the benefit of private capital.  For all this, I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Employment Committee is provided for in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is another cosmetic body only designed to smoke the anti-social policies of this European Union and its devastating effects on populations and workers.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I also refused to give my assent to this decision to set up an Employment Committee. I am opposed to the EU's extension of competences in the areas of employment, social affairs and socio-economics.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the new regulations establishing and operating an 'Employment Committee' and a 'Social Protection Committee' within the Council of the EU, committees composed of 'Member States' experts, because we believe that their sole purpose is to bring existing committees into line with the mechanisms of the European Semester and enhanced EU economic governance, i.e. the supervision and enforcement of those unpopular reforms and measures co-decided by the EU and civil governments in all Member States of the EU. The role reserved for old and new, in any case disreputable to workers, committees, is an additional attempt to manipulate the labour and popular masses by promoting the 'dialogue of the social partners', i.e. class cooperation and the subjugation of the working people to the aspirations of business groups, the 'sprinkling' of the anti-labour attack with propaganda smears of so-called 'social sensitivity', such as those to which the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government in our country is particularly zealous. The unpopular policy agreed jointly by the EU institutions and the governments of urban management in all its Member States is not 'made up', no matter how many committees and propaganda mechanisms they set up. A strong popular alliance is needed for radical changes in power and the economy for the benefit of the people.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of the Employment Committee is provided for in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. This advisory Committee is formally set up to "reflect the development of the European Semester". That is, this Employment Committee should contribute to "the adoption of the broad economic policy guidelines in order to ensure coherence between the employment guidelines and the general guidelines and to contribute to the synergy between the European employment strategy, macroeconomic policy coordination and the economic reform process in a mutually beneficial manner". We ask ourselves: advantageous to whom? I am sure that, following the logic of the European Semester, it will not be for the workers.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision establishing the Employment Committee and repealing Decision 2000/98/EC in view of the recommendation of the parliamentary committee responsible. The Council wishes to set up an Advisory Committee on Employment to ensure better coordination between Member States on employment and labour market policies. The Committee should ensure that the European employment strategy, macroeconomic policy coordination and economic reforms are designed and implemented in a consistent manner and in the mutual cooperation of the Member States. Each Member State and the European Commission should appoint two members of the Committee for a period of two years, which may be renewed once. The Committee should elect its chairman from among the members appointed by the Member States. The Committee should follow the development of employment and employment policies in the Member States and in the EU, consult the social partners and work with other bodies and committees dealing with social and economic policy issues. It should promote the objective of a high level of employment in the formulation and implementation of EU policies and activities and contribute to all aspects of the European Semester within its mandate.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported the Council Regulation, which regulates the multiannual financial framework, because this change is very important for the Czech Republic, which I represent here. It allows the money, which was intended for 2014 and was CZK 80 billion, to be spent only in 2015.  In a situation where this change would not occur, the Czech Republic would lose all money for 2014, because unfortunately not a single operational programme has been approved so far.  In addition to the delay in the Czech administration, the culprit is that the regulation itself, which regulates these rules, was adopted relatively late. I therefore think that the change that we have pushed through today is beneficial because it will lead to the money intended for economically weaker regions being properly spent.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted in favour of amending the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, because this will allow funds that have not been used in the past to be transferred in 2015. 300 operational programmes will be implemented. In particular, in relation to Greece, programmes to reduce unemployment, which has reached 26%, could be financed. Programmes will be implemented for projects of community service and training for thousands of young people in Greece, at a time when unemployment among our young people, due to the Troika and the Memorandums, has reached 51.7%. Programmes in the primary sector will also be financed in order for Greek farmers and livestock farmers to cope with the increased cost of production. Through the Cohesion Fund, projects for transport and energy infrastructure will be implemented. Finally, research, innovation and education will be strengthened through the implementation of the relevant programmes.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion affecting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being used.  This project transfers these amounts to subsequent financial years to ensure that programmes adopted in the multiannual budget can be effectively financed despite accumulated delays. Because of its technical nature and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 As the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework took a long time to complete, many of the appropriations planned for 2014 remained unused. The amount that had been left unused and could not be transferred amounted to EUR 21 billion and concerned all Member States. In order not to lose this money, the European Commission has presented a proposal to amend the Multiannual Financial Framework and transfer this money in 2015. The Committee on Budgets has unanimously given its assent to this amendment and I hope that Parliament's plenary will do the same.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This rule change provides for the transfer of unused commitment credits in 2014. More than 300 programs, or 47% of all operational programs, are covered by these appropriations.  In addition, this regulation makes EUR 172 million available to the Asylums, Migration, Integration fund, which promotes legal immigration within the European Union.  This change is likely to exacerbate the problem of late payments. However, we still have 24 billion unpaid bills (11 billion in 2011).  However, this change remains purely technical and I have therefore abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As per my speech in the Chamber on this subject, it is entirely consistent for me to vote against. Money not spent should be returned to the taxpayer, not appropriated to the European Union in future.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion affecting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed amendment to the Regulation, which aims to carry over to this year 21.1 billion euro, which was not used in 2014. The amount of unused funds was caused by a delay in agreeing a regulation on the multiannual financial perspective. Consequently, various pieces of legislation laying down provisions for the implementation of the Funds have also been adopted late. This concerns the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. Their provisions were not adopted until May 2014. For this reason, as many as 300 programmes (47 %) could not be accepted in 2014 and the appropriations allocated to them were used. It is therefore necessary to adopt the amendments to the Regulation as soon as possible and to transfer unused funds to this year's budget in order to ensure the implementation of all the programmes envisaged.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The aim is to defer 21 billion unused appropriations to 2015 due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes for certain European funds. I am pleased to see that the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (FEADER) and fisheries are included in the budget lines. However, the recommendation also provides for EUR 172 million to be made available to the Asylum, Migration, Integration Fund, which, as the name suggests, aims to facilitate legal immigration. This recommendation of the European Parliament is totally disconnected from reality: in a damning 113-page report published in February 2015, the French experts of the Court of Auditors put the cost of asylum at more than 2 billion euros a year for our national community alone. For at the cost of those who arrive is added that of those who do not leave: only 1% of the rejected actually leaves the French territory. Therefore, I could not contribute my voice to this recommendation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The revision of the multi-year financial framework is aimed at transferring EUR 21 billion in commitment appropriations over subsequent years that were not used in 2014, the equivalent of 15% of the 2014 budget!  If this is a purely technical revision, it should be noted, however, that EUR 172 million will be made available to the "Asylum, Migration, Integration" fund and to promote legal immigration to the EU, an eminently questionable policy. It is also indicative of serious and even scandalous substantive elements such as the stock of unpaid debts, which grows from year to year, thus displaying a totally sclerotic management. The amount reached 24.7 billion in 2014 compared to 11 billion in 2011. And we are still waiting for a clean-up plan. Meanwhile, it is the local authorities that are paying the price.  This absurd system justifies for some a new federal leap which is nothing more than a leap into the void and would be an intolerable attack on the sovereignty of States. The only answer to this appalling management is to leave the Member States with full sovereignty over their budget and the allocation of investments.  Taking into account the purely technical aspect of the text, I therefore abstained.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in this report, it is clear that the entire multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 has been programmed in a completely unrealistic way that has led to measures such as this, which push the European institutions to move the funds in subsequent years to make ends meet; For these reasons, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 MFF Regulation provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014 and, due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion affecting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation, in which the European Parliament welcomes the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020. It is important to support the proposal for the transfer of appropriations from 2014 to 2015 in order to complete the process of starting the new programming period for cohesion policy and to avoid any negative consequences for regions and cities, and also for European citizens.  This proposal does not address any changes in payment appropriations on the assumption that the transfer of commitment appropriations from 2014 to 2015 will not create any particular impediment to payments in the coming years. The European Parliament's rapporteur doubts that this approach is correct and expects the commission services' calculations to prove realistic and that the flexibility provisions of the existing MFF Regulation will be sufficient to respond to any increase in interim payment requests in 2017 and 2018.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the amendment appears to be a formal act, I attach great importance to the full use of the Budgetary Instruments of the European Union in accordance with the objectives initially set. In line with the Fidesz-KDNP position, I voted in favour of the amendment of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Support for this draft Council Regulation amending the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework was the only logical move by Members to make appropriate use of certain financial resources that had already been approved but not used in 2014 in the same areas as their original purpose. In the future, such restrictions would encourage consumers to rush to prepare their programmes in fear of losing their funds as a result of short deadlines, while making so many more mistakes and superficiality. It therefore makes sense that where there has already been approvals for specific areas, there are not such strict limits on the year. Therefore, my support for this change or financial redistribution.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I give my consent to the Draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2012/2013. 1311/2013 establishing a multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The proposed amendments are intended to allow the postponement of unused appropriations to 2015 in 2014, i.e. EUR 21 billion, which corresponds to 15% of the 2014 budget, due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes for certain European funds. I can only regret that EUR 172 million is made available to the Asylum, Migration, Integration Fund, which is intended to promote legal immigration to the European Union, which is politically questionable and economically disastrous, particularly for France, as the Court of Auditors recently pointed out. However, I abstained on this text in view of the delays in payment which are piling up and which are likely to worsen on the one hand and, on the other hand, endanger programmes that help sectors of the French economy at risk, such as fishing or FEADER.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation amending the Multiannual Financial Framework for the years 2014-2020 because this is an indispensable step to complete the starting process of the new cohesion policy programming period, and it is of paramount importance to start a process as soon as possible in order to avoid any negative impact for EU citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Article 19 of the MFF allows for an amendment to transfer 21 billion euros of 2014 commitment credits for 2015 due to the delay in the adoption of operational programmes for European funds.  This amendment raises the question of the European Union's budgetary since when the last MFF was adopted, everyone knew that the latter would not be respected.  In addition, the one-year postponement of commitment appropriations will have the impact of the worsening of the payments crisis already estimated at 24 billion euros by the end of 2014.  Because I no longer support the small budgetary arrangements between the Council and the European Parliament, I abstained on the vote of this resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation to amend the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020 so that unused financial allocations in 2014 can be transferred for use for the following years. The Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Fisheries and Maritime Affairs Fund are just a few axes that will be revised with a view to transferring funds for the next years.  The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is a multiannual programming structure that translates the Union's political priorities into financial terms over a period of at least five years. It shall set the maximum annual amounts for large categories of expenditure. The annual budgetary procedure must comply with these maximum ceilings. The Multiannual Financial Framework ensures budgetary discipline and predictability of expenditure at EU level.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion for programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Regulation (EU, Euratom) 1311/2013 sets the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  Given the late adoption of the 2014-2020 cohesion policy regulations, which prevented the adoption of operational programs, the regulation needs to be revised accordingly.  The programmes concerned include European structural and investment funds. We absolutely need these operational programs to be quickly started and implemented at the end of the year.  That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014/2020. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the Union's most important investment policy and it is therefore essential that all resources are used quickly and effectively. The revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework must therefore be carried out by ensuring the implementation of the programmes that have been adopted later than planned: the new programming period has already suffered too many significant delays and we must prevent any further delays. Attention must be paid to the quality of the projects submitted and ensure that the programmes are aimed at stimulating growth and creating jobs, particularly for young people. Procedures must also be simplified with the aim of achieving full, constructive and effective use of all resources and, above all, enabling citizens and local authorities to have access to these financial resources.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This Report proposed to increase the ceilings on various headings. It needs to be stated for clarification that the increase does not provide new money – instead it is money being moved from 2014 to 2015 as various programmes were not adopted by the end of 2014. However, it was necessary to vote in favour of this report in order to enable this technical change.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for Parliament to give its consent to the proposal for a Council regulation revising the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020, as this proposal did not include any changes in payment appropriations.  The proposal was necessary due to the late adoption of the Cohesion Policy (as part of the European Structural and Investment Funds) regulations for this period, which resulted in only a handful of Operational Programmes being adopted by the end of 2014.  The European Structural and Investment Funds are the Union’s most important investment policy. It is therefore important that any negative impact for regions and cities and consequently for European citizens is avoided and that all resources are used in a timely and effective manner in order to generate growth and jobs.  I particularly welcome the statement by the Commission on the need for the Commission to cooperate with Member States and regions to swiftly adopt all remaining programmes and to carefully implement these programmes, with the aim of achieving full and effective use of all resources.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on an amendment to the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. It is an important technical change with a very concrete impact. Article 19 of the Regulation (EU, Council Euratom) No 1311/2013 provides that, where the new rules or programmes under shared management for the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the EAFRD, the EMFF, FAMI and the FSI are adopted after 1 January 2014, the multiannual financial framework will be revised in order to transfer unused allocations in 2014 to subsequent years. This vote allows us to insert changes in order to reallocate over 21 billion over the next few years, but these have not been used.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report which amends Regulation (EU) 1311/2013 to allow the transfer of unused commitment credits in 2014. Of course, this is an important measure since it involves at least EUR 21 billion, or 15% of the 2014 budget. However, I am concerned that the need for such a measure appears as a result of an increasing stock of unpaid bills: 24 billion euros of unpaid bills in 2014 compared to 11 billion in 2011. Furthermore, I would like to underline my total opposition to the fact that EUR 172 million is provided in the budget for the "Asylum, Migration, Integration" fund: everyone knows that this fund allows the financing of legal immigration, even though the EU is the first land of migration in the world; each year, more than 1.5 million migrants are registered and more than 128,725 irregular stays were recorded in the third quarter of 2014, a year that saw the flow of illegal immigration jump with an increase of 170% compared to 2013. It is expected to jump further in 2015, with the first two months of which show an increase of more than 200% compared to 2014!

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Pending a general review and a more in-depth review of the multiannual financial framework in 2016, the amendment we have approved will make it possible to "recover" and use, in the coming months, around EUR 21 billion of commitment appropriations that have unfortunately been unused in 2014 due to the delay in the development of many important programmes. This will make it possible to transfer EUR 16.5 billion to the 2015 budget and EUR 4.5 billion to the 2016 budget. These resources should be allocated to crucial areas of expenditure such as economic, social and territorial cohesion policy, sustainable growth and the enhancement of natural resources, so as to facilitate the development and implementation of local development programmes, and to trigger processes of economic recovery and employment growth, especially among young people, also by promoting the necessary revival of public investment at internal level. The Commission will have to work to avoid further delays in the preparation of programmes and commitment appropriations, and all the possibilities provided for in the MFF's flexibility provisions will have to be used, both to provide for payment appropriations on time and to increase employment support. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approves the draft Council regulation amending the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  As noted in the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development, the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. At the end of 2014, only 252 programmes were adopted (39%) the Union's activities. For 93 programmes (14%) there is no need for a review of the MFF as they were ready for adoption before the end of 2014 and were not adopted due to lack of time. The 2014 appropriations can still be adopted for these programmes. For the remaining 300 programmes (47%), a revision of the MFF is required.  The project aims to transfer to 2015 almost all programmes for economic and social cohesion, with the exception of ERDF contributions to cross-border programmes under the Pre-Accession Instrument (IPA) and the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) which are instead transferred to 2017. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of changing the multiannual financial framework, as delays in adopting the rules governing the programmes have undermined access to European structural development funds. This led to the non-implementation of numerous programmes in 2014 and the consequent stalemate of unused funds. For Italy alone, about 66% of the funds for 2014 were not allocated to programmes. This waste is no longer tolerable, and since my election I have been fighting for Italy, which already appears to be a net contributor, to obtain everything it deserves.  With the approval of these changes, we will be able to finance 300 national programmes that were delayed in 2014, and we will be able to transfer for the period 2015-2016-2017, the EUR 21.1 billion in commitment appropriations not used in 2014, but which are due to us. With the hope that no more snags will intervene later.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the draft Council regulation amending Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014/2020.  Given that, due to delays in adoption, it was not possible to commit part of the allocations for the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund to 2015, it is considered appropriate to amend the annex to the abovementioned Regulation.  I have therefore decided to support the Council's proposal for a revision, which will make it possible to transfer unused commitment appropriations in 2014 to subsequent years.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 led to the impossibility of a timely adoption of all operational programmes, which as a consequence were not advanced enough to benefit from the special carry-over procedure. A revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation was thus proposed to transfer unused commitment appropriations from 2014 to subsequent years. Apart from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund, these operational programmes include the European Structural and Investment Funds that are the European Unionʼs most important investment policy. It is essential that all resources are used in as timely a manner and as effectively as possible, to generate growth and jobs. I have thus voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being used.  This project transfers these amounts to subsequent financial years to ensure that programmes adopted in the multiannual budget can be effectively financed despite accumulated delays. Because of its technical nature and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 First of all, we must welcome the speed with which the Commission has taken action to remedy the late adoption of certain operational programmes, avoiding the loss of resources. From 1 May, at last and just as quickly, the programmes still in progress will have to be adopted and, more importantly, the resources, the only ones, available to the economies of our regions can be released. The aim, however, must be to prevent the concentration of resources in a single year from putting their absorption at risk and increasing the risk of disengagement in 2018. That is why we are calling on the Commission, in the months and years that follow, to step up its efforts by playing a genuine role as an active partner, working with national and regional authorities and adopting all available measures, including considering, in the 2017 review, the possibility of legislative interventions and changes. Without looking so far ahead, it will be essential – and we trust in this – that from the day after the entry into force of the new MFF, the Commission will activate all its resources and the instruments available to simplify and facilitate the task of national and regional authorities.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the EU’s seven year financial programme through which EU funds are distributed to the 28 Member States. This report suggests carrying-over EU funding for late-starter national programmes to 2015. The proposed changes to ceilings within the EU’s 2014-2017 framework would allow EUR 21.1 billion in unused commitment appropriations to be carried over from 2014 to 2015-2017. To me it is quite clear that we should do all that is possible to secure the full use of available funds towards bettering the lives of our citizens, hence I voted in favour of the flexibility required to achieve it in this particular circumstance.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the revision of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework and its budget amendment No 2/2015. Delays in the approval of the MFF, the regulations of the Funds in question and the operational programmes led to the use of Article 19 of Regulation 1311/2013. This is a technical initiative which calls for a broader review of budgetary policies. The current historic moment is crucial for the Union, flexibility responds to the needs of implementing cohesion policy. Large sums of the European budget will be transferred from 2014 to 2015 management, in support of regional policy whose priorities, convergence, competitiveness and cross-border cooperation, deserve constant attention from the European Parliament to ensure effective smart, inclusive and sustainable growth of the Union. The funds involved are therefore essential for the completion of the real single market and for Union security. Preventing the avalanche effect of late payments means providing rapid and preventive responses for the coming years too, avoiding aggravating the economic and financial crisis to the detriment of European citizens and administrations. In order to promote fair development and the protection of financial interests, a simplification of procedures and an active and synergistic role of institutional actors are desirable.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The delay in the adoption of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF), caused by difficult negotiations between states, should not penalise the beneficiaries of EUROPEAN funds. I support this proposal to amend the PSC regulation because the majority of allocations not used in 2014 would be transferred to 2015, particularly with regard to cohesion policy. This is the guarantee of equal treatment with programmes already adopted in 2014 or postponed. This will allow the start of the new programming period to be successful without slowing the pace of investment in growth and employment.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Written. \u2012 21 billion! 21 billion is left by this Commission. 21 billion have been overpaid by the European taxpayer. And now that money needs to be transferred to 2015 and next years. No, no and no! In the Netherlands, the elderly lie in their own shit for 24 hours, because there is no money for elderly care. In the Netherlands, 400 care homes are closed because the EU is demanding cuts. In the Netherlands, pensions are being cut by billions and money is flowing to Brussels. And there is no record of 21 billion here! There is only one destination for this money: those Member States that pay more than they receive! The Netherlands is the EU's biggest taxpayer! This money must be returned to the Dutch taxpayer. I hope that this Commission will finally regain its common sense and implement this proposal immediately.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed changes to the Eu ropean Union budget for 2014-2017, to fund 300 national programmes that were delayed in 2014. These changes, requested by the European Commission, will make it possible to transfer EUR 21.1 billion in unused commitment appropriations in 2014 to the period 2015-2017. For Italy this is an important milestone because about 66% of the funds planned for 2014 that have not been allocated to programmes can now be available for the period 2015-2017.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as by the end of 2014 only a small percentage of programmes (39%) adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, some through the transmission procedure provided for in the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the MED. The proposal aims to redeploy almost all unused budget appropriations under subheading 1b for 2015.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as by the end of 2014 only a small percentage of programmes (39%) adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, some through the transmission procedure provided for in the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the MED. The proposal aims to redeploy almost all unused budget appropriations under sub-chapter 1b for 2015. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the Report on the Amendment of the Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 1311/2013 setting the multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  Caution should be exercised in light of this change. On the face of it, it would help to facilitate the functioning of the European programmes for the period 2014-2020.  However, other major elements could be affected in the background. Indeed, the European Union, which is heavily indebted, has to pay the bills it has accumulated. It is therefore a question of adopting a far-sighted and responsible attitude to ensure that the benefits of these unpaid debts are not borne by the citizens of the Member States.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020, because as a representative of the poorest country in the European Union, Bulgaria, it is of paramount importance to me that all operational programmes work properly. Bulgarian citizens hoped that with Bulgaria's accession to the EU, our country would report economic growth and rising living standards. Unfortunately, this process has been deterred by many different factors, such as the economic crisis, demographic problems and, last but not least, the internal migration process within the Union itself. All this has led to the depopulation of entire regions in my country, because there is no prospect in them, no economic growth, no education, no health care. In addition to my support for the report, I call on the Commission to review the principles for the provision of projects in the Member States and to genuinely implement Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Last but not least, the Commission must cooperate with Member States and regions not only with a view to the rapid adoption of all other programmes, but also on the careful implementation of the programmes themselves in order to achieve a full and efficient use of all resources.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because the transfer of appropriations not used in 2014 to subsequent years will lead to their exploitation and help growth.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020 as its rapid adoption is indispensable for the start of the new cohesion policy period, ensuring the most complete use of financial resources necessary for the growth of the economy and employment.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The transfer of unused appropriations in 2014 to later years in order to finance structural fund programmes worth EUR 21.1 billion deserves my agreement. In order for 300 programmes (47% of the total) financed by European funds not to lose last year's appropriations, this review was necessary to transfer to subsequent years, in addition to the corresponding expenditure ceilings, the unused authorisation appropriations in 2014. Due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes on European funds, appropriations for the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund were not committed to this year. A first tranche of €16.5 billion is expected to be transferred for 2015, a second of €4.5 billion for 2016 and a third of €100 million for 2017.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion for programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report allows you to transfer the unused portion of the Structural and Investment Funds in 2014 for the coming years, ensuring that they are not lost. Under-use of the Funds is due to the late adoption of the respective regulations, which has led to only a small proportion of the programmes being adopted by the end of 2014. The unused appropriations in 2014 that would not be carried over to 2015 are very significant, equivalent to 15 per cent of the 2014 Budget. Hence the need for a revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) in place to ensure the budgetary commitment and payments to the various programmes that have been delayed. In practice, this review will allow unauthorized funds to be preserved and used in 2015 and later years. The alternative to this change would be that these resources would not be used and lost to this scope (operational programmes) and that appropriations would be reduced in member states' contributions to the EU budget this year, which would benefit mainly the wealthiest countries. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Commission's forecasts were all too optimistic and by the end of 2014 only a very small percentage of programmes had been adopted under cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and the adoption of the remaining programmes was postponed. Programmes thus transferred shall not lose appropriations unless the Multiannual Financial Framework is revised and moved to the following year. It is very important that there should be a compromise between the various institutions of the European Union, because this is necessary in order to complete the start-up process of the new programming period for cohesion policy. The European Union must use its resources efficiently and in a timely manner and, through its investment policy, create the conditions for a return to growth and new jobs.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against late adoption of cohesion policy regulations which caused a delay in the start of implementation of the vast majority of operational programmes for the period 2014-2020.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002. 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 because the transfer of appropriations not used in 2014 to subsequent years will lead to their exploitation and help growth.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal for a Council regulation amending the regulation on the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020, as this proposal will have positive consequences on the new Cohesion Policy, which is essential for the European development and recovery from the economic crisis.  The new cohesion policy provides support to new innovative business, supports SMEs, creates sustainable jobs, improves skills, combats poverty, promotes social inclusion, gives remote regions broadband, tackles the brain drain, improves the environment, promotes energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy resources, builds vital transport links and strengthens efficiency of public administrations. It is therefore important that resources are used in a timely manner and as effectively as possible, to generate growth and jobs.   I hope that the swift adoption and implementation of remaining programmes will be carried out soon, that the calculations made by the Commission will prove to be realistic and that the increase in the payments will be sufficient.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as only a small percentage of programmes were adopted by the end of 2014. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, part of them by means of the carry-over procedure provided for in Article 13(2)(a) of the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the multiannual financial framework. I welcome the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on a multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. The decision proposes that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards ending the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy without detriment to regions and cities and, therefore, to European citizens.  The European Structural and Investment Funds are the most important elements of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. I believe that the new programming period has already been significantly delayed, so it is necessary to ensure that there is no further delay or loss, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the amendment of the MFF, considering that the late adoption of the Cohesion Policy Regulations for the period 2014-2020 prevented the timely adoption of all operational programmes. The proposal for a Council Regulation amending Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is therefore very positive news. It is essential to avoid any negative impact on European regions, cities and citizens, as the Structural and Investment Funds are the most important investment policy in the European Union.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion for programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion for programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Olbrycht / Thomas report, because it is only common sense that allocations not used in 2014 are carried over to the next year if there is a delay in adopting programmes.  What is not common sense is that people in the UK are disadvantaged over other EU citizens due to the failure of the UK Government to agree on the mechanics by which funds allocated to our regions will be invested. My region of the West Midlands was supposed to receive European Funding worth GBP 719 million last year, but this did not happen because the Government declined to devolve powers to Local Enterprise Partnerships.  When it comes to quality jobs and inclusive growth, every day and every pound counts. But not for the UK Government. Another sad example of the Tories keeping power locked behind Westminster’s doors and failing to conduct an EU policy that benefits our citizens.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of amending the current Multiannual Financial Framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee. But it is again an insufficient measure. First, let us note that if this availability of funds exists it is because Member States barely spent 3% of the amount available in 2014. But let us also remember that as far as 2013 the ILO recommended that EUR 21 billion per year be devoted to the Guarantee, i.e. twice as much as the Commission envisaged. Finally, let us ask ourselves: what will happen to our young people from December 2015, when this modest provision of funds is over? We will be vigilant to prevent subsidies or loans that have only proved effective in lowering labour costs under this guarantee at least in Spain. We will continue to advocate a much larger increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and activity generation from the social and solidarity economy approach.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendment to the Regulation because the amendments adopted allow the successful completion of the process of the start of the new programming period for cohesion policy and to avoid any negative consequences for The Member States and their citizens. In order to accelerate the EU's economic recovery and create new jobs, we need to make the most efficient and timely use of the investments that come through the European Structural and Investment Funds. Only by providing the necessary legal framework for smooth investment programming can we achieve what Europe needs most today: efficient investment absorption.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion for programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as by the end of 2014 only a small percentage of programmes (39%) adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, some through the transmission procedure provided for in the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the MED. The proposal aims to redeploy almost all unused budget appropriations under subheading 1b for 2015.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as by the end of 2014 only a small percentage of programmes (39%) adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, some through the transmission procedure provided for in the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the MED. The proposal aims to redeploy almost all unused budget appropriations under subheading 1b for 2015.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of amending the current Multiannual Financial Framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee. But it is again an insufficient measure. First, let us note that if this availability of funds exists it is because Member States barely spent 3% of the amount available in 2014. But let us also remember that as far as 2013 the ILO recommended that EUR 21 billion per year be devoted to the Guarantee, i.e. twice as much as the Commission envisaged. Finally, let us ask ourselves: what will happen to our young people from December 2015, when this modest provision of funds is over? We will be vigilant to prevent subsidies or loans that have only proved effective in lowering labour costs under this guarantee at least in Spain. We will continue to advocate a much larger increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and activity generation from the social and solidarity economy approach.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation in favour of the better use of appropriations for economic, social and territorial cohesion. It also calls on the Commission to cooperate with Member States and regions with a view to rapidly adopting all the remaining programmes and diligently implementing the programmes themselves, in order to make full and effective use of all resources.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council regulation amending the Regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, as this concludes the initial phase of the new cohesion policy programming period in the form of preventing negative consequences for European cities and regions.  It is important that all financial resources of the European Union, in particular structural and investment funds, are directed towards efficient and efficient use to stimulate growth and employment. I therefore support the transfer of some unsuspecing funds from 2014 to 2015.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. \u2012 Approval of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 is a completely technical matter, but necessary for the Czech Republic, where five operational plans were waiting for the approval of the amendments. Thanks to this revision, there is nothing to prevent projects that focus on the development of employment, infrastructure and services from being launched, thus directly touching the lives of Czech citizens.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas amending the regulation setting out the European multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  The purpose of the vote was to validate a transfer to subsequent years of unused commitment credits in 2014 for certain European funds (structural funds, cohesion funds, FEAD and FEAMP in particular). Many European projects could not be financed in 2014 because of the delay in adopting the multi-year financial framework, necessitating this transfer of funds (nearly 16.5 billion euros for 2015) in order to strengthen funding capacity for later years. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this project to transfer unused European commitment credits to later years in 2014, due to the late adoption of some European programmes.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft regulation because it is a necessary step to complete the process of starting the new programming period for cohesion policy, without having a negative impact on regions and cities and, consequently, on European citizens. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the Union's most important investment policy and it is necessary to use all resources, as timely and efficiently as possible, in order to achieve growth and jobs. The new programming period has already been significantly delayed and it must be ensured that there will be no further delays or any losses.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to the late adoption of the cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020, it was not possible to adopt all operational programmes in time. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, as by the end of 2014 only a small percentage of programmes (39%) adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed, some through the transmission procedure provided for in the Financial Regulation and others on the basis of an amendment to the MED. The proposal aims to redeploy almost all unused budget appropriations under subheading 1b for 2015.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I support the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2020 on the multiannual financial framework for the period 2013-2014. We propose that Parliament give its consent, as this is an essential step towards the end of the process of triggering the programming period for the new cohesion policy. The European Structural Funds are the most important element of the Union's investment policy and it is essential that all resources are used in the best timely and efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. The new programming period has already suffered significant delays and it is necessary to ensure that no further delays or losses occur.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because it is a matter of deferring in 2015 the 21 billion euros of unused commitment credits in 2014, in order to be able to settle the outstandings, which would be unreasonable to prevent. The enormity of this postponement, however, shows how bad the Union is.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Abstention. The aim of this report is to amend Regulation (EU) 1311/2013 to allow unused commitment appropriations to be deferred in subsequent years. Which seems like a positive thing.  But 172 million euros are planned for the "Asylum, Migration, Integration" fund, which will undoubtedly encourage immigration to European countries. Various reports, including the Court of Auditors for France, having highlighted the problems of the countries of the European Union in managing migration, and the consequences of migration, this desire to transfer such a sum to this sector seems illogical.   Another important point is the cost of unpaid bills, which amounts to 24 billion euros, an amount that has doubled since 2011. This, of course, has serious consequences for the management of local authorities. The European Commission's willingness to solve this problem by introducing a European tax is unacceptable because it will further challenge the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being used.  This project transfers these amounts to subsequent financial years to ensure that programmes adopted in the multiannual budget can be effectively financed despite accumulated delays. Because of its technical nature and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the most important investment policy in the European Union, so it is essential that, in order to create growth and employment, all resources are used in the most timely and effective manner possible.  The late adoption of the Cohesion Policy Regulations for the period 2014-2020 prevented the timely adoption of all operational programmes, so this proposal aims to transfer to 2015 virtually all unused appropriations in 2014 that were earmarked for heading 1(b), 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion', with the exception of the ERDF's contributions to cross-border programmes under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) and the European Instrument (IEV), which were transferred to 2017.  That's why I voted favorably.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. \u2012 If money was saved in one year by not being able to use it, I will not support spending it in the following year. The money saved is to be returned to the budget of the Member States or used for the next year's budget.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) ensures systematic development of EU spending. It sets the amount of annual ceilings (maximum amounts) that the EU can spend in different areas of its activities. The current revision of the MFF 2014-2020 aims to make transfers for subsequent years of unused funds in 2014 or EUR 21.1 billion. The role of the European Parliament here is key because, without its approval, the Council cannot adopt an act amending the MFF. The late adoption of a large part of operational programmes (47 % or 300 programmes) has led to the need to revise the MFF in order to avoid further delays and losses. This is a technical amendment in nature and was supported by an overwhelming majority in Parliament (591 votes in yes against only 24 against). The conclusion that is required from the political analysis of this situation is that more speed and flexibility of procedures are needed, an issue of utmost importance that is yet to be discussed.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote, which concerns the postponement of 21 billion unused appropriations in 2015 due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes for certain European funds.  Although the problem of late payments is likely to worsen, funds benefiting France, such as FEADER or fisheries, are also included in the budget lines at issue: it is therefore fairer to abstain.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) represents the set of rules that the European Union defines with the aim of ensuring the orderly development of its expenditure within the limits of its resources. Given that it was not possible to commit in 2014 and to bring back in 2015 the money allocated to the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural fund and the Maritime Affairs Fund, it was appropriate to revise Regulation 1311/2013 - Euratom - because it is necessary to transfer the commitment appropriations not used in 2014 for the following years.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the proposal to establish the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. In this way we are taking an essential step to complete the process of implementing the new cohesion policy programming period, avoiding any negative impact on regions and cities and, consequently, on European citizenship. Programme delays or loss of funds must be avoided, and we must establish the best mechanisms for the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds to enable the creation of economic growth and job creation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I refused to support this request to amend the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, as unused Cohesion Fund funds from 2014 are to be used for 2015. These funds were not called up last year for various reasons and, in my opinion, should not be spent by force in 2015, but should be returned to the respective Member States.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report to help fund 300 state-managed programmes, in all EU Member States, that started too late to qualify for EU funding in 2014.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ As an explanation of my vote, I felt that this was a balanced report on this issue.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report endorses a major change to the 2013 regulation that sets out the EU's multi-year financial framework for the period 2014-2020.  In intangible principle, this framework can be revised in the event that some programmes could not be launched as early as 2014. Rather than losing all 2014 appropriations for these programs, this amendment allows them to be carried forward by raising spending limits for future years.  This only corrects the notorious shortcomings of this austerity-marked multi-year financial framework. And this once again reflects the unprescing of European budgetary management.  Plagued by the fussy conditionalities imposed by the European Commission, 47% of EU programmes could not be adopted at the end of 2014, i.e. 300 programmes. This represents 11 billion unused appropriations for structural funds alone. To prevent these credits from being lost, I vote for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Although it is opposed to the deferral of funds on the "Asylum, Migration, Integration" policy, it seems that other budget lines remain of interest. Therefore, I preferred to abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the late adoption of Regulation (EU/Euratom) No 1311/2013, it is necessary to establish a new MFF for the period 2014-2020 which includes the necessary transfers of funds.  The transfer of unused appropriations in 2014 to later years aims to finance programmes under the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum Fund, Migration and Integration and the Internal Security Fund. Due to the late adoption of several programmes, eur 21.1 billion was not used in 2014.  Hence my assent.

name: Roberta METSOLA
