text: in writing. ‒ The delayed adoption of the 2014-2020 legal acts for a number of funds meant that a significant number of programmes could not be adopted in 2014. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal as it will lead to the appropriation of these unused funds from 2014 to subsequent years.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the change in the 2014-2020 Multi-Year Financial Framework, which will allow 300 national programmes from all Member States to finally be implemented quickly. These programmes were launched too late to be able to access European funding for 2014. This amendment, adopted by a very large majority of Parliament, will allow 21.1 billion euros of unused commitments to be transferred from 2014 to the period 2015-2017. These appropriations represent 15% of the EU budget for 2014 and 47% of all programmes.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the Amendment of the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020. Since a significant amount of programmes could not be adopted in 2014, commitment appropriations for programmes under shared management lapsed in 2014 for an amount of EUR 21 billion. This corresponds to the 2014 tranches of programmes that could neither be committed in 2014 nor carried over to 2015. The Commission proposes to transfer this bulk of the allocations that were not used in 2014, to 2015.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this recommendation, which is aimed at better and full use of all available resources for the year 2014.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council's draft regulation allows for the transfer and subsequent use of some EUR 21 billion of the various EU funds not used up to 2014 for later years. The draft cannot be adopted without the agreement of the European Parliament.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 On 1 January 2014 new rules or programmes in the form of shared management in relation to the Structural Funds entered into force: the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. To this end, the multiannual financial framework should be reviewed with a view to transferring unused appropriations in 2014 to subsequent years, in addition to the corresponding expenditure ceilings. I therefore vote in favour of this report which aims to transfer almost all cohesion policy appropriations not used in 2014 to sub-heading 1B 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' for 2015, with the exception of ERDF contributions to cross-border programmes under the Instrument for Pre-Adoption Assistance (IPA) and the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI), which are transferred for 2017.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The revision of the multi-year financial framework is aimed at transferring EUR 21 billion in commitment appropriations over subsequent years that were not used in 2014, the equivalent of 15% of the 2014 budget!  If this is a purely technical revision, it should be noted, however, that EUR 172 million will be made available to the "Asylum, Migration, Integration" fund and to promote legal immigration to the EU, an eminently questionable policy.  It is also indicative of serious and even scandalous elements of funds such as the stock of unpaid debts, which grows from year to year, thus displaying a totally sclerotic management. The amount reached 24.7 billion in 2014 compared to 11 billion in 2011. And we are still waiting for a clean-up plan. Meanwhile, it is the local authorities that are paying the price.  This absurd system justifies for some a new federal leap that is nothing more than a leap into the void and would be an intolerable expectation of the sovereignty of states. The only answer to this appalling management is to leave the Member States with full sovereignty over their budget and the allocation of investments.  Taking into account the purely technical aspect of the text, I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which provides for a simple transfer to subsequent years of unused commitment appropriations in 2014. It is a question of not losing and quickly implementing these structural and investment funds, which represent the UNION's most important investment policy.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this recommendation as the late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. This is an essential procedure for completing the process of initiating the new cohesion policy programming period, avoiding any negative impact on europe's regions and cities and, consequently, on European citizens. We cannot afford any further delays. We agree with the rapporteur on the need for the Commission to cooperate with the Member States and the regions, not only in order to adopt all the remaining programmes quickly, but also to implement the programmes carefully, with the aim of achieving full and effective use of all resources. We would like to stress that this proposal does not contain any changes to the payment appropriations: the transfer of commitment appropriations from 2014 to 2015 will not, in fact, lead to any particular obstacles to payments in the coming years. In this regard, however, we reiterate our reservations in this regard and ask that the issue of a backlog of payments should be addressed once and for all and that any further problems in payments should be avoided by all means and efforts for the coming years.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 meant that it was impossible to adopt all operational programmes in good time. In order not to lose the 2014 appropriations, it is therefore appropriate to revise the Annex to Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 by transferring unused commitment appropriations in 2014 to subsequent years for subheading 1b and headings 2 and 3.  Given the enormous importance of European funds at this time of economic and financial crisis for Italy and for Europe as a whole, I have given my approval to the draft Council regulation amending the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1493/1999. 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020. This recommendation provides the necessary legal framework for the implementation of multiannual financial programmes and cohesion policy. A transfer of budgetary resources maintains the financial capacity of european programmes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Under the Regulation on the MFF for 2014-2020, the EU needs to revise the Multiannual Financial Framework if programmes to be financed from the EU budget are adopted later than planned. The proposal aims to enable the EU to transfer EUR 21.1 billion of unused commitments from 2014 to subsequent years as follows: EUR 16.5 billion in 2015; €4.5 billion in 2016; EUR 0.1 billion in 2017. In times of savings such as these, this must be rejected in principle. It is incomprehensible why municipalities, countries and states should save on an iron, but the EU wants to spend more and more money. What we need in many areas is a transfer of EU competences to the nation states. Then the EU's financial needs will also fall significantly. That is why I voted against the amendments.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to change the multi-year financial framework following the late adoption of certain operational programmes as part of the cohesion policy. This change is necessary so as not to lose the unused 2014 appropriations and transfer them to subsequent fiscal years.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. This amendment to the Regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020 is a purely technical amendment following the delay in the implementation of operational programmes in 2014. However, it is necessary to make a critical comment. The programmes that have been affected are fundamental to employment, growth, innovation and research, and have a direct impact on the development of regions. In particular, we are talking about the European Social Fund, Youth Employment Initiative, Cohesion Fund, European Regional Development Fund, Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund, among others.  We cannot afford such a loss of resources at a time of crisis like the present one; the credibility of the institutions has been affected, first by the rigidity of the previous system and now by the slowness in changing the procedure. And it's still a patch.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. It should be noted that this amendment to the Regulation is necessary in order to complete the process of starting the new programming period for cohesion policy and to avoid any negative consequences for regions and cities and, consequently, for European citizens.  Another important aspect is the issue of late payments. which is unacceptable and requires an immediate solution. Decisive action and measures need to be taken and resolved once and for all and any additional payment problems avoided. In order to promote growth and create jobs, it is essential that all resources are used as efficiently as possible and as efficiently as possible. The new programming period is already significantly delayed and it is therefore necessary to ensure that there are no further delays or any losses in the future. Furthermore, it is essential to ensure that the existing flexibility provisions of the MFF Regulation are sufficient to respond to any increase in interim payment requests.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The transfer of unused funds, in particular the EU's regional and cohesion funds, from the 2014 Community budget to that of 2015 will do no good to the peoples who will continue to groan from the unpopular policy of the EU and the governments of its Member States. These funds are intended for projects and infrastructures that bring profits to business groups, while projects necessary for popular needs (flood protection, earthquake shielding, public housing projects, schools, etc.) are considered "ineligible", since they are not linked to the profitability of the groups. The EU budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework are unpopular, regardless of the amount of funds they provide for disposal, because their main direction is to finance the monopolies or projects necessary for their profitability. It is the people who pay with their heavy taxes both the Community and national budgets for the benefit of plutocracy. To meet popular needs requires conflict with the EU and the power of monopolies, a strong popular alliance to pave the way for popular power and economy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approves the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014/2020 as set out in the Annex to this resolution and instructing its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to national parliaments, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 has led to the impossibility of adopting all operational programmes in a timely manner. The Commission's forecast proved too optimistic, with a small percentage of programmes adopted by the end of 2014 (39% or 252 Union programmes). Adoption of the remaining programs has been delayed. Transposition programmes (14% or 93 Union programmes) do not require an MFF review as they were ready for adoption by the end of 2014 and were not adopted only due to lack of time. For them, although adoption has been delayed until early 2015, the 2014 budget can continue to be used.  I welcome the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, which sets out the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and voted for Parliament to give its consent, as this is a necessary step to complete the process of launching the new Cohesion Policy programming period, avoiding any negative impact on regions and cities, and thus on European citizens.  The European Structural and Investment Funds are a very important EU investment policy and it is essential that all funds are used in a timely and efficient way as possible, in order to generate growth and jobs. The new programming period has already experienced significant delays and it must be ensured that there are no further delays or losses.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. These deferrals of appropriations relate to a variety of measures. It should be noted in passing that they are due to delays in the adoption of programmes and regulations, which shows the inability of the European Union to organise itself. Some would be perfectly acceptable while others deserve fierce opposition. In these circumstances, I cannot accept or reject the text as a whole, and I therefore prefer to abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I naturally supported this resolution which allows the multiannual financial framework to be amended by transferring funding that for various reasons was not committed in 2014 to this year's budget. In particular, because these resources, which have not yet been committed, are the structural funds that the regions so much need at the moment in order to restart their growth. We are talking about a 'technical' adjustment, but it means giving scope to the implementation and implementation of the new programming of cohesion policy funds.  Beyond that, I hope that in the next mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, the Council will re-implement its well-established approach to austerity and give the Union a budget that is worthy and sufficient to ensure that the European policies necessary for the recovery of our economies can be fully implemented.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report of my colleague Olbrycht and my colleague Thomas on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2012/2013. 1311/2013 establishing a multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, by which the European Parliament, under the specific legislative consent process, gives its consent to the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2020/2020. 1311/2013 establishing a multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, as set out in annex to this resolution.  I also express my satisfaction that, in addition to the rules of procedure and previous reports, the recommendations of the Committee on Budgets and opinion of the Committee on Regional Development were taken into account when giving their consent.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. \u2012 The late adoption of the Cohesion Policy Regulation 2014-2020 led to the lack of timely approval of all operational programmes. Therefore, it was not possible to allocate in 2014 to nor to transfer by 2015 eur 11 216 187 326 earmarked for the Structural and Cohesion Funds, as well as eur 9 446 050 652 earmarked for the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and eur 442 319 096 earmarked for the Asylum Fund , the Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. I am glad that the European Parliament has given its consent to the transfer of funds to the next year, as this is a necessary step towards preventing a negative impact on regions and cities and, ultimately, on European citizens. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the most important means of The Union's investment policy and therefore, in order to achieve growth and job creation, it is imperative that all resources are used in a timely and effective manner. The new programming period has already been noticeably delayed and it is therefore necessary to ensure that there are no further delays or losses.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the draft regulation amending Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. With Parliament's approval, the process is completed to begin the new programming period of cohesion policy. As we know, the Structural Funds are part of the EU's largest investment policy and it is clear that it is vital that resources are used effectively without unnecessary delay so as not to cause negative consequences for European citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. After the approval of the Council of the Union, Parliament in turn voted on the change of the multi-year financial framework for the transfer of cohesion policy funds from 2014 to 2015-2017. The variation of the broad directions of cohesion policy has fallen too far behind, and this was not sustainable.  I have spoken in favour of these changes, which will help to finance 300 national programmes that were launched too late to qualify for European funding in 2014. This would amount to the sum of 21.1 billion euros of unused commitments appropriations in 2014 and which will be transferred to 2015-2017.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 has made it impossible to make all operational programmes timely adopted, and the multiannual financial framework (MFF) needs to be revised for the period 2014-2020. The European Structural and Investment Funds are the union's most important investment policy and it is therefore essential that all resources are used in a timely and most effective manner to generate growth and jobs. The new programming period has already experienced significant delays, so it is important to ensure that no further delays or losses occur. This proposal sets out the MFF for the period 2014-2020 and aims to transfer almost all unused appropriations in 2014 to 2015 to subheading 1B 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion'. The only exception concerns certain ERDF contributions, which will be transferred to 2017.  The transfer of appropriations is an indispensable step in completing the process of starting the new cohesion policy programming period, so as to avoid any negative impact on regions and cities and, consequently, on European citizens. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In times of budgetary scarcity, managing money optimally is more than ever an obligation. This is how we must assess the vote this evening by the European Parliament to approve the transfer for the years 2015 to 2017 of a considerable envelope of 21 billion euros of appropriations not used in the 2014 budget.  This is due to the overly optimistic forecasts made by the Commission last year on the European programmes adopted in national capitals: less than one in two has been completed in the Member States. Logically, the remaining 61% was therefore carried over to 2015 or transferred to the following years. It is now to be hoped that this revision of the multi-year financial framework will be used to finance important and visible projects for regions and cities, and therefore for European citizens. Too often, localities are reluctant to highlight European financial aid for any construction or improvement in transport and thus to provide objective information on the EU's concrete contribution to daily life in rural areas, tourist areas or disadvantaged neighbourhoods of large cities, etc.  This silence becomes guilty in a growing context of rising Euroscepticism.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. This proposal aims to transfer almost all unused appropriations in 2014 to 2015. Knowing that the European Structural and Investment Funds are the EU's most important investment policy, it is essential that all resources are used, in a timely and most effective way, to generate growth and jobs. Above all, it is important to ensure that no further delays or losses occur, often as a result of the excessive bureaucratisation of the European system itself.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion affecting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The late adoption of policy regulations for 2014-2020 prevented the timely adoption of all operational programs.  The Commission's forecasts proved to be too optimistic: at the end of 2014, the percentage of programmes adopted was low (39%, or 252 EU programmes). Fourteen per cent do not require a review of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF). But... another 300 programs require — in order not to lose the 2014 appropriations — a review of the PSC in accordance with section 19 of the Regulations, under which the 2014 allocations are transferred to the following years.  This step is essential to complete the process of starting the new period of cohesion policy programming, avoiding any negative effects for regions and cities, and therefore for European citizens.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The timely adoption of all operational programmes has been difficult to achieve due to the late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020. In fact, 47% of the 2012 programmes, which is equivalent to 300 Union programmes, which require a revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework so that they do not lose the appropriations for 2014 and can be transferred for the following years. I therefore welcome the proposal for a recommendation put forward and the rapporteur's position that this decision to transfer almost all unused appropriations in 2014 to the subheading on 'Economic Cohesion, social and territorial programmes' for 2015 ,with the exception of erdf contributions to cross-border programmes and the European Neighbourhood Instrument (EVI), which are transferred to 2017,[12) is an indispensable step towards completing the process of starting the new cohesion policy, avoiding possible negative impacts on regions and cities and, for the most part, on European citizens.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against changing the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 on a matter of principle: in practice, the entire MFF has not been realistically programmed, to the point that with measures such as this, the European institutions have to shift the funds to subsequent years.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of amending the current Multiannual Financial Framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee. But it is again an insufficient measure. First, let us note that if this availability of funds exists it is because Member States barely spent 3% of the amount available in 2014. But let us also remember that as far as 2013 the ILO recommended that EUR 21 billion per year be devoted to the Guarantee, i.e. twice as much as the Commission envisaged. Finally, let us ask ourselves: what will happen to our young people from December 2015, when this modest provision of funds is over? We will be vigilant to prevent subsidies or loans that have only proved effective in lowering labour costs under this guarantee at least in Spain. We will continue to advocate a much larger increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and activity generation from the social and solidarity economy approach.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being usability.  This project transfers these amounts to subsequent financial years to ensure that programmes adopted in the multiannual budget can be effectively financed despite accumulated delays. Because of its technical nature and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my support for the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020 in order to transfer to subsequent years, in addition to the corresponding expenditure ceilings, also the allocations and amounts not used in 2014 for the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime And Fisheries Fund , the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund. I am convinced that this budgetary manoeuvre will allow the pace of investment to be maintained in favour of growth and employment.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs today voted in support of the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 laying down the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020. This is an indispensable step to complete the starting process of the new Cohesion Policy programming period avoiding any negative impact for regions and cities and consequently for European citizens.  The European Structural and Investment Funds are the Union’s most important investment policy. It is vital that all resources are used in as timely a manner and as effectively as possible, to generate growth and jobs. The new programming period has already experienced significant delays, and it must be ensured that there are neither further delays, nor any losses.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation. As the adoption of operational programmes for the period 2014-20 was delayed, Slovakia could not exhaust some of the funds of these programmes for 2014 to which we are entitled. It was therefore necessary to agree to amend the overall multiannual financial framework so that these funds would not be lost and that we could use them this year. In fact, the revision of the multiannual financial framework requires up to 47% of EU programmes to ensure that unused funds allocated for 2014 are used during 2015. The new programming period is already characterised by a significant delay in time, so further losses and delays must also be avoided.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of amending the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020. The change was necessary to ensure that countries that failed to conclude the approval process for their operational programmes by the end of 2014 did not lose the funds allocated from the EU budget for this year. As a result of the change in the MFF, these so-called unused commitments will be carried over to the 2014 budget by 2015. This change, which must take place by 1 May 2015, also benefits the Czech Republic, which by the end of 2014 had not approved a single operational programme, and would thus lose the full amount of structural funds allocated for 2014, i.e. approximately CZK 80 billion, without changing the MFF.  At present, five operational programmes are already ready for approval in the case of the Czech Republic. By carrying out this revision, which I consider a necessary technical change, it will finally be possible to start drawing on these programmes. Already, the start of the use of funds in the Czech Republic is delayed. In proportion to this delay, there is a growing risk of under-implementation of cohesion policy funds throughout the period 2014-2020 and the failure to implementation of projects key to the economic growth and development of the Czech Republic for purely time-based reasons. It was therefore necessary for the budgetary revision to be approved without unnecessary delays and for the whole thing not to be politicised, which fortunately did not happen.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – The late Agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 only adopted a number of legal acts containing provisions for the implementation of the Funds in December 2013. Subsequently, a number of implementing and delegated acts were adopted for each fund in 2014, and a number of shared management programmes could not be adopted in that year. Among the programmes not adopted are programmes that were ready for adoption at the end of 2014 but could not be formally adopted due to a lack of time. For these programmes, 2014 commitments can automatically be transferred to 2015. Appropriations which were neither used in 2014 nor allowed to be transposed (programmes were not sufficiently elaborated) should be reallocating to the coming years by revising the MFF ceilings, which is a precondition for the adoption of programmes and the start-up of the corresponding budgetary commitment and the payment of initial pre-financing. In 2014, commitment appropriations for shared management programmes of EUR 21 billion were due. As the Commission proposes to reallocate much of these appropriations directly to 2015 in order to ensure the planned level of investment in growth and jobs, I supported the draft recommendation on the amendment of the regulation.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of amending the regulation on the financial framework for 2014/2020. Due to late action in the adoption of the cohesion policy regulations, it was impossible to adopt all the programmes planned for 2014, in fact as many as 300 Union programmes (47% of the total) saw appropriations blocked, resulting in huge losses. Delays in adoption have led to more than EUR 20 billion being blocked without being able to be allocated. It was therefore necessary to amend the regulation of the financial framework so that unused allocations for the 2014 financial year could be transferred to subsequent years. In this way, most of the appropriations planned for 2014 will be usable in 2015, while a smaller part will be usable in 2017. Although such a delicate situation has been resolved, it is still necessary to ensure that the new programme, marred by initial errors, does not lead to delays or losses, but can allow the necessary funds to be allocated without further hasso.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing \ u2012 It is important that, even with any changes within this period of the financial framework, they maintain the priority of cohesion policy. At the same time, it is crucial that individual states simplify the system of drawing down and reducing administrative burdens for individual applicants.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Due to the late agreement on the MFF for 2014-2020, various legislative acts setting out provisions for the implementation of the Funds were adopted for the ERDF, ESF, KF and EAFRD in December 2013, and for the EMFF, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (FAMI) and the Internal Security Fund (FUS) only in May 2014. A significant part of the programme could not be adopted in 2014. 300 of the EU's 645 programmes were delayed.  For this reason, I supported this amendment, as the European Commission made a proposal for audits concerning the transfer of unused allocations for 2014. The revision of the MFF Regulation allows €16.5 billion to be transferred in 2015, €4.5 billion in 2016 and €0.1 billion remaining in 2017.  These commitments were not used in 2014. Commitments are legal promises to spend money on activities that can take several financial years to implement. In order to maintain the pace of investment in growth and employment, to minimise differences in treatment for programmes adopted in 2014, I support the Commission's proposal to transfer most of the allocated funds not used in 2014.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ I did not support the proposal. First of all, it is interesting that the 'victim of globalisation' in this case is to be a road transport company. In search of all the damage that globalisation has done, the applicants for money are clearly quite creative. But regardless, this post, as well as other similar posts, is harmful. As it is paid from taxes on employees and companies, fewer real jobs are created and competitiveness is reduced. This further increases the problem that this money was supposed to solve.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i supported the recommendation on the draft Council order amending the MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 to transfer unused allocations for a whole range of funds from 2014 to subsequent years. As the cohesion policy regulations for 2014-2020 were adopted very late, the adoption of operational programmes was immediately ed and it was not possible to use the funds in 2014. Without a change in the regulation, resources would be lost and we cannot afford to do so. This would mean that european funds, including the Structural Funds, the Cohesion Fund and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, would have fewer resources and, as a result, would find it more difficult to achieve the European objectives set.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We disagree both with the logic on which the Union budget is based and with the way it is distributed. Our position is that the funds should be used as best as possible to improve the quality of life of peoples. For the above reasons we consider it politically wrong to allow funds that were part of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to be lost and which were neither spent in 2014 nor included in the 2015 budget. Funds such as those of the European Social Fund, the Youth Guarantee, the Cohesion Fund, the Rural Development Fund, the Asylum Fund, Migration and Social Inclusion relating to sensitive areas are absolutely essential.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The transfer of appropriations not used in 2014 to subsequent years will lead to their exploitation and help growth.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The proposal aims to transfer almost all unused appropriations for the 2014 financial year for heading 1b, Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion, with the exception of ERDF contributions to cross-border programmes under the Pre-Accession Aid Instrument and the European Neighbourhood Instrument, which are transferred to FY2017.  The need for the Commission to cooperate with Member States and regions should be emphasised in order not only to quickly adopt all other programmes, but also to rigorously implement the programmes themselves, with the aim of achieving full and effective use of all resources. Regarding the transfer to the 2017 financial year of the entire 2014 ERDF participation in cross-border programmes under the pre-accession aid instrument and the European Neighbourhood Instrument, the rapporteur for opinion recognises the delays in the adoption of these programmes and the complexity that characterizes them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the amendment of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020: the transfer of unused funds in 2014, as this transfer will not change the existing amounts of the Multiannual Financial Framework. Furthermore, I consider the transfer of these funds necessary as significant amounts of funds within the programme have remained unused due to the late adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework. I find it particularly positive that this amendment allows for the continuation of the financing of unfinished European Union programmes in the Member States, thereby preventing these projects from being halted.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of amending the current Multiannual Financial Framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee. But it is again an insufficient measure. First, let us note that if this availability of funds exists it is because Member States barely spent 3% of the amount available in 2014. But let us also remember that as far as 2013 the ILO recommended that EUR 21 billion per year be devoted to the Guarantee, i.e. twice as much as the Commission envisaged. Finally, let us ask ourselves: what will happen to our young people from December 2015, when this modest provision of funds is over? We will be vigilant to prevent subsidies or loans that have only proved effective in lowering labour costs under this guarantee at least in Spain. We will continue to advocate a much larger increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and activity generation from the social and solidarity economy approach

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This amendment to the regulation is only a technical postponement on 2015 of unused appropriations in 2014 due to the late adoption of regulations and programmes concerning certain European funds.  These are mainly concerned by this amendment to the regulation of the Structural Funds for Asylum and Immigration Policies, which should have opposed this text. Only the funds allocated to the FEADER and the fisheries have been deftly associated with it to force us not to oppose the adoption of the text.  My final position: ABSTENTION.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Structural and Investment Funds are the most important elements of the Union's investment policy. It is essential that all resources are used in the best possible time and in the most efficient way possible, in order to stimulate growth and create jobs. That is why I voted in favour of this report, because I consider it important that the previous programming period can be closed without member states losing resources due to various administrative delays.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of amending the current Multiannual Financial Framework to transfer the resources planned for 2014 to the 2015 financial year under the so-called Youth Guarantee. But it is again an insufficient measure. First, let us note that if this availability of funds exists it is because Member States barely spent 3% of the amount available in 2014. But let us also remember that as far as 2013 the ILO recommended that EUR 21 billion per year be devoted to the Guarantee, i.e. twice as much as the Commission envisaged. Finally, let us ask ourselves: what will happen to our young people from December 2015, when this modest provision of funds is over? We will be vigilant to prevent subsidies or loans that have only proved effective in lowering labour costs under this guarantee at least in Spain. We will continue to advocate a much larger increase in European and national funds aimed primarily at R&D&I investment programmes, socially useful public infrastructures and activity generation from the social and solidarity economy approach.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of an amendment to the Regulation of the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is necessary due to delays in the implementation of the new generation of the Structural Funds.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, colleagues, I supported the first revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF 2014-2020) as a necessary technical amendment, but also as a clear political signal to citizens that the commitments made to finance and implement cohesion, common agricultural policy and development programmes are respected. The transfer of £21bn to The New York Times EUR 2014-2015 unused funds will allow already approved 300 programmes in different Member States not to be cancelled due to the more than 6 months delay in the approval of the MFF and the serious delay in approving the new operational programmes, which implies the conversion of 2015 into a zero year for the absorption of EU funds.  I support the need for flexibility in the MFF to allow for amendments such as today's, because this is necessary to avoid interruptions and problems in the implementation of EU projects and programmes, as well as to prevent the loss of eu funds in large amounts, as would be the case with the €21 billion in question. without the amendment adopted today. Today, as the European economy recovers from the crisis, more than anything, it is necessary to use all the opportunities to create jobs and revive investment, which in many Member States comes from EU funds.  Let us not allow bureaucratic procedures to stifle EU programmes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Due to the delay in the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework, there was a delay in the adoption of shared management programmes in 2014. In this context, the Commission proposes to transfer the affected allocations from 2014 to 2015. We are talking about commitments amounting to EUR 21 billion, about 300 programmes. By amending Article 19 of the Regulation establishing the multiannual financial framework, the expenditure ceiling is adjusted and this allocation can be made, which is of vital importance for carrying out shared management programmes.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. Council Regulation No 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 (MFF Regulation) provides for a review of that framework in the event of delays in the adoption of shared management rules or programmes.   As of 31 December 2014, and due to the delay in reaching agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, around three hundred operational programmes had not been adopted. As a result, more than EUR 21 billion affecting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund or the Internal Security Fund (ISF) would have been lost without this review. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in accordance with Article 19 of the MFF Regulation allows the transfer of unused allocations in 2014 or extended for lack of programme adoption. This report proposes to transfer these assignments to subsequent fiscal years. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this review.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The late implementation of several EU programmes (some as important as fisheries, cohesion, social or asylum funds) has resulted in many of the budget transfers allocated for 2014 not being used.  This project transfers these amounts to subsequent financial years to ensure that programmes adopted in the multiannual budget can be effectively financed despite accumulated delays. Because of its technical nature and despite the limitations of the European budget, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We welcome this flexibility mechanism that allows the reallocate of unused funds in 2014 for the coming years, thus allowing us to safeguard the continuity of some 300 projects currently underway. This was already predictable in view of the lengthy application procedures in the new Community framework. At the level of the common agricultural policy and in particular in terms of single payment applications, there are significant delays which should be deserving of measures on the part of the committee to make time limits more flexible. We must take advantage of this debate to once again stress that this multiannual plan, which for the first time in the EU's history lowers its effort rate, is at odds with propaganda calling for a Europe of social cohesion but then does not give it the means to correct asymmetries, more than a period in which the EU itself constrains national states and uses expansionary policies. We do not understand that in this context, the extraordinary revenue stemming from the own means of financing is not used to try to reduce this deficit which remains a stain on the credibility of the EU that imposes on national states what it cannot do in its own home.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I refused to support this request to amend the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, as unused Cohesion Fund funds from 2014 are to be used for 2015. These funds were not called up last year for various reasons and, in my opinion, should not be spent by force in 2015, but should be returned to the respective Member States.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of changing the multiannual financial framework because I believe that the European Commission's proposal is fair and common sense. However, these continuous corrections to the MFF reveal a fundamental weakness in the current financial structure of the Union which, I hope, will be thoroughly reformed with the mid-term review of the financial framework itself.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of the European Parliament's recommendation on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1493/1999. 1311/2013 establishing the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 to 2020. I voted for this recommendation, which concerns the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the aim of ensuring the transfer to the following years, above the corresponding expenditure ceilings, of unused allocations in 2014.  This proposal for a regulation is absolutely necessary, given that the late adoption of cohesion policy regulations for the period 2014-2020 has caused delays in the timely adoption of all operational programmes.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this change to the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is necessary. According to the regulation establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020, if some programmes had been adopted after 1 January 2014, action could have been taken to amend the MFF and reallocate unused amounts in 2014 to subsequent years. This has been the case and it has therefore been requested that more than EUR 21 billion be carried over to the next few years concerning the Structural and Cohesion Funds, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and, finally, the Asylum, Immigration and Internal Security Fund because they were adopted belatedly. I believe that this is a correct and acceptable choice, which is also welcomed in the committees, and that is why I wanted to vote in favour.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The transfer of unused funds, in particular the EU's regional and cohesion funds, from the 2014 Community budget to that of 2015 will do no good to the peoples who will continue to groan from the unpopular policy of the EU and the governments of its Member States. These funds are intended for projects and infrastructures that bring profits to business groups, while projects necessary for popular needs (flood protection, earthquake shielding, public housing projects, schools, etc.) are considered "ineligible", since they are not linked to the profitability of the groups. The EU budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework are unpopular, regardless of the amount of funds they provide for disposal, because their main direction is to finance the monopolies or projects necessary for their profitability. It is the people who pay with their heavy taxes both the Community and national budgets for the benefit of plutocracy. To meet popular needs requires conflict with the EU and the power of monopolies, a strong popular alliance to pave the way for popular power and economy.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. This is a proposal to reallocate unused funds in 2014 from the Structural Funds for the coming years due to the late adoption of the new Cohesion Policy rules for the period 2014-2020. That is why only a small percentage of programmes at the end of 2014 were adopted.  The appropriations that could not be used in 2014 and which did not carry over to 2015 are very significant, totalling more than EUR 21 million, equivalent to 15% of the 2014 Budget. Hence the need for a revision of the MFF in order to ensure the budgetary commitment and payment to the various programmes that have been delayed. In practice, this review will allow unauthorized funds to be preserved and used in 2015 and later years. The alternative to this change would be that these resources were not used and lost for this scope (operational programmes) and these appropriations reduced in mS contributions to the EU budget this year.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, as this is the only way to avoid negative consequences for regions, cities and European citizens. There have already been long delays in the new programming period of cohesion policy and further delays must be avoided. The Structural and Investment Funds are essential for the EU's investment policy, the creation of growth and jobs, so it is important that resources are used as quickly and efficiently as possible. Due to delays in the adoption of cohesion policy regulations for 2014-2020, not all operational programmes could be adopted in time. By the end of 2014, only 39% of EU programmes had been adopted. The adoption of the remaining programmes has been postponed either by the transfer of funds or by an amendment to the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). There is no need for a MFF change for transmission programmes (14 % of EU programmes) because they were prepared for adoption before the end of 2014 and can therefore be used for 2014. However, all other programmes (47% of EU programmes) require a change in the MFF and a transfer to subsequent years in order not to lose the 2014 appropriations.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I supported this resolution. Today, the European Parliament is an institution that debates human rights strongly and protects them not only in the European Union, but everywhere in the world.  It is therefore right that we have recalled this tragic event, essentially the first genocide in the twentieth century. It is not only about recalling this tragic moment in the history of the Armenian people, but also about creating an opportunity for Turkey, which – although it has recently made a significant shift in relation to this tragedy and in its perception of its role in this tragedy – has still not recognised genocide as such.  So, personally, I am very glad that this resolution contains paragraph 5, where there is talk of creating a chance for Turkey to move forward in recognising its past and recognising the Armenian genocide.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – I voted in favour of the resolution on the terrible Armenian genocide that was implemented by Turkey 100 years ago. Unfortunately, to date, the country has not admitted atrocities in the form of the murder of 1.5 million innocent Armenians, but also 300,000 Syrians, who are ancient Christians in Syria, and pontiff Greeks, who are said to be 500,000. The Armenian genocide must be recognised so that Turkey can repair its historical memory and move on to a better future and to rapprochement with the Member States of the European Union. Indeed, Turkey should understand that effective regret and lessons from the past will help it more to join the European Union than to push for pragmatic reasons for its accession. And the deniers of the Armenian genocide should understand that covering their eyes from reality, extermination of a significant part of one nation for the sake of political correctness, is a repetition of the fatal mistakes of our ancestors, who were silent about many other genocides. However, the Armenian genocide carries one more important message. The Western world must not allow more senseless bloodshed by Christians and non-Christians in the Middle East by Muslim states.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of the European Parliament's resolution, which clearly calls for recognition of the Armenian genocide. At the same time, I express my desire for reconciliation between Armenians and Turks.  The European Parliament is neither a historical institution nor a tribunal. It is our duty to take a stand on such important events that have implications for our times. I think that the political representations of the countries of the European Union that have not yet done so should also do so.  The European Union was founded precisely on the basis of the naming of guilt and mutual forgiveness. The French and Germans in particular have experienced this, but so have other countries in the European Union, and it is these days that we are commemorating the 70th anniversary of the end of the worst war disaster in our modern history.  The cruelty of the occupation, on the one hand, and the subsequent lawlessness in the turbulent post-war period further deepened the trench, for example, among Czechs and Germans. We know how much effort was needed for Czech-German reconciliation.  Let us wish both nations and both countries, Turkey and Armenia, to find their way together.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, we abstained from the vote because we did not know how to vote, because in Poland there is no problem with gypsies. There is no anti-Gypsy feeling. Gypsies are jolly fellows travelling in a cart, playing violins and so on, but we have problems with ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr President, this is an explanation of the vote on the Armenian genocide. What else armenian, what else gypsies. You are on the list of explanations for voting on the genocide in Armenia. You are talking about gypsies– these are two different nations. I understand that you can wait until the next point and speak when we talk about Roma. Thank you very much, Mr President.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution recognising the Armenian genocide, because this is how we can pay tribute to the millions of Armenian men, women and children slaughtered by the Neo-Turkish troops whose aim was ethnic cleansing. One hundred years after the Armenian genocide, humanity leans the brood on their grave. From the ordinary citizens of the world to the Pope, everyone with one mouth condemns the mass massacres of Armenians, condemns this crime against humanity. The vote in favour of the resolution is therefore not only a restoration of the truth, but also a historic act which puts pressure on Turkey, which must finally recognise the Armenian genocide, but also the Pontian genocide, and apologise. Turkey must commit itself in practice to respecting international law by withdrawing Turkish occupying troops from Cyprus and removing the casus belli against Greece.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Slovakia is the only country in the European Union that has introduced criminal responsibility for denying the armenian genocide. This is a follow-up example for other countries as well. Genocide is a crime against humanity. The only way to prevent nations from being able to learn from the horrors that have happened in the future goes through pleading guilty and asking for forgiveness. As Pope Francis said, concealing or denying evil is like letting the wound bleed without bandaged it. I consider the reaction of Turkish President Erdogan to Pope Francis' comment to be inadequate. When voting on the motion for a resolution, I therefore voted in favour of adopting amendments that recall the wise pope's words: 'Only openness to the truth can heal the wounds of the past'.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, I voted in support of this resolution because it must serve as another reminder of where excessive nationalism can lead, and also as a warning that nowadays extreme right xenophobic, anti-Semitic, anti-Roma or ethnic violent nationalism directed against other nations and national minorities is spreading in Europe, often tolerated and even supported by political leaders and governments.  I would have preferred the aspect of the danger of reviving nationalism to have been reflected more strongly in the text. Nevertheless, I believe that in this resolution Parliament is sending a sufficiently clear and alarming signal to all affected governments and political forces.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In 1934, a novel by the Austrian writer Franz Werfel, "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh", was published in Vienna and Berlin, in which Werfel was the first literate in history to describe the genocide of the Armenians by the Turkish-Ottoman Empire. But today, 100 years later, the Turkish government is still aggressively denying the genocide. Prime Minister Davutoglu openly accused the Holy Father, Pope Francis, who spoke clearly of racism and xenophobia. However, it seems to me particularly worrying that not only the Islamic nationalists on the Bosphorus are denying their history, but today Turkish youth groups in Europe, the Turkish youth 'TGB Europa', are now calling all those who speak of genocide as defamators of Turkey in a flood of broadcasts. This is worrying and threatening to me, noting that third-generation immigrants have obviously still not arrived in democratic Europe. That is why I support this motion today with my vote.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I have proposed, signed and supported this resolution for several reasons. First of all, from deep sympathy and condolences to the heirs of these million and a half fallen Armenians who were victims of the Armenian genocide. Not only because of the memory of these victims, but also of all the other victims of the young Turkish genocide within the Ottoman Empire, which lasted from 1913 to 1921, in the insane human-like attempt of the young Turkish government to create a united nation, killing all other peoples and nationalities within the borders of the Ottoman Empire. Secondly, today's Turkish state must be compelled to recognize the historical guilt of its predecessors, condemn this act, assume political, if necessary, financial responsibility and compensate the victims of Armenian, Bulgarian and all other nationalities. Thirdly, the behavior of today's Turkish political elite is outrageous. They deny and try to deny any guilt. It is not only genocide that must be recognised, but its denial must be prosecuted.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The genocide suffered by the Armenian people took place just a hundred years ago and deserves to be commemorated. It is important to honor your victims to remember that facts of this nature cannot be repeated. It is therefore necessary to emphasize the importance of the recognition of historical truth. The proposed resolution, in addition to being a commemoration, is important in terms of the future of relations between Armenia and Turkey. In this regard, even if Turkey does not yet recognise this genocide, Parliament welcomes the recognition of these atrocities by the President and prime minister of Turkey, pending the fact that this is only the first step towards the recognition of genocide and subsequent reconciliation between the two peoples. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide. The killing of approximately one-and-a-half million people from the Armenian community one hundred years ago, in what was then the Ottoman Empire, was a genocide. Indeed an increasing number of Member States and national parliaments recognise the Armenian Genocide. Dealing with the past and truth recovery are vital to any meaningful reconciliation process, a fact we in Sinn Féin are keenly aware of given our own post-conflict situation in Ireland. The joint motion for resolution expresses recognition of the Armenian Genocide in the context of on-going and further reconciliation between Armenia and Turkey. This is to be welcomed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Parliament with this resolution participates in the remembrance events for the 100th Anniversary of the Armenian Genocide and pays tribute to the victims of the genocide.  In our resolution, the European Parliament calls on Turkey to recognise genocide and to stop denying the historical reality and crimes committed against the Christian populations of the then faltering Ottoman Empire. The Armenian Genocide was one of the first genocides of the 20th century. Acceptance of history and memory are essential elements in order to avoid repeating such crimes in the future

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. On the eve of the commemoration of the Armenian genocide, this motion for a resolution pays tribute to the victims of this genocide, who are more than 1.5 million who have been massacred.   It calls on Turkey to fully respect and fulfil its obligations to protect cultural heritage and, in particular, to carry out in good faith a complete inventory of the Armenian and other cultural heritage destroyed or damaged in the last century on its territory. In addition, she congratulates and adds the words of the Holy Father Pope Francis, who honors the memory of Armenians in a spirit of peace and reconciliation.  I therefore voted in favour of this recognition of the Armenian genocide.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – This matter does not appear to be subject to a roll-call vote. In the interests of transparency and democracy therefore, I wish to clarify that I voted in favour of all the EFDD amendments and in favour of the resolution as a whole.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide.  In 1987, the European Parliament adopted a resolution recognising the Armenian genocide and becoming one of the first international organisations to recognise the event. In the subsequent EP resolutions on EU-Turkey relations, the EP also called for the Turkish Government to do so. The motion for a resolution expresses its gratitude to all those who have contributed to the investigation, recognition and remembrance of the Armenian genocide. I agree that the prevention of genocide and crimes against humanity should be one of the priorities of the international community and the European Union. It is important for Turkey to recognise the Armenian genocide and thus pave the way for genuine reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In favour of the recognition of the terrible genocide suffered by the Armenians while the Ottoman Empire was collapsing, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Considering that recognition of the Armenian genocide is a necessity, I voted for this text.  The resolution adopted by the European Parliament takes advantage of the centenary of the Armenian massacre to recognise it as 'genocide'. Already recognized as genocide by France, the resolution clearly calls into question the role of the Ottoman authorities of the time.  Although the resolution calls on Turkey to recognise the Armenian genocide in order to open the door to reconciliation with Armenia, the reaction of the current Turkish President, who refuses the genocidal character, testifies to the extent to which Turkey's accession to the European Union is a foolish goal, driven only by the submission of the European authorities to the American desiderata.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the positions supported in this report, which I find balanced and well developed, for these reasons I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it pays tribute to Parliament between 1915 and 1917. Remembrance of the armenian genocide victims in the territory of the Ottoman Empire. Parliament also proposes to declare a European Day of Genocide remembrance in order to remind all peoples and peoples in the world of the right to peace and dignity. In its report, Parliament encourages Armenia and Turkey to follow examples of successful reconciliation between the peoples of Europe and to focus on an agenda aimed at cooperation between peoples, because it believes that these actions will facilitate the historic reconciliation between the Armenian and Turkish peoples in the spirit of truth and respect. Parliament also supports the initiatives of civil society in Turkey and Armenia to try to normalise relations.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. My support for the resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide is based on the fact that historical events, tragic or happy, must be aware and learn from them. It is necessary to be aware of your mistakes or mistakes of your ancestors and to draw energy from them for cooperation, not dissuading.  The killing of more than a million and a half Armenians under the Ottoman Empire, which took place during the 1st World War, represents one of the most horrific chapters in the history of mankind. Genocide is a discarded act that deserves all condemnation, regardless of the time or period in which it took place. Any deliberate and deliberate killing of an ethnic minority is inconsistent with the humanity and ethos under which we are obliged to live, and therefore the denial and relativism of such acts must also be condemned.  A glimmer of optimism about those atrocities can, however, be seen in the more conciliation words of the Turkish State Summit. But the goal will be met once genocide is actually recognised. This will make it easier to leave a dark history behind and focus on the path of reconciliation and cooperation. To be possible, it is an example to us of the founders of a united Europe, who almost seventy years ago started building the story that we are now part of. I believe the Turks and Armenians are capable of this!

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. Although there was no term genocide a hundred years ago, practically the disappearance of Armenians from ottoman empire cannot be classified differently. Open and free debate in Turkish society on historical issues, including the Armenian genocide, is inseparably linked to the democratisation process. Indeed, a healthy and mature democracy cannot be built on the basis of denial and distortion of historical facts and responsibilities. The process of joining the European Union played a key role in promoting Turkey's democratisation. Therefore, I believe that unfreezing the negotiation process can be a driver of a more open and free debate on historical issues. In conclusion, I call on Turkey and Armenia to renew efforts to normalise relations by ratifying protocols on establishing diplomatic relations and opening borders without preconditions.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide. I can only express my solidarity with this people massacred by the Ottoman regime. We can only regret the denialist attitude of the Turkish authorities on this issue. They still refuse to consider that the recognition of the Armenian genocide is part of the Copenhagen criteria, which set conditions for the candidate countries of the European Union. As the pope recently pointed out, this is the first genocide of the twentieth century. This massacre was perpetrated mainly for religious reasons. One hundred years later, in the Near and Middle East, Christians are persecuted. Let us not forget and stand in solidarity with the Christians of the East.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide because I believe that, in order to never repeat the tragic mistakes of the past, it is fundamental to never forget about them, and the remembrance of the Armenian genocide of 1915-1917 serves this purpose exactly. We remember it in order to prevent other genocides from happening in the future.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. By voting in favour of this resolution, I would like to pay tribute to the 1.2 million Armenians who were massacred and deported in 1915 by the Ottoman Empire. This genocide is still an open wound for the Armenian people, a people who have always defended the recognition of this genocide with humility.  That is why Turkey must embark on the path of recognition of the Armenian genocide, including the opening of its archives. I would also like to salute the words of Pope Francis, which honour the memory of Armenians and advance the cause of recognition.  In order to move from words to deeds and to force Erdogan to recognise the genocide and to stop the persecution of Christian minorities, including Chaldeans, Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union should be suspended immediately.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. 2012 100 years ago, the Armenian people were the victims of a terrible genocide perpetrated in the Ottoman Empire. It is very important to remember this event that dramatically marked the spirits.  Turkish leaders must realize that it is essential to recognize this genocide as such. This is a necessary step towards Turkey's cooperation with Armenia but also with the European Union.  The European Parliament, with this resolution, has decided to pay tribute to the memory of the victims and to reaffirm the recognition of the Armenian genocide. Mr Erdogan saw fit to denigrate this text, once again acknowledging the difficulties of negotiating with him.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. The massacre of one and a half million Armenian Christians by the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1917 can be defined as the first genocide of the twentieth century. Remembering the innocent victims of this extermination is therefore absolutely necessary so as not to forget such a tragic event and avoid its repetition.   That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution commemorating the victims of the Armenian genocide in a spirit of solidarity and justice, and stresses that the denial of genocide represents a continuation of the perpetuated violence against the Ottoman Armenians.  The resolution adopted by Parliament also has the merit of strongly condemning all crimes against humanity and genocide and of reiterating that one of the main motivations of the Movement for European Unification and one of the founding values of the European Union itself is the desire to prevent a repetition of wars and crimes against humanity.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide. The killing of approximately one-and-a-half million people from the Armenian community one hundred years ago, in what was then the Ottoman Empire, was a genocide. Indeed an increasing number of Member States and national parliaments recognise the Armenian Genocide. Dealing with the past and truth recovery are vital to any meaningful reconciliation process, a fact we in Sinn Féin are keenly aware of given our own post-conflict situation in Ireland. The joint motion for a resolution expresses recognition of the Armenian Genocide in the context of on-going and further reconciliation between Armenia and Turkey. This is to be welcomed.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution as I agree with keeping alive the memories of the past; there can be no reconciliation without truth and remembrance. It is important to pay tribute to the memory of the innocent victims of the Armenian genocide and all genocides and crimes committed against humanity. It is heartening to read the statements by the President of Turkey Erdoğan and the Prime Minister of Turkey Davutoğlu offering condolences and recognising atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians. These are a step in the right direction. I do hope that additional efforts are made by both sides to normalise their relations by ratifying and implementing, without preconditions, the protocols on the establishment of diplomatic relations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 As I said during the debate, this resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide is not an act of condemnation. It is a dutiful contribution to our memory and a humble invitation to reconciliation. I hope that the Turkish people will soon be able to take a just and noble step towards reconciliation, so that calm relations can be re-established between Armenia and Turkey, and this wound that still divides them can finally be healed. We welcome the great commitment of civil society in this direction.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. The Armenian genocide is a resolutely European issue, considering the irreversible effects of this genocide on the many Armenian descendants who are refugees in the Union. I therefore fought for Europe to join these commemorations, in a spirit of openness and solidarity. The centenary of such a tragic event imposes a dignified attitude, to which all the Members involved in the negotiations have complied. This joint resolution is in the direction of appeasement and represents a step towards full recognition of the Armenian genocide.  I would have liked the spirit of this text to be more commemorative, more focused on the links between Armenian and Turkish civil societies, and less oriented on Armenian-Turkish diplomatic relations.  Personally, I also believe that we cannot be satisfied with the condolences of Mr Erdogan and Mr Davutoglu to the victims of this genocide, because they were nothing like excuses but more akin to a political manoeuvre. I would not have specifically referred to these statements in a solemn context of commemorations. Nevertheless, I welcome once again our parliamentary work, in line with the idea that there is no reconciliation without truth or a work of memory.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting with conviction in favour of the resolution commemorating the centenary of the Armenian genocide, and I do so in the words of the Holy Father who, in no uncertain terms, declared the Armenian genocide the first genocide of the modern era.
