In 1915, some one and a half million innocent Armenian victims were massacred in the then Ottoman Empire, atrocities of this kind must not happen again, and that is why it is important to call things by their names.  At the same time, however, I join with those who welcome turkey's efforts and are making to harmonise relations with Armenia, in a spirit of reconciliation that promotes the search for truth and mutual respect. Relations between the two countries must normalise as soon as possible and we, the citizens of Europe, must do our best to ensure that this happens, not by criminalising Turkey today for what has happened in the past, but by helping it to accept its past, to review it and to reconcile itself from the bottom up with the Armenian people. This is the way to enter Europe.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I can only associate myself with the tribute to the victims of the Armenian genocide, whose massacre was planned by an Ottoman Empire in agony. One million Armenians, including women and children, were murdered between 1915 and 1916.  Following His Holiness Pope Francis, we must tell the Armenian people that we remember; we remember, not to make us the judges of history, but because to keep the memory of the past, of what we have been and of what we are is necessary to build the future; let us remember, as Bernard de Chartres advocated in the twelfth century, that "we are like dwarves sitting on the shoulders of giants. If we see more things and more distant than them, it is because we are raised by them." We are no better than our ancestors, but we must make their history our own to raise us.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today in Plenary, we commemorated the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. In 1915, one-and-a-half million innocent Armenian victims perished in the south-east part of the Ottoman Empire, what is today Turkey. However, Parliament does recognise the current government’s efforts to improve its attitudes towards the Armenian minority still present in Turkey today. Furthermore, there is room for greater mutual understanding which can be achieved through cooperation between Armenia and Turkey.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, on the eve of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, decides to pay tribute to the Armenian victims. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, in its resolution on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party, recalls the victims of all genocide and crimes against humanity and proposes the establishment of a 'European Day of the Memory of Genocide'.  The GROUP of the European People's Party also calls on Turkey, a candidate country for accession to the European Union, to respect and fulfil its obligations to safeguard its cultural heritage. The group sent Turkey and Armenia to begin a process of reconciliation and reconciliation leading to the normalisation of their relations. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of introducing a day dedicated to commemorating the Armenian genocide, the centenary of which is celebrated this year, because we must not be afraid to call things by their own name. For this reason I agree with the words used by the Holy Father, who defined it as the first modern genocide. We must have the courage to defend christians who are oppressed, wherever they may be.  Since, however, in history reason is never on one side, we must shed light on the facts and responsibilities, and stress that those tragic events were the result of complex political plots that have their roots very far away. Reconciliation, which I hope should pass through the admission of blame, on the one hand and on the other, and my intention in voting in favour of this resolution was to take a step in this direction.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. This document reaffirms its firm condemnation both of all the episodes recognised as crimes against humanity and genocide and of the various attempts at denialism; Calls on Turkey to respect its obligations to safeguard Armenia's cultural heritage and to continue its efforts to definitively recognise the crime of genocide perpetrated by the Ottomans. Thanks to the centenary, it is believed possible, in particular, to strengthen the efforts made by Turkey and the Armenian people to achieve faster reconciliation, which would pave the way for cross-border cooperation and economic integration of the parties. Consider, in this regard, that the European Union itself could benefit significantly from the normalisation of relations between Turkey and Armenia, located on the borders of our continent. Finally, I welcome the proposal to establish the European Day of remembering genocide, to pay tribute to the victims of past crimes and to reaffirm the right of all peoples and nations to safeguard their identity and dignity.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – 2015 marks the centennial of the Armenian genocide. There can be no reconciliation without truth and remembrance. This resolution pays tribute to the memory of the one-and-a-half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire and to the memory of the innocent victims of all genocides and crimes committed against humanity. The resolution also invites Armenia and Turkey to use examples of successful reconciliation between European nations and to focus on an agenda that puts cooperation between peoples first. I have thus voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The genocide suffered by the Armenian people that took place just a hundred years ago deserves to be commemorated. It is important to honor your victims to remember that facts of this nature cannot be repeated. It is therefore necessary to emphasize the importance of the recognition of historical truth. The proposed resolution, in addition to being a commemoration, is important in terms of the future of relations between Armenia and Turkey. In this regard, even if Turkey does not yet recognise this genocide, Parliament welcomes the recognition of these atrocities by the President and prime minister of Turkey, pending the fact that this is only the first step towards the recognition of genocide and subsequent reconciliation between the two peoples. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Bernard Bruneteau defined the twentieth century, the century of genocide. Not that at other times there had been no extermination. But only in the last century, the combined combination of nationalism and modernity, gave rise to that mass crime that plans and carries out the scientific annihilation of an entire group. 24 April will be the centenary of the beginning of the Armenian genocide, the first example ever. What better opportunity to call for the establishment of an International Day of Remembrance for Genocide. Pope Francis also expressed himself in important words, reminding everyone of his responsibilities, and reminding everyone of the barbarity of which the human being was capable in a civilized age such as that of the twentieth century. It was not the last, Stalin's Soviet Union, Nazi Germany and, after the Second World War, ethnic cleansing in the former Yugoslavia, again to remain in civilian Europe. I would, however, like to mention Rwanda, where a woman has planned the most horrific of crimes against her own sex. We must always keep our memories alive in order to instil culture in the new generations in respect for religious, cultural and political diversity. Only in this way can we try to prevent what happened then from happening again.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The resolution pays tribute to the memory of the 1.5 million Armenian victims who perished in the times of the Ottoman Empire 100 years ago. It also confirms Parliament’s view that what happened in 1915-1917 represents a genocide as defined by international law. As this resolution clearly holds that what happened 100 years ago was a horrendous genocide, while opening up space for further positive dialogue between the two sides, I voted in favour.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide to honour the memory of the one and a half million victims of the atrocities committed during the First World War under the Ottoman Empire. The aim of this resolution is to keep alive the memory of what has happened, so that the memory promotes a real resumption of diplomatic relations between the two countries and a definitive reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian people.  The commemoration of the centenary of the Armenian genocide must not, however, be limited to remembrance; above all, it must be a warning, at a time when discrimination and religious persecution are still having too many victims.  The same atrocities suffered by Armenian Christians affect Christians all over the world every day, and the recent massacre on the Garissa university campus is, unfortunately, proof of this. It is the duty of the European Union, as well as of the entire international community, to condemn any form of crime against humanity and to expose any attempt at denialism and religious intolerance.  I am convinced that the united voice of the European Parliament and the words of Pope Francis in recent days can strengthen the commitment of Europeans to interreligious dialogue and coexistence between different peoples and cultures.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Exactly a century ago, in 1915, massacres and deportations of the Armenian population began in the Ottoman Empire. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution recogniseing armenians because, with this text, the European Union not only pays tribute to the memory of the one and a half million Armenian victims, but above all strongly deplores and strongly condemns any attempt at denialism.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the proposal for a joint resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide. This text is not only an opportunity to pay an official tribute to the memory of the 1,500,000 innocent Armenian victims who lost their lives in the Ottoman Empire. It is also a way of encouraging Turkey to look its history in the face. I would like to welcome Pope Francis' statement of 12 April, in which he refers to the massacre of Armenians from 1915 to 1923 as the first genocide of the 20th century. I consider that, following the 2014 statements of the President and Prime Minister of Turkey, which expressed their condolences to the Ottoman Armenians and acknowledged the atrocities committed against them, it is now essential that Turkey cease to regard this as a civil war and that it officially acknowledge the Armenian genocide in order to lay the groundwork for genuine reconciliation. , to relaunch diplomatic relations, to actively improve their relations, particularly with regard to cross-border cooperation and economic integration.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution because the recognition of the Armenian genocide and the pressure on Turkey in this direction is entirely in agreement with me.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide. It is important not to silence the brutality of massacres and forced deportations in the name of policies of cultural homogenization. It is essential to admit and recognize the mistakes made in the past to close this dark chapter of history and to promote reconciliation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament was one of the first international institutions to recognise the Armenian genocide in 1987. Over the years, the EP has asked the Turkish government to recognise the genocide committed against the Armenians in 1915-1917. In its annual report on human rights adopted on 12 March, the EP also calls on "all Member States to recognise it". In a resolution adopted in 1987 on a political solution to the Armenian issue, the European Parliament states that it is "of the opinion that the tragic events that occurred in 1915-1917 against Armenians established on the territory of the Ottoman Empire constitute genocide within the meaning of the Convention for the prevention and repression of genocide crimes adopted by the UN General Assembly on 9 December 1948".

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. On April 24, the date on which more than 200 Armenian intellectuals and leaders were arrested and later murdered, the 100th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide, considered the first genocide of the 20th century, is celebrated, the first the Turkish Youth movement, then the Turkish Nationalists, nationalist organizations, is part of a plan to liquidate the Armenian minority from the territory that would later constitute the Republic of Turkey. , persecuted, arrested, deported and murdered hundreds of thousands of human beings.  The academic discussion remains, but seems to point to the extermination or withdrawal of the entire Armenian population from that region, accounting for between 1 and 1.5 million deaths of a population of about 2 million people. A historical example that should serve as a warning so that we do not lose sight of the present in the face of the emergence of nationalist and Nazi-fascist movements, such as ukraine, where they have the support of the EU and the US. In either case, this memory cannot serve to create divisions between the Armenian and Turkish peoples. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ This anniversary marks the anniversary of the genocide committed by the Ottoman authorities in 1915. This genocide has caused the extermination of the Armenian community, which lived in the southeastern part of the Ottoman Empire, that is, today's Turkey. After the defeat of the Ottoman Empire in World War I, the new Republican Turkey denied this historical fact. The actions of the current Turkish Government, which is seeking to improve relations with the existing Armenian community, should therefore be applauded. The two countries must continue to normalise their relations and promote cultural and educational exchanges in order to improve mutual understanding and improved relations, which are disrupted by historical events.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In 1915, armenians were killed along with The Ottoman Empire's Syrians of Catholic and Orthodox faith, Assyrians, Chaldeans and Greeks. More than two decades later, German Nazism was the perpetrator of the Holocaust. Mass extermination also affected m.in cambodian, Rwandan, Burundian and Bosnian citizens.  My people in the last century experienced genocide by German Nazism, Soviet communism and Ukrainian nationalism. The destruction of intelligence, the shooting of prisoners, mass executions, pacification of villages and, finally, the construction of a system of German concentration camps were aimed at realizing plans to destroy the Polish people. Katyn, Kharkiv, Twer, Kiev and Minsk in 1940 became the places of the polish officers killed by the Soviets for being the Polish elite. More than 250,000 Poles from Volynia, Podola, Polesia and Malopolska East three years later became victims of the brutal genocide perished by Ukrainian nationalists. Hence our Polish sensitivity to all forms of mass crimes, regardless of whose hands and where they take place.  By voting in favour of the resolution, I am convinced that true reconciliation can only take place in truth. However, I would like to stress firmly that the resolution cannot be an instrument of policy towards the Republic of Turkey and the Muslim world. The government in Ankara has done much in recent years to clarify and bring closer the real reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the 100th Anniversary of the Armenian Genocide because the recognition of the Armenian genocide and the pressure on Turkey in this direction is entirely in agreement with me.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ With this resolution, Europe’s elected representatives have joined the worldwide commemorations that will culminate on 24 April. I believe that, on the commemoration of the centenary of the Armenian genocide, we must make more efforts in order to move beyond and to build a common future, by pushing for a deep process of normalisation and reconciliation between the Armenians and the Turks.  Turks and Armenians should support smaller, symbolic efforts that allow for dialogue and understanding, like last year’s statements by Erdoğan, or the return of the Armenian properties that were confiscated by the Turkish state. This process must occur at the individual, societal, and state levels. This is a process that requires time and reconsideration of identity, as well as of history, but that is essential for both countries mutual trust and future cooperation. I believe that it is fundamental that we all recognise, remember and condemn these kinds of tragedy, if we want to avoid them in the future. Only through awareness of universal human rights, through passing down a collective memory, and through the consistent application of legal norms and international law, can these kinds of crime can be prevented or stopped in their evolution.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Turkey must recognise the historical fact of the Armenian genocide as a way of creating the basis for real reconciliation. In the resolution I voted for, the EP welcomed Pope Francis' message of 12 April, in which the Head of the Church commemorated the genocide. We call on Armenia and Turkey to normalify their relations on the basis of the 'example of successful reconciliation between European nations' by unconditionally ratifying and implementing the Protocols on the uptake of diplomatic relations, opening the border and effectively improving their relations. I also welcome the statement by the President of the Turkish Republic and the Turkish Prime Minister, in which they expressed their condolences and acknowledged the atrocities committed against armenians in the Ottoman Empire.  The EP now encourages Turkey to "consider the commemoration of the centenary of the Armenian genocide as an opportunity for reconciliation with its own past" for example by opening archives and "to recognise the Armenian genocide, thereby creating the possibility of effective reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples". Finally, Parliament proposes 'the creation of an international day of remembrance of genocide, recalling that all peoples and nations around the world have the right to peace and dignity'.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution considering that 2015 marks the centenary of a tragic event that brings great suffering to the Armenian people. Today we pay tribute to the one and a half million innocent Armenian victims who lost their lives amid the nonsense and barbarity of war. Armenia and Turkey still have a long way to go, so they must continue to make progress towards reconciliation and overcoming the terrible events that have occurred, always bearing in mind the memory of the victims based on truth and mutual respect. There will be no reconciliation without truth, and without truth neither Turkey nor Armenia can ever overcome the terrible past in common.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The armenian genocide is a historical truth that cannot be denied, but rather must be recognized and remembered, so that certain horrors do not happen again. Denialism is the last act of genocide and it is important that today the European Union has spoken out in clear and courageous words condemning one of the dark pages too often forgotten of the twentieth century.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of today's resolution, and I would also like to take this opportunity to reiterate that it is precisely the memory of what happened a hundred years ago that must lead us to concentrate all our efforts on putting an end to all the persecution that is taking place today, first and for all of those against Christians. We cannot change the past, but we can and must change the future.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution adopted on the occasion of the 100th  anniversary of the Armenian genocide to pay tribute to the one-and-a-half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire. I welcome the statements of Turkish president Erdoğan and prime minister Davutoğlu offering their condolences and recognising atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians. This is a step in the right direction, and I now encourage Turkey to use this commemoration as an opportunity to come to terms with its past and recognise the Armenian genocide, which is crucial for achieving genuine reconciliation between the people of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the anniversary of the Armenian genocide, in the belief that the main objective to be pursued at present is to promote the improvement of bilateral relations between Turkey and Armenia. The recognition of the tragedies of past injustices is a fundamental step in building stable relationships in the present. Turkey should therefore officially acknowledge the mistakes made by the Ottoman Empire in order to usher in a new season of appeasement and friendship with the Armenian people, with a view to a renewed spirit of mutual understanding

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide.  This resolution is in its spirit close to the resolution tabled by patriotic MPs on 29 January. In the spirit of reconciliation and tribute to the victims of this genocide, we called on the Turkish government to acknowledge the crimes committed by the Ottoman Empire in 1915 against the Armenian population. I recall that the continuation of Turkey's accession process to the European Union is incompatible with the so-called values of the Union, insofar as Turkey: - does not formally acknowledge its responsibility for multiple genocides (against Armenians, Assyro-Chaldeans and Greeks); - occupies part of the territory of a European country (Northern Cyprus);  - provides assistance to Islamist groups in the Middle East.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. On the occasion of the centenary of the genocide perpetrated by the decaying Ottoman Empire, it commemorates the genocide and urges the Turkish government to advance its recognition. In the past few weeks, the Turkish government lamented the suffering caused to the Armenian population, and this is welcomed in the Resolution, even if they continue to resist classifying it as genocide. Although the Joint Resolution is incomplete and contains the usual hypocrisy about the EU's role as an international human rights defender, we consider its adoption to be positive for the historical demands of the Armenian people and for that reason we voted in favour.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, because I believe that reconciliation and the common building of the future of nations must be based on truth and dialogue. For many years, the truth about the Katyn genocide carried out by the NKVD on Polish officers was similarly concealed. The Turkish authorities should not make the same mistake. They should use this unique moment in history – the 100th anniversary – to continue their efforts at reconciliation by opening their archives and recognising the crimes in armenians as genocide. Turkey is seeking EU membership and is therefore committed to European standards. However, without the recognition of crimes in armenians, this will not be possible.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide. Indeed, I believe it is crucial that the European Parliament recognises the Armenian genocide when an increasing number of Member States and national parliaments are also doing so. Timely prevention and effective punishment of genocides should be among the main priorities of the European Union.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. I agree with the European Parliament's desire for the prevention of genocide and crimes against humanity to become one of the priorities of the international community and the European Union.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as an increasing number of Member States and National Parliaments are this year recognising the centenary of the tragic events that took place against the Armenians in the territory of the Ottoman Empire. I believe it is appropriate to pay tribute to the memory of the one and a half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire. The importance of remembering such tragic events of the past is paramount to the future, as there can be no reconciliation without the truth of remembrance. I would also like to pledge my support for the establishment of an International Remembrance Day for Genocides to recall once again the right of people and nations throughout the world to peace and dignity.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. On the occasion of the centenary of the genocide perpetrated by the decaying Ottoman Empire, it commemorates the genocide and urges the Turkish government to advance its recognition. In the past few weeks, the Turkish government lamented the suffering caused to the Armenian population, and this is welcomed in the Resolution, even if they continue to resist classifying it as genocide. Although the Joint Resolution is incomplete and contains the usual hypocrisy about the EU's role as an international human rights defender, we consider its adoption to be positive for the historical demands of the Armenian people and for that reason we voted in favour.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour because the bloody genocide that took place with the Armenian people and which Pope Francis himself has condemned and remembered in his last public appearance cannot go unpunished or forgotten. Hoping that no more genocide will occur around the world.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide because it is a well-balanced document.  Notwith regardless of some of the terminological definitions being challenged, such as the use of the term "genocide", there is no escaping the fact that a huge number of people were killed and therefore I supported this Resolution. It also warns of major accidents, and it is important to ensure non-obsolescence of crimes committed against humanity. In addition, the resolution seeks good-budgetary relations between Turkey and Armenia.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The crimes committed by Turkey on civilian populations of the Ottoman Empire during the First World War are an undeniable reality.  The Armenians in the first place, but also the Assyro-Chaldeans and the Pontic Greeks suffered mass massacres, the extent of which is denied by successive Turkish governments. Recognition of these crimes against the Christian population is necessary for Europe to build lasting relations with Turkey, even though Turkey has no place in the European Union.  I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide.  With this resolution, the European Parliament was keen to remind that without truth and memory, reconciliation is impossible. In addition to commemorating the memory of the innocent victims who perished, it serves as a reminder to the world that many communities are still persecuted today because of their origin or religion.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. On the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide, this resolution pays tribute to the memory of the victims and calls on the Turkish authorities to recognize this genocide in order to enable lasting reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. I welcome its adoption.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the resolution that pays tribute to the memory of the one-and-a-half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire. The tragedy against the Armenians represents genocide as defined by the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide of 1948.  The resolution encourages the Turkish authorities to use the commemoration as an opportunity for Turkey to continue its efforts to come to terms with its past, to recognise the Armenian genocide and thus pave the way for a genuine reconciliation between the people of Turkey and Armenia. It is of utmost importance that we keep the memories of the past alive in order to help prevent new conflicts and build a brighter future, but it is as important to emphasise the need to prevent using this event to serve different political agendas. All parties must continue to work towards reconciliation.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support the European Parliament resolution, which, recognising the Armenian genocide, calls on Turkey to take a similar decision and encourages further efforts to normalise relations and reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia. The slaughter of more than 1.5 million Armenians in the Ottoman Empire 100 years ago is one of the most vicious and shameful acts of violence in human history. Genocide cannot be justified by any circumstances: tradition or religious motives, and must be condemned.  Turkey's recognition of the truth about the Armenian genocide is necessary because a common future cannot be built without sincere dialogue and mutual understanding. The memory of the victims is the basis for reconciliation, on which we can begin to build peaceful relations both between people and between states. Turkey, as a country aspiring to EU membership, must reconcile and account for its past, as historical hostility does not foster integration between states and can undermine human rights, which are fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, the House is recalling a tragic and immense extermination, the forgotten genocide of a people. Remembering over a million Armenians killed in 1915 under the Ottoman Empire means embarking on the path to reconciliation. Denying memory is like keeping alive what that pain caused. A century after these events, the time has come for this tragic wound to be re-found and for the road to genuine reconciliation between the Armenian people and the Turkish people to be paved. Our European Union was founded precisely on the will to prevent wars and crimes against humanity. An evil, which, if not cured, risks spreading and expanding. With this vote, we are encouraging Turkey to continue its efforts to date to come to terms with its past, through a free and open debate. A fundamental stage in the process of democratization.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, I voted against the draft resolution not because I deny the need for a general assessment of these events, but because I believe that the way to achieve a common assessment may be difficult to adopt such a position of the EP. Controversial historical events should not be transformed into modern political conflicts. Historical disputes are in the field of historical science, not in the field of politics. Let's leave this to the academies of sciences and universities. Parliament is a highly politicised body and is not the most appropriate environment for establishing historical truth. We as politicians are not allowed to write content and direction of thinking.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution because I am convinced that a fair assessment of past crimes will contribute to the democratic development of Turkey. We must keep a memory of the suffering of all nations, but we should focus not only on the regret that has been there, but on the future that unites us. I am pleased to recognise that relations between Turkey and Armenia are improving, and the resolution adopted also recognises this. However, we are unfortunately seeing the opposite development in Russia, where the crimes of the communist regime have not been critically assessed to date and where the undemocratic regime led by Putin instead continues to commit crimes against other peoples.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution calling on Turkey to recognize the Armenian genocide, without preconditions, in order to lay the foundations for genuine reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. 2015 marks the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. On this occasion and through this resolution, the European Parliament paid tribute to the memory of the 1.5 million Armenian victims who lost their lives in the Ottoman Empire a century ago. In voting on this resolution, I also wished to welcome the message of Pope Francis dated 12 April 2015, in which "it commemorates the centenary of the Armenian genocide in a spirit of peace and reconciliation". Finally, as part of this resolution, we propose to establish an international day of commemoration of genocides, which should reaffirm every year the right of all peoples and nations of the world to peace and dignity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The Members of the National Front voted in favour of the resolution on the recognition of the Armenian genocide, even though the text shows a certain naivety when we welcome the statements of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, President of the Republic of Turkey, and Ahmet Davutoun, Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey, who last year expressed their condolences to the Ottoman Armenians and acknowledged the atrocities committed against them.  The reactions of Mr Erdogan and Mr Davutoglu to Pope Francis' recent statements on the Armenian genocide are of rare violence, with Davutoglu saying that the Pope has joined a "conspiracy of a front of evil". The Turkish President, for his part, had already announced in advance that he would not give any importance to the European Parliament resolution.  As the recognition of the Armenian genocide is essential, in particular, for the improvement of relations between Turkey and Armenia, and since good-neighbourly relations are part of the accession criteria, the European Union must incorporate this recognition as a prerequisite for the continuation of the accession process.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it recognises the reality of the Armenian genocide, which occurred a hundred years ago. She also has the merit of congratulating the pope for his words that honour the memory of Armenians in a spirit of peace and reconciliation.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Positive vote for the recognition of the Armenian genocide.  Beyond the fact that it is essential to pay tribute to the Armenian victims of this massacre, this must prompt the Turkish authorities to make the effort to question the responsibilities of this massacre and to recognize this genocide.  The holy Father's recent position on this issue is a great step forward as it is taken in a spirit of peace and to promote the reconciliation of peoples.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The genocide suffered by the Armenian people took place just a hundred years ago deserves to be commemorated. It is important to honor your victims to remember that facts of this nature cannot be repeated. It is therefore necessary to emphasize the importance of the recognition of historical truth. The proposed resolution, in addition to being a commemoration, is important in terms of the future of relations between Armenia and Turkey. In this regard, even if Turkey does not yet recognise this genocide, Parliament welcomes the recognition of these atrocities by the President and prime minister of Turkey, pending the fact that this is only the first step towards the recognition of genocide and subsequent reconciliation between the two peoples. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. \u2012 There have been many conflicts and injustices between peoples and ethnicities in history. Let us remember the sacrifices made by these unfortunate events. However, it does not seem to me to be beneficial to anyone if we choose and vote on some of these conflicts at official level. Let's focus on a peaceful future, not a conflicted past.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Every Bulgarian knows about the suffering of armenians in the Ottoman Empire. He knows from our native history and literature, from the stories of the representatives of the Armenian communities scattered all over Bulgaria. They come as refugees in Bulgaria, find in it their second homeland, preserve and pass on the memory of the massacre of the Armenians – because that's how for a 100 years we Bulgarians have called their heavy fate. Therefore, I have no doubt that the concept of genocide that emerged and imposed after The Second World War fully corresponds to the facts and depth of their tragedy.  Even 100 years after the terrible events, we must show that we have not forgotten those one-and-a-half million innocent victims. Europe knows best that only through truth is reconciliation between nations born. European citizens have shown the whole world how to do this. Therefore, the Armenian genocide must also be recognised by all European countries. I am convinced that the National Assembly of the Republic of Bulgaria will very soon follow the example of the European Parliament and adopt a declaration acknowledging the Armenian genocide. I am proud to have been part of today's truly overwhelming majority.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin, of course, voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. In favour of Turkey's recognition of the Armenian genocide, he supports this text, which pays tribute to the victims, and encourages the Turkish authorities to open their archives and finally acknowledge this genocide.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the '100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide'. On 24 April this year the whole world will remember the genocide of the Armenian people committed at the hands of young Turks during the years of the First World War. Parliament called on Turkey to respect and fully implement its legal obligations. It is essential that Armenia and Turkey take advantage of the centenary of the genocide to renew and improve their diplomatic relations, with particular reference to economic integration and reconciliation between their peoples.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ By way of an explanation of my vote, I thought it right to pay tribute to the memory of the innocent Armenian victims who perished during the First World War, in the spirit of European solidarity and justice.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the text of the joint resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide committed in the Ottoman Empire, which killed 1.5 million civilians. I believe that it is extremely important to remember the past and learn from it so that we do not repeat the same mistakes in the future. I believe that one of the main motives for European integration should be to prevent a repeat of wars and crimes against humanity, not only in Europe. Dialogue and mutual understanding must be fundamental pillars of the coexistence of all peoples. I have therefore joined in honoring the memory of the innocent victims of all genocides and crimes committed against humanity, and with my vote I supported the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. From the European Parliament, we wanted to pay tribute, on the eve of the centenary, to the memory of the one and a half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire. My support for this Resolution and international action for the timely prevention and effective punishment of genocides and crimes against humanity. From the European Parliament, we encourage Turkey to take advantage of the commemoration of the centenary of the Armenian genocide as an important opportunity to continue its efforts to assume its past, to recognise the Armenian genocide and, in this way, to pave the way for true reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the Armenian genocide 100 years ago must be condemned in the strongest possible terms. In 1915, 1.5 million Armenians were systematically killed and 500,000 survivors were driven from their homes in the Ottoman Empire. This massacre is a crime against humanity.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to commemorate the centenary of the Armenian genocide.  Armenia and Turkey should use the centenary of the Armenian genocide to renew diplomatic relations, open the border and pave the way for economic integration.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The resolution recognizes that the tragic events that took place from 1915 to 1917 in the Ottoman Empire against the Armenian population constitute genocide as defined by the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide Crimes of 1948.  The resolution pays tribute to the victims. It calls on the Turkish government to continue its efforts towards the recognition of the Armenian genocide to pave the way for genuine reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. I'm voting FOR.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Considering the Armenian genocide as one of the most atrocious crimes of the 21st century, too long forgotten, and in favour of the recognition of this genocide I voted FOR.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I am sympathetic to this Initiative of the EP which aims to bring to our memory the Armenian genocide perpetrated by the Ottoman Empire. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – This cross-party joint resolution should be commended as it encourages further reconciliation between Turkey and Armenia and also pays tribute to the memory of the victims of all genocides and crimes against humanity.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution, which commemorates the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide perpetrated by the Ottoman authorities in 1915, which put an end to the existence of the Armenian community living historically in the south-east part of the Ottoman empire (today’s Turkey).  The resolution criticises the new, Republican Turkey, established after the defeat of the Ottoman empire in the WWI, for the denial of this historical fact. It also recognises the steps taken by the current Turkish Government in improving the treatment of the remaining Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country’s past. The resolution calls on both Turkey and Armenia to normalise bilateral relations without preconditions, and promote people-to-people, academic, cultural and educational exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the anniversary of such a tragic and inhumane event must also be accompanied by a warning: prevent a repetition of these massacres. The Attitude of the Turkish Government towards the Kurdish minority is a serious indicator of ethnic segregation and is certainly not one of the behaviours admitted by a candidate country to join the Union. I would like to remind you that Turkey receives almost EUR 1 billion under the pre-accession instruments.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution commemorates the centenary of the Armenian genocide and calls on Turkey and Armenia to reconcile, to settle their relations and to open the border between the two countries. It also stresses the importance of timely prevention and effective punishment of genocide and crimes against humanity. I agree with the proposed resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The recognition of the 1915 Armenian genocide is a no-brainer that only Turkey still dares to deny today. Europe, which is still actively negotiating Turkey's entry into the Eu, should be concerned about Mr Erdogan's scathing response to the pope's recent remarks and the European Parliament's resolution, saying that he would ignore it.  Indeed, more than ever, the Turkish government treats with contempt or sanction any allusion to this genocide, which would have claimed nearly 1.5 million lives and was the first of a dramatic series in the twentieth century.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 It should be stressed that in 2015 marks the centenary of the Armenian genocide perpetrated under the Ottoman Empire and that an increasing number of Member States and national parliaments condemn heinous crimes against humanity, of which this genocide is an example. On this centenary, I would like to join in the just tribute paid by the European Parliament to the some 1.5 million innocent Armenians who lost their lives under the Ottoman Empire and condemn all cases of crimes against humanity and genocide that still exist in the 21st century. I am voting in favour of this report and I hope that both Armenia and Turkey will follow the examples of successful reconciliation between European nations and take an agenda that puts cooperation between peoples at the fore.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament takes advantage of the centenary of the Armenian massacre to recognise it as "genocide".  Already recognized as such by France, the resolution clearly calls into question the role of the Ottoman authorities of the time. Although the resolution calls on Turkey to recognise the Armenian genocide in order to open the door to reconciliation with Armenia, the reaction of the current Turkish President, who refuses to acknowledge the genocidal character, reflects how Turkey's accession to the European Union is a foolish goal, solely driven by the submission of the European authorities to the American desiderata.  I therefore voted in favour of this text, because I consider the recognition of the Armenian genocide necessary.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide in the Ottoman Empire.  The text pays tribute to the one and a half million Armenian victims who lost their lives between 1915 and 1917. He welcomed the statements of the highest Turkish authorities who expressed their condolences to the Ottoman Armenians and stressed that Turkey and Armenia had been engaged since 2009 in a process of normalizing their diplomatic relations.  Finally, it calls for a historic reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this resolution which is intended to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide perpetrated by the Ottoman authorities in 1915. Indeed, one of the EU's founding values is precisely the desire to prevent a repetition of wars and crimes against humanity in Europe. We welcome President Erdogan's recent statements on the recognition of atrocities committed against the Ottoman Armenians, considering them to be a first step in the right direction. We encourage Turkey to use the commemoration of this centenary as an opportunity to continue its efforts, to come to terms with its past and, therefore, to pave the way for true reconciliation between the two peoples. We are convinced that only an open and free debate in Turkish society on historical issues, including the Armenian genocide, can facilitate the process of democratisation that is already under way. A mature democracy cannot, in fact, be built on the basis of denial of historical facts and responsibilities. We therefore call for the negotiation process with the European Union to be used as an important catalyst for a more open and free debate on historical issues. We therefore call on the parties to normalise bilateral relations, without conditions, in order to improve their mutual understanding.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution calling on Armenia and Turkey to draw inspiration from examples of positive reconciliation, such as that which took place between European nations, through the ratification and application, without conditions, of the protocols on the establishment of diplomatic relations, the opening of borders and the improvement of relations, with particular reference to cross-border cooperation and economic integration.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 Events that took place 100 years ago and affected the Armenian population cannot be ignored. They are a historical fact and they are part of our history. In this context, together with partners in Turkey, the means must be found to honour the memory of the victims.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – The resolution commemorates the genocide of the Armenian people in The First World War and the memory of the victims. It encourages Turkey to use the upcoming 100th anniversary to process the past and urges it to allow unhindered access to the entire archive of what happened. The resolution is capable of drawing attention to the dangers of ethnic hatred and violence and promoting reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples, and I therefore support it.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution which recognises the genocide against the Armenian population that took place during the First World War in the Ottoman Empire and pays tribute to the victims.  The resolution also calls on the Turkish government to officially recognize this genocide in order to allow genuine reconciliation between peoples.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Every nation must find the strength to resurrect, overcome grievances and build life further. All people and nations in the world have the right to peace and dignity. It is therefore essential that all attention is paid to efforts to prevent and effectively punish genocide and crimes against humanity in a timely manner. This must become a global priority.  In addition, it is essential to preserve the living memory of the past and to pay due tribute to the memory of the one and a half million innocent Armenians who died in the Osman Empire. We are well aware of the long, honorable and rich history of the Armenian people. Unfortunately, in this history, like many other nations in history, there are also painful, just tragic periods that have claimed the lives of many people.  I support the proposal for a European Day of Genocide remembrance in Europe. This would be a prime example of the expression of solidarity among all of us, expressing respect for the memory of innocent victims of any genocide and all crimes against humanity.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that 2015 marks the centenary of the Armenian genocide, that the importance of keeping the memories of the past alive is essential as there can be no reconciliation without truth and I remember, for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Disrespect for human dignity and the deliberate killing of people is against human nature. Nevertheless, we have witnessed that throughout history there have been murders of people, and they still happen today. When ethnic cleansing and deliberate killing and destruction of a national, ethnic, racial or religious group is carried out, as happened in Vukovar, Srebrenica, Rwanda or as today happens to Christians around the world, then it is genocide.  Genocide also took place in 1915 against the Armenian people and historians agree with this statement. The nearly 1.5 million Armenians killed and 2 million displaced are a permanent reminder of the first genocide of modern times and I therefore supported this resolution. In addition to the deep condolences I offer to the families of the victims, I also expect Turkey to acknowledge that genocide against the Armenian people took place 100 years ago because it bears responsibility for such a terrible tragedy. While relations between Turkey and Armenia have improved in recent years, this is far from the desired situation.  Dealing with the past is an important step that can lead to reconciliation and cooperation, which Turkey should do given its aspiration to become an EU member.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. One hundred years after the events, it is time to acknowledge what has happened and to correctly name the horrific tragedy experienced by the Armenian people.  That is why I support this amendment to recognize the Armenian genocide and hope that all nations that have not yet done so will follow this path, especially those with the ambition to join the European Union.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution on the centenary of the Armenian genocide perpetrated by the Ottoman authorities in 1915, which put an end to the existence of the Armenian community that had historically lived in the south-east of the Ottoman Empire (now Turkey), pays tribute to the memory of the one and a half million innocent Armenian victims who were victims of atrocities during the First World War and encourages Turkey to recognise the Armenian genocide.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it of the utmost importance to condemn all forms of crimes against humanity and genocide, the timely prevention and effective punishment of which should be one of the fundamental priorities of the international community and the European Union. , also recognising the measures taken by the current Turkish Government to improve the treatment of the remaining Armenian minority.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I support this resolution, which stresses above all that the timely prevention and effective punishment of genocide and crimes against humanity should be priorities for the international community and the European Union. With this resolution, we call on both Turkey and Armenia to renew efforts to normalise their relations by ratifying protocols on establishing diplomatic relations and opening the border without preconditions, but also highlighting the social, human, cultural and economic benefits that normalising relations between Turkey and Armenia would bring to the Turkish and Armenian peoples, including the end of their mutual prejudices. Open and free debate in Turkish society on historical issues, including the Armenian genocide, is inseparably linked to the democratisation process because a healthy and mature democracy cannot be built on the basis of denial of historical facts and responsibilities.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒After the European People's Party adopted the Resolution on the 100th Anniversary of the Armenian Genocide as well as the Parliamentary Assembly of the Eastern Partnership EURONEST, I also supported the Resolution we accepted at the plenary session on 15 April 2015.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported this resolution because I consider it important that we send a clear message to Ankara that the Armenian genocide must be recognised. I believe that this report can be the trigger for the reconciliation process between Armenia and Turkey, which I consider to be really necessary. The border between Armenia and Turkey has been closed since the early 1990s. I would consider it an important gesture on the part of Turkey to open the border crossing just to mark the centenary of the tragic events that have left such a deep scar on relations between the two countries. I consider the fact that President Erdogan and Prime Minister Davutoğlu have expressed their condolences to the families of the victims and acknowledged the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians as a positive start to the efforts for genuine reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the process of diplomatic normalisation that Armenia and Turkey began a few years ago, I believe that it can be an important step towards the two countries moving towards a path of good relations and possible reconciliation. I hope that careful work will be done on the Armenian genocide, that the archives will be opened and that the tragic events of 100 years ago will be studied in a constructive spirit, even if the discomposed reaction of the Turkish Prime Minister, Ahmet Davutoglu, to the Pope's words does not bode well.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We wanted to adopt a resolution to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. I voted in favour of this text, which also sends a diplomatic message to Turkey.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The European Parliament joins the centenary commemoration of the Armenian genocide, commemorating the memory of the innocents who lost their lives in the tragic events perpetrated under the Ottoman Empire during the period 1915-1917.  This resolution also welcomes the statements of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan in expressing his condolences and recognising the atrocities perpetrated, and encouraging Turkey to use the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide as an opportunity to continue its efforts, paving the way for true reconciliation between the Turkish and Armenian peoples. Finally, it stresses that timely prevention and effective punishment of genocide and crimes against humanity should be among the main priorities of the international community and the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. On the eve of commemorative ceremonies, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the centenary of the Armenian Genocide, which I fully support.  After the Second World War, European nations came together for peace. It is in this logic of peace and international cooperation that we once again encourage Armenia and Turkey to reconcile. More broadly, we condemn all forms of genocide and propose to create an international day of remembrance of genocide. The Armenian genocide has been recognised by the European Parliament since 1987. In adopting this resolution, we pay tribute to the one and a half million Armenians who died in the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1917. This atrocity cannot remain a mere memory on this centenary vigil. The European Parliament will also participate in the commemoration of the centenary of the Armenian Genocide which will take place on 24 April in Armenia. We also welcome Turkey's recent positions. We now encourage it to fully acknowledge the Armenian genocide and fulfill its obligations regarding the protection of Armenian heritage. Today, we must constantly recall the atrocities that have struck our world so that future generations are fully aware of them.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. This is the first time that the European Parliament has put the issue of the Armenian Genocide, as such, on the agenda of its plenary and I am delighted. Relations between Armenia and Turkey have always been particularly tense. There is no formal diplomatic relations between the two states.  One of the reasons for this mutual enmity is the darkest episode in their shared history, the massacre of 1,500,000 Armenians by the Ottoman government between 1915 and 1923.  Today, although Turkey acknowledges "massacres", it still categorically denies responsibility for genocide.  The recent exchange on this issue between Pope Francis and President Erdogan shows how recognizing genocide, or even naming it, remains a taboo for the Turkish authorities. The step is important, we are all aware of it, it was also difficult for those in Europe who were on the wrong side of history between 1940 and 1945. It is essential, however, if Turkey is to join us.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a reconciliation with the past. In the States, as in men, assuming the past, even if terrible, will always be a sign of maturity and goodwill. Until that happens, the Armenian genocide will always be there, like a shadow over Europe.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recognition of the Armenian genocide that led to the death of hundreds of thousands of Armenian Christians during the First World War under the yoke of the rulers of the Ottoman regime.  Considering that historical truth has its rights, it seems to me right, undeniable and necessary to describe these massacres as genocide. So, on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the genocide, I hope that the Turkish authorities will hear what the European Union and the world tell them, look at history critically and finally deliver the same message.  The challenge is not to overwhelm those in power today, but to enable, in the light of the past, to build the future by paving the way for reconciliation. The Armenian people have the right to know their past, including through archives, and Turkey has a moral obligation to allow them access to it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is with sadness, but also with the deep conviction that these dates and the facts behind them have to be remembered and explained to the new generations, who join me in the evocation of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide through this resolution, which aims to pay tribute to the memory of the 1.5 million innocent Armenians who lost their lives a hundred years ago , victims of genocide and crimes against humanity, perpetrated in the then territory of the Ottoman Empire.  Because humanity (and especially the younger generations) can never forget what its darkest side is capable of, I consider it extremely important to create an International Day of The Memory of Genocides, so that the memory of the past may be kept alive and thus to stimulate mutual understanding and tolerance, reconciliation and the promotion of peace between peoples.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 After the statements of Pope Francis there was a clash on the Armenian question. In various quarters, one of the most tragic events in our history, the origin of the horrors of the twentieth century, is kept quiet or misrepresented, which is why I voted in favour of the EP resolution: to call things by their names and to learn from the mistakes of the past and to prevent such tragedies from happening again today.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. On the occasion of the centenary of the genocide perpetrated by the decaying Ottoman Empire, it commemorates the genocide and urges the Turkish government to advance its recognition. In the past few weeks, the Turkish government lamented the suffering caused to the Armenian population, and this is welcomed in the Resolution, even if they continue to resist classifying it as genocide. Although the Joint Resolution is incomplete and contains the usual hypocrisy about the EU's role as an international human rights defender, we consider its adoption to be positive for the historical demands of the Armenian people and for that reason we voted in favour.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The genocide suffered by the Armenian people took place just a hundred years ago deserves to be commemorated. It is important to honor your victims to remember that facts of this nature cannot be repeated. It is therefore necessary to emphasize the importance of the recognition of historical truth. The proposed resolution, in addition to being a commemoration, is important in terms of the future of relations between Armenia and Turkey. In this regard, even if Turkey does not yet recognise this genocide, Parliament welcomes the recognition of these atrocities by the President and prime minister of Turkey, pending the fact that this is only the first step towards the recognition of genocide and subsequent reconciliation between the two peoples. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the Joint Motion for a Resolution on Armenian Genocide. MEPs paid tribute, on the eve of the centenary, to the memory of the one-and-a-half million innocent Armenian victims who perished in the Ottoman Empire. Armenia and Turkey should use examples of successful reconciliation between European nations and focus on an agenda that puts cooperation between peoples first.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The year 2012 marks the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide that took place in the Ottoman Empire and ended the lives of a million and a half innocent Armenians. I support a growing number of Member States that recognise and condemn this genocide, as it represents one of the major crimes against humanity in Europe. And it is right that the Armenian genocide has also been publicly condemned by the European Parliament, expressing its support in the fight against human rights violations. It is important to remember and mark the difficult events of the past, because then we are made more awareness of the negative effects of such acts and, as a result, the effort to prevent something like this from happening in the future is increasing. We cannot and must not allow crime to recur on such a scale at any time in the future. For this reason, I also support the idea of 2010 in memory of the genocide, which is dedicated to commemorating the basic rights of all the peoples of the world, that is, life in peace and dignity. It is important to prevent and punish any acts that indicate genocide or human rights violations in a timely way. As I strongly condemn violence against humanity and the violation of human rights in any form, I voted in favour of it in the European Parliament.

name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide because I was bombarded by young Turks with a flood of elegantly pre-worded emails declaring that there had never been a genocide of the Armenians. Love outraged young Turks outside at the devices, of course it was a genocide; I am German and i am familiar with something like this.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Commemorating such tragic events is of particular importance at present precisely so that similar disasters will never happen again. It is our duty to speak out on the protection of fundamental human rights and, in particular, on the position of smaller nations, which are threatened by exemplary violations of rights by their larger neighbours. It is important that we commemorate this tragedy and pay tribute to the innocent Armenian victims.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the position of European commoners, and Pope Francis' stance on genocide against the Armenian people prompted by this resolution should help Turkey condemn the great tragedy of the past.  I believe that we in Parliament must no longer close our eyes to the crimes committed and committed around the world against Christians. Modern Europe respects all religions and religious commitments, including Islam, and I believe that Turkey as a state that has started negotiations for membership in the European Union, together with Croatia, must respect fundamental European values and principles if it wants to approach the Union and call the crimes of 1915 by its real name.  Only by jointly adjudicting and adequately qualifying crimes can we ensure that such misdeeds are no longer repeated because I fear that the systematic policy of ignoring such and similar crimes has led to Christians being undesirable and exiled in many areas today. That is why it is important to support this resolution in order to put an end to such practices.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on a European memorial service on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. I support the appointment of a European Memorial Day for genocide, which should be intended to further remind all peoples and peoples in the world of peace and dignity. I also join the commemoration ceremony on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide in the spirit of the European Brotherhood, solidarity and justice.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The recognition of the Armenian genocide by the Ottoman Empire is a necessary step both for the democratization of Turkey and for the improvement of the country's relations with Armenia. It is also very important that the resolution ing Turkey's actions to end the occupation of Cyprus, and to resolve the Kurdish problem, are a necessary step in order to stop the human rights of the peoples residing in those countries being violated. The resolution is a positive step and contributes to the achievement of the objective of recognising the Armenian genocide, but also to the objective of ending the occupation and colonization of our country. That is why we voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Recognition of the Armenian genocide and pressure on Turkey in this direction is entirely in agreement with us.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. While the European Parliament itself has already recognised the Armenian genocide as early as 1987, Europe is still divided on the issue and the European Commission has also not officially recognised the term genocide. But it is above all the attitude of the Turkish President, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, that is for him an obstacle to this recognition. This is not about attacking Turkey. He was not born, he was not the one who sent the troops and organized the massacres of Armenians and the systematic genocide, that is, a state crime - that is the definition of genocide.  On the other hand, it is he who today refuses to acknowledge the memory of this genocide, even though he has begun to express, with his Prime Minister, condolences, a gesture which I welcome. Other similar actions seem to me to be indispensable.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. On the occasion of the centenary of the genocide perpetrated by the decaying Ottoman Empire, it commemorates the genocide and urges the Turkish government to advance its recognition. In the past few weeks, the Turkish government lamented the suffering caused to the Armenian population, and this is welcomed in the Resolution, even if they continue to resist classifying it as genocide. Although the Joint Resolution is incomplete and contains the usual hypocrisy about the EU's role as an international human rights defender, we consider its adoption to be positive for the historical demands of the Armenian people and for that reason we voted in favour.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I am obviously in favour of the adoption of this text for natural reasons in a general international dramatic context for Christians.  The recognition of the Armenian genocide by the Turkish authorities today engaged in a real undertaking to destabilize Syria where every day Christians die under the bullets and blades of the terrorists they protect, is in my opinion a duty for every self-respecting Frenchman.  We must seize the opportunity to put pressure on the Turkish authorities to recognize the first genocide of the 20th century, a genocide that continues today by using the same processes and giving the same results.  The persecution, exodus and exile of Christians in this region is now taking on horrifying and dramatic proportions. In passing, I would like to welcome the statement of the pope who courageously called on the Turkish authorities to recognize the Armenian genocide.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's most important good remains the history from which those who are must learn, so as not to repeat the horrors of those who are no longer. 100 years ago, in the confusion generated by the fall of the Ottoman Empire, the people who paid were the Armenians. Genocide was the result of a mixture of nationalism, religious hatred, fear and cowardice. The memory of the hundreds of thousands of Armenians killed in 1915 must be accompanied by a good understanding of the lessons of history, because the same killer mixture also led to subsequent genocides in European history. Western Europe, Eastern Europe and Turkey must cooperate to leave generations coming with a well-researched and defended history of hubris, distortion and false patriotism.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. On the occasion of the centenary of the genocide perpetrated by the decaying Ottoman Empire, it commemorates the genocide and urges the Turkish government to advance its recognition. In the past few weeks, the Turkish government lamented the suffering caused to the Armenian population, and this is welcomed in the Resolution, even if they continue to resist classifying it as genocide. Although the Joint Resolution is incomplete and contains the usual hypocrisy about the EU's role as an international human rights defender, we consider its adoption to be positive for the historical demands of the Armenian people and for that reason we voted in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing.
