I voted in favour of the Resolution to commemorate the centenary of the deaths of one and a half million innocent Armenian victims, provoked by the Ottoman Empire in 1915, because the Socialists condemn all crimes against humanity.  The Resolution also recognizes the measures taken by the current Turkish government in improving the treatment of today's Armenian minority, in the context of a freer debate on the country's past.  Turkey and Armenia are called upon to ratify and implement the Zurich 2009 protocols, to take all necessary measures to normalize their bilateral relations without preconditions and to promote educational, academic and cultural exchanges in order to foster better mutual understanding. The Resolution welcomes the statements made by The President of Turkey, Tayyip Erdogan, offering his condolences and recognizing the atrocities against the Ottoman Armenians, and encourages Turkey to take advantage of this commemoration as an opportunity to continue its efforts to establish an objective version of what happened and thus move towards true reconciliation between the peoples of Turkey and Armenia.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The genocide suffered by the Armenian people took place just a hundred years ago deserves to be commemorated. It is important to honor your victims to remember that facts of this nature cannot be repeated. It is therefore necessary to emphasize the importance of the recognition of historical truth. The proposed resolution, in addition to being a commemoration, is important in terms of the future of relations between Armenia and Turkey. In this regard, even if Turkey does not yet recognise this genocide, Parliament welcomes the recognition of these atrocities by the President and prime minister of Turkey, pending the fact that this is only the first step towards the recognition of genocide and subsequent reconciliation between the two peoples. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. – Following debate within our political group, the ECR has not placed a whip on this resolution but left individual members to exercise a free vote. I voted against the resolution, not because I do not have great sympathy for the thousands that died through neglect and illness or were massacred during the upheavals in Turkey, in a state of war in 1915. The atrocities are fully acknowledged by the Turkish authorities who have consistently offered to open their archives for scrutiny by a joint commission of Turkish and Armenian scholars in order finally to resolve controversy. My objection is to the use of the highly contentious term "genocide" and a politically-motivated initiative, primarily designed to offend and provoke Turkey. At this time, we need Turkey to remain a good ally in NATO and in the fight against terrorism and jihadism. And we need to send messages of reconciliation. It is not helpful to incite further malice and to try and push Turkey away.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. In what is considered the first genocide of the 20th century, in the last years of the Ottoman Empire, between 1915 and 1923, nationalist organizations persecuted, arrested, deported and murdered hundreds of thousands of human beings. There are between 1 and 1.5 million deaths in a population of about 2 million people according to various estimates that are not always coincident. This example should serve as a warning not to lose sight of the present, with the emergence of nationalist and Nazi-fascist movements, which have been supported, in particular from the EU and the US. We stress that this case cannot serve to create divisions between the Armenian and Turkish peoples.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the Armenian genocide 100 years ago must be condemned in the strongest possible terms. In 1915, 1.5 million Armenians were systematically killed and 500,000 survivors were driven from their homes in the Ottoman Empire. This massacre is a crime against humanity.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. The debate on this resolution was essentially about two points of contention: firstly, is the systematic young Turkish action against the Armenian minority a genocide? Secondly, if this is a genocide, can we actually name it as such? First of all, to answer the second question: I call an egg an egg. I will therefore not refrain from calling genocide for diplomatic reasons. To address the first question: without going into the historical details, I think that from 1915 onwards, the events of 1915 could be classified as genocide. I would like to see an honest investigation, which will also provide a broad investigation of the Turkish people's crimes committed by their state.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU interventions in nation state matters should be very limited. With reference to the tragic chapter of history that occurred over a century ago between Ottoman Empire and Armenia, I consider the European Parliament’s interference both inappropriate and counterproductive. These issues must first be settled at a bilateral level, between the two sovereign nation states. Also the European Parliament is not entitled to make legal judgments of historical events. The word ‘genocide’ is, however, a legal judgement as it is a definition of crime, according to international law. But the European Parliament has no jurisdiction in international law. The European Parliament should curb its political activism and act appropriately. Therefore I do not support this resolution as a matter of principle.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today adopted a resolution acknowledging the genocide of the Armenians, paying tribute to its victims, proposing the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance and deploring any attempt at denial. A hundred years ago, the Armenian people suffered what is remembered as the first genocide of the twentieth century, in which one and a half million innocent people died, massacring and completely destroying this population.   As the Pope also stated, remembering the victims is necessary, indeed, necessary because where there is no memory it means that evil still keeps the wound open.  I believe that all Member States, in view of the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, must recognise this legally and I hope that today's vote will encourage the European institutions to contribute further to its recognition.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ Slovakia prides itself on being one of the countries that officially recognised the genocide of the Armenian Christian nation during 1915-1917, in which between 1.5 and 2 million people died. Crimes against humanity of this magnitude have no excuse in a modern and democratic society. I would like to offer my sincere condolences to all those who have lost their relatives and loved ones. I consider it a moral obligation to stand up for persecuted Christians around the world and to express our support and assistance to them. Unfortunately, history cannot be returned, but by working together and pointing out historical events, we can contribute to lessons to be learned from human error by future generations. It is an absolute priority for me to stand alongside the weaker, the sufferers and those who pull for the shorter end, and yet want to live a dignified and peaceful life in the circle of their loved ones, both internationally and in Slovakia.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the joint text of the resolution because memory and truth are invaluable values both in the lives of individuals and entire peoples. The future and trust between states cannot be built when historical facts are ignored and the suffering of the victims is ignored in a case as painful as the genocide per nation per nation. On the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide in the Ottoman Empire, which claimed the lives of 1.5 million people, we must once again call for this fact to be recognised, because it is still not indisputable for everyone. Without truth, it is difficult to forgive, and without forgiveness it is edgiving to speak of trust. The current tensions in relations between Turkey and Armenia undoubtedly have their origin in a different perception of the massacre of the Armenian people at the beginning of the 20th century. We Europeans have had to deal with similar problems many times. Accepting a common history in which some nations were tormentors and others victims. Where we were able to find an agreement, acknowledge mistakes without forgetting the lessons they came from, and start working together, we achieved great results. I wish our Armenian and Turkish friends the courage to come to terms with the difficult past and, in the spirit of historical truth, to build good neighbourly relations from scratch on the 100th anniversary of this unjustifiable massacre.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – It is fair to remember and honor all the peoples who have been victims of the horrors of Nazi-fascism. It is therefore right to pay tribute to the Roma people who are victims of the Nazi barbarism of World War II, an act committed by a regime founded on fascism and the worst of its expressions, Nazism, a racist, xenophobic and terrorist dictatorship in the service of the great German capital that has pushed almost the whole of Europe into a war in which more than 60 million people died , many of them murdered in concentration camps.  A tribute as important as today's resurgence of racist, xenophobic and fascist phenomena and movements that attack the rights of migrants, minorities and various peoples, including the Roma people and when the EU's dominant ideology whitens fascism and carries out ideological campaigns of historical revisionism aimed at equating the Nazi beast to those who , like the Communists and other democrats and patriots, fought against it, from here to rehabilitate and support coup forces, fascists and neo-Nazis, of which the example of Ukraine is perhaps the most dangerous.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. In my joint motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, I voted because it is of the utmost importance to preserve the memory of the past, and because there is no reconciliation without truth and memory. The European Parliament has already acknowledged in its resolution of 18 June 1987 that the tragic events against the Armenians of 1915-1917 on the territory of the Ottoman Empire are genocide as defined by the 1948 Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. One of the main reasons for European integration is the desire to prevent wars and crimes against humanity in Europe. Timely prevention and effective punishment of genocides and crimes against humanity must be one of the main priorities of the international community and of the European Union.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – I voted in favour of this resolution because the Roma genocide – like no other – cannot be forgotten. Not just as a reminder of terrible events, but as an incentive to work for the benefit of this community. The Roma MEP in Slovakia, Peter Polák, the Government Plenipotentiary for the Roma Community, proposes for the Roma for genocide the designation 'porajmos', which means 'ingeration' in Roma and expresses the perception of the Roma themselves on the matter. More than 400,000 Roma live in Slovakia. We face the issue of Roma integration into society on a daily basis. One of the main causes of failure is the lack of knowledge about the Roma community and non-systemic social solutions that do not have the necessary effects. It is therefore time for the solutions for these communities to be proposed together by the Roma themselves and for the Institutions of the European Union to involve the Roma in the development of the necessary policies. If the Roma are not invited to participate in these decisions, we will once again spend the financial resources without effect.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, in 2011 the European Parliament took a historic decision and recognised the genocide of the Roma murdered by the Nazi regime and its collaborators because they were considered racially inferior. Seventy years have come since the Roma were dragged by the thousands to the crematoriums of the Nazi camps, Auschwitz, Dachau, Belsen, Mouthausen, where thousands of Greek patriots were also murdered. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution condemning the Genocide of the Roma by the Nazis, because I believe that this honours the memory of thousands of Roma who were murdered en masse by the Nazis, while sending a decisive message to all sorts of nazism nostalgics.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, we abstained from the vote because we did not know how to vote, because in Poland, and I think in Europe, there is no anti-Gypsy feeling. Gypsies are regarded as jolly fellows travelling in their carts, singing, dancing, playing violins and so on. The problem is with the so-called Roma, who are living in dirty flats, demanding more and more money from social security. It is a problem of how to regard the declarations. One is using the word ‘Roma’, and one is using the word ‘gypsy’.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution calling for the establishment of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day, remembering the genocide of the Roma people in Nazi concentration camps on the anniversary of the murder of 2,789 Roma people in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in a single night, in a roma and gypsy camp known as Zigeunerlager in which 23,000 people were imprisoned , of the 20,000 were killed by fascism. So far, the Roma people have been treated as a secondary victim of fascism despite the extermination suffered, and this Resolution seeks to end this historical injustice. The Resolution refers not only to this particular period, but to the historical discrimination that this people has suffered to this day, on which we hope that the Resolution can shed light. We would have liked it to also be accompanied by specific measures to address the situation of a people with high unemployment and marginalization rates through the European Union as a whole, but we agree because of the symbolic value it has and the support it brings from the Roma social fabric.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that at least 500,000 Roma were exterminated during World War II by the Nazis and their allies. For this reason, the European Parliament calls in its resolution for the recognition of the Roma genocide during The Second World War and, for the establishment of a European Roma Holocaust Remembrance Day, an act which would be an important symbolic step in preserving historical memory and would make an important contribution to tackling anti-Gypsyism.  That is why I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Although this proposal provides for the commemoration of the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War, which, in proportion to their number, were the first victims of Nazi policies, the proposal is unclear with regard to the definition of "Rom". The term includes all traveller communities, including "national" communities.  Moreover, this issue seems to be a pretext for ever more interference on the part of the Commission in the social policy of the Member States. It gives the Commission the right to monitor, assess and remedy any systemic violation of the fight against 'anti-Gypsyism' which it would report in Member States policy. Moreover, the issue of Roma integration seems more complex than it is developed in this proposal, which never evokes the attitude of the communities themselves. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – Although I very much support the principle of opposition to discrimination, I am advised that some of the language in this report is overly strong and should not be supported. I therefore voted in favour of the two amendments, and abstained on the final vote.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  Moreover, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of the European Day for the Commemoration of the Gypsy Holocaust is essential to recognising the place in our common history for this people.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to recognise the genocide of the Roma during World War II in Europe. There are around 10-12 million people in Europe. roma and they are the largest ethnic minority in Europe. The Nazi regime and other regimes destroyed at least 500 000 Roma during the second world war, and in some countries more than 80% of the Roma community was destroyed. The resolution publicly acknowledges the historical fact of the Genocide of the Roma during World War II. Europe Day should be dedicated to the victims of the Roma genocide during World War II, and I agree that this day should be called European Roma Holocaust Remembrance Day.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I refused to support this resolution, which, under the pretext of combating discrimination, makes a dangerous amalgamation by claiming that the term "Rom" brings together all the communities of travellers, including gypsies, gypsies, and other Sintis, even when they have been sedentary and integrated for a long time.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Unfortunately, the issue of Roma integration in the European Union is still relevant today.  Discrimination against the EU's first ethnic minority is unjustifiable. They need to stop as soon as possible. Moreover, after being a victim of slavery for centuries, the Roma had to endure the violence of the Nazi regime during the Second World War. However, this part of history is too often overlooked.  It is for these reasons and in the name of equality, human rights and the values of the Socialist Group that I voted in favour of this text.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution because it is necessary to take a stronger position in the face of the worrying rise of anti-itanism, which is accompanied by acts of violence, implementing Framework Decision 2008/ 913 to combat certain forms of racism and xenophobia. Its situation requires more active policies on the part of Member States, with plans and strategies at regional and local national level in which children are a priority and the special situation of discrimination against women is take into account, thereby complying with the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies.  I voted against my group's position on Amendments Nos 1 and 2, which sought to remove the reference to the Holocaust; I voted in favour of recital N and paragraph 14 of the Resolution on the Gypsy Holocaust. This is why it was defined by the United Nations when they declared 27 January, the day of the liberation of the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp as "International Holocaust Memorial Day".

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This resolution calls for more efforts to end discrimination against Roma and to recognize 2 August as a day of remembrance of the Holocaust of the Roma during the Second World War.  However, this text justifies the specific affirmative actions for Roma.  Moreover, this should not overshadow the problems of integration of the Roma populations. Public policies for Roma integration bear witness to this: their effectiveness is close to zero. The EUR 50 billion put on the table between 2007 and 2013 was, in most cases, very little used, showing the lack of interest of national authorities such as Romania in their sustainable integration.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support the resolution being voted on.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  Moreover, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of the European Day for the Commemoration of the Gypsy Holocaust is essential to recognising the place in our common history for this people.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it seeks to mark the International Roma Day and to draw attention to the hostility towards the Roma and the resulting racial hatred and discrimination in our societies. This resolution also seeks to recognise the Roma genocide during World War II as a Memorial Day in Europe, because, although, according to various figures, the Nazi regime and other regimes and their allies destroyed at least 500 000 Roma during the second world war, the public is still unaware of the genocide of the Nazi regime and other regimes and their allies during the second world war, and the vast majority of the public do not yet recognise it.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The Roma are one of the largest ethnic groups in Europe, representing their home for centuries, and there is practically no country where they are not inhabited. However, despite their long-term stay in Europe, the Roma are unfortunately everywhere being pushed to the edge of society. They are discriminated against, and the majority population often does not give them equal rights and equal treatment. The Roma problem is multifaceted and, in my opinion, it cannot be tackled from top to bottom. Yes, there are needs to be goals and a direction for achieving equality, but problems must be solved where they arise - in the local communities where the Roma are inhabited. Through a tolerant dialogue and a smart approach, the integration of roma into society can be achieved, human dignity is created, and discrimination against the Roma population can be reduced. I know from my own experience that this is a time-consuming and difficult process, but with the right approach it is feasible. I support the proposed resolution, which calls, among other things, for the recognition of the genocide against the Roma during World War II. At the same time, I am calling on the Member States to tackle the Roma problem with the utm highest adherence to the principle of subsidiarity. Countries must provide support to municipalities in dealing with such problems and conduct a tolerant dialogue with all stakeholders. Only in this way will it be possible to ensure the long-term involvement of Roma in society and to reduce their discrimination.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. Half a million Roma were killed during World War II. In some countries, their number decreased by 80%. The resolution calls for the recognition of the Genocide of the Roma in World War II and the commemoration of Remembrance Day at the European level. I support the text of the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on International Roma Day.  I regret his approximations and lack of precision, particularly semantics, in his explanatory statement. Thus, the text, in recital B, includes "Roms" as a "generic term that refers to several related groups in Europe, sedentary or not". While this word corresponds, strictly speaking, to a population present, in particular, in Central and Eastern Europe. I cannot support such a "victimizing" resolution which carefully fails to call into question the attitude of the communities concerned.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the occasion of the International Roma day – anti-Gypsyism in Europe and EU recognition of the memorial day of the Roma genocide during WWII, since I maintain that the discrimination against the Roma ethnic group, both past and present, is unacceptable and we should treat them with the respect that they deserve.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution combines the fight against "anti-Gypsyism" and the recognition of a day specifically dedicated to the genocide of the Roma community during the Second World War.  In addition, the text equates all the communities of travellers with the term "Rom". They'll appreciate it. Moreover, by never seeking the responsibility of the Roma community in its refusal to integrate into the countries in which it resides, this motion for a resolution is disconnected from reality and pours into the most excessive dogmatism. That is why I abstained on the vote of this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's largest ethnic minority, the Roma community, has been an integral part of European culture and heritage for centuries. Whether they are migrants or steadfast, Roma are sometimes exposed to a strong stream of discrimination and stigma. I believe that we must continue to work towards improving this situation.  The social inclusion of the Roma involves initiatives to bring this community closer to European values and to highlight the potential of Roma society and the qualities that their representatives possess.  I believe that funding lines through the European Social Fund providing for social inclusion should contain better outlined programmes with a view to developing the skills of representatives of the Roma community. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution because I believe that racist attitudes or social discrimination have no place in European society. The fact that the EU holds the Nobel Peace Prize reinforces my belief that democracy, tolerance, reconciliation and human rights are essential values that underpin our society.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The resolution seeks to recognise the discrimination that Roma have been suffering since the 14th century and calls for the historical recognition of the Roma genocide during World War 2 (WW2). It is vital that collectively we must unite to eliminate all forms of human rights violations from society.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst Roma have been historically part of society in many European countries, and they are part of Europe’s culture and values, a special kind of racism is directed towards them, anti-Gypsyism. This is one of the main causes of the discrimination and marginalisation that the Roma people have suffered historically in many European states.  The genocide of Roma by the Nazi and other regimes and their allies during World War II is still largely ignored and not acknowledged by the public. I believe that this recognition will provide an important symbolic step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism and contribute to the general knowledge of Roma history in Europe.  In fact, I voted in favour of this resolution as I agree that these elements should be highlighted on the occasion of the International Roma Day and the need to condemn all forms of racism and discrimination faced by the Roma.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the commemoration of crimes against humanity and serious violations of human rights is essential to promote the causes of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe. At least half a million Roma were exterminated by the third reich regime and its allies during World War II. This resolution aims only to call on the Member States to officially recognise this genocide and to call for a European day to commemorate the victims of the Roma genocide during the Second World War.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I abstained on this motion for a resolution which, under the pretext of recognising genocide, interferes in the legislative and criminal process of the Member States and threatens to punish sovereign nations if they do not submit to the views of the European Union on this issue which, as a historical fact, is a matter of debate by historians. Moreover, while there is no question of questioning the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War, the motion for a resolution in question was too vague: recognising the diversity of those covered by the name "Roms", the text nevertheless wishes to give a uniform and unilateral reading of these tragic events. It cannot therefore be called for a "European Day dedicated to the commemoration of the victims of the Genocide of the Roma" even though it is accepted that this name covers different communities.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today, some small but highly symbolic steps have been taken towards achieving recognition of the plight of ethnic minorities in the European Union, starting from the recognition of the Roma genocide in World War II. It is estimated that 500 000 Roma were murdered and in some countries more than 80% of the Roma population was exterminated. Today, we officially acknowledge the Roma genocide which took place during the Second World War. Anti-Gypsyism is very much alive today, and the discrimination it entails must not be ignored.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 Roma, estimated at around 10-12 million people, make up the largest ethnic minority in Europe. Although they do not have a reference state entity, the Roma contribute to Europe as citizens and are often the subject of anti-Gypsyism, which is considered to be a form of racism. During the Second World War, some 500 000 roma people died at the hands of the Nazis.  Europe considers that the commemoration of crimes against humanity and violations of human rights is essential in order to promote peace. It is therefore considered necessary to combat all forms of anti-Gypsyism, as xenophobic, and to commemorate the Roma victims of the Second World War. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, as the Roma, who make up the largest ethnic minority in Europe, have different characteristics from other European minorities, which justifies the adoption of specific measures at European level. It is important to remember, over and above populism, that during the Second World War 500 000 Roma were exterminated by the Nazis. The recognition and commemoration of what this population has suffered is a first symbolic step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism. Discrimination against Roma, by which I mean people from different but similar groups, located throughout Europe, bearers of different cultures and lifestyles, is incompatible with the values and principles of the European Union and is an obstacle on the road to their integration. My intention, in voting, was to show that we are willing to open our arms to those who want to contribute to the advancement of our society, respecting its rules and participating in the forms and ways that best reconcile our laws and their customs and customs.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the establishment of The Day commemorating the Genocide of the Roma during the Second World War. Even today, anti-Gypsyism is one of the main causes of discrimination and marginalisation, especially against women, who are exposed to multiple and cross-sectoral discrimination, mainly because of their ethnic origin. I believe that every European citizen must have the right to participate fully in the development of society and to have equal access to education, employment, health care and housing. It is therefore necessary for all Member States to adopt a comprehensive approach to integration and the fight against all forms of discrimination, in order to ensure compliance with and respect for the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – This resolution expresses its deep concern at the rise of anti-Gypsyism, condemns all forms of racism and discrimination faced by the Roma, calls for the promotion of equal rights for Roma children, stresses the need to ensure that specific measures for women’s rights and gender mainstreaming are included in the National Roma Integration Strategies (NRIS), calls for the recognition of the genocide of Roma that took place during World War II and calls for a European day dedicated to commemorating the victims. I have thus voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution calling for the establishment of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day, remembering the genocide of the Roma people in Nazi concentration camps on the anniversary of the murder of 2,789 Roma people in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in a single night, in a roma and gypsy camp known as Zigeunerlager in which 23,000 people were imprisoned , of the 20,000 were killed by fascism. So far, the Roma people have been treated as a secondary victim of fascism despite the extermination suffered, and this Resolution seeks to end this historical injustice. The Resolution refers not only to this particular period, but to the historical discrimination that this people has suffered to this day, on which we hope that the Resolution can shed light. We would have liked it to also be accompanied by specific measures to address the situation of a people with high unemployment and marginalization rates through the European Union as a whole, but we agree because of the symbolic value it has and the support it brings from the Roma social fabric.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the resolution marks a fundamental and non-derogatory principle of civilian living in Europe that also excludes the same specific case: the protection of people regardless of race and ethnic origin, eliminating all discrimination. In the case of Roma minorities, creating fictitious 'good/evil' Manichean divisions, with racial, cultural or living conditions as the sole point of view, is little less than very low-profile political speculation, contrary to the basic principles of the Founding Charter of the Union. The policy of "nomadic camps" has fuelled housing hardship until it became a prerequisite and cause of spatial marginality and social exclusion. Naples, but not only, is an example of a city in which, thanks to European support, action must be taken to redevelop the existence and dignity of dozens of human beings. We must overcome the model and system of nomadic camps. Schools are also the main instrument of positive discrimination for children and adolescents, which is why it is a decisive factor in emancipation. The new European Social Fund can provide important economic support in these areas, and we call on the Commission to ensure that the regions implement integration plans and respect the targets and objectives set.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – This resolution requests further efforts to put an end to discrimination, hate crime and hate speech against Roma people and call on the EU to recoginse 2 August as the Roma Genocide Remembrance Day. I believe that all citizens should abide by the rules set by the society they live in and contribute to their communities. By voting in favour of this resolution I wanted to pass on a clear message against discrimination and that the wrongs of the past that the Roma people had to endure should never happen again.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Discrimination, poverty, social exclusion, lack of education and access to basic healthcare are just a few problems that the Roma community faces and that we must continue to fight for. I believe that the Member States and the Commission must prioritise the implementation of the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies, and I believe that it is important to promote equal access to housing, healthcare, education and sustainable living conditions for all Roma citizens.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. As the fight against discrimination has always been at the heart of my political struggle, I wished to support this text. As far as the Roma population is concerned, the European Union has a real role to play in combating anti-Gypsyism, which is still present in too many Member States. This resolution aims to recognise the genocide of this population during the Second World War, by proclaiming a "European Day of Commemoration of the Genocide of the Roma". Memory work is important to change attitudes about this ethnic minority. In this resolution, I have paid particular attention to the double discrimination experienced by Roma women, whose difficulties in finding employment are tenfold.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to put an end to discrimination, hate crimes and hate speech against roma and to call for it to be recognised on 2 August as Roma Holocaust Remembrance Day, to commemorate its genocide during the Second World War. Any form of discrimination against the individual must be condemned by the EU as incompatible with EU rules and principles and an obstacle to full social integration.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I consider it particularly important to acknowledge the Roma Holocaust more widely in Europe. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma Holocaust, the European Parliament's resolution states its recognition at EU level. International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust (2 August) Official Memorial Day in Hungary. The European Union has begun to carry out the tasks before it. Hungary adopted a European Roma strategy during the EU Presidency of the European Union in 2011. Its main objective is to promote the social inclusion of roma and to reduce anti-Gypsyism. This is an important challenge in today's European policy and one of the most promising opportunities for Europe.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution on international Roma Day – anti-Gypsyism in Europe and EU recognition of the commemorative day of the genocide of the Roma during The Second World War, as I believe that it lacks important points of importance for the current situation in Europe. I do not believe that the notorious "Roma integration" happened anywhere in Europe. On the contrary, there are a number of examples of exactly how Western European countries do not apply it. Furthermore, there is a lot of evidence of outright abuses in the financing of "Roma integration". There is a frank double standard between the official documents to be adopted between the programmes being set up and the behaviour of a number of Member States. I also believe that tying International Roma Day to the so-called "Roma Day" will be a good thing. anti-Gypsyism is at least a manifestation of a poor compilation between two issues that, in their genesis, do not have much in common. I stress that our efforts should focus not on the creation of artificial standards and privileges based on origin, such as the spirit of the resolution in question, but on practical solutions with measurable results. The truth is that integration in this kind, which is preached, will not and will not be. For so many years of integration, the current approach has proved completely untenable.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because I believe that the existing legislation does not need to be supplemented.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aimed at the recognition by the European Union of the day of memory of the Roma genocide during World War II.  There are between 10 and 12 million Roma people living in Europe, with roma people being the largest ethnic minority on the continent.  This contingent has suffered, throughout history, a strong discrimination, culminating in one of the most significant systematic persecutions ever carried out in Europe, the persecution that occurred during World War II by the weight of Nazi racial ideology, leading hundreds of thousands of Roma to concentration camps, exposing this minority to aggressive forms of violence, exploitation, genocide (500,000 dead) and general stigmatisation of them , something that endures to this day. This is the only way to explain the degree of social exclusion and poverty in which many Roma live, oblivious to their importance in building the culture and history of the European people. To that end, the European Parliament and I voted in favour of the recognition of the UN initiative to mark 27 January as the European Day of Remembrance for the Gypsy Holocaust, celebrating the day of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau by allied troops in 1945.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Roma, with an estimated population of 10 to 12 million, are europe's largest ethnic minority and many of them still live in extraordinarily precarious conditions and face extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination. Women are often exposed to multiple and intersectoral discrimination on gender and ethnic reasons and have limited access to employment, education, health, social services and reduced decision-making capacity. According to estimates, at least 500 000 Roma were exterminated by the Nazis and other regimes and their allies during World War II, and that in some countries more than 80 % of the Roma population was wiped out. I therefore agree that discrimination and marginalisation are essentially the result of society at large not recognising the rights of individuals and that there are no necessary structures to enable individuals to invoke those rights. Member States should effectively implement the Directive determining the principle of equal treatment between persons, regardless of racial or ethnic origin, in order to prevent and eliminate discrimination against Roma, in particular in employment, education and access to housing.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is fair to remember and honor all the Gypsies killed during the Nazi barbarism of World War II, an act committed by a regime founded on fascism and the worst of its expressions, Nazism, a racist, xenophobic and terrorist dictatorship, in the service of the great German capital, which pushed almost all of Europe into a war in which more than 50 million people died , many of them murdered in concentration camps. We cannot, however, in this circumstance, fail to regret and denounce the historical revisionism that tends to conceal and misrepresent the role of communists in World War II. Murdered by the Nazi regime, men and women who from the first hour bravely confronted the regime by paying with their own lives 2012, organized the resistance and fought each other until the expulsion and defeat of the invaders, making an indispensable, central and indispensable contribution to liberation and victory.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution because these kinds of proposals are initiatives made for political purposes only, used instrumentally and do not take into account the priorities that Europe has at the moment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on "International Roma Day - anti-Gypsyism in Europe and EU recognition of the day dedicated to the memory of the Roma genocide during the Second World War", because I do not consider it necessary to defend Roma rights.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to congratulate Mr Damian Drăghici on the report on International Roma Day – anti-Gypsy attitudes in Europe and the EU's recognition of the Day of Commemoration of the Genocide against Roma in the Second World War.  As presented in the report, the Roma genocide deserves full recognition, commensurate with the seriousness of the crimes of the Nazi regime and other regimes that set out to physically eliminate the Roma, as well as other target groups in Europe. During the Second World War, at least 500 000 Roma were exterminated, with more than 80% of the Roma population being exterminated in some countries, which is largely still ignored, which is why it is unknown to the general public. Commemoration of crimes against humanity and extremely serious violations of human rights is essential for supporting the causes of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I consider it particularly important to acknowledge the Roma Holocaust more widely in Europe. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma genocide, the European Parliament's decision states its recognition at EU level. International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust, 2 August, official Day of Remembrance in Hungary. The European Union has begun to carry out the tasks before it. Hungary adopted the European Roma Strategy during the EU Presidency in 2011. Its main objective is to promote the social inclusion of roma and to reduce anti-Gypsyism. This is an important challenge in today's European policy and a serious opportunity for Europe.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution commending the Roma Holocaust during The Second World War by the European Parliament. In Hungary, the International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust on 2 August is already an official day of remembrance. To this day, few people know about the Roma Holocaust, Porrajmos, despite the fact that it claimed the lives of 500,000 Roma and Sysans. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma Holocaust, with today's decision, the European Parliament declares its recognition at EU level.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 The Roma people, representing between 10 and 12 million people in Europe, have been a people discriminated against for centuries in Europe, by an anti-itanism that has manifested itself in acts of violence, exploitation and stigmatization. A sign of the terrible stigmatization of this group is that, by estimates, at least 500,000 Roma were exterminated during World War II by Nazism and other allied regimes. Therefore, we must recognize the historical fact of the genocide of the Roma people that took place during World War II. It is imperative that Member States effectively implement Directive 2000/43/EC on the application of the principle of equal treatment of persons regardless of racial or ethnic origin, in order to prevent and end discrimination against the Roma community, in particular in employment, education and access to housing, as well as to actively combat manifestations of racism and xenophobia.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the resolution because it highlights the pressing problem of intolerance, social exclusion and discrimination against Roma in Europe. Effective political action must be taken to combat this racism and to ensure equal treatment of Roma and respect for their fundamental rights, including the right to access education, employment, healthcare and housing. The Roma form part of European culture and share our common values, and therefore the tragic history of this nation must be taken up, in particular the subject of the Nazi genocide and other forms of persecution of the Roma, such as the deportation and internment that took place during the Second World War. This is still a little-known fact and is therefore not widely recognised by European society. And it must be remembered that 500,000 representatives of this nation were victims of this war. The fact of the genocide of the Roma in Europe during the Second World War must therefore be fully recognised. This would represent an important symbolic step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism and at the same time contribute to the spread of knowledge about Roma history in Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I supported the resolution adopted on the occasion of International Roma Day because I find it deeply disturbing that, 70 years after they suffered unspeakable atrocities under the Holocaust, the Roma people are still suffering from human rights violations as well as social and economic exclusion.  Extreme right and nationalistic parties are rearing their heads in the EU, and it is a disgrace that politicians from a right-wing UK party have made suggestions to the effect that contact with members from the local Roma Slovak community is detrimental to the wellbeing of other British citizens.  It is a dangerous path to tread. It means we have not learned the lessons from the Holocaust and are excluding the youngest and fastest-growing demographic group of our population from our common agenda for developing a prosperous and secure Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, the importance of which has to do with the historic moment we are going through, when anti-Itanism and other forms of racism find their place in Europe. We understand that the recognition of gypsy genocide, as occurred during World War II, is essential to keeping alive a story that prevents the same mistakes of the past from being made in the future. We have therefore voted in favour of writing a story with the words it deserves.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the occasion of International Roma Day – anti Gypsyism in Europe and EU recognition of the memorial day of the Roma genocide during World War II. I am deeply concerned by the rise of anti-Gypsyism manifested through violent attacks against Roma in Europe. Anti-Gypsyism constitutes a major obstacle to the successful social integration of Roma and to ensuring full respect for their human rights. I believe the European Parliament plays a key role in calling on the Commission to develop a European Roma Strategy.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am convinced that only by learning from history mistakes and educating the public about crimes against humanity can we ensure the implementation of the values of the European Union. The resolution recognises the genocide of the Roma during World War II in Europe, which most of the public does not know about and therefore does not recognise. This must be taken into account when initiating national and international legislation. By learning from history, we need to do more in our Member States, in particular by working with Roma communities and educational organisations to change the xenophobic and discriminatory attitudes towards people of this nationality, and to increase social integration.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I consider it particularly important to acknowledge the Roma Holocaust as widely as possible in Europe. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma Holocaust, the European Parliament's resolution states its recognition at EU level. International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust (2 August) Official Memorial Day in Hungary. The European Union has begun to carry out the tasks before it. Hungary adopted a European Roma strategy during the EU Presidency of the European Union in 2011. Its main objective is to promote the social inclusion of roma and to reduce anti-Gypsyism. Achieving this is one of the major challenges of today's European policy and one of the most promising opportunities for Europe.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as I would like to recognise and commemorate the genocide of Roma during World War II. This Memorial Day is paramount for providing Roma people with restitution where appropriate for the atrocities committed against them by the Nazi and other regimes and their allies during WW II. We need to take responsibility for our failure as a society to stand up to this discrimination and recognise the rights of these individuals. It is time to provide the necessary structures for individuals to invoke their rights and ensure that specific measures for women’s rights and gender mainstreaming are included in the National Roma Integration Strategies (NRIS). It is time to call on the Commission to consider children a priority when implementing the EU framework for National Roma Strategies and it is time for Member States to effectively implement the Council Directive 200/43/EC that reinforces the principle of equal treatment between persons, irrespective of racial or ethnic origin, in order to prevent and eliminate discrimination against Roma, in particular in employment, education and access to housing.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I consider it particularly important to acknowledge the Roma Holocaust more widely in Europe. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma Holocaust, the European Parliament's resolution states its recognition at EU level. International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust (2 August) Official Memorial Day in Hungary. The European Union has begun to carry out the tasks before it. Hungary adopted a European Roma strategy during the EU Presidency of the European Union in 2011. Its main objective is to promote the social inclusion of roma and to reduce anti-Gypsyism. This is an important challenge in today's European policy and one of the most promising opportunities for Europe.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. On Wednesday 15 April, Parliament voted in favour of the resolution calling for the EU's recognition of the Roma genocide during the Second World War and the establishment of a day of remembrance on 2 August. This tragedy, which claimed more than 500,000 lives, led to the extermination of nearly 80% of the Roma population. The resolution considers that the Roma genocide is still unknown and regrets that it is not taught in schools. It considers that this official recognition is essential to combat anti-Gypsyism and all forms of discrimination against the Roma population. As a result, Member States are encouraged to implement the Equal Treatment Directive, to take better account of the situation of women and children in national Roma integration strategies and to condemn hate speech more strongly. Let's make no mistake about the debate. It is not a question of denouncing the actions or inactions of the Member States, but of recognising a historical fact and paying tribute to the victims of the atrocities committed during the Second World War.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion.  The Roma originate from Northern India but there are estimated to be around 10 million living in Europe, making them the continent’s largest ethnic minority group. In their history the Roma have faced persecution, most notably the genocide during World War II.   I support the text in this resolution that addresses the discrimination and marginalisation that the Roma people have suffered historically in many European countries, and notes that that many Roma live today in overwhelmingly poor conditions and face extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination. Celebrations to mark International Roma Day were held in Glasgow this year involving the city’s Roma residents and the wider community.  It pleases me that the Scottish Government is advancing the idea of One Scotland – a nation that empowers its communities and meets the hopes and aspirations of all its people, and that continues on a path towards a vibrant, diverse multi-cultural society based on mutual trust, understanding and respect.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, the importance of which has to do with the historic moment we are going through, when anti-Itanism and other forms of racism find their place in Europe. We understand that the recognition of gypsy genocide, as occurred during World War II, is essential to keeping alive a story that prevents the same mistakes of the past from being made in the future. We have therefore voted in favour of writing a story with the words it deserves.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this Motion for a Resolution because we must denounce the xenophobic policies that are so often against the Roma people, and reject the persecution that has suffered at many stages in history.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Resolution on International Roma Day - anti-Roma sentiment in Europe and recognition, in the EU, of the Day of Remembrance of the Genocide against Roma in World War II, because it is essential to put an end to discrimination, prejudice and intolerance of all kinds.  For many years, as istrian prefect, but still today, I am constantly committed to promoting and strengthening the integration of the Roma community. Istria County is an excellent example of efficient and effective integration through economic, social, educational and other activities that contribute to synergy and mutual understanding and appreciation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this motion for a resolution to establish an International Roma Day and to commemorate the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War.  Indeed, this proposal highlights the Roma populations, thus omitting all other communities of travellers who have suffered Nazi crimes, especially so-called national communities such as Gypsies or Gypsies.  This type of amalgamation is intolerable in a motion for a resolution. Finally, this proposal defends a new form of interference by the Commission as it serves as a pretext to intervene in the social policy of the Member States by arrogating the right to assess and remedy the deviations in the fight against 'anti-Gypsyism'.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which officially recognises the historic fact of the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War and calls for the creation of a European Day of Remembrance of this genocide. Recognition of genocide and war crimes is essential for peace, reconciliation and democracy in Europe. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported this resolution calling for the recognition and commemoration of the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War. The recognition of this genocide, which has claimed more than 500,000 lives, and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance is an important symbolic step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism and contributes to a better knowledge of the history of Roma in Europe.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am concerned about the gypsyphobia that is manifesting itself against the Roma, this special form of racism based on an "idea" of racial superiority, which is a form of inhuman treatment and is among the main causes of discrimination and marginalisation that have historically suffered in many European countries. The consequence of all this is that many Roma continue to live in extremely poor conditions and experience extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination.; the pursuit of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe and therefore the Roma genocide in Europe must be fully recognised, corresponding to the seriousness of the crimes committed by both the Nazis and other regimes. I believe that a European day should be devoted to the memory of the victims of the Roma genocide during the Second World War and I propose that this be called the European Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the resolution. It breaks the silence around the Roma victims of the Nazi regime and it gives Roma the place in our common history that they have been denied for so long. The recognition of the Roma Holocaust and the establishment of a memorial day for its victims are crucial for the fight against anti-Gypsyism in Europe. Roma people are still victims of racist and violent attacks. Only a continued and open dialogue between Roma and non-Roma stakeholders and the European institutions will help overcome our prejudices, constant discrimination and segregation. The Commission should monitor the respect of EU citizens’ fundamental values and respond to any systemic breaches which may occur.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I consider it particularly important to acknowledge the Roma Holocaust more widely in Europe. While not all Member States have yet formally recognised the Roma Holocaust, the European Parliament's resolution states its recognition at EU level. International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust (2 August) Official Memorial Day in Hungary. The European Union has begun to carry out the tasks before it. Hungary adopted a European Roma strategy during the EU Presidency of the European Union in 2011. Its main objective is to promote the social inclusion of roma and to reduce anti-Gypsyism. This is an important challenge in today's European policy and one of the most promising opportunities for Europe.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 'Resolution on the occasion of International Roma Day – anti-Gypsyism in Europe and the EU's recognition of the Day of Remembrance of the Roma Genocide during The Second World War' because of its symbolic importance in combating the marginalisation of the Roma community in Europe. The Roma are the largest – with 10-12 million – and at the same time the most discriminated ethnic minority in Europe, which is why countering anti-gypsyism is a key challenge for European countries in an effective policy to integrate Roma communities into society. The social exclusion of Roma takes on different dimensions – material, linguistic, legal – which overlap, making it difficult to break the vicious circle of discrimination. Therefore, the strategically most important from the point of view of inclusive policy is the precise diagnosis of the causes of marginalisation of Roma communities in the various regions and the strict alignment of measures to combat this phenomenon and integration measures.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because this resolution, although full of good intentions, is poorly drafted and lacks nuance. In particular, it confuses the "Roms" and the "travellers", who are two different categories of populations. Having said that, I condemn, of course, the genocide of the Roma committed by the Nazis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution calling for the establishment of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day, remembering the genocide of the Roma people in Nazi concentration camps on the anniversary of the murder of 2,789 Roma people in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in a single night, in a roma and gypsy camp known as Zigeunerlager in which 23,000 people were imprisoned , of the 20,000 were killed by fascism. So far, the Roma people have been treated as a secondary victim of fascism despite the extermination suffered, and this Resolution seeks to end this historical injustice. The Resolution refers not only to this particular period, but to the historical discrimination that this people has suffered to this day, on which we hope that the Resolution can shed light. We would have liked it to also be accompanied by specific measures to address the situation of a people with high unemployment and marginalization rates through the European Union as a whole, but we agree because of the symbolic value it has and the support it brings from the Roma social fabric.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to remember events such as the Roma genocide during the Nazi rule and during The Second World War. However, I think this is a matter for individual politicians and citizens, not a matter that parliament should decide on. He should look at how to limit the power of politicians as much as possible in the future and give people as much freedom as possible so that such events never happen again. At the same time, greater freedom and respect for the law and equal access to all people will help the most in the fight against discrimination against Roma.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Written. – The PVV is voting today against the motion for a resolution on the International Day of the Roma and the commemoration of the Genocide of Roma during World War II. The PVV considers that the International Holocaust Remembrance Day, following UN Resolution 60/7 on 27 January, pays sufficient attention to all the victims of the Second World War every year. All victims are commemorated equally, including Jews, homosexuals, disabled people, but also Roma and other groups who were brutally murdered by the Nazi socialist regime.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin abstained on this motion for a resolution. Indeed, many concepts are mixed here: it explicitly states that the term "Rom" includes all communities of travellers, including "nationals". Discrimination is mixed up without ever questioning the attitude of communities, and the idea of creating a Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of the Roma during the Second World War is added. This motion is too catch-all to be voted on in any event.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ As an explanation of my vote, I believe it important to recognise and remember the millions of innocent people who were exterminated by the Nazis, 500 000 of whom were Roma people.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 More effort is needed to end discrimination against hate crimes and hate speech against Roma, as such discrimination is incompatible with EU values. It also calls for the recognition of 2 August as a Roma Holocaust Remembrance Day to commemorate all the victims of the massacre at the Auschwitz- Birkenau camp during the Second World War. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the European Parliament's Resolution condemning discrimination and marginalisation of the Roma people and alerting them to the rise of anti-Itanism, something that we all have to combat. All of us, the EU and the Member States, need to work together to implement the national roma integration strategies well, getting Roma communities and NGOs increasingly involved in this task. My most resounding condemnation of the genocide of the Roma people that took place during World War II, and my remembrance of the victims of the murders, deportations and internments that were experienced.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution because the Roma integration strategies are not clear and therefore cannot be assessed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution as more needs to be done to end discrimination, hate crime and hate speech against Roma people.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The genocide of the Roma by the Nazis and their allies during the Second World War is still largely unknown to many schoolchildren or citizens. In addition to the international day dedicated to the memory of the victims of the Holocaust (Jews, Roma, communists, gays...), the resolution proposes the creation of a European Day of Commemoration of the Genocide of the Roma, on 2 August, which would shed light on this too often forgotten part of the tragic history of our continent.  In the current context of rising racism, the text is a fitting reminder of the duties of Member States to implement existing anti-racism legislation. It is regrettable that the resolution does not denounce the governments themselves participating in the rise of racism against Roma through discriminatory words or policies. We have had good examples of this in Eastern Europe or even in France with Mr Sarkozy and then Mr Valls, who have declared the Roma incapable of integration.  I vote in favour of this text in the hope that it does not remain at the stage of good resolutions, but is really followed by a fight against discrimination against these populations.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution remains unclear and creates an amalgamation between several communities. Once again, the European Union wants to be binding because it proposes sanctions if states do not submit. The member abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to combat hostility towards Roma at all levels and by all means, as this is a phenomenon and a form of racism that is particularly persistent, violent, recurrent and common. I therefore support the initiative to be dedicated to a European day in memory of the Roma victims of genocide during World War II and that that day should be designated European Day in Remembrance of Roma Victims of the Holocaust. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – I support this cross-party joint resolution as it calls on Member States to combat the rising anti-Roma sentiment in Europe, and also urges Member States to recognise the genocide committed against the Roma community during World War II.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome this resolution calling for more efforts to put an end to the rise of anti-Gypsyism in Europe. Roma, representing Europe's largest ethnic minority, are still too often discriminated against and undermine their social integration. The recognition of the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War and the creation of a European Day of Commemoration of the Genocide of the Roma are already a symbolic step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism which is unquestionably incompatible with the norms and values of the European Union.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ the Roma Holocaust during The Second World War is a historical fact that must be officially recognised and disseminated.  So far, there is little awareness that the Nazis and their allies have murdered more than half a million Roma. In some countries, more than 80% of the Roma population has even been wiped out.  I support the announcement of the European Day of Remembrance for Roma Victims of the Holocaust, which will be dedicated to commemorating the victims of the Roma genocide during the Second World War.  I believe that Memorial Day will also contribute to overcoming prejudice and discrimination in the name of consolidating the human dignity and human rights of all, regardless of their ethnic origin or skin colour. Racial hatred clearly has no place in European society in the 21st century, in any of its states or regions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which calls for recognition of the day on which the genocide of Roma took place during the Second World War, in order to give the genocide of Roma its rightful place in history, and for the establishment of a European Roma Holocaust Memorial Day

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On the occasion of International Roma Day, the draft acknowledges the historical fact of the Roma genocide during The Second World War and calls on the Member States to do the same. It stands up to all forms of discrimination and racism against Roma, recognises Roma as part of a common European culture and values and calls on the Member States to implement Council Framework Decision 2008/913/IB of 28 November 2008 on combating certain forms and manifestations of racism and xenophobia by criminal law. I fully support the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Some zealous MEPs, especially from the far left, want to make European citizens feel guilty again, suspected of racist reactions to the massive presence of Roma populations. As the French Prime Minister, Manuel Valls, has rightly said, Roma are not destined to stay in France and must return to their countries, mainly Bulgaria and Romania.
