The European Union has made it possible, with the opening of borders, for the arrival of these populations whose way of life has nothing to do with European culture, and who most often live off the exploitation of women, children and the elderly through mafia networks of begging, illegal street gambling or various trafficking.  To blame Europeans for rejecting populations that constantly defy the laws of host countries and embody the rejection of the other by marginality and self-containment is a sham. However, to the extent that the plight of the Roma during the Second World War, another element of this resolution, must be recognised, the position of compromise is abstention.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Roma community integration remains a challenge for most Member States. In addition to the Comprehensive Action Plan adopted by the OSCE Countries, in 2011 the Union called on Member States to adopt a comprehensive approach to genuine roma community integration.  This document also addresses the recognition of the Genocide of the Gypsies by the Nazis. According to estimates, we are talking about at least 500 000 Roma exterminated, and there is a ignorance of the majority of the European population in this way. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution which draws attention to the need for Member States to apply existing rules on the principle of equal treatment. "United in diversity" must be the Principle that guide our activity.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution calls for more efforts to end discrimination against Roma and the recognition of 2 August as a day of remembrance of the Holocaust of the Roma during the Second World War.  However, this text justifies affirmative action specifically aimed at Roma.  Moreover, this should not overshadow the problems of integration of the Roma population. Public policies for Roma integration bear witness to this: their effectiveness is close to zero. The EUR 50 billion put on the table between 2007 and 2013 was, in most cases, very little used, showing the lack of interest of national authorities, especially Romanian ones, for their sustainable integration.  That's why I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution, which recalls that the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War killed more than 500,000 people, or more than 80% of the Roma population. The resolution solemnly recognises this genocide and calls on Member States to officially recognise it.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We believe that the Genocide of the Roma, perpetrated in Europe during the Second World War, deserves full recognition, commensurate with the seriousness of the crimes committed by the Nazis and other regimes. We therefore express our deep concern at the resurgence of anti-Gypsyism, which is manifested, among other things, through anti-Roma rhetoric and violent attacks throughout Europe, which are incompatible with the rules and values of the European Union and which constitute a serious obstacle to the success of their social integration and to ensuring full respect for their human rights. We therefore call on the Member States to implement effectively Council Directive 2000/43/EC of 29 June 2000, which implements the principle of equal treatment of persons irrespective of race and ethnic origin, in order to prevent and eliminate discrimination against Roma, particularly in the areas of employment, education and access to housing. We welcome the establishment of a European day for the commemoration of the victims of the genocide during the Second World War and that this day should be called The European Day for the Commemoration of the Roma Holocaust.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that discrimination is incompatible with the rules and values of the European Union and constitutes a major obstacle to the successful social integration of minorities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Resolution on International Roma Day - Anti-Gypsy Attitudes in Europe and the EU's Recognition of the Day of Commemoration of the Genocide against Roma in the Second World War. It is very important that our common memory and history also contain elements related to what happened in the Second World War against the Roma community.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – I think it is important that the European Parliament takes a position on this important issue. Roma in Europe face constant discrimination in all areas of daily life: education, employment, health. Our job as Members of Parliament is to do something about it. I consider it a worthy step that Parliament proposes to classify 2 August as a Day of Remembrance for the Roma Holocaust, because this terrible act is a matter for the consciences of all of us, and I am deeply ashamed that the Hungarian authorities were also involved in this terrible event at the time. We must draw attention to the fact that hatred, discrimination and racism are still present today. That is why I support the resolution.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. 100 years ago, 2,897 Roma, mostly women, children and the elderly, were murdered in the Roma camp at Auschwitz-Birkenau. In recognition of these atrocities, 2 August will be dedicated to the memory of the victims of the Roma genocide in the Second World War and will therefore be declared the European Holocaust Remembrance Day for the Roma. The Roma are the largest ethnic minority in Europe, with an estimated population of 10 to 12 million in Europe, including the 6 million Roma in the EU. In my opinion, International Roma Day is a fine recognition, but I do not think that recognition alone is enough. Depending on the season, Austria is visited by 8,000 to 12,000 beggars per month. These are exclusively "professional beggars" from the gypsy milieu. A large number of criminal organisations in Eastern Europe are hired and smuggled in – mainly from the Sinti and Roma tribes. They are often themselves victims of these criminal groups. In my opinion, these elements must also be taken into account – that is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which proposes the creation of a European Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of the Roma during the Second World War. I think it is important to recall this genocide perpetrated by the Nazis and which is too little known to European citizens. In the current context of rising racism and extremism in Europe, this resolution also reminds Member States of their duties to combat racism.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Members of the Roma community still face extreme problems of exclusion and discrimination across the EU. In this context, measures must be taken to strengthen the fight against anti-Roma hostility. EU countries should formally recognise the genocide of the Roma during World War II. I support the proposal that Europe Day should be dedicated to the victims of the Roma genocide during World War II and that this day should be called the European Roma genocide that took place during World War II. Recognising the Genocide of The Roma across the EU would be a historic event for members of the Roma community and europe. It should be noted that Roma are discriminated against in all areas of life. This has a particularly negative impact on the most vulnerable groups in society, especially children. It is therefore essential to promote equal access to housing, health, education and dignified living conditions for Roma children.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The JRC supports the Roma' claims for equal, full and completely free access to education, health protection, care and welfare, i.e. all social protection infrastructures. The Communist Party fights against discrimination and racism against them, fights against all forms of racism, fights against the unpopular policy of governments and the EU, defends the protection and preservation of their cultural, racial and linguistic identity. But the resolution is in the face of their fair claims. This is an unaccessed wish list that serves only to obscure capitalist barbarism, which is the cause of the suffering experienced by the Roma in all EU Member States. The resolution defiantly calls for the implementation of the EU's shameful decision to criminalise the different view of historical truth, in order to supposedly protect Roma from discrimination. The capitalist system, driven by the profit of capitalists, breeds and reproduces with cruel exploitation discrimination, racism, anti-communism, hatred and creates fascism from its bowels. The unprecedented conquests and rights enjoyed by Roma communities and every minority in the Soviet Union and other socialist-building countries demonstrate that only socialist-communist society abolishes the shame of exploitation and is able to ensure the well-being of all working people, without any discrimination, racial, ethnic, religious or any other.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that roma, with an estimated population of 10-12 million, are the largest ethnic minority in Europe; whereas anti-Gypsyism, the specific form of racism against Roma, is an ideology based on racial superiority, a form of dehumanisation and institutional racism fuelled by historical discrimination; whereas anti-Gypsyism is one of the main causes of discrimination and marginalisation of the Roma population in many European countries; whereas many Roma still live in absolute poverty and are victims of extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination; whereas such discrimination can occur in society in general, against a background of increasing racism against Roma, but also within women's communities because of their gender; Whereas the Commission communication of 5 April 2011 on an EU framework for national Roma integration strategies calls on the Member States to adopt or further develop a comprehensive approach to Roma integration and to support a number of common objectives; For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The resolution certainly has good feelings. Recognition of the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War, however, cannot be accompanied by a definition of a Roma people that includes French citizens. France, one and indivisible, cannot accept the recognition of ethnic minorities, this concept being contrary to the very notion of the French Republic. That is why I abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. During World War II, 500,000 Roma were killed by the Nazi regime and its allies, 23,000 killed in gas chambers in the Zigeunerlager (Gypsy camp) of Auschwitz and in some countries more than 80% of the Roma population was exterminated.  This initiative, for which I voted in favour, launched by the Group of the Party of European Democrats and signed by all the political groups, solemnly recognises the genocide of the Roma as a historical fact, supporting the establishment of a European day for the commemoration of the victims of the Roma genocide, which should be called 'European Day for the Commemoration of the Roma Holocaust', calling on all States to officially recognise this genocide and other forms of persecution against the Roma population and condemning in full the fact that the Roma have been persecuted. that to date the Roma are still victims of racist and violent attacks. This recognition is essential for the fight against antinomadism, which is still strongly present in Europe, and for promoting the inclusion of the Roma population in the EU, which has always been one of the priorities of the S&D Group. The institutions should follow the S&D Group in making the fight against anti-Gypsyism a top priority, promoting the overcoming of prejudices and forms of racism against the Roma population, the largest minority group in Europe.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of this resolution, given the importance of the Roma community in Europe, as Roma, with an estimated population of 10 to 12 million in Europe, are Europe's largest ethnic minority.  Roma are historically part of society in many European countries, but without a single home country. They have contributed to Europe as its citizens, but their status is different from national minorities in Europe, which justifies specific measures at European level. This and more because of the rise in racial animosity towards the Roma, which is expressed, inter alia, by anti-Roma rhetoric and violent attacks against Roma in Europe, including killings, which is incompatible with the norms and values of the European Union and constitutes a major obstacle to the successful social integration of Roma and ensuring full respect for their human rights. Discrimination and marginalisation are never the result of weakness inherent in an individual or group suffering such discrimination and marginalisation, but are mainly the result of the failure of the general society to recognise the rights of individuals and the failure to provide the necessary structures to invoke those rights.  Last week we marked World Roma Day, so on this occasion roma, but also everyone who respects traditions and works for the benefit of one great people, I congratulate their day.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. \u2012 Roma, who live in Europe between 10 and 12 million, are Europe's largest national minority. In its resolution, the European Parliament expressed its deep concern at the rise of anti-Roma sentiment, which is reflected, inter alia, in anti-Roma rhetoric and violent attacks on Roma in Europe. I am convinced that the elimination of anti-Roma sentiment will not take place without effective cooperation between Member States, on the one hand, and Roma communities and NGOs, on the other. I believe that, in implementing national Roma integration strategies, priority should be given to children and their access to housing, healthcare and education. I very much welcome the fact that the European Parliament has called on the Member States to officially recognise the genocide and other forms of Persecution of the Roma that took place during World War II. I consider this to be a necessary step towards full integration of the Roma into mainstream society.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The genocide of the Roma during the Second World War is still little recognized and commemorated in Europe. On the occasion of International Roma Day on 8 April, the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the recognition and commemoration of the Roma genocide on 2 August, which killed more than 500,000 people, or 80% of the Roma population, which was exterminated. I voted in favour of this text for that reason.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Roma, with an estimated population of 10 to 12 million, are the largest ethnic minority in Europe and are part of European society, culture and values. However, many Roma still live in extraordinarily precarious conditions and face extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination. The situation of these citizens and their contribution to Europe differ from other national minorities, which justifies specific measures at European level.  On the other hand, according to estimates, at least 500 000 Roma were exterminated by Nazism and other regimes (and their allies) during World War II. Finally, it is essential to recall crimes against humanity and blatant violations of human rights and to ensure the defence of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe.  This resolution therefore condemns absolutely and unequivocally all forms of racism and discrimination against Roma, calls on the Member States to step up the fight against hostility towards Roma and argues that a European day should be dedicated in memory of roma victims of genocide during World War II. I voted in favour.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Roma, who make up 10 to 12 million people in Europe, are the largest minority on our continent. Of great concern, many of them are marginalized, discriminated against and subjected to violent attacks. Anti-Gypsyism is a hindrance to their inclusion in society and to full respect for their rights.  This resolution, to which I fully agree, calls on Member States to combat all forms of racism and stigma against Roma, and to prevent and eliminate discrimination against them, including in employment, education and access to housing. In this sense, it is time for national Roma integration strategies to be fully implemented, with particular attention to the situation of women and children.  Through this text, MEPs also wish to shed light on the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War, often forgotten by history books. They solemnly declare that a European day should be dedicated to the commemoration of the victims of this genocide, which will contribute to a better knowledge of the history of the Roma in Europe. European citizens who are at the heart of our Europe; an open, tolerant and inclusive Europe.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. After recognising the genocide of the Roma in 2011, the European Parliament is now voting in favour of a full day of remembrance, so that this crime will never be erased from the collective memory. Nearly 500,000 Roma have perished in concentration camps and remain the ignored victims of Nazi genocides.  This day will not repair what can never be, but it is an important step in the fight against the increasingly expressed and violent racism that this community is experiencing in Europe. Assaults are committed, and speeches are given (including in this Chamber!) against the values that underpin us. On 2 August 1944, 3,000 Roma, women and children were gassed in Auschwitz-Birkenau. The date must seal forever our will not to forget.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 We must ensure that the fundamental rights of every citizen, without exception, as well as democracy and the rule of law are respected by all Member States. We must also monitor and effectively monitor member states' compliance with these values and respond to all systemic breaches. Discrimination and marginalisation result from society not recognising the rights of individuals and that there are no necessary structures to enable individuals to invoke those rights. This includes the fight against hostility towards Roma in the context of the national strategies for integrating this community of the Member States, promoting the best practices and fundamental values of the European Union. The genocide of Roma by the Nazis and other regimes during World War II cannot be allowed to remain a fact largely ignored by the majority of the population.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Roma currently make up 10 to 12 million people in Europe. As such, they constitute the largest ethnic minority on the continent. A majority of them still live in the deepest misery and are subject to extreme levels of social exclusion and discrimination.  I am deeply concerned by the rise of anti-Gypsyism, which is manifested in, among other things, by anti-Roma rhetoric and violent attacks in Europe, including killings, which run counter to the norms and values of the European Union and which constitute a major obstacle to the social integration of Roma and full respect for their rights.  The resolution passed today calls on Member States to effectively implement the Council's Directive 2000/43/EC of 29 June 2000 on the implementation of the principle of equal treatment between persons regardless of race or ethnic origin, in order to prevent and eliminate discrimination against Roma, particularly in employment, education and access to housing, and in particular condemns, in the strongest and unequivocal way, all forms of racism and discrimination against Roma.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution, because I consider it extremely relevant that the European Parliament's recognition of the genocide of the Roma population, which took place during The Second World War, for the same reasons as i called for the Resolution on the Armenian Genocide. Unfortunately, we have seen an increase in hostility towards Roma and other minorities which is not compatible with the set of principles and values that govern the European Union. I would therefore stress the need to implement Directive 2000/43/EC effectively on the application of the principle of equal treatment between persons and Framework Decision 2008/913/JAI on combating certain forms and manifestations of racism and xenophobia through criminal law.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because I believe that Europe must have other priorities than that of wanting to establish a day commemorating the genocide of the Roma during the Second World War. Furthermore, the text expressly calls for: 'recalls that the Roma are part of Europe's shared culture and values, and therefore encourages Member States and other European countries to address roma history through dialogue with citizens and young people'.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, the importance of which has to do with the historic moment we are going through, when anti-Itanism and other forms of racism find their place in Europe. We understand that the recognition of gypsy genocide, as occurred during World War II, is essential to keeping alive a story that prevents the same mistakes of the past from being made in the future. We have therefore voted in favour of writing a story with the words it deserves.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution calling for the establishment of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day, remembering the genocide of the Roma people in Nazi concentration camps on the anniversary of the murder of 2,789 Roma people in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in a single night, in a roma and gypsy camp known as Zigeunerlager in which 23,000 people were imprisoned , of the 20,000 were killed by fascism. So far, the Roma people have been treated as a secondary victim of fascism despite the extermination suffered, and this Resolution seeks to end this historical injustice. The Resolution refers not only to this particular period, but to the historical discrimination that this people has suffered to this day, on which we hope that the Resolution can shed light. We would have liked it to also be accompanied by specific measures to address the situation of a people with high unemployment and marginalization rates through the European Union as a whole, but we agree because of the symbolic value it has and the support it brings from the Roma social fabric.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on anti-Gypsyism in Europe and EU recognition of the memorial day of the Roma genocide during WW II. It must be noted that Roma, with an estimated population of 10 to 12 million in Europe, are Europe’s largest ethnic minority. Anti-Gypsyism, racism that is directed towards Roma, is an ideology founded on racial superiority and is one of the main causes of the discrimination and marginalisation that the Roma people have suffered historically in many European countries. The resolution underlines the need to combat anti-Gypsyism at every level and by every means, and stresses that this phenomenon is an especially persistent, violent, recurrent and commonplace form of racism. It calls on the Member States to further strengthen the fight against anti-Gypsyism as part of their National Roma Integration Strategies.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I welcome this initiative by the European Parliament.  By commemorating the tragic fate of the Roma people in the Second World War with this international Memorial Day, the European Parliament sends an important message of solidarity and remembrance. This dark episode in European history reminds us of the traps of discrimination, racism and intolerance of ‘the other’. Europe is united in diversity, and within this diversity, the human life is sacred.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. There are currently around 12 million Roma living in Europe, half of whom are in EU Member States. The Roma are the largest ethnic group in Europe, the foundation of which is respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and human rights, but we are nevertheless facing a strong anti-Roma stance, which is the main cause of the increasing discrimination and marginalisation of the Roma.  Modern society is therefore still unable to recognise the rights of minorities and provide adequate mechanisms for exercising those rights! This is clearly a conflict with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which promotes smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The 2014-2020 financial framework also foresees that marginalised communities should also be taken into account at all stages and levels of funding through European funds. After talking to key stakeholders in the area of cohesion policy, I note that too little attention is still being paid to the Roma issue. Strategic approaches to improve their inclusion are rather an exception than a rule, and municipalities across Europe do not support enough of those projects, especially in the context of cohesion policy, to improve the situation of the Roma community.  Member States have the tools to change the situation of marginalised communities, inter alia, by officially acknowledging the genocide of The Second World War and other types of violence against the Roma, as called for by this motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the establishment of a European day for the commemoration of the victims of the Roma genocide during the Second World War. In fact, it is estimated that at least 500 000 Roma were exterminated by the Nazis and other regimes and their allies during the Second World War, and in some countries more than 80% of the Roma population was exterminated. At least 23 000 Roma were killed in gas chambers in the Zigeunerlager (Gypsy camp) of Auschwitz-Birkenau during the Second World War. Furthermore, the genocide of the Roma by the Nazis and other regimes and their allies during the Second World War is still largely ignored and is therefore unknown to the general public and often not recognised or taught in schools, which places the Roma among the 'ignored' victims of the genocide perpetrated during the Second World War. Since between 2 and 3 August 1944, 2 897 Roma, mainly women, children and the elderly, were killed in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp, 2 August was chosen by Roma organisations as the day of commemoration of all Roma victims of this genocide.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA delegation has chosen to support the resolution as a whole because it contains solid elements and is therefore a good compromise across party lines. Roma remain victims of racism, and this rising trend must be combated. They therefore deserve sustained efforts on the implementation of these directives and a day of remembrance for the crimes against them during World War II. The N-VA wishes to note that it is not satisfied with the strict wording of paragraph 2. For us, the cause of discrimination is fully due to the failure of society, the individual responsibility component. Society must indeed provide structures so that minorities can exercise equal rights, but those rights must be linked to duties, first and foremost the obligation to seize the opportunities offered with both hands and to strive for inclusiveness as a minority community itself.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - There are an estimated 10-12 million Roma across Europe, making them the largest ethnic minority. They differ from each other in religion, languages and economic position. Despite the fact that discrimination is prohibited in EU Member States, Roma are unfortunately still victims of prejudice, social exclusion and social exclusion that limit the life perspectives of Roma families. Unfortunately, in some Member States, the animosity towards the Roma is so great that in 2009 11 Sinti and Roma were put at risk and the right to life (in Hungary in 2009, 11 Sinti and Roma were killed).  During World War II, this nation experienced mass destruction and discrimination, and roma and Sinti waited many years for the recognition of the victims. It was not until Helmut Schmidt, then German Chancellor, in 1982 that he declared the mass killings of members of this nation an act of genocide on the basis of racism.  As the European Union is founded on values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, we must jointly fight that none of the human rights on European soil will be compromised and I therefore support this resolution.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on International Roma Day – racial hatred of the Roma in Europe and recognition by the EU of the Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of the Roma during The Second World War. Racial hatred against the Roma, which is the largest ethnic minority in Europe, is a special type of racism based on racial superiority, a form of dehumanisation and institutional racism. I supported the motion for a resolution because I believe that racial hatred against the Roma must be combated at all levels and in every way possible. I also support a special European Day called the European Holocaust Remembrance Day for the Roma, which will be dedicated to commemorating the victims of the Roma genocide during The Second World War.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's resolution on International Roma Day, as I consider it important to continue to speak out against any form of discrimination. In particular, I agree with the part of the resolution in which the European Parliament 'stresses that discrimination and marginalisation are never the result of the innate shortcomings of individuals or groups who are affected by such discrimination and marginalisation, but are mainly due to the fact that majority society does not recognise the rights of individuals and does not provide the structures necessary for every individual to enjoy those rights'.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Any race or people who wish to be recognised and treated equally and without discrimination within civilised societies should first be able to recognise, understand and therefore obey rules of law, while implementing the corresponding obligations a source of decent and harmonious coexistence of all.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because I think it is important for the European Parliament to draw attention to the dangers of hostile, exclusionary rhetoric, discrimination in economic, social and labour discrimination that still affects our fellow Roma citizens, who are a significant minority in several EU countries. The commemoration of the Roma genocide during World War II can make responsible governmental and political factors realise that tolerating and encouraging such extremist ideas can lead to national tragedies and ethnic cleansing. However, I do not consider the debate on the naming of the mass and systematic murder of the Roma to be relevant in the context of this decision, and therefore my vote cannot be regarded as a resolution on this. In fact, the holocaust designation of the event does not in the least relativise, but rather underscores the tragedy of Judaism, which is the largest and most dramatic genocide in European and world history, and this Parliament's resolution may also remind the European public of this.  Politically and historically, I would consider it the most correct and respectable if the names of the Roma in their own language, which differed in part from region to region (e.g. 'Porajmos', 'Pharrajimos', etc.) in some parts of Central Europe and the Balkans) were also used in the relevant political texts.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is estimated that between 7 and 9 million Roma live in Europe. Many Roma are still victims of gypsy xenophobia. And it can only be countered by recognising their history, their culture and their contribution to European heritage. Because of ignorance or misconceptions, they are still subjected to varying degrees of racism and discrimination. A duty of remembrance Today, the extent of the Genocide of the Roma is not sufficiently recognized by a large public, and some are unaware of its existence. This international day is very important.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. The Roma people, who currently represent Europe's largest ethnic minority, have historically suffered very serious situations of discrimination and rejection that remain today. The commemoration of the genocide suffered by the Roma people during the Second World War strongly reminds us of the need to strengthen European policy towards the Roma people and to support their communities and families throughout Europe. The number of people belonging to the Rom people killed by Nazi terror in the concentration and extermination camps is not known exactly, a very graphic example of the lack of support that for decades has had the study of porrajmos (Devastation) also called Samudaripen (Hell on Earth), ultimately the genocide committed against the Rom. It is therefore imperative that the European institutions show their absolute readiness to safeguard the memory of the genocide, to show their respect for the Roma people and to commit decisively and uncompromisingly to ending any kind of discrimination and attack on the Roma people.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, the importance of which has to do with the historic moment we are going through, when anti-Itanism and other forms of racism find their place in Europe. We understand that the recognition of gypsy genocide, as occurred during World War II, is essential to keeping alive a story that prevents the same mistakes of the past from being made in the future. We have therefore voted in favour of writing a story with the words it deserves.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 For too long the Nazi genocide against the Roma remained an obscure and unrecognized chapter. The extermination of the Roma population was part of Europe's racial cleansing programme. The history of the suffering of the Roma in Eastern Europe, but also in areas of Western Europe, must be researched and passed on to the coming generations. Official recognition of the anti-Roma genocide is all the more necessary, as prejudice and hostility towards the Roma population in Europe are still alive.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, the importance of which has to do with the historic moment we are going through, when anti-Itanism and other forms of racism find their place in Europe. We understand that the recognition of gypsy genocide, as occurred during World War II, is essential to keeping alive a story that prevents the same mistakes of the past from being made in the future. We have therefore voted in favour of writing a story with the words it deserves.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day during World War II, recalling that the victims of this group have historically been marginalized and discriminated against.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. The Socialist Group has always led the fight for the integration of the Roma and against anti-Itanism in Europe. Too often, Roma people, the EU's largest ethnic minority, live in conditions of extreme poverty and social exclusion, with limited access to employment and social services.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it strongly condemns the racist and violent attacks of which they are still victims. We therefore call on the European Commission to monitor respect for the fundamental rights of all EU citizens and to respond to any infringement that may occur. We also call for children and women to be considered a priority when implementing the European Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies and to develop specific measures to ensure and improve their access to education and housing.  In addition, I believe that the recognition of the genocide suffered by Roma during the Nazi regime and the establishment of a European Day of Remembrance of the Gypsy Holocaust are essential to recognising the place of this people in our common history.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution calling for the establishment of a European Gypsy Holocaust Commemoration Day, remembering the genocide of the Roma people in Nazi concentration camps on the anniversary of the murder of 2,789 Roma people in the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in a single night, in a roma and gypsy camp known as Zigeunerlager in which 23,000 people were imprisoned , of the 20,000 were killed by fascism. So far, the Roma people have been treated as a secondary victim of fascism despite the extermination suffered, and this Resolution seeks to end this historical injustice. The Resolution refers not only to this particular period, but to the historical discrimination that this people has suffered to this day, on which we hope that the Resolution can shed light. We would have liked it to also be accompanied by specific measures to address the situation of a people with high unemployment and marginalization rates through the European Union as a whole, but we agree because of the symbolic value it has and the support it brings from the Roma social fabric.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues at the European Parliament, I voted in favour of an EU recognition of the memorial day of the Roma genocide during WWII, because commemorating crimes against humanity and gross violations of human rights is crucial in order to pursue the causes of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe.  Also, the genocide of the Roma in Europe deserves full recognition commensurate with the gravity of the crimes of the Nazi and other regimes that were designed to physically eliminate the Roma of Europe, as well as Jews and other targeted groups.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a fair concern about the increased hostility towards Roma demonstrated, inter alia, by speeches and acts of violence, including murders, against Roma in Europe, which are incompatible with the rules and values of the European Union and constitute a huge obstacle to the social integration of Roma and full respect for their human rights. We follow the condemnation of all forms of racism and discrimination against Roma and underline the need to effectively combat hostility towards Roma so that measures in other areas can also be effective. However, we believe that this resolution should deepen the causes of this phenomenon and the role of anti-social policies affecting the general population, generating poverty and unemployment, and a broth of factors where racism and xenophobia find sustitus conditions to develop.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution because the Roma integration strategies are not clear and therefore cannot be assessed.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that all forms of discrimination must be combated and condemned with the necessary firmness. The Roma people have suffered insults, acts of violence and discrimination for centuries. Now it's time for a change. The European Union is the bearer of civil values and memory, storing up the horrors of the past and looking to the future with respect for and coexistence of all its citizens.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on 'International Roma Day – Anti-Gypsyism in Europe and the EU's recognition of the Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of the Roma in World War II', together with my group. The Roma have also become the victims of genocide in the past. As the largest ethnic minority in Europe, they still suffer from legal discrimination. This discrimination is contrary to the purpose of the rule of law, which is precisely against such discrimination and which is intended to establish the same rules for all people, regardless of their origin or ethnicity. It is ironic that the broad support for this resolution from all the political groups in the European Parliament means nothing less than a criticism of the conditions of the rule of law within the EU. The EU and its institutions often interfere in the internal affairs of non-members of the EU in an almost hilarious way, even though they do not seem to be able to regulate their own conditions under the rule of law in the Union. I will be happy to continue to highlight this contradiction and put my finger on the wound of the EU's shortcomings in the rule of law.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ With my Socialist colleagues at the European Parliament, I voted in favour of an EU recognition of the memorial day of the Roma genocide during WWII, because commemorating crimes against humanity and gross violations of human rights is crucial in order to pursue the causes of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe.  Also, the genocide of the Roma in Europe deserves full recognition commensurate with the gravity of the crimes of the Nazi and other regimes that were designed to physically eliminate the Roma of Europe, as well as Jews and other targeted groups.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ as I announced in the debate, I considered it my duty to support the resolution tabled on International Roma Day. But I would like to add that symbolic statements are not enough. We will needlessly adopt resolutions on the poor situation of the Roma in Europe and its historical causes, when we also see that the desperate conditions in which the Roma live in many – especially the new ones – remain the same for decades. Programmes that have the ambition to change something about this state are too short-term because they copy election cycles. We need policies set at least for a generation. It is also confirmed that in the Roma strategy, the EU should have cooperated more with the new Member States, where the problems of the Roma are much more serious and their solution requires a completely different approach.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The JRC supports the Roma' claims for equal, full and completely free access to education, health protection, care and welfare, i.e. all social protection infrastructures. The Communist Party fights against discrimination and racism against them, fights against all forms of racism, fights against the unpopular policy of governments and the EU, defends the protection and preservation of their cultural, racial and linguistic identity. But the resolution is in the face of their fair claims. This is an unaccessed wish list that serves only to obscure capitalist barbarism, which is the cause of the suffering experienced by the Roma in all EU Member States. The resolution defiantly calls for the implementation of the EU's shameful decision to criminalise the different view of historical truth, in order to supposedly protect Roma from discrimination. The capitalist system, driven by the profit of capitalists, breeds and reproduces with cruel exploitation discrimination, racism, anti-communism, hatred and creates fascism from its bowels. The unprecedented conquests and rights enjoyed by Roma communities and every minority in the Soviet Union and other socialist-building countries demonstrate that only socialist-communist society abolishes the shame of exploitation and is able to ensure the well-being of all working people, without any discrimination, racial, ethnic, religious or any other.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. \u2012 By supporting this resolution, I expressed my deep regret for the victims of the Roma genocide during World War II. The European Union is founded on diversity, respect for traditions, as well as respect for cultural history and ethnicities. This resolution is very important because it stresses that Europe recognises roma as part of European history and culture. We must remind ourselves of the past so that such things do not happen again in the future. Intolerance towards the Roma community is growing. But we must fight this hatred and hostility. I believe that the best way is to focus on the positive cases of roma involved in the EU Member States and to involve Roma communities in NGO programmes as a better integration strategy.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – On 24 April, the date on which more than 200 Armenian intellectuals and leaders were arrested and later murdered, in the last years of the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1923, first with the Turkish Youth movement, then with the Turkish Nationalists, nationalist organizations, as part of a plan to liquidate the Armenian minority of the territory that later constituted the Republic of Turkey. , persecuted, arrested, deported and murdered hundreds of thousands of human beings. The academic discussion remains, but seems to point to the extermination or withdrawal of the entire Armenian population of that region, accounting for between 1 and 1.5 million deaths of a population of about 2 million people. A historical example of the consequences of nationalist movements, which should serve as a warning not to lose sight of the present, with the emergence of nationalist and Nazi-fascist movements, which have been counting on the support, particularly from the EU and the US. In either case, this memory cannot serve to create divisions between the Armenian and Turkish peoples.  We voted in favour.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the draft motion for a resolution on International Roma Day (on racial hatred of the Roma in Europe and recognition by the EU, The Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of the Roma during World War II) because commemorating the remembrance of crimes against humanity and serious violations of human rights is crucial for the increased pursuit of peace, reconciliation, democracy and human rights in Europe. At least 500,000 Roma were killed during The Second World War, in some countries over 80% of the Roma population. At least 23,000 Roma have died in gas chambers in a special part of the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp reserved for the Roma. On the night of 2 August 1944, 2897 Roma were killed, most of them women, children and the elderly. The perpetrators of crimes against the Roma were not only Nazis, they also had concentration camps for roma in Italy, and Stalin also had the slaying of Roma families from Leningrad to Moldova in the 1930s. Several hundred Roma were also killed in Slovenia during the war, most of them killed by partisans led by the Communist Revolutionary Movement, while the rest were Nazi and fascist authorities. Only totalitarian regimes and forces carried out genocide against the Roma. Today's generations must remain committed to remembering the victims so that the atrocities of our semi-previous history will never happen again.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I thank you and Mr Members for your presence, I also thank the Commissioner, i thank our translators very much and I wish everyone a good night or a tasty one, although there is an old Polish saying 'eat breakfast alone, lunch with a friend and give dinner to the enemy'. (The meeting was closed at 10.15pm)
